STRUCTURE OF FIRST-YEAR STUDENTS IN SOUTH-AFRICAN UNIVERSITIES

Author: VAN DER MERWE, A.B.1; TOIT, J.M. DU1 U OF STELLENBOSCH, S. AFRICA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/60537615?accountid=14667

Abstract: An analysis of the structure of a typical pop of 1st yr students at a South African U, re general courses followed, Sch achievement, intellectual ability, & diff's between sexes. There were more M than F students. In the case of F's, a spontaneous diff.iation resulted in only the best of them attempting courses leading to degrees. The weaker girls contended themselves with diploma courses. The distribution of scores on an IQ test was markedly skewed. The mean/average intellectual ability was so good that there should have been few academic failures on account of intellectual limitations. Diff's in intelligence between age-groups, sexes, & cliff lines of study are also reported. Modified AA.

PROBABLE FUTURE NUMBERS OF UNIVERSITY STUDENTS IN THE UNION OF SOUTH AFRICA AND THE PROVINCE OF TRANSVAAL

Author: Badenhorst, L T1; KOTZEE, A K1 U OF THE WITWATRSARAND, JOHANNESBURG, SA & TRANSVAAL EDUC DEPT, PRETORIA, SA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/60552436?accountid=14667

Abstract: An estimate of the probable number of future students in the Union & Transvaal based on the estimated future size of the 17-21 age group in the pop. Estimates of the white pop aged 17-21 is made by applying the life expectation values of the most recent official Life Table (1946) to the census pop of 1951. On this basis an increase in student enrollment of 30% between 1957 & 1970 in the Union is noted. This estimate is considered to be a conservative one. In the Transvaal the estimated increase is 44%. The following factors are noted as possibly of adverse effect on the future numbers: the shortage of skilled labor in a period of prosperity & rapid industrial & commercial expansion; & the possible instit of special U entrance examinations. I. Taviss.

A STUDY OF THE EFFECT OF PREFERENCE ON THE PERCEPTION OF SIZE

Author: BOTHA,E.11 U OF CAPE TOWN, S. AFRICA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/60558286?accountid=14667

Abstract: A study of 17 boys & 18 girls aged 9-11.5 to test the following hyp's based on J. G. Taylor's behavioral theory of perception: (1) an object is likely to be perceived as smaller than its real size if the general response it evokes is to approach &consume,& if the quantity presented is less than the amount required to satisfy the S's need & conversely; & (2) the choice of values assigned to the symbol representing the object is a function of the habits acquired by the S in response to the object so that habits of eager approach may be expected to result in the choice of larger values of the symbol while habits of avoidance or withdrawal will lead to the choice of smaller values. The S's were presented with 2 photographs projected on a screen: one of standard size & the other smaller or larger & to be adjusted until the S reported that it was equal in size. The following objects were portrayed: a slice of dry bread & a slice of chocolate cake of the same size; equal quantities of ice cream & spinach; & a bottle of cold drink & a bottle of castor oil. The eating preferences of the children were ascertained from the S's' mothers. The hyp's were confirmed. I. Taviss.

THE VOCATIONAL CHOICES, INTERESTS AND APTITUTDES OF SECONDARY SCHOOL BOYS, WITH SPECIAL REFERENCE TO THE CONSISTENCY OF THESE FACTORS

Author: Arnold, J

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/60552482?accountid=14667

Abstract: A test of 1,092 S's in 4 large provincial HSch's in Pretoria over 3 successive yrs to determine the following: (1) the relationships between intelligence, academic aptitude, clerical aptitude, & technical aptitude; (2) the consistency of vocational choice; (3) the consistency of interest; & (4) the consistency of aptitude. Tests included an Interest L?J for HSch students by 0. K. Garretson & P. M. Symonds; a Test for Clerical Ability by E. J. Benge; & the MacQuarrie Test for Mechanical Ability. Results indicated that positive is exist between academic, clerical, & technical aptitudes, though the is are all low, the highest being .48 between academic & clerical aptitude. The general tendency of the group of secondary Sch boys as a whole was to be inconsistent re their choice of vocation over 2 or 3 successive yrs, but to be consistent re interest & aptitudes. I. Taviss.

RELATIVE POVERTY IN A PERI-URBAN AREA: A REPORT FROM THE CAPE FLATS 'VLEILAND SURVEY'

Author: Batson, Edward11 U OF CAPE TOWN, S. AFRICA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/60553236?accountid=14667

Abstract: A report of a 1951 Soc Survey of Cape Town among the largely colored pop of the Cape Flats (known as the Vleiland Survey). The SE condition of the Cape Colored pop of Cape Town was compared with that of the Cape Colored of the Cape Flats. It is noted that 'the households in the Cape Flats area were much poorer than those of the municipality as a whole, because although their needs (as computed by poverty datum lines) were similar, their incomes were much lower.' The economy in dwelling accommodation costs secured by the households in the Flats area amounted to very little, although it did afford a signif reduction in the amount of poverty that would have existed if the mean/average rents of the municipality had been paid. But 'the saving in dwelling costs was accompanied by a small (but by no means proportionate) sacrifice of accommodation & by a striking prevalence of occupier-ownership.' I. Taviss.

A FURTHER APPLICATION OF BEHAVIORAL THEORY TO EXPERIMENTS ON THE ROLE OF PREFERENCE IN PERCEPTION OF SIZE

Author: Botha, E11 U OF CAPE TOWN, S. AFRICA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/60532381?accountid=14667

Abstract: 2 postulates are tested: (1) a liked object is one that is sought after, & a disliked object one that is avoided, implying that the avoided object will be perceived as larger than the sought after object in a free choice situation. The probability that the disliked object will be perceived as larger is greater in the case of aggressive than timid children. The effect of putting the S's in a homework situation will lead to an increase in reaction of potential of the approach response to the disliked object in docile S's, but not in aggressive S's, ie, docile S's will now perceive the disliked objects as smaller & there will be no change in obstinate S's. In an experiment in which the S is presented with a pair of pictures of objects to which he habitually reacts in diff. ways & he has to adjust the size of one which is presented as very large or very small to the size of the other one shown life size, his adjustment will reflect his overt behavior towards the objects represented by the pictures. Sch books representing liked & disliked Sch subjects are used as stimuli in the exp's. In addition, an analysis is made of the S's behavior in the diff. situations as reported by mothers & teachers. It is concluded that adjustment of size in the type of experiment carried out & size perception of the stimuli used, are based on complex, but specific patterns of behaviors towards the stimuli in specific situations. Modified AA.

REPORT ON AN AFRICAN DEMOGRAPHIC SURVEY

Author: Flegg, H1; Lutz, W1 CANCER RES UNIT, LOURENCO MARQUES, SA & U OF THE WITWATERSRAND, JOHANNESBURG, SA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/60533371?accountid=14667

Abstract: Description of a method devised for carrying out a demographic survey of an African native pop scattered on the outskirts of an Ur area occupied almost exclusively by people of nonindigenous origin. The aim of the survey was to estimate the number & the age & sex structure of the pop as a basis for a Cancer Rate Survey, & the demographic study was limited by its terms of reference. Problems arose from a lack of firsthand knowledge of the subUr area, the scattered nature of its dwellings (which precluded the use of any conventional frame for taking a sample) & from the absence of trained personnel for field work. These difficulties were overcome by thorough preliminary investigation of the area, the use of aerial photographs to construct a frame for sampling purposes, & the training of local African native field personnel for interviewing. All of the above techniques met with success. Results of the study show an interesting age & sex structure & indications that the pop is not yet settled in welldefined Ur communities. Modified AA.

A SOCIOGRAPHIC STUDY OF THE ISOLATED COMMUNITY IN THE DISTRICT OF MARICO IN WATERBERG

Author: POEGIETER, J F11 NASIONALE INSTITUUT VIR PERSONEELNAVORSING, WETENSKAPLIKE EN NYWERHEIDNAVORSINGSRAAD

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/60506657?accountid=14667

Abstract: A study of the factors which led to the soc isolation, econ retrogression, & religious relaxation of the inhabitants of 3 isolated community groups, in the hope that a positive policy will in future be followed to alleviate the need of the distressed faro's. The 3 communities have in common the urge to migrate & gain independence, as well as the urge to secure the existence of their descendants, eventually resulting in disadvantageous division of the land. Farming methods among the groups are similar & lacking in intensive planning. 50% of the people are farmers; 28% exist on income derived from allowances. The State is responsible for 52% of the total/sum income of the communities. Housing conditions & other essential services are primitive, & the households are patriarchal. The poverty of the faro's derives in part from the low educ'al level of the older generation. The IQ of Sch-going children is 11 points lower than that of Sch children in the Union, & the youth of these communities, when they migrate to Ur areas, perform unskilled work & live in the poorest sections of town. Modified AA.

MARRIAGE CUSTOMS AMONG THE BANTU IN THE HOUSING PROJECT IN THE MUNICIPALITY OF KLERKSDORP

Author: Schmidt, J J

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/60574099?accountid=14667

Abstract: A & interview study (N= 100 fam's) to determine current marital & premarital att's & behavior in a Bantu pop in Klerksdorp which has been in contact with the Europeans for many yrs. Results indicate that the Bantu have definitely been influenced by European customs at all stages of contracting marriage, though a number of traditional customs are adhered to in both modified & unmodified form. Traditional educ of Bantu youth has fallen into disuse. The meeting between the 2 sexes can no longer be controlled, & the weakening of other traditional soc controls has resulted in unrestrained sexual relations between courting couples & a high illegitimacy rate. Crosscousin marriages no longer occur, parents are no longer consulted in the choices of a spouse, & a man will generally test the fertility of a girl before deciding to marry her. Money has replaced cattle as the bride-price, & the European legal marriage ceremony is engaged in along with certain of the traditional ceremonies. The practice of living together for yrs before the eventual marriage is rapidly gaining ground. Modified AA.

CRIMINAL ENVIRONMENT OF YOUTH IN SOUTH-AFRICA

Author: Venter, J D11 NASIONALE BURO VIE OPVOEDKUNDIGE EN MAATSKAPLIKE NAVORSING

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/60568869?accountid=14667

Abstract: Data on juvenile crime (JC) in S. Africa from 1945 to 1957, taken from the Bur for Census & Statistics, were analyzed re age, race, & nature of the offense. These data were further r'ed with pop figures & JC statistics prior to 1945. The incidence of JC reached its peak during 1957. It was lowest among whites & highest among colored, while rates for serious crime were lowest among Asiatics & highest among colored. But if the offense of driving without a license is removed from the serious crime list, the lowest incidence will again be found among Whites. The highest rate of increase in serious crime is among the colored, & the lowest among the Asiatics pop. Modifed AA.

ACADEMIC RATINGS OF STUDENTS IN A SOUTH AFRICAN UNIVERSITY-A FOLLOW-UP STUDY

Author: VAN BILJON, I.J.11 U VAN STELLENBOSCH, SA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/60530868?accountid=14667

Abstract: A comparison of academic success & failure of 1st-, 2nd-, & 3rd-yr students at a South African U. A number of S's are not successful in their studies at the U. The failure of 3rd-yr students appears to be exceptionally high. F students & students who obtained first class passes in matric do well in their studies. Further investigation is essential, as there are a number of problems yet to be solved. AA.

ASPECTS OF THE CENTRAL BUSINESS DISTRICT OF PORT ELIZABETH CAPE PROVINCE

Author: Young, B S11 U OF NATAL, S. AFRICA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/60577573?accountid=14667

Abstract: A report of a survey of the Central Business District of Port Elizabeth, Cape Province, during Jan-Feb 1959, presenting 7 maps of the area indicating the way in which the District was delineated on the basis of blocks & lots, the various zones & land usage therein, the relative position of the Central Business District & the outlying business district, the proportions of the total/sum floor space of the District devoted to various uses, & the land use regions of the District. Information is presented re: site, size, & shape of the District, barriers to expansion, growth of a non-central business district, & analyses of the following land use regions: the wholesale region, the residential region, the public region, the inner retail-office region, & the outer retail office region. The following factors are seen as likely to influence future developments in Port Elizabeth: the removing of the civic center from the Central Business District; the construction of an expressway; the development of the foreshore area north of the harbor; the expansion of the harbor as the hinterland develops; the development of new industrial zones; & the implementation of apartheid involving the expansion of retail & business uses in the non-European quarters. On the basis of these factors, suggestions for planning are offered. I. Taviss.

THE CRIME PATTERN OF WHITE FEMALE RECIDIVISTS

Author: Venter, J D11 NASIONALE BURO VIR OPVOEDKUNDIGE EN MAATSKAPLIKE NAVORSING

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/60579872?accountid=14667

Abstract: An analysis of the crime pattern of European F recidivists (EFR's). Studied was a 50% sample of all EFR's who had relapsed into crime since 1949, based on data from the records of the S. African Criminal Bur Liquor law offenses are the most frequent 1st, 2nd, & ensuing offenses; their incidence is increasing, whereas the incidence of theft is decreasing. EFR's tend to commit their crimes in the same locality, & certain crimes are committed more frequently in certain areas, prostitution occurring only in the 5 larges Ur areas. 34.6% EFR's received a suspended sentence for their first offense, 39.5% received a sentence with the option of a fine or imprisonment, & 19.8% were sent to prison without the option of a fine. Modified AA.

THE BEARING OF FAMILY ALLOWANCES ON FAMILY SIZE IN AN URBAN WHITE POPULATION

Author: Higgins, Edward

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/60569213?accountid=14667

Abstract: A report of a 1957-58 study of 1,022 white married women under the age of 50 to examine reproductive facts, norms, & att's among the various SE groups in Johannesburg. It is found that the mean/average white Johannesburg wife would like to have (or have had) 4 children in her fam. This figure is definitely higher than the mean/average size of the Ur white fam in South Africa today. If fam allowances were made available, R's answered that they would have an mean/average of 1 more child than they would otherwise have. The Afrikaans-speaking R's would have larger fam's than the English-speaking women if fam allowances were provided. The lower-blue-collar R's would have more children than any other occup'al group if fam allowances were provided. Desired fam size, if fam allowances were available, was negatively r'ed with standard of educ & income. Fam allowances appeared to make little diff re fam size to those F's who only received a primary Sch educ, while it mattered most to those who had a secondary Sch educ, & much less among the Coll educated F's. I. Taviss.

VENDA CERAMICS

Author: VAN DER LITH, A.A.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/60593506?accountid=14667

Abstract: A study of the nature of the ceramics of the Venda, how & by whom articles were made, &what role they played in the life of this Bantu tribe. An investigation in which 10,233 ceramic vessels were studied, revealed 28 diff types. 50% of these vessels were directly connected with the preparation, storing & serving of food, while 36% were used for brewing, storing & conveying beer. The rest consisted of 2 types of clay basins, a water pot & a small bowl in which tobacco leaves were ground for the manufacturing of snuff. No ceramic objects used for secondary purposes were found. The art of pottery rests almost entirely with the Lemba women. Not until recently did the Venda people make any ceramic vessels & it appears as if they never really practised the art of pottery. Although the technique which the Venda & Lemba use is basically the same, there is a marked diff in their products, due to the diff in skill. The Lemba have completely mastered the art of pottery while the Venda still appear unskilled. The motifs with which the vessels are decorated seem to have no definite meaning. Motifs are applied to vessels according to a systematic plan, & only the vessels seen by visitors are decorated with care. Modified HA.

VALUATION OF MARRIAGE IN THE FAMILY CONTEXT

Author: Mann, J W

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/60548687?accountid=14667

Abstract: For the fam to give rise to new fam's, the value the children attach to marriage is important. There are grounds for believing that only children set a relatively high value on marriage; while children identifying with the parent of the opposite sex set a relatively low value on marriage. A study of English adolescents supports the 1st belief but not the 2nd. HA.

FATHER'S EDUCATION AS A FACTOR AFFECTING SOCIAL DISTANCE

Author: Lever, H1; WAGNER, O.J.M.1 U OF WITWATERSRAND, JOHANNESBURG, SOUTH AFRICA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/60540937?accountid=14667

Abstract: A modified E. M. Bogardus SD test was admin'ed to a sample of 2,302 pupils drawn from the white HSch pop of Johannesburg, South Africa. The relationship between the ethnic att's of pupils & the level of educ attained by their fathers was studied, specifically, the hypothesis that 'SD increases in inverse proportion to the level of educ attained by the S's father.' S's' att's towards Natives, Coloreds, & Indians are examined, & it was found that father's educ was related to the S's' att's towards nonwhites. In English-medium provincial Sch's, there was a tendency for S's whose fathers were highly educated to be relatively favorably disposed toward nonwhites. In Afrikaans-medium Sch's, there were indications that the influence of the level of the father's educ operated in the opposite direction. No signif diff's were found between att's of M S's & F S's. Some hyp's are advanced to explain these relationships; eg, in English-medium Sch's, fathers with more educ are likely to have Hs & therefore a position further removed from that of nonwhites. They can then encourage an attitude of understanding toward nonwhites. Less educated fathers are likely to have Ls, & to be closer in position to nonwhites. They may therefore feel the need to enhance their position by fostering a disparaging attitude toward nonwhites. A direct influence may exist in which higher educ leads to greater understanding in the father, which is directly communicated to the S. In the case of Afrikaans-medium Sch's, a possible consequence of upward SM, as opposed to firmly established status, may be unfavorable att's. 4 Tables. Modified HA.

DEMOGRAPHIC VIEW OF THE CAPE PENINSULA

Author: Truu, M L11 RHODES-UNIVERSITEIT, GRAHAMSTOWN, SOUTH AFRICA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/60594535?accountid=14667

Abstract: A description of the composition, growth & geographical distribution of the pop of the Cape Peninsula & the Western Cape (South Africa) is followed by an analysis of the former. The analysis is confined to the sex & age composition, fertility, mortality, & migratory trends, & a projection for 1980 of the white, colored & bantu pop's of this area. It is found from the data that the white & colored groups display the demographic properties of settled pop's, & that the chief characteristics of the bantu are those of a migrant pop. White & nonwhite labor in the Cape Peninsula can be regarded as complementary from an econ point of view, whereas colored & bantu labor appear to be of a competive nature. Modified HA.

PROBLEMS AND POLICY IN RECREATION PLANNING IN THE NETHERLANDS

Author: Davies, D Hywel11 U OF CAPE TOWN, SOUTH AFRICA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/60629453?accountid=14667

Abstract: The nature of outdoor recreational demand in the Netherlands is typical of much of Western Europe, but the severity of the supply problem that results from a small geographical space & the world's highest nat'l density of pop is peculiarly Dutch. Following a brief discussion of demand, the existing natural recreational facilities are examined in each of the major geographical regions of the country-the beaches & dunes; the woods, heaths, & moors of the interior sandy 'uplands'; & the water recreation areas in the polder lands. Broad nat'l policy for the development of recreation is then discussed in relation to each of these regions. The aim is to classify the beaches as a basis for providing for diff types of recreational use. An attempt must also be made to preserve natural amenities in the sandy uplands in the face of Ur encroachment & the fractionalization of holdings. New water recreation facilities can be developed on a large scale by taking advantage of the giant civil engineering projects in the Ijssel Lake & Rhine Delta areas & on a small scale by converting areas of sand excavation in the polderlands into additional centers for water sports. It is concluded that on a nat'l scale Dutch planners have no option but to develop all possible facilities to their maximum extents. Modified HA.

SUCCESS AND FAILURE OF FIRST-YEAR STUDENTS

Author: VAN DER MERWE, A.B.1; TOIT, J.M. DU1 U OF STELLENBOSCH, S. AFRICA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/60578777?accountid=14667

Abstract: Academic success & failure of a 1st yr student pop at a South African U is analyzed re age distribution, main direction of study, sex, success in Sch, & intelligence. An attempt is made to assess the cause or causes of failure in individual cases, leading to the conclusion that in at least 50% of these cases, failure could have been avoided. Modified AA.

Accreditation of Social Work Courses: Lessons for South Africa from the North American Experience?

Author: McKendrick, B W11 School Social Work U Witwatersrand, Johannesburg 2050 Republic South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61553039?accountid=14667

Abstract: Because many developing countries are attempting to enhance the quality of social work education by prescribing core curricula to universities, an attempt is made to establish why & how prescribed minimum standards are accepted by educators, via an analysis of the literature on the origins, present nature, & procedures of social work course accreditation in the US, & a 1989 study visit to the US. Results show that: successful accreditation is controlled by educators themselves; its central mechanism is the mutual educational activity of peer review; standards are minimum & qualitative, rather than extensive & quantitative; & there is clear understanding that it is courses of education that are accredited, not the persons who graduate from them. 1 Reference. Modified AA

The Role of Lifestyle and Opportunity in the Vulnerability of Women to Rape

Author: Cole, J11 Dept Kriminologie U Pretoria, Brooklyn 0002 Republic South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61237040?accountid=14667

Abstract: A discussion of the victim precipitation theory of rape -- an admittedly biased approach -- with focus on the lifestyle theory found in M. J. Hindelang's, M. R. Gottfredson's, & J. Garafalo's Victims of Personal Crime: An Empirical Foundation for a Theory of Personal Victimization (Ballenger, 1978). This theory suggests that the victim contributes to her own rape by creating opportunities for the criminal, eg, walking unnecessarily in deserted areas, hitchhiking, leaving doors & windows open, or falling under the influence of drugs & alcohol. Women can become better informed about these vulnerable actions & reduce the chance of rape. The educating role of the social worker in this regard is emphasized. 18 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Relationship between Parents and Their Institutionalised Mentally Handicapped Child

Author: Lea, S J11 Dept Psychology U Cape Town, Rosebank 7700 Republic South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61590369?accountid=14667

Abstract: Interview data are used to examine parent-child relations in 10 families with mentally handicapped male children, age 18 or less, residing in a large state institution in the Republic of South Africa. Content analysis of clinical case formulations identifies 3 factors that influence the relationship between parents & their institutionalized mentally handicapped child: parents' personal resources, the availability of social support, & parents' ability to express & accept their emotional response to their handicapped child. The limitations of the findings are noted. 1 Table, 20 References. Modified AA

Private Adoptions

Author: De Bruyn, M

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61534809?accountid=14667

Abstract: Private adoption in the Republic of South Africa represents 50% of all South African adoptions. Here, risk factors & the potential for malpractice in the adoption process are examined based on registry records on 48 private adoptions; in addition, 3 biological mothers of the adopted children & 8 adoption intermediaries were interviewed. 1 Table, 9 References. An Analysis of Future Roles, Outputs and Competencies of Social Workers

Author: Van Zyl, M A11 Dept Social Work Rand Afrikaans U, Johannesburg 2000 Republic South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61553076?accountid=14667

Abstract: Utilizing a Delphi technique, a list of 26 probable future conditions that will impact social work practice in the Republic of South Africa during the 1990s were identified at a task force meeting involving 18 social workers. Related knowledge & skills that will be required in the future, along with critical social work roles, are revealed via a review of the literature. It is recommended that competencies necessary for each role be explored in future studies. 3 Tables, 5 References. S. G. Yates

The Mission Statement and the Welfare Organization

Author: Pitt, L F11 School Management Curtin U Technology, Bentley Western Australia 6102

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61576799?accountid=14667

Abstract: A discussion of mission statements & their purpose in welfare agencies, stressing the importance of goal formulation & organizational responsiveness to client needs. Three dimensions of mission statement formulation are described -- client group, client needs, & technology -- based on questionnaire data collected from 224 human & animal welfare organizations in the Republic of South Africa regarding the basic purpose of each organization. Results show that the majority of organizations had mission statements focusing on the client group. A team approach is recommended in the formulation of a mission statement, & a methodology for this process is presented. It is concluded that the mission statement creates a distinct purpose for the organization, enhances planning efforts, motivates members, & ensures support from those outside the organization. 2 Tables, 2 Figures, 10 References. S. G. Yates

The Future of Social Work in South Africa

Author: McKendrick, B W11 School Social Work U Witwatersrand, Johannesburg 2050 Republic South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61627050?accountid=14667

Abstract: A historical contextual analysis of social work in South Africa, from its inception in the 1920s to the present, suggests that it has been used as a method of social control & as an adjunct of an unjust apartheid political system. Most social work is therapeutic, rather than change-oriented, white people are the major beneficiaries of service, & the profession has become overprofessionalized, identifying with the policies of ruling power groups rather than the development needs of the disadvantaged majority. It is concluded that social work, as presently practiced, is irrelevant to the political, social, & economic realities of a democratizing South Africa. As an alternative, & to make the profession more pertinent to contemporary needs & circumstances, it is suggested that an ecological paradigm be adopted as the overarching perspective for practice; changes in direction are detailed for both social work practice & education. 21 References. AA

The Feelings of Emotionally Abused Children

Author: Roberts, J I11 Dept Social Work U Durban-Westville, 4000 Republic South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61660181?accountid=14667

Abstract: Feelings that emotionally abused children have about themselves & their families are investigated drawing on interview data obtained from 32 children (average age 15.5) in Durban, South Africa, all of whom were living in some type of foster care situation. In general, respondents showed feelings of being unloved & unwanted: about 66% felt rejected by their foster caretakes, while 37% did not wish to return home. Implications for foster home placement & for comprehensive prevention programs are discussed. 4 Tables, 39 References. M. Meeks

Facilities for Mental Handicap in South Africa: Implications for Social Workers

Author: Hollingshead, J; Tickton, T J; van der Westhuizen, Y

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61629573?accountid=14667

Abstract: To obtain an accurate picture of existing facilities for the mentally handicapped in South Africa, questionnaire data were collected in 1985 from all centers (N not provided) delivering special care, training, & protective work environments for those with IQs below 50. Glaring deficiencies were observed in the services available for blacks, for whom only 8% of total needs were met, compared with 28% for Asian & mixed race, & 62% for whites. Community welfare organizations take care of more than twice as many cases than does the state. To remedy this situation, a social work intervention program is described emphasizing education, facilitation, & advocacy. 2 Tables, 5 References. M. Meeks

Fragmentation of Psychiatric Service Delivery in Natal Consequent upon the Policy of Apartheid

Author: Sewpaul, V11 Dept Social Work U Durban-Westville, 4000 Republic South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61627697?accountid=14667

Abstract: An investigation of the impact of fragmentation & the apartheid regime on the delivery, coordination, & decentralization of psychiatric services in Natal, South Africa. Drawing on quantitative data obtained from representatives of various state departments & hospitals (N not specified), & a review of the literature, considered are: the inequitable distribution of scarce resources; multidisciplinary team work & need for a holistic biopsychosocial approach; the disparity of priorities attributed to different levels of intervention; & problems related to primary health care & grass-roots social work. An alternative health care system based on the values & principles of socioeconomic equity, political liberation, & health for all is proposed, based on a unified nationalized health service. 1 Figure, 8 References. The Use of Music for Reflection in Social Group Work

Author: De Swart, G.1; Hofmeyer, L1 Dept Maatskaplike Werk U Pretoria, Brooklyn 0002 Republic South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61615751?accountid=14667

Abstract: It is suggested that music can serve different therapeutic uses in social group work, in particular, to promote group reflection. The type of music employed in the therapeutic process should be determined by the nature & needs of each individual group. Although musical reflection offers advantages over verbal reflection, it should be remembered that music may bring about negative reactions. 8 References. Adapted from the source document.

Burn-Out in Social Work: Its Incidence and Trends in Causation

Author: Smit, A. de V.11 School Social Work U Cape Town, Rondebosch 7700 Republic South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61655518?accountid=14667

Abstract: Data obtained using the second edition of the Maslach Burnout Inventory (MBI) & a structured questionnaire from registered social workers (N = 252) employed by 16 private welfare organizations in the Cape Peninsula of South Africa were assessed to determine Ss' degree of burnout. Responses to MBI subscales reflected average levels of burnout. Differences in demographic characteristics & in how jobs & organizations were viewed by the entire sample, vs by a group of 41 Ss reflecting average to high degrees of burnout, are noted to be consistent with findings of other studies. Implications are discussed, & further study is recommended. 8 Tables, 19 References. Modified AA

Author: Schieke, E E; Du Preez, M. S. E.

Abstract: An evaluation of a special assistance program for unwed mothers in Berg-en-Dal, South Africa, based on case studies of clients (N not given) served 1983-1987. Special attention is given to the following program goals: improving the personal & social functioning of the clients; providing needed medical & spiritual care; & guaranteeing opportunities for continuing education. Some Perceptions of the Public Concerning Privatisation and Community Participation

Author: Snyman, S A11 Instit Sociological & Demographic Research Human Sciences Research Council, Private Bag X41 Pretoria 0001 Republic South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61637996?accountid=14667

Abstract: An investigation of South Africans' acceptance & involvement in privatization & volunteerism in general, & with respect to social services in particular, in the context of economic recession. Analysis is based on an interview survey of approximately 5,000 respondents (Rs) drawn independently from Caucasian (white), brown (Coloured), Asian (Indian), & African (black) population groups, with response rates of 81%-99%. Questions tapped Rs' views on the major locus of responsibility for preschool services, homes for the aged, housing for low-income families, manpower training, community recreational facilities, & community health facilities. In general, all four population groups favored the central government taking major responsibility, with the trend weakest among Caucasians. In fact, as far as recreational & community health facilities were concerned, whites were more inclined to choose a regional or local public authority as mainly responsible. Africans were not against privatization as much as was expected. Results of a multiple regression procedure indicated that level of education achieved, area (metropolitan vs nonmetropolitan), type of home tenure, & income were significant predictors of views on privatization. In terms of magnitude of influence, the most important factors in the ranking order for each subsample were: income (Africans), marital status (Asians), age (Coloureds), & educational level (Caucasians); however, the %s of influence were relatively low. Analysis of Rs' willingness to join welfare & service organizations suggests that Asians & Caucasians were least likely to join. Other predictive factors are enumerated. If attitudes toward privatization & joining welfare & service organizations are observed together, higher education is found to be associated with a proprivatization, projoining response. It is suggested that policymakers evaluate the extent to which local participation is clouded by a connotation of population-based participation. 11 Tables, 3 Figures, 25 References. Modified AA

Development Actions from a Sociological Point of View: The State of the Art

Author: Groenewald, C J11 Dept Sociology U Stellenbosch, 7600 Cape Province Republic South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61260846?accountid=14667

Abstract: Development actions in South Africa are analyzed according to a typology of state attitudes toward community participation. South African state development programs, it is concluded, are not able to elicit authentic community participation under conditions of apartheid rule; however, cooptational modes & strategies would be regarded as an alternative. Problems in generating community participation are highlighted in reference to recent international experience, & information sources on South African development actions & programs are provided. The need for evaluation research, as an institutionalized aspect of development action, is emphasized. 12 References. Modified AA

The Relapse Process of Alcoholism

Author: Joubert, H F; Langley, M J

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61615703?accountid=14667

Abstract: The treatment of alcoholism is complicated by the fact that 93% of those entering treatment programs will drink alcohol again within 4 years, & 54% will suffer a relapse. Relapse prevention is a strategy designed not only to help the alcoholic make an initial withdrawal, but also to alter addictive patterns & maintain positive habit changes. As such, it is a type of therapy based on cognitive behavior & is an alternative to psychodynamic or disease models of treatment. Following an illustration of the relapse process, attention is focused on the anger & frustration frequently encountered by recovering alcoholics. High-risk situations, self-efficacy, & expectations play a key role in the relapse process. Appropriate coping responses need to be taught. 2 Figures, 2 References. M. Meeks

Social Work at the Crossroads

Author: Gray, M11 Dept Social Work U Natal, Durban Republic South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61633217?accountid=14667

Abstract: An examination of the current status of professional social work in South Africa. It is suggested that national social policy directly conflicts with the values & ethics of the social work profession in South Africa: in day-to-day practice, social workers are continually required to put aside professional values that afford people equality regardless of race, color, or creed. Thus, political interests have tended to override professional interests. It is argued that the most important task facing the profession is the breakdown of barriers between social workers themselves & the development of a strong power base, in order to influence events both within the profession & in the wider social context more effectively. 7 References. Modified AA

Agency Effectiveness in Child Abuse Cases

Author: Roberts, J I11 Dept Social Work U Durban-Westville, 4000 Republic South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61655474?accountid=14667

Abstract: To investigate the quality of care received by children in accordance with South African Child Care Act No. 74 of 1983, questionnaire data were obtained from files on 49 court cases in Durban opened in 1986/87. Of the 140 children mentioned in the files, 52% suffered some form of physical &/or sexual abuse. Data are presented on the sex & age of the victims, their ordinal position in the family, legitimacy at time of birth, severity of abuse, socioeconomic status, perpetrators of abuse, outcome of court enquiry, & institutionalization or movement of children. Special attention is given to preventive strategies. 14 Tables, 50 References. M. Meeks

Workers' Rights and the Social Worker

Author: Middleton, A J11 U South Africa, Pretoria 0001

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61657631?accountid=14667

Abstract: Considered are the rights & duties of social workers vis-a-vis their clients, employers, the courts, & the profession. Legal principles governing these relationships are outlined, especially those protecting against unfair labor practices. Legal protection against verbal & physical abuse by clients is also reviewed, outlining appropriate professional responses to such incidences. The fiduciary relationship between social workers & the courts is discussed, along with issues of professional disciplinary action. It is emphasized that the obligations of social workers are concomitant to their rights. 23 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Black Middle Class Family in the City

Author: Rautenbach, E A1; Kellerman, A P R1 Dept Sosiologie U South Africa, Pretoria 0001

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61274790?accountid=14667

Abstract: Using data from The South African Social Value Study ([author not specified] Pinegowrie: Markinor, 1982), the social values of middle-class black families (N = 63) are compared with those of Afrikaans- & English-speaking (N = 108 & 95, respectively) white families. Despite homogeneity of major features, analysis reveals several differences between blacks & whites: eg, the proportion of black families who own their own homes is much lower than that of white families. Such deviations are best explained as a result of government interference in the urbanization process rather than a consequence of traditional black social patterns. 1 Table, 2 References. Adapted from the source document.

Beyond Apartheid: An Alphabet of Challenges for Social Work Education

Author: McKendrick, B11 School Social Work U Witwatersrand, Johannesburg 2050 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61630422?accountid=14667

Abstract: The two circumstances most likely to shape future South African society are: the people's aspirations for a democratic social order, & the country's need for concerted economic development. Societal institutions will need to be adapted to respond to these two priorities. The social work profession, previously closely identified with the structures of apartheid social control, is challenged to become both a means of furthering democratic ideals & an instrument of national development. Based on an analysis of social work's historical growth in South Africa, critical issues are identified for the institution of a professional education for social work that will equip practitioners for the profession's new role. 24 References. AA

Abstract: Guidelines are offered for social workers in the South African Nasionale Instit insake Misdaadvoorkoming en die Rehabilitasie van Oortreders (NIMRO) to solicit volunteers from the community for serving clients needing rehabilitation. A Model for Social Work Practice Education

Author: Botha, Narisscia J11 Dept Social Work U Stellenbosch, 7600 Cape Province South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61648137?accountid=14667

Abstract: While social work (SW) education has a theoretical base, its practical component is the most important. The practice course for SW students gives them the opportunity to apply their knowledge & skills in hands-on practice. The curriculum for a practice course should cover: situation analyses; goal formulation; selection of learning experiences, methods, & techniques; & evaluation. A model for developing a fieldwork curriculum is outlined that includes: (1) determination of the theoretical premises; (2) assessment of the purposes & objectives of the practice component; & (3) evaluation of the fulfillment of the objectives. 2 Figures, 24 References. Interracial Adoption

Author: Simpkins, D1; Boult, B1 Dept Sociology U Port Elizabeth, 6000 Cape Province South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61282281?accountid=14667

Abstract: Following a review of international adoption statistics & research questionnaire data are used to investigate attitudes of sociologists (N = 44) toward interracial adoption in South Africa. Analysis in 4 categories -- against interracial adoption, in favor, conditionally in favor, & conditionally against -- reveals that the majority of respondents were in favor of interracial adoption. 1 Figure, 14 References. The Use of Constructive Confrontation with the Alcohol-Dependent Patient

Author: Van Der Walt, G. E.1; Van Der Westhuizen, C. H. J.1 Dept Maatskaplike Werk U Pretoria, Brooklyn 002 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61638583?accountid=14667

Abstract: Research on the use of constructive confrontation with the alcohol-dependent patient is outlined, & an illustrative case study is presented. Constructive confrontation is based on the involvement of significant others in confronting the alcohol-dependent patient in a concerned & caring manner, with the medical social worker acting as a facilitator. The primary aim of such confrontation in a medical setting is to increase the patient's motivation for long-term therapy upon discharge. 14 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Roles and Tasks of the Medical Social Worker regarding the Infertile Couple

Author: Laurence-Carbonatto, C1; Du Perez, M. S. E.1 Dept Social Work U Pretoria, Brooklyn 0002 Republic South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61617406?accountid=14667

Abstract: Counseling infertile couples in treatment at infertility clinics or in private medical practices requires medical social workers to have particular skills & specialized medical knowledge. The goals, roles, & tasks of medical social work, & the dynamics of interdisciplinary teamwork are defined for medical social work in general, & guidelines specific to medical social work with infertile couples are presented. Discussed are: initial screening & psychosocial assessment; preparation of couples for medical investigations & supportive counseling during this phase; postdiagnostic crisis intervention; preparation for treatment procedures & supportive counseling during this phase; & posttreatment counseling. 22 References. C. Grindle

Self-Esteem in Deaf Young Adults: An Ecological Perspective

Author: Ross, Eleanor11 Dept Speech Pathology & Audiology U Witwatersrand, Johannesburg 2050 Republic South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61626325?accountid=14667

Abstract: A test of the hypothesis that a relationship exists between level of self-esteem of young adult deaf persons & the degree of satisfaction that they experience in their transactions with ecological systems, eg, assistive devices, the family, employment, religion, leisure, & social work service delivery. Data are drawn from inventories & interview schedules completed by a sample of 50 prelingually deaf young adults through the medium of "total communication," ie, speech, sign language, & the written word. Results reveal significant relationships between self-esteem & satisfaction with life in general, family life, & the use of hearing aids. Findings on attitudes & communication suggest that deaf people are disabled more by their transactions with the hearing world than by the pathology of their hearing impairment. 1 Figure, 18 References. Modified AA

Social Work and Community Health: The Interface

Author: Pick, W M11 Medical School U Cape Town, Rosebank 7700 Republic South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61620448?accountid=14667

Abstract: A discussion of the relationship between social work & health care, with specific reference to community health in South Africa. The history of social work in the English/American model is outlined as it influenced South African social work. The impact of measurement, social, health management, & environmental health sciences is stressed. Functions & roles appropriate to social workers within community health services include case finding, outreach, mobilizing community support services, & health education. Three areas in which community health & social work particularly interface are: epidemiological prevention approaches, community diagnosis, & health planning. 2 References. C. Grindle

Development of Family Therapy Services and Supervision in a Hospital Social Work Department

Author: Hochstadter, S; Rubenstein, J

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61639758?accountid=14667

Abstract: The evolution of a family therapy supervision group for social workers at Johannesburg Hospital in South Africa is described in five stages: (1) introduction of systems thinking & practice; (2) establishment of the family therapy supervision group as a subsystem; (3) redefinition of the supervisor-supervisee system; (4) development of the concept & practice of systems consultation; & (5) establishment of a second family therapy supervision group. Case examples of successful interventions are presented. It is concluded that this attempt to establish a family therapy service has been a success, although issues for future attention are raised. 1 Figure, 15 References. C. Grindle

Apartheid, Poverty, Social Transformation: A Pilgrimage to a Non-Racial Democracy Challenges Social Work in South Africa

Author: Louw, Lionel R11 School Social Work U Cape Town, Rosebank 7700 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61607433?accountid=14667

Abstract: The legacy of racial discrimination in South Africa has intensified since 1948 under the apartheid ideology. This legacy has systematically eroded the rights of people & dominated the societal order, social work training included. The most disastrous consequence has been the impoverishment of the majority of South Africans. In recent history, growing protest against apartheid has resulted in a movement of intense resistance, & the transition to a nonracial democracy has been set in motion. The challenges presented by this transition for social work education & training of helping professionals are considered. 7 Tables, 16 References. Modified AA

The Use of Experimental Research in Social Work

Author: Strydom, H11 Dept Maatskaplike Werk U Christelike Hoer Onderwys, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61607508?accountid=14667

Abstract: The distinction between knowledge objectives & research designs in social work is described & the term "experimental research" is evaluated, noting the difference between true & quasi-experiments. The different components of an experiment -- eg, the manipulation of the independent variable, controlling for intervening variables, random sampling procedures -- are discussed, & a variety of experimental designs reviewed. The advantages & disadvantages of experimental research are analyzed. 19 References. Adapted from the source document.

Social Work Unity: Present Quest for the Impossible?

Author: Drower, Sandra J11 U Witwatersrand, Johannesburg 2050 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61651283?accountid=14667

Abstract: Differing interpretations of the primary social work values of social justice & democracy are profoundly influenced by the societal, ideological, & personal values held by the individual social worker & are at the heart of much of the present disunity among South African social workers. This disunity is evidenced most clearly by the existence of a number of professional associations & reflects both the historical legacy of South African society & the profession's position as a subsystem of that society: all the tension & confusion within the wider community are mirrored in the profession itself. As South Africa enters a period of transition to a nonracial, democratic, & united society, social workers are challenged to actualize these same ideals within their own professional ranks. The process of unifying the social work profession in South Africa will require a willingness to confront & reframe personal interpretations of values; in addition, social workers will have to explore the meaning of unity for both the profession & its clientele. Placing emphasis on unification as a process, as opposed to a single moment in time, is most likely to facilitate the unity sought, & is also likely to increase the potential for the emergence of shared interpretations of professional values that reflect South African reality. 15 References. Modified AA

Provision of Social Welfare: Employer Participation

Author: Thomas, A

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61631859?accountid=14667

Abstract: It is argued that, given the pressing human needs in South Africa, the inadequacies of the social welfare system, & the failure of the private sector to ameliorate the situation, employer-sponsored social welfare assistance is necessary & crucial. Two models of social welfare are discussed: the institutional model, which views social welfare as a normal function of a modern industrial society; & the residual model, which holds that social welfare is necessary only after traditional support mechanisms, eg, the family & the market, have broken down. In South Africa, social welfare is regulated on the basis of the residual model; however, this model does not acknowledge the importance of such factors as economic vicissitudes, old age, disabilities, & troubled home environments. It is claimed that business should recognize its complementary social & economic functions & provide welfare assistance to employees. 8 References. Adapted from the source document.

Khaya Lethu -- An Abortive Attempt at Dealing with Street Children

Author: Bernstein, Andrea J1; Gray, M M A1 Dept Social Work U Natal, Durban 4001 Republic South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61607382?accountid=14667

Abstract: In South Africa, the problem of street children has been related to the changing nature of society. With rapid urbanization, the society has become increasingly characterized by the social conditions experienced in other Third World countries; for many children in South Africa, these social problems are exacerbated by political inequalities. It is suggested that while street children may be running away from persons & abusive situations, they are also reaching out to people who will empathize with them, & looking for situations in which they will regain their sense of self-worth. Here, three possible strategies for working with street children -- containment, cure, & prevention -- are considered in the South African context. Focus is on an open door residential unit, Khayalethu (our home), established in Durban by a voluntary organization modeling its activities on the cure approach, which involves weaning children away from street life & gradually introducing them to educational & more regular work patterns. The activities of this organization are documented, noting its relationship with statutory & municipal authorities & the constraints of existing legislation. The eventual closure of the residence is described, & the need for a coordinated response that involves simultaneous interventions at micro, mezzo, & macro levels is recommended. 6 References. Modified AA

A Study of Attitudes towards and Tolerance of Violence by a Group of School Children

Author: Setiloane, C W M

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61274844?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examined are attitudes toward violence among South African youths ages 13-19, who have grown up in an environment of multifaceted violence, drawing ona model of the psychological effects of violence on young people. Questionnaire data from 58 male & 55 female secondary school students from the Mamelodi township of Pretoria indicate that the young people abhor violence; this finding was supported in postquestionnaire discussions with student groups. Girls, however, were more likely than boys to express the opinion that violence for self-defense is justifiable. It is noted that the students' rejection of violence could be the consequence of using the school as the research site; it is recommended that future studies should be conducted in nonschool settings, eg, church or community clubs. It is concluded that the violence of contemporary South African society leads young people to desire a more benevolent & nonviolent society. 2 Tables, 3 Figures, 16 References. W. Howard

Social Work and a New South Africa: Can Social Workers Meet the Challenge?

Author: Bernstein, A11 Dept Social Work U Natal, Durban 4001 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61619736?accountid=14667

Abstract: A discussion of social work practice in South Africa, with focus on: where South African social workers stand in relation to professionalization; unity among professional associations, which are now divided by ideological & value differences; & alternative representation through unions. The difficulty in operationalizing the ecosystems theory within the sphere of social work is illustrated in the persistence of South African social workers in seeing themselves as caseworkers, with little emphasis on group work. It is suggested that explanations in the gap between theory & practice may lie in their education & training & in the narrow way in which social work is conceptualized in South Africa. It is contended that: educators must consider the relevance & appropriateness of their curricula & courses; practitioners must adopt a holistic approach & develop programs based on participatory, egalitarian, & inclusive strategies; & agencies must accept that such practice requires endorsement & support. Furthermore, social workers must involve themselves in the social policy arena & become active participants in their own, their clients', & South Africa's future. 32 References. S. Millett

Social Development Perspectives: Challenges for the Social Work Profession

Author: Triegaardt, J D11 School Social Work U Witwatersrand, Johannesburg 2050 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61619690?accountid=14667

Abstract: Incorporating multistage cluster sampling techniques, an interview survey conducted in 3 Cape Town, South Africa, townships (N = 150 households) in 1989 revealed 46% unemployment, predominantly among youth. Social networks were utilized by the unemployed in order to survive. The unemployed made attempts to secure employment but lacked the resources to seek employment opportunities. The unemployed found that their situation was traumatic & a burden to depend on their families for assistance. Social workers need to advocate for more humane & just policies for the unemployed. 15 References. Modified AA

Towards Non-Racist Social Work Practice

Author: Galloway, E M11 Dept Social Work U Natal, Durban 4001 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61653018?accountid=14667

Abstract: It is argued that social work in South Africa manifests racism through: its value base, with its focus on the residual model of welfare & the belief that the individual is responsible for his or her own welfare; social work service delivery, which excludes people & becomes a rationing device in the hands of under-resourced social work agencies & training institutions; &, increasingly, social control. A number of government documents that endorse racist & exlusionary policies in South Africa are identified & discussed. Social workers are urged to eradicate racism by becoming racially aware, working to eliminate racism in the agency & practice, & taking up the antiracist struggle more generally through political activity. 20 References. S. Millett

Research and Education as Key Concepts in the Transition to a Non-Racial Social Work Practice

Author: Jacob, Leigh-Ann1; Joseph, Gail M; Van Rooyen, Colin A. J.1 Dept Social Work U Natal, Durban 4001 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61624275?accountid=14667

Abstract: A discussion of multicultural social work in South Africa, with specific reference to education & practice. It is argued that direct extrapolation of Western thought, which advocates the racial & cultural matching of social workers & clients may be inappropriate in South Africa; rather, authentic & indigenous practice needs to evolve relevant to the developing South African context. A contextual framework for the transition to nonracial social work practice is presented, as are results of a questionnaire survey of 80 Ss, drawn from an agency case list, which investigated client attitudes toward nonracial social work. It is concluded that social work services have to adopt a nonracial stance in order to ensure that service provision is relevant. Challenges for social work education are considered. 3 Tables, 43 References. Modified AA

Powerful Talk and Talking Power: Dilemmas in the Construction of Socio-Cultural Diversities Courses in the South African Social Work Curriculum

Author: Mackintosh, I O11 School Social Work U Cape Town, Rosebank 7700 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61637149?accountid=14667

Abstract: Key issues & dilemmas specific to courses covering sociocultural diversities, & relevant to the needs of social workers practicing in a transitional, postapartheid society in South Africa are examined. It is argued that local historical & current sociopolitical realities have created controversies around issues of race, culture, & ethnicity that are, to some extent, peculiar to the South African context. This context partly accounts for the relative silence on issues of "difference" in South African progressive, antiapartheid social sciences. Raising these issues is a hazardous task; such "powerful talk" needs to be handled in careful & constructive ways given the diverse nature of the social work student body in a liberal, open South African university. The relevance of the concept of power as an essential construct in informing theoretical analysis & social work practice in South Africa is elucidated. It is argued that without "talking power" when addressing culture, race, & ethnicity, there is a danger that South African social work teachers will participate in introducing, rather than eliminating or reducing, discriminatory & oppressive attitudes & practices. Specific educational strategies found to be both effective in the classroom & congruent with the broad cultural & reflexive framework of a cultural diversities perspective are elaborated. 24 References. AA

Marginalization and HIV Infection in Cape Town: Crisis Intervention as a Dynamic, Effective Strategy

Author: Isaacs, G1; Pegge, J1 School Social Work U Cape Town, Rosebank 7700 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61624234?accountid=14667

Abstract: The value of crisis intervention as a therapeutic approach in dealing with persons living with HIV (human immunodeficiency virus) & acquired immune deficiency syndrome is considered, on the retrospective examination of 300 case files & clinical research conducted in Cape Town, South Africa. The crisis-loss-anxiety triad is examined, & a model of intervention is offered, linking the legacy of HIV crisis & sexuality, in order to facilitate the appropriate expressions of loss, including grief & mourning. It is concluded that HIV infection triggers unfinished business from the past, & that crisis intervention provides a relevant counseling space to assist persons in dealing with both state & object losses. Clients are afforded the opportunity to release (& deal with) unrecognized growth (gain) potential, including sexual identity (coming out) & relationship (intimacy) issues. 34 References. Modified AA

Social Work and Agriculture

Author: Kotze, G J; Theron, E

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61655475?accountid=14667

Abstract: To determine the need for social work among farmers & their families in the drought-stricken areas of the Western Transvaal, South Africa, questionnaire data were obtained from 80 farm families. Analysis shows that high interest rates, high capital costs, low prices for agricultural commodities, & poor financial management led to financial problems compounded by the drought. A biographical profile is offered of the respondents' age, educational level, & church affiliation. Also discussed are: the results of the drought on psychological functioning; alcohol usage; interpersonal relationships; mothers working outside the home; participation in social activities; the adaptability of children; & the effects of delinquent loans & foreclosures. 3 Tables, 5 Figures, 12 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Complexity of Adult Adoptee Needs to Search for Their Origins: A Research Finding

Author: Boult, Brenda Ernestine11 U Port Elizabeth, ZA-6000 Cape Province South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61658867?accountid=14667

Abstract: Mail questionnaires sent in 1987 to adult adoptees in South Africa yielded 82 responses (71% female, ages 18-70). Of these, 29 had traced their birth parents, siblings, or other kin before changes in 1987 in the country's adoption laws allowing adult adoptees access to court records. The decision to search was most often made during young adulthood, triggered by leaving home/starting work, marriage, or birth of the first child. Primary reasons given were: to discover origins; to know birth parents' identity; to understand why they were placed; & replace a parent figure after the death of one or both adoptive parents. Analysis of the outcomes shows that: 48% of those who had found kin experienced this as positive & rewarding; 28% were ambivalent, expressing reservations; & 24% were disappointed. On-going contact between adoptees & their newly found kin was contingent on the adoptee's perception of the initial meeting as warm, loving, & accepting. 1 Table, 19 References. Modified AA

The Use of Functional Aids in Social Work

Author: du Preez, M. S. E.1; Alpaslan, A H1 Dept Maatskaplike Werk U Pretoria, Brooklyn 0002 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61595734?accountid=14667

Abstract: It is shown how a social worker can use functional aids (FAs) to stimulate & complete the assistance process. FAs are more specific, concrete ways of helping the client in an immediate way; examples include activities, program media, & structured experiences. Special attention is given to the criteria for the choice of FAs. The various types of FAs are especially valuable in building social skills, assessing problems, working with children, & achieveing specific goals. 26 References. Adapted from the source document.

Family Functioning and Preschool Performance in Indian South African Families

Author: Mason, J B1; Candotti, S1 Dept Social Work U Durban-Westville, Private Bag X54001 4000 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61641143?accountid=14667

Abstract: An investigation of the family functioning of 78 Indian South African families (as measured by the family assessment device [FAD]) from a lower socioeconomic area, & the impact of family variables on their children's performance at the beginning & end of the preschool year. The children were assessed via a teacher rating scale, hearing, language, & speech tests, & measures of cognitive functioning. The impact of the family was measured by step-wise regression analysis between the FAD & the children's cognitive tests. The families were in general found to be similar to nonclinical families in other parts of the world. Parents experienced most difficulty with behavior control. The greater the degree of open communication in the family, the better were the child's expressive & receptive language skills. The more affectively involved the parents were, the better the child's overall cognitive functioning on entering preschool. The influence of the family system was found to diminish over the year. Interventions were undertaken to help parents & children. The expected relationship between formal learning at preschool & informal education in the home was confirmed, & the efficacy of home programs demonstrated. 2 Tables, 12 References. Modified AA

The Profile of Potentially Successful First-Year Students in Social Work: An Approach to Selection

Author: van Zyl, M A; Terblanche, S; Jacobs, G J

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61592723?accountid=14667

Abstract: To determine what type of students show potential for training as social workers, questionnaire data were obtained from 81 female & 3 male students at a South African university. Rather than academic ability, it is found that successful first-year students share common psychological traits, eg: sociability, intelligence, emotional maturity, dominance, cautiousness, sense of duty, & love of adventure. Identifying these traits should lead to better student selection mechanisms, & improved methods for training social workers. 8 Tables, 15 References. Adapted from the source document.

A Pragmatic Approach to Social Work Unity

Author: Gray, M M A11 Dept Social Work U Natal, Durban 4001 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61656818?accountid=14667

Abstract: An examination of the current status of professional social work in South Africa concludes that social workers (SWs) need to overcome the barriers that divide them & work toward professional unity. To this end, four broad areas are addressed: the need for a pragmatic approach to unity, personal & professional values, the potential of ethical codes for uniting SWs, & the political nature of social work. It is argued that a shared value framework is essential in social work, & that the notion of social justice is central to this framework. It is proposed that all SWs in South Africa who are concerned about the future development of their profession should meet the challenge for professional unity & search for a common means through which to achieve this goal. 14 References. Modified AA

Divorce Mediation

Author: van Staden, S M1; Grove, E; Kruger, M1 Dept Maatskaplike Werk U Pretoria, Brooklyn 0002 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61630169?accountid=14667

Abstract: Divorce mediation is an efficient conflict resolution method helping the separating partners achieve an acceptable working relationship despite the failure of the marriage. The ex-spouses can identify their particular needs & reach creative solutions that they themselves help to formulate. Special attention is given to: the theoretical fundamentals of mediation; legal issues; the role of the mediator; assessment of property as a component of the mediation process; the benefits of mediation; the mediation process per se; & mediation in a multidisciplinary context. Also discussed are child custody arrangements. 1 Figure, 13 References. Adapted from the source document.

Sexuality and Spinal Cord Injury

Author: Sishuba, J E

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61625746?accountid=14667

Abstract: Few physical disabilities are as complex & challenging as a spinal cord injury. Rehabilitation programs have traditionally focused on imparting special techniques for mobility & daily living, eg, in bathing, dressing, eating, homemaking, & bowel & bladder management; regaining a normal sex life is not usually addressed. Depending on the type of spinal lesions, many women may be able to participate in intercourse, & some will be able to achieve a pleasurable sensation or even a full orgasm. For men, however, certain types of injuries result in impotency. Counseling should be provided to help patients learn about alternate modes of sexual expression. 6 References. M. Meeks

Preparation for Labor Market Competition

Author: Uys, Rene

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61611472?accountid=14667

Abstract: To investigate the integration of the disabled into the South African workforce, survey data were collected from 47 handicapped citizens whose disabilities included blindness, deafness, & epilepsy. Attention is focused on the role played by schools & special training centers in preparing the disabled for the labor market. Despite the training & the willingness of the disabled to work, few find jobs; only 0.258% of all South African workers are disabled. This is especially unfortunate & surprising in view of the high educational qualifications of many disabled. 6 Tables, 1 Figure, 13 References. Adapted from the source document.

Parents of Children Who Commit Suicide as Victims of Stigma

Author: Pretorius, Ronelle11 Dept Criminology U Pretoria, Brooklyn 0002 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61622927?accountid=14667

Abstract: To investigate the feelings experienced by parents of suicide victims, interview data were obtained from 11 South African couples who had suffered such a loss. Analysis reveals that their trauma is due not only to the suicide per se, but also to subtle or open victimization by society leading to stigmatization. Parents may become victims of self-blame, guilt, & self-imposed isolation. Because of the taboos about suicide, there are no formal structures to help families through the grieving process. Many families felt that they were the target of gossip by neighbors, friends, & colleagues. Publication of details of the suicide in the local newspapers made the families feel ashamed; many siblings refused to attend school. Suggestions are offered to overturn this situation. 7 References. M. Meeks

How Really Different Is Different: A Reply to Kasiram

Author: Malan, A

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61643118?accountid=14667

Abstract: A response to M. Kasiram's "Is Family Therapy an Appropriate Intervention Strategy in South Africa?" (Social Work/Maatskaplike Werk, 1991, 27, 2, 28). Kasiram's choice of the Milan school of family therapy (FT) as representative of all FT is left unexplained. Further, by focusing on systemic thinking as the theoretical basis of FT, she ignores the diverse orientations proposed for FT by different conceptualizations of systems theory. An epistemological analysis refutes her contention that FT is based in circular causality. It is concluded that she should opt not for the combination of various epistemologies, but rather, for conversion to an alternative epistemology. 10 References. M. Meeks

Helping a Woman to Construct a Weekly Budget

Author: [Unknown]

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61622878?accountid=14667

Abstract: A case study is presented of a social work intervention that attempted to assist a South African woman bring her finances into order by following a weekly budget. A key component of the intervention strategy was the process of formulating budget goals. A daily record of expenditures was kept over a four-week period to establish a baseline. Attempts were made to control impulsive spending. The client established spending priorities by ranking desired items on a scale of need. Additional components included the responsible use of credit & prompt repayment of bills. This project was highly successful & is recommended for use by other social workers. 11 References. M. Meeks

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Helping+a+Woman+to+Construct+a+Weekly+Budget&amp;rft.au=%5BUnknown%5D&amp;rft.aulast=%5BUnknown%5D&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=1992-03-01&amp;rft.volume=28&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=101&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378054&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The Process of Victimization in Childhood Sexual Abuse

Author: Collings, S J11 Dept Psychology U Natal, Durban 4001 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61598740?accountid=14667

Abstract: Questionnaire data collected from 68 white South African women ages 18-57 are used to examine the incidence of child sexual abuse victimization in a nonclinical sample. Findings are consistent with those obtained in previous studies of clinical victims; ie, there are three interconnected processes of child sexual abuse: sexualizing the relationship, justifying the sexual abuse, & maintaining the child's cooperation. Implications for prevention programs are discussed. 3 Tables, 14 References. R. Logsdon

Parents as Victims of Abuse by Rebellious Children and the Role of Tourette's Syndrome as a Causal Factor

Author: Pretorius, Ronelle11 U Pretoria, Brooklyn 0002 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61625029?accountid=14667

Abstract: Empirical data collected from 50 attendees at a support group for abused parents in South Africa are used to demonstrate the need to recognize & treat abused parents as victims of violence. The abuse received from children ranged from verbal & physical abuse to property damage. The role of Tourette's syndrome in parental abuse is discussed, showing that 11 rebellious children treated for the disease experienced dramatic behavioral changes. 6 References. Adapted from the source document.
