An Exploration of the Use of the Genogram with Families of Different Cultural Groups

Author: Becker, Lily1; Lewis, Heather1 School Social Work U Cape Town, Rosebank 7700 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61595926?accountid=14667

Abstract: An experiment was conducted in 1989/90 at the U of Cape Town (South Africa) to investigate the applicability of the genogram (a diagrammatic tool used in social work practice to monitor intergenerational family history) to a cross-cultural population. Interview data collected from a random sample of parents in 95 nuclear families demonstrate that the use of genograms was judged helpful in learning more about their families. However, African parents were more likely to report that discussing their family history was private, sensitive, or taboo. 16 References. R. Logsdon

Report on the Regional Consultative Conference, "Social Welfare in National Reconstruction and Social Development". Johannesburg, 21-22 June 1991

Author: Drower, S J11 School Social Work U Witwatersrand, Johannesburg 2050 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61620205?accountid=14667

Abstract: Reported are proceedings of the 1991 conference of the South African group, Concerned Social Workers, whose goal is to develop an equitable welfare system in South Africa & to devise a critical theory & practice of social work. At the conference, findings were presented from a three-year research project that identified social services programs affiliated with the United Democratic Front & the Congress of South African Trade Unions. This information will be used to help develop principles, guidelines, & recommendations for a welfare policy appropriate for a nonracial, democratic South Africa. 5 References. R. Logsdon

Strategic Planning: Critical Element in Changing the Nature of Welfare Services

Author: McKendrick, B W11 School Social Work U Witwatersrand, Johannesburg 2050 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61640953?accountid=14667

Abstract: South African community welfare agencies were shaped by apartheid, racially organized, & concentrated on therapeutic services, & most of their clientele were white. Here, explored is whether community welfare agencies think that their services should be changed in line with the democratization of the wider society, & if so, how successful they have been in making the desired changes. Interview data were collected in 1992 from the directors of 5 registered welfare organizations in Johannesburg, & agency documents & reports were analyzed. All directors thought that change was necessary -- mainly through the deracialization of services, a move from therapy to prevention, & the targeting of services to especially needy groups, principally black people. All attested that state policy no longer blocked this sort of change, & that money was relatively freely available for preventive activities & services to blacks. Most noted that the major obstacle to change was social work personnel, who were skilled in therapeutic counseling & who did not wish to move away from this activity. Every agency had made some changes in service direction, but most were modest rather than dramatic. Modified AA

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Strategic+Planning%3A+Critical+Element+in+Changing+the+Nature+of+Welfare+Services&amp;rft.au=McKendrick%2C+B+W&amp;rft.aulast=McKendrick&amp;rft.aufirst=B&amp;rft.date=1992-08-01&amp;rft.volume=28&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378054&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The Ethical Implications of a Primary Model of Care

Author: Gray, M M A11 Dept Social Work U Natal, Durban 4001 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61611294?accountid=14667

Abstract: As South Africa undergoes the transition to a postapartheid society, increased attention will have to be given to the distribution of scarce social & health resources. Explored here are the ethical implications of a primary social care model & the feasibility of its achieving its major goal, ie, helping the poor reach a level of social functioning & improving social conditions in communities to enhance overall health & quality of life. The model's philosophical & theoretical underpinnings are outlined, & the need to shift intervention toward the community rather than the individual is emphasized. Imbalances wrought by apartheid must be rectified so as to achieve equality in the provision of & access to health & social resources/services. 6 References. Adapted from the source document.

Primary Care: The Challenge to Social Work Educators

Author: Sewpaul, V11 Dept Social Work U Natal, Durban 4001 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61626740?accountid=14667

Abstract: Though legislative apartheid is in the process of being abolished in South Africa, the persistence of one of its cornerstones -- the tricameral system -- has perpetuated the fragmentation & inequitable distribution of social, psychiatric, & welfare services. It is argued here that educational programs should focus on training social workers in the fundamentals of primary health care to address the larger problems of human resource development. After outlining the benefits of the primary care model, challenges facing its implementation in social work training & practice are discussed. A client-centered approach is advocated that stresses the participation of poor, rural communities in their own development. 26 References. K. Hyatt

Training of Social Work Assistants in and for Rural Areas: The Hungarian "Socialis Asszisztens" as a Model for South Africa's Rural Social Services

Author: Woods, Ronald11 School Social Work U Witwatersrand, Johannesburg 2050 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61651779?accountid=14667

Abstract: Based on experiences in Hungary, 1988-1991, a model is presented for the training of social work assistants, primarily in towns with close links to the surrounding rural areas, with a curriculum that prepares students to work in & with rural conditions. Such a model is seen as suitable for South Africa, a country dissimilar from Hungary in many respects, but sharing the common feature of undergoing far-reaching sociopolitical transformation. This provides a strategic opportunity for establishing creative, cost-effective responses to human problems in its neglected rural regions. 13 References. Modified AA

Resource Development as a Priority in Rural Areas -- The Role of the Social Worker

Author: Rankin, Pedro11 Dept Social Work Rhodes U, Grahamstown South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61627987?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examined are the problems caused by the lack of resources for the social worker practicing in rural areas. It is argued that these workers should focus on the mobilization of existing resources & rearranging them through a process of networking & coordination. Eight different kinds of resources normally found in rural areas are described, & the role that the social worker can play in mobilizing them is outlined. Also discussed are implications of the priority of resources development in rural areas for social work education & training. 13 References. Modified AA

An Assessment of Basic Needs and Related Factors Affecting Rural Women's Interest in Literacy Programmes in Zimbabwe

Author: Kiire, Ruth H11 School Social Work U Zimbabwe, Mount Pleasant Harare

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61645535?accountid=14667

Abstract: Interviews conducted in 1986 with rural women (total N = 89 respondents ages 23-60) in 3 villages of the Seke District of Zimbabwe provided data on their sociodemographic characteristics, basic living needs, & rate of/interest in achieving literacy. Surprisingly, results indicate no correlation between the satisfaction of basic needs & desire for literacy. An approach to the development of literacy programs is thus advocated that integrates them into social development & income-generating programs. 3 Tables, 2 Figures, 8 References. Adapted from the source document.

Mediation as a Means of Social Work Intervention to Empower People

Author: Lombard, Antoinette11 Dept Social Work U Pretoria, Brooklyn 0002 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61656772?accountid=14667

Abstract: Outlined is an integrated approach by which social workers can function as mediators in an effort to empower South Africans, who typically consider themselves powerless in the face of poverty, racial discrimination, prejudice, & social injustice. Key concepts in the approach are described, & four phases of social work intervention outlined. 1 Table, 1 Figure, 34 References. Modified AA

Acceptability of the Single-System Design in the Evaluation of Social Work Practice

Author: Fourie, S11 Dept Maatskaplike Werk U Stellenbosch, Cape Province Republic South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61594957?accountid=14667

Abstract: It is contended that social work in South Africa lacks a means of evaluating the effectiveness of direct practice that would make social workers accountable to clients, organizations, & donors. The Treatment Evaluation Inventory was administered to 19 social workers & 20 social work students to evaluate the effectiveness of the single-system design. Results suggest that the design is appropriate for both social work practice & training; implications for curriculum design, undergraduate field instruction, & continuing education for practicing social workers are discusssed. 8 Figures, 39 References. Adapted from the source document.

Author: Molefe, S P11 Dept Social Work U North, Sovenga 0727 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61623576?accountid=14667

Abstract: A description of the experiences of student social workers who employed innovative strategies to assist the rural community of Makgeng, South Africa, to procure water. Is School Dropout in a Semi-Rural Community Related to Poverty?

Author: Keen, A W1; Naidu, A1 Dept Social Work U Durban-Westville, Private Bag X54001 4000 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61611248?accountid=14667

Abstract: Interview data obtained from a snowball sample of 12 high school dropouts in a semirural community outside Pinetown, South Africa, are drawn on to explore factors associated with dropping out in this poor community. Results indicate that socioeconomic conditions are less significant than previously assumed; peer influence, family breakdown, lack of parental control & family values, & perceived irrelevance of the curriculum are more important contributors. Implications for intervention are discussed. 9 References. Adapted from the source document.

A Dream... and the Reality

Author: Cronje, Johan11 Dept Social Work U Stellenbosch, Cape Province Republic South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61592476?accountid=14667

Abstract: An editorial on the future of South Africa describes the generally hopeful views of social workers & other human service professionals, & argues that these must be tempered by acknowledgement of the country's political, socioeconomic, & racial realities. Constraints posed by social problems such as the acquired immune deficiency syndrome epidemic, colonialism, lack of economic resources, & increasing numbers of refugees, & health hazards due to poverty & unemployment are discussed. Job Analysis, Design, Description, Specification and Evaluation: An Introduction for Social Workers

Author: Smit, A. de V.11 School Social Work U Cape Town, Rosebank 7700 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61587562?accountid=14667

Abstract: Job analysis involves identifying the nature & design of the job, formulating a description reflecting the job content, setting the requirements, & determining the salary. Ultimately, performance appraisals are tied to these same features. The economic crisis in South Africa is leading agencies to ask social workers to perform more tasks with fewer resources; job analysis would help the profession take greater control of its own management. More equitable salaries, within both the profession & the wider labor market, could be determined through more appropriate job evaluation. 6 Tables, 6 Figures, 10 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Multiple Problem Family: Who Are They and How Are They Being Helped?

Author: Sturgeon, S1; Conradie, I1 School Social Work U Cape Town, Rosebank 7700 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61631854?accountid=14667

Abstract: Following a literature review of the multiple-problem family in the UK & US, an attempt is made to determine if similar patterns exist in South Africa, examining family files (N = 30) from various social service agencies in Cape Town. The absence of black families in the files suggests that, possibly for historical reasons, they are not receiving their due share of social services. Key family problems include: substance abuse, violence & neglect, psychological problems, social deviance, marital problems, family dysfunction, financial problems, & housing. Only 13% of the files indicated complete diagnoses. Outcomes of intervention strategies were improved when: a full multi-axial, systemic assessment was made, a clear treatment plan developed, & regular contracted contact maintained. Results indicate patterns similar to those in other countries. 1 Table, 1 Figure, 25 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Adoption of Single-System Design in Social Groupwork with Adolescent Girls

Author: Strydom, H; Strydom, C

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61613291?accountid=14667

Abstract: The complexity of modern society has a significant influence on the adolescent girl, complicating her attempts to cope with everyday problems. Appropriate guidance & counseling can make her adjustment easier. To determine how social groupwork can enhance self-image, an experiment was conducted measuring self-esteem of mothers & daughters (N not given). Special attention was given to the purposes, characteristics, & state-by-state implementation of the single-system design. Results show that the single-system design is useful & that the social groupwork technique enables teenage girls to mature into happy, well-adjusted women. 2 Tables, 2 Graphs, 7 References. Adapted from the source document.

Social Work Responses to AIDS: A Programme for Social Work Education in South Africa

Author: Woods, Ronald11 School Social Work U Witwatersrand, Johannesburg 2050 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61613657?accountid=14667

Abstract: On the assumption that social work has a clear part to play in dealing with the AIDS (acquired immune deficiency syndrome) pandemic in sub-Saharan Africa, a course was designed for senior undergraduate social work students, with the key to the profession's effective & comprehensive intervention within the wide person-environment transactional field being the practitioner's holistic understanding of human sexuality & the meanings that people attach to it. The course is described & evaluated, using a before-after research design that measured students' knowledge of AIDS-related terminology, revealing increased knowledge, but not determining changes in attitudes. Recommendations are made for social work education, & for research that would shed more light on sexuality-related behaviors & attitudes, not only of the general population, but also of social work students & practitioners. 36 References. AA

AIDS Education for Student Social Workers in South Africa: Are Social Workers Being Educated to Meet the Needs of the Society in Which They Function?

Author: Van Rooyen, C. A. J.1; Bernstein, A J1 U Natal, Durban 4001 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61618006?accountid=14667

Abstract: The typical pattern of racial disparities in all aspects of life in South Africa makes no exception of AIDS (acquired immune deficiency syndrome). By early 1992, an estimated 446,000 people were infected, of whom 69% were urban black & 20% rural blacks. To determine the level of social workers' preparedness to address AIDS issues, questionnaire data were obtained from 19 university social work departments throughout the country; 6 schools had not yet introduced a course dealing with AIDS, 3 of which had a majority black student body. In most curricula, the AIDS class was taught in the fourth year. Topics included: the history & development of the AIDS epidemic; statistical data on transmission; identification of risk groups & activities; medical aspects; psychosocial impact; legal & ethical questions; the role of social workers in delivering services; AIDS prevention; & counseling. Some departments reported that AIDS information was integrated into other courses on health & sexuality. Of 894 student research projects, only 2% dealt with AIDS. Thus, the need exists for a more dynamic, contextually relevant, coordinated response to the AIDS crisis by social work departments. 1 Table, 1 Graph, 37 References. Adapted from the source document.

Author: Van Zyl, M A1; Anderssen, E C; Myburgh, C P H1 Dept Social Work Rand Afrikaans U, Johannesburg 2000 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61586584?accountid=14667

Abstract: Systematic efforts to study mediation increased during the 1980s with notable progress in the systematic formulation of theory, principles, & process skills for mediation. Assessment, Contracting and Evaluation in Groupwork

Author: Coughlan, Felicity J11 Social Work Dept Rhodes U, Memphis TN 38812

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61613609?accountid=14667

Abstract: Although changing times & growing needs have led to the realization in South Africa that social work practice must be extended beyond individual casework, groupwork methods remain unpopular. Possible reasons for this reluctance include fear of being exposed & of negative feedback, too much responsibility, lack of control, & the complexity of group interrelationships. A literature review addresses the definition of the group method & its potential, ways of assessing its purpose & effectiveness, & strategies for effective evaluation & contracting. Practioners have access to an extensive literature on groupwork theory. Moreover, groupwork practice is manageable & professionally viable. If one of the key benefits of groups is their ability to empower people through collective action, then failure to utilize groups is tantamount to the continued oppression of clients. In summary, groupwork is effective, efficient, mobilizing, & socially responsible -- the hallmarks of modern social work. 6 References. M. Meeks

An Affirmative Action Strategy: The Implementation of Academic Development with First Year Social Work Students

Author: Sewpaul, V1; Hoosen, S1 Dept Social Work U Natal, Durban 4001 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61629576?accountid=14667

Abstract: In addition to academic issues, freshmen students in South African universities are confronted with their first multicultural experiences -- moving away from their immediate family & peers. The new environment may lead to feelings of inferiority, rejection, & isolation. An academic development program was begun at the U of Durban-Westville in 1990 addressing students' study skills & personal development issues; 60 freshmen in the social work department were assisted by 8 third-year student group leaders. Pre- & postprogram administration of W. Hudson's Index of Self-Concept questionnaire demonstrated that 97% of respondents registered improvements in self-concept. 2 Graphs, 20 References. M. Meeks

Educating Social Workers to Practice in Rural South Africa: Dilemmas and Challenges -- A Case Study

Author: Taback, Rayna1; Triegaardt, Jean D1 School Social Work U Witwatersrand, Johannesburg 2050 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61613242?accountid=14667

Abstract: Although white South African farmers have generally prospered economically, despite the recent drought, most rural blacks are very poor. The 1913 Land Act forced blacks off their lands & forbade them to own property. Many men leave to work in the cities; thus, the rural population consists largely of the young, the old, & women. The U of Witwatersrand School of Social Work, seeking to incorporate rural social work into its curriculum, initiated a week-long internship for third-year students at a satellite campus at Umbabat, northeast of Johannesburg. Another program was started at the Muldersdrift Clinic in periurban Johannesburg. Many students made aware of the stark realities of rural poverty felt unprepared to deal with the limited community resources. Plans are underway to extend the internship & allow for more thorough interventions. It is emphasized that trained social workers cannot always assume they have the right skills to work in any community. 3 References. M. Meeks

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Educating+Social+Workers+to+Practice+in+Rural+South+Africa%3A+Dilemmas+and+Challenges+--+A+Case+Study&amp;rft.au=Taback%2C+Rayna%3BTriegaardt%2C+Jean+D&amp;rft.aulast=Taback&amp;rft.aufirst=Rayna&amp;rft.date=1992-10-01&amp;rft.volume=28&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=91&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378054&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Die maatskaplike funksionering van minderjarige kind van die alkoholis: 'n verkenningstudie = [The social functioning of the children of alcoholics: an exploratory study]

Author: Malherbe, B R

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/42423586?accountid=14667

Abstract: The children of alcoholics are mainstream in the field of chemical dependency today. It is generally assumed that growing up in an alcoholic family has an impact on the social functioning of children that reaches into adulthood. This impact depends on the severity of parental alcoholism and other variables, for instance the personal characteristics of the child and factors concerning his family. Some children are resilient -- they don't succumb to the negative influences and are able to cope with the stress. Certain features of the expected development sequence of the child become distorted as a result of living in an addicted-family environment. Children of alcoholics suffer physical, psychological, and emotional effects that impact on their educational experience. Some have serious health and safety hazards. Often they are the victims of physical, emotional and sexual neglect and abuse. They react to parental alcoholism with a flood of emotions, but are unable to identify and express them. Compulsive disorders, like eating disorders and alcohol and chemical abuse, are not uncommon. These children may suffer symptoms of PTSD. They assume several roles as ways of coping and employ different defense mechanisms in the interest of self-preservation. [Author Summary]

Values, Attitudes and Ideologies in Social Work Practice

Author: Botha, Narisscia J11 Dept Social Work U Stellenbosch, Cape Province Republic South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61588873?accountid=14667

Abstract: The purpose & objective of social work emanate from its value system. Professional values, however, do not exist separately from societal values. Social workers should be sufficiently flexible to accomodate differing value positions on most moral & political issues, while they also assert themselves as individuals of a professional organization. In case of differing opinions, social workers should accord their colleagues who hold such opinions the same respect, dignity, & right to self-determination that they would accord clients. Explored here is how the daily practice of social work is influenced by the social worker's values, beliefs, & ideologies, arguing the importance of social workers being aware of their own values, how these values fit with values of the profession, & the impact these phenomena may have on the client, whose values may differ from those of the social practitioner, & whose behavior may offend the latter. 6 References. Modified AA

Information Privacy Rights in a Social Work Environment

Author: Sing, D11 Dept Public Administration U Durban-Westville, 4000 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61621500?accountid=14667

Abstract: The nature & characteristics of information privacy rights & their relevance for South Africa are examined. The desire for privacy is a basic human need that takes three forms: territorial privacy, privacy of the person, & information privacy. In the present age of increasing computerization of personal information, concerns over abuses of information privacy are particularly appropriate & relevant to the field of social work. Social work privacy concerns include use of information consistent with purpose for collection, individual consent of information disclosure, & verification of information accuracy. At present South Africa offers only limited protection of personal information. General information protection privacy based on internationally accepted information privacy principles is needed. 16 References. D. Generoli

Brief Dynamic Psychotherapy: An Exploration of Attitudes and Practice among a Group of Clinicians in Cape Town, South Africa -- Some Implications for Training

Author: Becker, Lily1; Isaacs, Gordon1 School Social Work U Cape Town, Rosebank 7700 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61630558?accountid=14667

Abstract: Clinicians' practice & attitudes toward brief dynamic psychotherapy were examined through a survey of 32 practicing therapists from various disciplines. Of respondents (Rs), 48% practiced brief dynamic therapy, though only 41% were trained in the method, & only 20% viewed themselves as skilled in brief dynamic therapy. Of Rs who perceived themselves as unskilled in the therapy, 50% had been practicing psychotherapy for 5 years or less. Over 66% of Rs valued a focused, high therapist activity, & use of contracts & goal setting. An even higher % believed in its curative potential. Those using brief dynamic therapy were more likely than those not using it to view the therapy as its own treatment method & not an abbreviated form of long-term therapy. Most therapists saw brief dynamic therapy as suitable for patients with good ego strength, but not for patients with more severe psychopathology. Over 75% saw brief dynamic therapy as viable for South African society. 4 Figures, 39 References. D. Generoli

Community-School Relations: A Model for Application by Community Social Workers for Preparing People for Participation in South Africa

Author: Gathiram, N11 Dept Social Work U Durban-Westville, Private Bag X54001 4000 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61621902?accountid=14667

Abstract: With the dismantling of the statutory discrimination laws of apartheid, the majority of South African citizens are unprepared for coping with their newly acquired democratic rights. This adjustment is unlikely to be an easy one because of the history of oppressive laws. The community education model is based on participatory democracy & is a self-help approach to community development. The role of the school is seen as pivotal to society, as is the role of the community social worker in using the community education model to prepare people for participation, since schools are excellently placed to provide a social work base that can be used to reach out to the community. 12 References. Guidelines for Social Work Intervention in Families with a Cerebral-Palsied Child -- A Social Work Perspective

Author: Germishuys, J M; du Preez, M. S. E.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61591738?accountid=14667

Abstract: Data obtained through a literature study, & via observation, interviews, & questionnaires from physicians, social workers, & parents of cerebral-palsied children in South Africa show that such families are referred too late for social work assistance, & sometimes not at all. The definition, causes, symptoms & classifications of cerebral palsy, the emotional needs of cerebral-palsied children, & their treatment & prognosis are discussed, & the demands & strains that such children make on their families are noted. The need for social work intervention in the form of family therapy is noted. It is hypothesized that if parents with a cerebral-palsied child are referred for social work intervention directly after diagnosis, many problems will be avoided. 3 Tables, 4 Figures, 8 References. Modified AA

Title: Guidelines for Social Work Intervention in Families with a Cerebral-Palsied Child -- A Social Work Perspective

A Marriage Counseling Model for the Assessment of Marriages in Which Extramarital Affairs Occur

Author: Fourie, David P11 Dept Social Work U Stellenbosch, 7600 Republic South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61634695?accountid=14667

Abstract: To develop an integrated model for counseling partners of a marriage in which extramarital affairs occur, concepts of systems theory & the cognitive-behavioral approach were synthesized. The model's premise is that various components of the family as a system, as well as the nonparticipating spouse's perceptions about the extramarital affair, contribute to the problem & must be restructured. Focus here is on the assessment phase, offering guidelines for assessing the different dimensions of the system. The model was developed & tested with a random sample of 83 cases in South Africa. Results show that many of the contributory causes to extramarital affairs lie within the system's structure & functioning. Further, the nonparticipating spouse's perceptions of the affair may cause a stumbling block in treatment of the problem; thus, specific cognitive perceptions must be identified & restructured. 1 Table, 1 Figure, 28 References. Modified AA

Selected Aspects of Field Instruction in South African Undergraduate Social Work Programmes

Author: Hoffmann, Wilma11 School Social Work U Witwatersrand, Johannesburg 2050 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61617407?accountid=14667

Abstract: Discusses social work educational programs in South Africa, where society is in a critical stage of transformation. Focus is on the curricular design & development of the field instruction component of social work education. The field instruction course is perceived as constituting three course sequences, namely campus-based laboratory work, structured community experience, & actual field practice. Social work departments of 20 of South Africa's 21 universities participated in a survey of current programs. Findings show that the principles & procedures of curriculum design & development have not been utilized at all the universities, which detracts not only from the status afforded the field instruction component, but also from its goal-directedness. It is recommended that ongoing evaluation remain a feature of the instruction course design & development. 5 References. Modified AA

Programme Evaluation: A Case Study of the Leadership Institute

Author: Triegaardt, J D11 School Social Work U Witwatersrand, Johannesburg 2050 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61591667?accountid=14667

Abstract: Reports an evaluation study of a nongovernmental organization, the Leadership Instit in Johannesburg, South Africa, which provides services & training to community development practitioners in community-based organizations & grass-roots projects. The objective of training is to promote the development of competent community development practitioners, improve the efficacy of organizational management, & facilitate change & meaningful socioeconomic improvement. Both interviews (N = 8) & participant observation of the training programs were utilized, & data collected from a creche, trade union, remedial school, job creation program, children's home, & a community project were analyzed to ascertain the impact of training modules. Findings suggest that the training modules were relevant & appropriate. Both empowerment of participants & reciprocal accountability were achieved by the Leadership Instit. 1 Table, 15 References. Primary Social Care: Re-Shaping Policy and Practice

Author: van Wyk, W. P. J.11 House Assembly, Pretoria South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61625178?accountid=14667

Abstract: The need to realign South Africa's social welfare policies & practices is discussed. Since the establishment of its first Dept of Social Welfare in 1937, South Africa has experienced tremendous social change. These societal changes force reevaluation of value bases, present & future needs, & criteria for allocation of resources. Principles for establishment of such criteria include: (1) all human beings must be treated fairly & equally; (2) fairness of justice requires equal distribution of resources; & (3) available resources must be used first & foremost to ensure that people's basic needs are met. It is concluded that primary social care must involve the community at the grass-roots level. Primary social care needs to return to the community. D. Generoli

Process and Pre-Requisites Necessary for the Successful Implementation and Management of Community Development Projects

Author: Louw, Lionel R11 School Social Work U Cape Town, Rosebank 7700 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61632288?accountid=14667

Abstract: Community development criteria are reviewed, with an application to South Africa, & it is noted that community development articulates a holistic approach to environmentalism, focusing on people & process. Prerequisites for community development include the establishment of an interim government in South Africa, overall review of social welfare policy, democratized decision making, proceduralized accountability, education & training commitments, & development of nongovernmental organizations. Critical periodic assessment of community development projects must determine continued validity of the central organizing theme. 14 References. J. Sadler

Burnout among Social Workers: The Cost of Caring?

Author: van der Walt, G. E.11 Dept Social Work U South Africa, Pretoria 0001

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61646675?accountid=14667

Abstract: Explores causes, effects, & prevention of burnout in social workers, which is usually manifested in physical, emotional, & mental exhaustion, & changes in behavior. Social workers absorb emotional burdens of clients, & can experience burnout when needy clients cannot be helped. The accumulation of unmediated stress factors in the organizational environment, the individual personality, gender inequalities, & social, economic, & political factors also result in burnout. A 75-question burnout susceptibility test & effective burnout management techniques are offered, in addition to individual & multiprofessional team strategies for reversing burnout. 1 Table, 1 Figure, 21 References. J. Sadler

The Family as a Focus on Intervention for the Prevention of Mental Disorder: An Empowerment Approach

Author: Sewpaul, Vishanthie11 Dept Social Work U Natal, Durban 4001 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61636897?accountid=14667

Abstract: While the family is generally not the sole cause of mental illness in one of its members, nor is it a panacea for preventing such illness, it can serve as a focus of intervention for preventing or reversing the development of a mental disorder. The family unit can further the mental health of all its members through mutual reassurance, comfort, encouragement, & support. To fulfill this role, however, the family often needs to be empowered & strengthened by social workers & psychologists providing mental health services, How this can be done is described in the case of families in South Africa, first contextualizing the concepts of family, health, & empowerment & then focusing on the family developmental life cycle -- from marriage, through the various phases of raising children, to grandparenthood & old age -- & how support might be needed & provided during each phase. 42 References. J. W. Stanton

Several Legal Problems concerning Family Violence

Author: Jansen, M

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61622701?accountid=14667

Abstract: Domestic violence is not a well-defined legal concept under South African law. Rather, it is seen as a form of assault by one family member on another. Three main categories include common assault, assault with indecency, & assault leading to death of the victim or the assailant. Examples of these categories include baby battering, spousal rape, & murder of an abusive husband by a battered wife. Procedures governing each type of case are reviewed, & shortcomings in the legal structure are delineated. Suggestions are offered for breaking the cycle of family violence, emphasizing the positive contribution of the social worker. 27 References. Adapted from the source document.

Some Effects of Violence on Squatter Camp Families and Their Children

Author: McKendrick, B W1; Senoamadi, W1 School Social Work U Witwatersrand, Johannesburg 20509 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61601590?accountid=14667

Abstract: Reports a study of the impact on families & children of the violence bred in the crowded, poverty-stricken conditions of South African squatter camps & settlements, focusing on Phola Park in the Pretoria-Witwatersrand-Vereeniging region. Interviews were conducted in 1992 with 17 males & 2 females ages 21-40, representing 19 families with an average of 4 children. Most respondents reported feelings of fear, insecurity, & vulnerability with regard to loss of personal property & physical injury. The police were feared as much as fellow residents of different tribal backgrounds. During periods of extreme violence, children's lives were totally disrupted; schools were closed, & parents were too preoccupied with survival to provide physical attention & nurturing. Considering the fact that this situation is common to all such camps in South Africa, the number of people affected is in the hundreds of thousands. A plea is made for social work services to make squatter camps a primary target for intervention. 20 References. J. W. Stanton

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Some+Effects+of+Violence+on+Squatter+Camp+Families+and+Their+Children&amp;rft.au=McKendrick%2C+B+W%3BSenoamadi%2C+W&amp;rft.aulast=McKendrick&amp;rft.aufirst=B&amp;rft.date=1993-08-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=213&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378054&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Guidelines for AIDS-Related Social Work Education in South Africa

Author: Van Rooyen, Colin A. J.1; Sewpaul, Vishanthie1 c/o Sewpaul -- Dept Social Work U Natal, Durban 4001 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61644400?accountid=14667

Abstract: A set of guidelines is presented for social work education relating to the AIDS (acquired immune deficiency syndrome) epidemic as experienced in South Africa, based on a literature review & discussions with social work educators & postgraduate students as well as practitioners in the field. In addition to coursework covering the nature of the disease & how it is transmitted, myths & prejudices, & potential social responses, students should be given field placements in which they are faced with AIDS-related problems. Social work education institutions must develop more advanced courses dealing with the disease, & AIDS must be accepted as a challenge by the social work profession as a whole. A vignette is presented showing how a social worker could intervene in the case of a married couple exposed to AIDS through the bisexual husband's relationship with a man. 18 References. J. W. Stanton

Social Work and Genetics

Author: Maforah, N F

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61593691?accountid=14667

Abstract: The practice of genetic counseling has grown rapidly in the wake of major advances in scientific knowledge & technologies, but many substantive questions have been raised about the appropriate purposes of the technology & who should provide the counseling. Focus here is on the role of social work in this area, tracing it to two articles written in 1966 by A. L. Schultz & S. Schild, respectively, & reviewing these & other works written since. Although 42% of the social workers who responded (N not given) to a survey on the subject reported that they had participated in genetic counseling, there is general consensus that many practitioners are not adequately trained in this area. It is urged that schools of social work offer more extensive & advanced programs in genetic counseling, & that human genetics clinics be set up to provide in-service training for social workers already in practice. 22 References. J. W. Stanton

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Work+and+Genetics&amp;rft.au=Maforah%2C+N+F&amp;rft.aulast=Maforah&amp;rft.aufirst=N&amp;rft.date=1993-08-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=247&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378054&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The Social Functioning of Minor Children of Alcoholics: An Introductory Study

Author: Malherbe, B R

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61595900?accountid=14667

Abstract: Children of alcoholics are a primary focus in the contemporary study of chemical dependency. It is usually taken for granted that being reared in an alcoholic family has a negative impact on the social functioning of children, lasting long into adulthood. The overall effect depends on the extent of the parent's problem & other personal & family characteristics. Some children are surprisingly resilient, & emerge from the alcoholic home able to cope with the stress. In many cases, the expected development sequence becomes distorted for children of alcoholics. Such children experience physical, psychological, & emotional effects that impact school performance. Additionally, many are victims of abuse & neglect. Although they have a flood of emotions regarding their parent's alcoholism, they are unable to identify them clearly. Compulsive eating disorders & chemical abuse are common reactions. Many also suffer from posttraumatic stress disorder. As a means of self-preservation, many children assume special roles & adapt different defense mechanisms. 41 References. Adapted from the source document.

Marriage Counseling: A Theoretical Foundation

Author: Alpaslan, A H1; Du Preez, M. S. E.1 Dept Maatskaplike Werk U Port Elizabeth, 6000 Cape Province South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61603900?accountid=14667

Abstract: A model is proposed of a postmarital counseling program for newlyweds that would nurture growth & skill building, & enhance the development of the new couple's relationship. Preventative, proactive intervention against premature dissolution of marriage, as a complementary phase of premarital counseling, is a goal-oriented strategy crucial to postmarital counseling. Developed from empirical research, the model is theoretically grounded in the social work literature in marital & family counseling. 1 Table, 1 Figure, 36 References. Physically and Sexually Abused Children: A Comparative Analysis of 200 Reported Cases

Author: Collings, Steven J11 Dept Psychology U Natal, Durban 4001 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61611032?accountid=14667

Abstract: Compares child physical abuse (CPA) & child sexual abuse (CSA) in terms of victim demographics, characteristics of abuse, & family histories. From a review of case files on abuse referrals to Durban Child Welfare, South Africa (1985-1988), data on the sex, age, race, perpetrator, assault severity, family size, & ages of parents for equal numbers of sexually & physically abused children (N = 100 each, average age 8) were analyzed. Findings show that CSA victims were older & usually girls, while CPA victims were younger, more likely boys, & white. CPA was less severe & more likely perpetrated by a biological parent than was CSA. Further, smaller families with younger parents generated more cases of CPA than of CSA. These findings suggest likely profiles & patterns in child abuse. 1 Table, 15 References. J. Sadler

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61626118?accountid=14667

Abstract: A sketch of ethical guidelines for use by the social worker integrating the computer into a changing practice context, with a focus on issues of accountability, confidentiality, & autonomy vs paternalism. The Adult Child of the Alcoholic

Author: Malherbe, B R11 Dept Maatskaplike Werk Hugenote Koll, Wellington South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61626304?accountid=14667

Abstract: A review of the key personal & interpersonal relational traits of adult children of alcoholic parents (ACOAs), based on findings of research & clinical & personal practice. It is found that this group suffers with addictive behaviors & stress-related disorders of various kinds. ACOAs often exhibit emotional numbness & mental confusion. In interpersonal relationships, problems emerge with distrust, crisis orientation, codependency, & overcontrol. The spouse of an ACOA will be confronted with fears of both abandonment & intimacy, & poor definitions of boundaries. As parents, ACOAs create inappropriate boundaries for & make unrealistic demands of their children. They rarely experience success or satisfaction in their careers, elaborate spiritually distorted concepts of God, & are overly attached to parents & families. 33 References. Adapted from the source document.

Burnout among Social Workers: An Ecological Perspective

Author: Ross, E11 Dept Speech Pathology & Audiology U Witwatersrand, Johannesburg 2050 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61603827?accountid=14667

Abstract: In an ecological model, stress & burnout among social workers develop in a dynamic & complex context. A review of the literature shows that stressors perceived in the individual, in work with client systems, & in the workplace interact dynamically with pressures by elements of the exosystem (family, funding resources, & regulatory agencies) & the current state of the macrosystem (inflation, poverty, unemployment, racial conflicts, violence, etc). The social worker with a potential for burnout can alleviate stress proactively through accessing external resources, building coping skills, or acquiring experience. A balance of demands & resources of the environment favor the social worker's individual abilities & needs, while the social production of burnout, or ecological dysfunction, is likely to occur when the total environment is either too demanding or insufficient in resources. It is noted that, on an individual level, burnout can produce physical, psychological, intellectual, & spiritual effects; at the interpersonal & social levels, it can impact significant others, the work situation, & the larger sociocultural environment. 1 Figure, 45 References. J. Sadler

Consultation as an Alternative to Supervision

Author: Groenewald, H v H1; Van Staden, S M1 U Pretoria, Brooklyn 0002 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61609936?accountid=14667

Abstract: An exploration of substantive & structural features of a consultation with a social worker in which the consultant is newly promoted from a supervisory role. It is noted that, as different forms of practice, supervision & consultation have partially overlapping spheres of application, but different objectives. Consultation may be internally oriented in the social work agency, or provided by outside experts. Recognizing that the supervisor-worker relationship can become counterproductive & eventually hinder the worker's maturing processes, consultation represents the next step in the supervisor's professional career. The advancement of the supervisor to consultancy is marked by the attainment of certain objectives, criteria for which should be formally evaluated. Among the functions of consultation are: administrative, continual training, supportive, inspirational, & personal developmental. Findings of empirical studies are reviewed. 12 References. Adapted from the source document.

Management of Welfare Services in the Future

Author: Hall, N11 School Social Work, Zimbabwe

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61610998?accountid=14667

Abstract: An evaluation of the evolving role & duties of social welfare services in African nations, with implications for future service provision. It is noted that because welfare is centrally administered, isolated from community involvement, & subject to progressively fewer resource allocations, servicing the community is becoming increasingly difficult. In response to charges that the profession, bureaucratically preoccupied with meeting minimal legal requirements, has no community relevance, an expanded scope of social work perspectives integrates a substantial authoritative force in social development, where clients are networked with effective resource systems. To reverse the atypical defensive posture of institutionalized social work requires proactive agendas, best implemented by the agency's adoption of a progressive management style, & the development of consensual & committed participation. The advanced state of social work offered by nongovernmental organizations reflects on their flexible, responsive policies & their focus on the client's empowerment. 1 Table, 17 References. J. Sadler

Can Social Work Agencies Meet the Challenges in a Post-Apartheid South Africa? A Planner's Perspective

Author: Ramphal, R1; Moonilal, R1 Dept Social Work U Durban-Westville, Private Bag X54001 4000 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61609894?accountid=14667

Abstract: A 1993 study of the evolution in social work management & practice in the context of the challenges of the dismantlement of apartheid, as reported by social welfare agencies in Durban, South Africa, considered organizational structures, staffing procedures, & services provided. Interviews with administrators at the various uni- & multiracial agencies, both public & private, identified prospective trends in local & national social welfare & practice. Respondents agreed generally that a nonracial, democratic system constitutes the best direction for the government to lead the social welfare program, using citizen participation & client determination. Given citizens' increased demand for responsive public services, the desegregating government must confront accelerated population growth, bugetary constraints, modern social problems, & political instability. Findings indicate that the private sector has progressively implemented integrated multiracial services. It is contended that as human services managers, social workers should prioritize community development action & extend conventional casework to rural areas. 7 References. J. Sadler

Social Skills Training as a Sentencing Option for Juvenile Offenders: The Cape Peninsula Juvenile Sentencing Project

Author: Howes, M Frances11 Dept Maatskaplike Werk U Stellenbosch, Cape Province Republic South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61625557?accountid=14667

Abstract: A review of the development of alternative sentencing procedures for juvenile offenders in South Africa. After the UN's 1985 adoption of the Standard Minimum Rules for the Administration of Juvenile Justice, calling for processing young offenders through a legally sanctioned track, differing from criminal prosecution & prison sentences standard for adults, a 1991 interdisciplinary committee drafted a youth sentencing program adressing the young offender's social deficiencies, as uncovered through study of his or her profile. A social skills training program, informed by social work & criminological theory, set criteria for qualified staffing, program clarity & intensity, social skills objectives, & referral procedures. Its use in the juvenile courts as a conditional diversion strategy has resulted in standardization of referral procedures & legal briefs. After approval of the program by the committee, it was extended to other South African municipalities. 30 References. J. Sadler

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Skills+Training+as+a+Sentencing+Option+for+Juvenile+Offenders%3A+The+Cape+Peninsula+Juvenile+Sentencing+Project&amp;rft.au=Howes%2C+M+Frances&amp;rft.aulast=Howes&amp;rft.aufirst=M&amp;rft.date=1993-10-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=371&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378054&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The Social Work Manager as an Integral Factor in the Welfare Organization

Author: Cronje, J I11 Dept Maatskaplike Werk U Stellenbosch, Cape Province Republic South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61626263?accountid=14667

Abstract: The essential role of the social work manager in the welfare organization is explored. As a leader coordinating the efficient use of human resources & the work environment, the manager is responsible for implementing a specific philosophy of management within the organization. Manager-employee relations require proven skills in supervision, training, & team formation, built on a solid understanding of human behavior & a grasp of the secret of motivating others in the effective & voluntary performance of tasks. The manager should be competent in professional social work practices based on personal experiences to correct & direct employees in their client contacts. The best managers recognize that managerial & administrative functions demand adaptability to change, creativity & problem-solving capabilities, & an exemplary sense of ethical standards in the profession, all crucial elements for success in implementing welfare policies. 9 References. Adapted from the source document.

Planning for Social Welfare Services in South Africa: Organizational Perspectives

Author: Triegaardt, J D11 School Social Work U Witwatersrand, Johannesburg 2050 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61612923?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examines the planning of welfare services as it has emerged at an organizational level in South Africa, drawing on interview & scale data from 12 organization managers. Focus is on how managers acquired their planning expertise & the managerial styles that influenced planning. Findings suggest that the majority of respondents had learned managerial decision making on the job. In addition, the findings on planning models utilized by managers are discussed. It is concluded that any planning of welfare services in South Africa cannot overlook the perceptions of managers at an organizational level. 15 References. Modified AA

A Window on Welfare: Some Results from a Study of Government Welfare Departments

Author: Lund, Frances J11 Centre Social & Development Studies U Natal, Durban 4001 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61585322?accountid=14667

Abstract: Offers a comprehensive picture of South African state social security & welfare before the anticipated change in government. Under apartheid, welfare provision was fragmented into 17 racially separate departments, & interviews were conducted in 1991/92 with officials in these 17 & 2 coordinating departments. Findings demonstrate racial, spatial, & gender inequalities in the allocation of social work posts in government service. Paradoxically however, the controversial bantustan governments provided avenues for career mobility for black professional women. The procedures for subsidization of social workers in private welfare organizations are shown to be costly, ineffective, & biased toward articulate, organized white urban organizations. Views about whether health & welfare departments should be integrated was influenced more by professional welfare interests than by considerations of better services. A challenge for future planning & delivery will be the development of integrated & transparent information systems. 6 Tables, 1 Figure, 4 References. Modified AA

Exploring the Potential for Primary Level Services in the Occupational Setting: Future Considerations for Welfare Managers and Social Work Educators

Author: Du Plessis, A11 School Social Work U Witwatersrand, Johannesburg 2050 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61627258?accountid=14667

Abstract: Explores the disassociation between the worlds of work & social work by examining opportunities inherent in the placing of social work in work settings & then testing this against the reality of occupational social work practice in South Africa. Interviews with 70 social workers indicate that occupational social workers are stuck in tertiary level casework; this hampers efforts to humanize the workplace & to challenge organizational factors that hinder an ecological practice metaphor. Reasons for an overemphasis on casework as a service methodology in the South African workplace are offered. Considerations for social work educators & welfare managers are also outlined, intending to encourage social work at the workplace that moves away from tertiary level work to primary level services with an emphasis on preventive, promotive, & developmental programs. 6 References. Privatisation and Decentralisation of Welfare Services: South African Meanings and Realities

Author: Woods, Ronald K11 School Social Work U Witwatersrand, Johannesburg 2050 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61579674?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examines the use of the concepts "privatization" & "decentralization" in writings & discussions around welfare services. Interviews with 35 people involved in the welfare sector in Johannesburg are used to gauge their views regarding the social services in South Africa. Respondents were asked to provide definitions of privatization & decentralization, & to indicate their level of support for the application of these concepts to the South African situation. Results indicate: strong support among respondents for social services to be provided by agencies managed through elected committees, but with funding provided primarily by central & local government; not a great deal of support for privatization in the South African context; & much uncertainty regarding the concept of decentralization. Encouraged is a reconsideration among social policy decisionmakers of the meaning & value of privatization; support is given to a form of decentralization of welfare services that might be well-suited to the socioeconomic conditions in South Africa. In Response to Woods: On Belabouring the Obvious, W. A. Mitchell (Rhodes U, Grahamstown, South Africa) explains that, even though the South African government has accelerated, there is still a welfare crisis because private sector involvement in welfare services is extremely limited. Although South Africa is a welfare state, it is a Third World welfare state with inadequate services & funding, which partially explains why the respondents in Wood's study supported large-scale government intervention over privatization. 19 References. Modified AA

The Consequences of Urbanization and Westernization on Black Family Life in South Africa

Author: Bester, C W11 Dept Sociology Potchefstroom U Christian Higher Education, Transvaal South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61386743?accountid=14667

Abstract: An examination of the problematic impact of Westernization & urbanization on the familial situation of black South Africans, focusing on parent-child relationships. The majority of black South Africans have kept some of the cultural traditions of the rural lifestyle (eg, a self-supporting agro-economy & families governed by tribal customs). But a difficult adaptation to the Western education system & urban housing, along with a weakened communal structure & weakened social control mechanisms, have contributed to a decline in tightly knit family relations. 1 Table, 9 References. J. Sadler

Harmful Consequences of Sexual Abuse: Myth or Reality

Author: Cole, J1; Theron, A1 Dept Kriminologie U Pretoria, Brooklyn 0002 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61385947?accountid=14667

Abstract: Despite the lack of consensus among mental health professionals about the sequelae of childhood sexual abuse, data are presented here to document psychological disturbances & acting-out behaviors common to 80 victims in Witwatersrand, South Africa. Findings reveal sleeping disorders, sexual dysfunction, bodily complaints, feelings of guilt, fear, & poor self-image reported by 59 children, 57 of whom were subsequently involved in prostitution, substance abuse, suicidal tendencies, truancy, & disrespect for authority. 4 Tables, 25 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Effects of Maternal Employment on Mothers' Self-Esteem and Mother-Child Relationships in Low-Income Families

Author: Mahabeer, M11 Dept Psychology U Durban-Westville, Private Bag X54001 4000 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61406942?accountid=14667

Abstract: An exploration of how maternal employment affects both her self-esteem & the mother/child relationship, drawing on analysis of interview & questionnaire data from 203 low-income Indian working mothers in South Africa. It is found that, in contrast with nonworking housewives, working mothers show more positive attitudes in mother-child relationships. Not only do they favor the child's independence by curbing their own overprotective & overidulgent behaviors, but they generally have higher levels of self-esteem than their nonworking counterparts. 1 Table, 28 References. J. Sadler

Assault and Injury of the Aged: Implications for Health in Later Life

Author: Pretorius, R11 Dept Criminology U Pretoria, Brooklyn 0002 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61599411?accountid=14667

Abstract: In-depth interviews with 34 elderly victims of burglaries, 1991-1993, in Pretoria, South Africa, reveal that, besides the trauma of physical injury, almost 71% suffered posttraumatic stress syndrome. Recommendations for treating elderly violent crime victims are offered. 1 Table, 6 References. J. Sadler

Experiencing Infertility

Author: Ziehl, S C11 Dept Sociology Rhodes U, Grahamstown South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61363093?accountid=14667

Abstract: After examining the estimated incidence & etiology of infertility, based on in-depth interviews with 3 South African physicians specializing in infertility treatment, its impact on the couple relationship is explored, drawing on interviews with women patients at an infertility clinic. A case study of one couple's infertility experiences is presented, outlining the time factor involved, inconveniences, the costs, social support, & different rates of success for various treatment methods. Since successful impregnation depends on many factors unrelated to medical technology, a more holistic approach is called for. 25 References. J. Sadler

Informal Social Supports and Formal Provision of Social Services

Author: Osei-Hwedie, K11 Dept Social Work U Botswana, Gaborone

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61623452?accountid=14667

Abstract: An evaluation of the use of informal systems of social support in public social welfare policy focuses on conceptual problems involved with exclusively informal-based social services. While it is recognized that social support is essential to coping with stresses of everyday life, the shift of public sector social services to informal systems does not address the structural & contextual difficulties of social support systems. To overcome deficiencies in the effectiveness & comprehensiveness of informal systems as well as inadequacies in formal systems, a dynamic, interactive program is proposed that integrates both systems for social welfare provision. 24 References. J. Sadler

Humanising the Accused: The Social Worker's Contribution in Mitigation of Sentence

Author: Sacco, T M11 School Social Work U Witwatersrand, Johannesburg 2050 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61571567?accountid=14667

Abstract: An exploration of the humanizing role of the social worker in providing expert testimony in the form of background social information, individual traits, & unique life experiences about the accused in criminal trials in South Africa. It is argued that active participation of the social worker in this role may help the court make a more informed decision when sentencing. The profession implements humanist values within an ecological theoretical orientation, which concerns the impact of individual human actions on the family, the community, & the environment. Since the social reality of the judge & prosecuting attorneys are typically quite different from those of the average accused, the social worker can suggest an alternative, socially contextualized interpretation. 38 References. J. Sadler

Integrated Practice: A Misnomer in Social Work

Author: Gray, M M A1; Bernstein, A J1 Dept Social Work U Natal, Durban 4001 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61405292?accountid=14667

Abstract: To explain the ideal relationship between theory & practice, the notion of an integrated approach is often heralded as an organizing principle in social work. For the most part, social workers also say they favor such a knowledge-guided paradigm, which prioritizes the development & application of empirically grounded theory. In practice, however, few social workers have time to keep up with the literature due to their heavy daily workloads. After briefly reviewing the existing social work theory & examining the feasibility of the integrated approach, an alternative is offered: practice-guided theory, which recognizes the contributions of practical experience & encourages practitioners to write for professional journals. 60 References. M. Maguire

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocabsshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Integrated+Practice%3A+A+Misnomer+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.au=Gray%2C+M+M+A%3BBernstein%2C+A+J&amp;rft.aulast=Gray&amp;rft.aufirst=M+M&amp;rft.date=1994-08-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=199&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378054&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The Use of Employee Assistance Programs for Social Workers in Handling Alcoholism

Author: Strydom, A M M1; Botha, D1 Dept Maatskaplikewerk U Oranje-Vrystaat, Bloemfontein South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61614813?accountid=14667

Abstract: In South Africa, principles underlying employee assistance programs (EAPs) for alcoholism include: (1) the acceptance of alcoholism as an illness & individual attention for each case; (2) the involvement of a supervisor in early recognition of the problem; (3) the expectation of possible recurrence of drinking during rehabilitation; & (4) the use of constructive coercion -- a firm prohibition policy placing job security in jeopardy & motivating the employee to do something about the problem while offering a means of assistance. Steps in the operation of all EAPs consist of recognition or identification, rehabilitation or treatment, & disposition of relapses. 2 Tables, 4 Diagrams, 31 References. Adapted from the source document.

Social Welfare Policy Formulation at Macro- and Microlevels in a Fast Changing South Africa

Author: Weekes, M S11 Dept Social Work U Stellenbosch, Cape Province Republic South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61577042?accountid=14667

Abstract: Discusses social policy & issues of importance in the reform of the South African welfare system, including the choice of a policy & planning model, & problems in the processes of planning & policy formation. Values affecting social welfare policy in the new South Africa are based on equity & needs-based approaches, with objectives being a reduction in absolute poverty & increases in services to promote economic growth. Although the assumption of welfare services by the state is seen as a necessity, privatization can occur given certain conditions. The choice of a rational planning model involves problem analysis, goal formation, needs assessment, community participation, & above all, flexibility. Welfare policy formation must not depend on one ideology but incorporate different ideological positions, eg, residual & institutional models. 29 References. A. Cole

Management of Change: A Social Work Perspective

Author: Cronje, Johan I11 Dept Social Work U Stellenbosch, Cape Province Republic South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61605351?accountid=14667

Abstract: Discusses the management of social & organizational changes in social welfare institutions in South Africa, focusing on the impact of political forces, declining resources, special population needs, the changing nature of the workforce, accountability to the public, & the expansion of knowledge. To respond to such changes, welfare organizations must focus on the nature of change, planned changes in organizations, & resistance to change. To assist managers in the process of change, an education program should develop knowledge, skill, & a value system, & have a leadership development component. Theoretical knowledge & a positive attitude should aid the management of change in the new South Africa. 2 Figures, 20 References. A. Cole

Social Auxiliary Work

Author: Lombard, J; Pruis, S E

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61622925?accountid=14667

Abstract: Discusses social auxiliary work as a supplement to social work in South Africa. The Social & Associated Workers Act of 1978 made a provision for auxiliary workers to complement the activities of social workers by carrying out some of their routine, nonprofessional tasks. Auxiliary workers work under the guidance & control of a social worker &, to a certain degree, assume the same roles as social workers by promoting the well-being of clients. Auxiliary workers are registered with the South African Council for Social Work to protect the interests of the profession by instituting standards in education & training. 1 Figure, 23 References. A. Cole

The Balance-Sheet Method as a Technique for Social Work Counselling

Author: Collins, K1; Keel, U1 Dept Social Work U South Africa, Pretoria 0001

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61622883?accountid=14667

Abstract: Describes the balance sheet method as an aid to decision making for clients in the casework process. The balance sheet is a best-fit strategy for achieving goals by allowing clients to examine the consequences of different actions in terms of utility & acceptability. Four main categories of the balance sheet include: utilitarian gains & losses for self; gains & losses for significant others; self-approval or disapproval, & approval or disapproval of significant others. The use of the balance sheet as tested by counselors & 10 of their clients shows that it can be helpful to clients. Training in the use of balance sheets should be provided to counselors in the context of an overall eclectic approach to casework. 3 Tables, 3 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Developmental Research Model Proposed by Thomas -- Some Thoughts on Its Use in Social Work Research

Author: Van Rooyen, C. A. J.11 Dept Social Work U Natal, Durban 4001 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61405344?accountid=14667

Abstract: While E. J. Thomas's developmental research model (1985, 1987) is only one of the many models social workers use to guide their research activities, it has become increasingly popular as a guiding framework for academic research on social work in South African universities. As such, the central principles of Thomas's model are reviewed, & various issues related to its current application are examined, including the compartmentalization of the phases, models, & submodels into discrete research entities & the misalignment of the model with research that appears to be less positivistic. Thus, despite the model's obvious suitability to social work research, it is open to misinterpretation & incorrect application, which in turn can jeopardize particular research endeavors. 2 Tables, 16 References. M. Maguire

Implementing an Ecological Perspective in School Social Work Practice

Author: Kasiram, M I11 Dept Social Work U Durban-Westville, Private Bag X54001 4000 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61614781?accountid=14667

Abstract: An ecological perspective used to build partnerships among subsystems in order to prevent & solve problems in social work is ideally practiced in a school setting. Ecological perspectives take into account the complexity of the environment through the use of several theoretical approaches. The coexistence of schools & social agencies provides for the opportunity to effect change through social workers aware of problems in the community. Substance abuse is used as an example to illustrate the ecological paradigm, with a project involving awareness & education of substance abuse & the empowerment of students, schools, & the community to deal with this problem. Multiple interventions at the level of student, family, school, & community are combined in an ecological approach. 9 References. A. Cole

Community Intervention in a Society in Transition: Social Action

Author: Louw, L R11 School Social Work U Cape Town, Rosebank (Rondebosch) 7700 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61605310?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social action in the transition of South African society is discussed in the context of community social work intervention. Social action that promotes nonviolent confrontation fits within the parameters of social work given its basis of intervention. Strategies of intervention are based on the circumstances of the situation, with social action dependent on organization & mass mobilization to come to a different relationship with the enemy. South Africa experiences such mass mobilization & organization through student groups, nongovernmental organizations, & many grass-roots initiatives. International mobilization also follows patterns of social action. National elections held in Apr 1994 exemplify the social action initiatives of the resistance movement to apartheid, with the current challenge being the promotion of justice, gender equity, & democracy, & the elimination of racism. 4 References. A. Cole
