The Transition to Practice: How Employable Are New Social Work Graduates?

Author: McKendrick, B W11 School Social Work U Witwatersrand, Johannesburg 2050 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61622472?accountid=14667

Abstract: Past research indicates a gap in preparation of students for the social work profession. The transition from student to social worker is discussed, & difficulties in the assumption of a work role, the quality of preparation for practice, & the transition to an urban setting from the rural setting of many South African universities are considered. Questionnaires completed by 34 employers of social welfare organizations in Witwatersrand indicate that they value personal maturity & serious approaches. Because graduates were seen as being only partially equipped to practice social work, employers desired more practice experience & skills in students' education. An absence of systematic inservice training, & lack of practice skills in field instruction must be remedied. To offer better preparation for social work, new higher education policies should allow for equivalent & increased funding at all universities. 12 References. A. Cole

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+Transition+to+Practice%3A+How+Employable+Are+New+Social+Work+Graduates%3F&amp;rft.au=McKendrick%2C+B+W&amp;rft.aulast=McKendrick&amp;rft.aufirst=B&amp;rft.date=1994-10-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=310&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378054&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Social Service Agencies for the Elderly: Some Problems Concerning Present Approaches

Author: Pretorius, J C11 Depte Sosiologie U Suid-Afrika, Pretoria 0001

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61390075?accountid=14667

Abstract: In the search for a long-term solution to the problems of care for the chronically ill & disabled elderly in South Africa, in-depth interviews were conducted with members of a home care team with a multidisciplinary organizational structure. Analysis reveals that: respondents representing different health care professions rarely consult one another when assessing a patient; integrated treatment programs for patients with multifaceted problems are seldom developed; team members are often ill-informed about the potential contributions of each member's discipline in developing a comprehensive treatment program; & organizational structures are not easily changed once they have been established. Professional health care workers suggested that the services of lay volunteers could be extended to include more specialized tasks in in-service training programs. The development of interdisciplinary team structures at the inception of home care services to enable members of different disciplines to collaborate in the development of coordinated & comprehensive treatment programs is recommended. 11 References. Adapted from the source document.

Welfare State Principles for the Reconstruction of South Africa's Welfare Policy

Author: Luiz, J M11 Dept Economics Vista U Welkom Campus, Pretoria 0001

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61623015?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examines the welfare state as a possible option for South Africa. The current crisis in the welfare state is defined as one of cost, effectiveness, & legitimacy. Because of its mixed record, it may offer South Africa a basis on which to plan its own welfare system. The inclusion of welfare state philosophy into the residual welfare policy of South Africa is described, & various alternatives available for reconstructing the welfare system are considered, including both leftist & rightist views. It is concluded that, although South Africa can learn from the welfare state, it is not an affordable option. 1 Table, 19 References. Adapted from the source document.

Making Social Work Curricula Relevant for a Post-Apartheid South Africa

Author: Ramphal, R11 Dept Social Work U Durham-Westville, Private Bag X54001 4000 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61592918?accountid=14667

Abstract: Describes how social work has been affected by the sociopolitical changes in South Africa, & discusses implications for social work education. The Western model of social work education has been the basis for South Africa, but does not take into account South Africa's unique socioeconomic realities or social policy, planning, social action, & community development needs. Social work training must include the understanding & appreciation of cultural & social diversity, tolerance in community development projects, & adaptation to changing social conditions. 19 References. A. Cole

The Position of Black Women in South African Society: A Feminist Perspective

Author: Sewpaul, V11 Dept Social Work U Natal, Durban 4001 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61379759?accountid=14667

Abstract: Assesses the impact of the double standard in South African society in terms of the social position of black women. First, the relationship between personal & political attitudes is examined, finding that women need to become better informed about the oppressive forces that govern their lives. Second, the process of political & economic development in peace initiatives is reviewed, demonstrating that women need to be more fairly represented in the country's macrosocial institutions. Finally, the need for a charter on women's rights is addressed, noting that black South African women must be allowed to directly participate in this process. 21 References. M. Maguire

An Investigation of Factors Influencing Stress and Burn-Out among Child Care Workers in a Children's Home

Author: Veeran, D L1; Moodley, G1 Dept Social Work U Natal, Durban 4001 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61592863?accountid=14667

Abstract: Questionnaire data are drawn on to explore the incidence of stress & burn-out among 13 female child care workers at a children's home in Durban, South Africa. Analysis indicates that several organizational & job-related factors contribute to stress, including: unclear job descriptions, training, & supervision; poor relationships between workers & their peers; lack of recognition; & decision-making structures. Organizational responsibility for addressing stress & burnout is discussed, & several recommendations for worker education & group treatment are reviewed. 2 Tables, 18 References. K. Stewart

School Social Work in South Africa: Ensuring Its Relevancy and Survival

Author: Kasiram, M11 Dept Social Work U Durban-Westville, Private Bag X54001 4000 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61614368?accountid=14667

Abstract: The nature & extent of problems in school social work in South Africa are studied in an effort to develop an all-encompassing practice model. Empirical data obtained from representatives of 25 policy making bodies & training institutions, along with 253 educationists & school social workers from the Houses of Delegates, Assembly, & Representatives, are used to analyze extant policies & recommend changes for the future. Focus is on the need for policies & practice to encompass all provinces & racial groups. Adapted from the source document.

Sociocultural Factors and Their Importance in Working with People with AIDS in South Africa

Author: Bernstein, A J1; Van Rooyen, C. A. J.1 c/o Van Rooyen -- Dept Social Work U Natal, Durban 4001 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61622975?accountid=14667

Abstract: An analysis of factors that affect a response to the AIDS (acquired immune deficiency syndrome) epidemic in South Africa. It is argued that the political situation in South Africa has played a role in the spread of AIDS because of the government's lack of commitment to primary health care. Culture also plays a role in understanding the response to AIDS, eg: traditional African society does not openly discuss sex; disease is considered an external entity with no relation to physical contact; sometimes sorcery is considered a cause of AIDS & traditional healers consulted for treatment; & there is a low use of condoms in general. The existence of many languages & cultures within South Africa mandates cultural understanding on the part of social workers to treat & manage AIDS. 43 References. A. Cole

Perception of Family Relationships in Sexually Abused Children

Author: Magwaza, A S11 U Durban-Westville, 4000 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61374781?accountid=14667

Abstract: A child's perception of sexual abuse is influenced by developmental needs for dependency, nurturing, & protection as well as by cognitive abilities, environmental stressors, trauma, & other experiences. Within the black culture in South Africa, the extended family often creates an idiosyncratic system of family & power relations that can influence a child's perceptions of sexual abuse. Thus it is vital that South African helping professionals gain more insight into children's perceptions of familial interpersonal-emotional relationships. Using E. Berne & J. Antony's Family Relations Test (1978), the ways in which family relationships are perceived by abused children (N = 35) & a control group (N = 27) are therefore examined. 4 Tables, 2 Figures, 7 References. M. Maguire

Problems in South African Social Work Practice and Training: Is Sociotheatre a Partial Solution?

Author: Van Huyssteen, M B11 Dept Social Work U Western Cape, Bellville 7535 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61619366?accountid=14667

Abstract: Contends that social work education in South Africa could be enhanced by sociotheater, which has relevant characteristics & objectives. It is suggested that sociotheater would offer an opportunity to address indigenous approaches to: development, promotion of social awareness, prevention of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, cessation of violence, advancement of gender & cultural sensitivity, integration of a service approach, welfare democratization, & changes in teaching & learning. 29 References. Adapted from the source document.

Ethical Aspects of Social Work Practice

Author: Strydom, Herman11 Dept Maatskaplike Werk Potchefstroomse U Christelike Hoer Onderwys, Transvaal Republic South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61602004?accountid=14667

Abstract: Ethical quandaries of social work, particularly in research, are examined as significant elements in theory & practice. A social work researcher's responsibility is analyzed in terms of participant harm, informed consent, description of participants, privacy invasion, researcher capabilities, co-researcher cooperation, result publication, & participant debriefing. 35 References. Adapted from the source document.

Putting Quality Back into Social Work Research

Author: Gray, M11 Dept Social Work U Natal, Durban 4001 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61571031?accountid=14667

Abstract: A qualitative study of social work research's ethical & political issues approaches social work values in a nonpolarized manner for application in South Africa. Asserted is the need for a moral & political framework & the appropriate selection of a paradigm for study. The deficiencies of the empirical approach are discussed, & it is suggested that the qualitative method be employed to avoid neglecting the value of intuitive facts. Social workers are encouraged to consider the relationship between social work, ethics, & politics. 46 References. Adapted from the source document.

Author: Kasira, M I11 Dept Social Work U Durban-Westville, Private Bag X54001 4000 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61570969?accountid=14667

Abstract: An ecological model for school social work practice in South Africa was developed & tested with 5 social work students in their final year who had participated in the model's evaluative phase. Social Workers in Politically Volatile Areas in South Africa: Lessons for Social Work Education, Training and Practice

Author: Letsebe, M A11 School Social Work U Witwatersrand, Johannesburg 2050 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61571414?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examines the difficulties faced by social workers practicing in the politically volatile context of South Africa. Data obtained from the South African Black Social Workers' Assoc provided information on the reasons why social workers came in contact with violence, how situations were managed, & which support systems were needed & utilized. Individual & small group interviews were conducted with a sample of social workers (N = 30) living in Soweto, Sebokeng, Katorus, the Natal Midlands, & Umlazi. Respondents indicated significant areas of concentration for social work to be political education & analysis, crisis intervention training, group work, multidisciplinary team work, willingness to learn from others, stress management, & training workers at the community level. 14 References. S. Jameson

Violence and Peace: The Social Worker's Brief

Author: Sacco, T M11 School Social Work U Witwatersrand, Johannesburg 2050 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61599146?accountid=14667

Abstract: Offers recommendations for social workers striving for peace in South Africa. The moral imperative for peace building is described by the major elements in social work of the ethic of indignation, human understanding, compassion, & the quest for social justice. The impact of violence is examined, & coping strategies are suggested, eg, uses of internal mechanisms in developing strength, & the importance of identifying connectedness with others. Practical steps to decrease violence are discussed at the personal/professional, cultural/community, & social levels. 22 References. S. Jameson

The Contents of a Course in Multicultural Social Work

Author: Strydom, Herman11 Dept Maatskaplike Werk Potchefstroomse U Christelike Hoer Onderwys, Transvaal Republic South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61590205?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examines a South African curriculum aimed at creating ethnically competent social workers for a multicultural environment. A course in multicultural social work is described in terms of objectives & possible content, with an example given of a course in the Social Work Dept at the Potchefstroom U for Christian Higher Education. Based on the need for indigenous presence & authentication of the curriculum, the course focuses on socioeconomic problems & welfare structure & policies. Recommendations for student training in multicultural social work are presented. 23 References. Adapted from the source document.

Guidelines for Computer Use in Social Work Program Management

Author: Van der Watt, M. F.1; Cronje, J I1 c/o Cronje -- Dept Maatskaplike Werk U Stellenbosch, 7599 Republic South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61571369?accountid=14667

Abstract: Evaluates improvements to service management efficiency made possible by computer utilization in welfare agencies. Guidelines are suggested for the implementation of computer technology in management programs. Short- & long-term planning must be undertaken by social work managers, & tasks must be performed concerning utilization of personal computers, network implementation, systems operation, & database management. Programs may be used by social workers for planning, organizing, activating, controlling, communicating, decision making, & coordinating. Determination of appropriate programs must follow an assessment of user needs, chosen functions, & financial & personal implications. 38 References. Adapted from the source document.

Education Support Services: A Proposed Model for School Social Work

Author: Kotze, F G11 Dept Social Work U Western Cape, Bellville 7535 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61598625?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examines the potential & functions of school social work in South Africa. A case study is presented of a pilot project by the U of the Western Cape, the Urban Foundation, & the former Dept of Internal Affairs. Four practice models -- the traditional clinical model, school change model, community school model, & mediating problem model -- are described by their goals, client system type, perceptions of problem behavior causes, strategies, & methods. It is asserted that schools & social workers must focus on work with individual pupils, contact with families, liaison with teaching staff, liaison with community, group work, & research. An interdisciplinary approach based on these recommendations is suggested for application in South Africa. 6 References. S. Jameson

The Dynamics of the Inter-Disciplinary Team Approach

Author: Botha, N J11 Dept Social Work U Stellenbosch, Cape Providence Republic South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61406440?accountid=14667

Abstract: Advocates an interdisciplinary team approach to comprehensive & coordinated delivery of social services. Definitions & advantages of an interdisciplinary team, team principles, member criteria, & tasks for successful teamwork are presented. An Ecosystemic Perspective

Author: Malherbe, B R

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61567009?accountid=14667

Abstract: This literature review discusses the impact of an individual alcoholic family member on the structure & functioning of the family & its total ecosystem. Family systems are described & classified as functional, dysfunctional, codependent, neurotically enmeshed, or disintegrated. When alcoholism becomes the organized principle of family functioning, the impact on family identity, temperament rules, daily routines, boundaries, rituals, & short-term problem-solving skills is substantial. Social workers are urged to recognize & consider the impact of an alcoholic member on the entire family system. 30 References. Adapted from the source document.

Are Old Age Pensions for Urban Africans Family Allowances? Implications for the Reconstruction and Development Programme

Author: McKendrick, B W1; Shingwenyana, B Z1 School Social Work U Witwatersrand, Johannesburg 2050 Republic South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61563480?accountid=14667

Abstract: The uses of old age pensions in urban South Africa are examined to determine who benefits from the pensions. Survey data from 50 African women old-age pensioners in Soweto are drawn on to describe their living accommodations, household composition & operation, pension expenditure, & beneficiaries. Findings show that in urban areas, as in earlier studies of rural areas, money paid to an elderly person is considered a household asset & benefits an entire family, especially in typical 3-generation families. Further, pensions enable the elderly to remain in the community instead of having to be relocated to more expensive institutional care settings. It is concluded that pensioners are the conduit for transferring money from the state to at-risk families. The present system of old age pensions is recommended as a critical component of the social welfare system & the south African reconstruction & development initiative. 1 Figure, 17 References. M. Payment

From Cause to Function and Back to Cause in Social Work

Author: Bar-On, A11 Dept Social Work U Botswana, Gaborone

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61409005?accountid=14667

Abstract: Traces the history of social work by examining dependency theory & the personal expediencies of its practitioners. It is argued that mainstream social work has historically favored function over cause, where the latter refers to the combating of social ills. As the domain of social work continues to shift in changing times, reasons why social reform is expected to remain a marginal social work activity in spite of being the primary rationale for the existence of the profession are examined. The psychiatric worldview is contrasted with the environmental worldview, & three models of social work practice are discussed: psychodynamic, eclectic, & the social problems model. 58 References. M. Empirically Based Micro Practice

Author: Green, S11 Dept Social Work U Stellenbosch, Cape Providence Republic South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61411926?accountid=14667

Abstract: South Africa's Reconstruction & Development Programme (1994) is discussed as needing a new type of helping professional to improve the quality of life for all, especially poor & marginalized citizens. Social work practitioners are described as limiting their success because of their inability to apply research technology in the social work process. Single-subject research designs are examined as the best means for linking the research & practice of social work. The challenges of measuring client/system problems & types of measurement tools are discussed. It is concluded that the empirically based model provides the most effective social service practice orientation for the future. 24 References. M. Payment

Psychosocial Considerations in Infertility and the New Reproductive Technologies (NRTS)

Author: Sewpaul, V11 Dept Social Work U Natal, Durban 4001 Republic South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61411661?accountid=14667

Abstract: Based on literature review & data from in-depth interviews with 15 infertile couples, explored is the impact of infertility on individuals, couples, & families. Crises, loss, & bereavement issues are examined, along with adoption & other options. Ethical considerations & the extent society creates the market for new reproductive technologies are considered. How the array of new technologies for infertility may actually decrease women's choices is described. It is concluded that the meanings of reproduction, infertility, & parenthood are socially constructed, & social workers are urged to be aware of societal conditioning processes that impact people whose lives are touched by infertility. 39 References. M. Payment

Burnout: A Smouldering Problem among South African Social Workers?

Author: Ross, E1; Fridjhon, P1 Dept Speech Pathology & Audiology U Witwatersrand, Johannesburg 2050 Republic South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61593339?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examines the incidence of burnout among South African social workers as the country has shifted from an apartheid-dominated society to a nonracial democracy. Cross-sectional survey data from a national random probability sample of 1,200 registered social workers are drawn on to examine their demographic profile, length of work experience, field of service, employing authority, personality, work relationships, family support, coping resources, & work stressors. Moderate levels of emotional exhaustion, low levels of depersonalization, & high levels of personal accomplishment were found. Central hypotheses were confirmed: (1) a relationship exists between work stressors & burnout, & (2) this relationship is mediated by a host of societal, personal, & occupational variables. Results are used to formulate an ecological model of stress & burnout. 5 Tables, 26 References. M. Payment

The Importance of Setting Objectives in Practical Fieldwork Training

Author: Mupedizswa, Rodreck11 School Social Work U Zimbabwe, Mount Pleasant Harare

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61582216?accountid=14667

Abstract: Calls for carefully defined fieldwork training experiences for social work students. Fieldwork in both rural & urban environments is advocated so that students have experiences with a variety of social problems in real-life settings. The necessity for clearly defined objectives is urged. Factors to consider when setting objectives are outlined: level of student, duration of placement, relevance to social work, availability of resources, realism, practicality agency capabilities, validity of objectives, & modifications. It is concluded that conceptual & technical objectives in a learning contract, developed & agreed to by everyone involved, benefits the school, the student, & the agency. 6 References. M. Payment

The Helping Professions and HIV-Infected People

Author: Fouche, C B1; De Vos, A S1 Dept Maatskaplike Werk Randse Afrikaanse U, Auckland Park 2006 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61621487?accountid=14667

Abstract: Pressure is mounting on members of the helping professions to disseminate information on acquired immune deficiency syndrome/human immunodeficiency virus (AIDS/HIV) infection. Generic training in values & skills enables practitioners in various disciplines to do this effectively for different client groups, but lack of relevant information is an obstacle & leads to ineffective helping. The most important themes in the different phases of HIV infection are discussed. 4 Figures, 16 References. Adapted from the source document.

Survivors of Woman Abuse: A Support Group Experience

Author: Angless, T1; Shefer, T1 School Social Work U Cape Town, Rosebank 7700 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61627268?accountid=14667

Abstract: The value of group work for battered women in South Africa is examined through assessment of a 10-week psychoeducational battered women's group program that included relaxation exercises, guided visualizations, art therapy, & assertiveness training. A variety of benefits of the group experience are discussed: (1) breaking the silence; (2) depathologizing battering; (3) challenging battered women myths; (4) witnessing change in others; (5) accelerated healing; (6) increased self-esteem; (7) reduction in ambivalence & increase in power to make life decisions; & (8) breaking down of social barriers that divide women. Group work is discussed as a cost-effective method that can provide benefits unavailable in individual counseling. 24 References. D. Generoli

Marital Partners' Attitudes toward Treatment of Breast Cancer

Author: Van Niekerk, S.1; De Bruyn, M; Van Zyl, J A1 c/o Van Zyl -- U Stellenbosch, Cape Province South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61603555?accountid=14667

Abstract: Adjustment by South African women & their spouses to diagnosis & treatment for breast cancer was examined through interviews of 50 married couples, in which the wife had been diagnosed with breast cancer 1-7 years after primary treatment. Respondents reported that information & guidance received from doctors was generally inadequate. Husband's presence during diagnosis made a significant contribution to wife's adjustment, but husband & wife seldom discussed their feelings about the disease. Quality of marriage improved, but sexual relationship often deteriorated. Depression, self-consciousness about their bodies, & increasing religiosity were common among the women. Both spouses reported feeling the need for support through guidance & counseling during diagnosis & treatment. 4 Tables, 25 References. Adapted from the source document.

Problems in the Evaluation of Student Fieldwork

Author: Simpson, B11 Dept Social Work U Natal, Durban 4001 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61634886?accountid=14667

Abstract: Problems associated with the evaluation of student fieldwork were examined through semistructured interview of 30 agency-based supervisors involved in the supervision of U of Natal (South Africa) social work students & administration of a questionnaire to 50 third- & fourth-year social work students there. The following evaluation problem areas are discussed: (1) experience of supervisors; (2) qualification & training of supervisors; (3) frequency of supervision; (4) nature of feedback given to students; (5) supervisors' workloads; (6) purpose of fieldwork; & (7) clarity of objectives & expectations. Guidelines for the evaluation of student fieldwork are discussed. 32 References. D. Generoli

Social Work Research: A Continuum Theory Alternative to Positivism

Author: Woods, R11 School Social Work U Witwatersrand, Johannesburg 2050 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61376249?accountid=14667

Abstract: The dominant & alternative perspectives on social work in South Africa are here examined. The dominant position is typically associated with a positivistic orientation to research, tends to be a male-dominated field, & relies on the notion that reality can be objectively quantified outside of human behavior. The alternative position is typically understood as a social constructionist approach, which tends to study human perceptions in a holistic manner by taking account of biases & attempting to unify both research theories & practices. Instead, the continuum theory, as presented by Yair Caspi (see SOPODA 15:1/93W16669), is here posed as a third alternative to social work research, since it incorporates the positivistic notion of realism along with constructionist perspectives on phenomenology & hermeneutics to examine knowledge as a process. In conclusion, suggestions for applications of continuum theory in a social work setting are provided, with an emphasis on ethnographic, narrative, & case study projects. 25 References. J. MacDowell

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocabsshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Work+Research%3A+A+Continuum+Theory+Alternative+to+Positivism&amp;rft.au=Woods%2C+R&amp;rft.aulast=Woods&amp;rft.aufirst=R&amp;rft.date=1995-10-01&amp;rft.volume=31&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=368&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378054&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocabsshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Work+Research%3A+A+Continuum+Theory+Alternative+to+Positivism&amp;rft.au=Woods%2C+R&amp;rft.aulast=Woods&amp;rft.aufirst=R&amp;rft.date=1995-10-01&amp;rft.volume=31&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=368&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378054&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

From Literacy to Conscientisation: An Application of Paulo Freire's Concepts to a Literacy Training Programme in a Squatter Settlement

Author: Bailey, L R11 Dept Social Work U Durban-Westville, 4000 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61620543?accountid=14667

Abstract: A literacy program based on Paulo Freire's (1972) concepts of teaching & consciousness raising in a squatter settlement in South Africa is described. According to Freire's conceptualizations, literacy is a basic right, & even oppressed individuals are capable of seizing power for themselves & transforming their lives. Accordingly, the literacy program used a participatory learning-center approach that not only allowed students to obtain literacy skills, but also gave them opportunities to view their capabilities in a new light. Ultimately, the consciousness raising that occurred in the program resulted in greater resident participation in wider community issues. The contributions of three specific elements of Freire's ideas to the literacy program are discussed: (1) imposing elements; (2) boundary situations; & (3) dialogue. 7 References. D. Generoli

Making Social Work Services Accessible to Rural Communities

Author: Letsebe, M A1; Letsoalo, E M1 School Social Work U Witwatersrand, Johannesburg 2050 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61612869?accountid=14667

Abstract: The need, feasibility, & desirability of making social work services available to rural people in the northeastern Transvaal, South Africa, were examined through analysis of data obtained from focus group discussions with workers & residents (total N = 212) of the Bushbuckridge, Mhala, & Mapulaneng districts of the region. Findings are presented with regard to: (1) current providers of social services & the services they provide; (2) accessibility of services & the views of residents of current service locations & preferred service locations; (3) the role of tribal authorities in service provision; (4) resident knowledge of social workers & their roles; (5) potential areas for social work intervention; (6) education of social workers employed in rural areas; (7) gender issues related to social services & their provision; & (8) the views of social workers on social services & their provision. Rural communities are in need of a variety of social services to address problems related to chronic poverty & previous apartheid legislation. 16 References. D. Generoli

Promoting a Developmental Perspective in Social Welfare: The Contribution of South African Schools of Social Work

Author: Midgley, James11 Louisiana State U, Baton Rouge 70803

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61560464?accountid=14667

Abstract: A developmental social policy approach is suggested to replace remedial social work in South Africa. Social work currently faces an opportunity to become academically & professionally involved in the stages of analysis & implementation of development programs that are of global importance. Outlined are the characteristics & historical significance of developmental models of social welfare & approaches that synthesize social & economic policies. It is concluded that social workers can utilize access to academic information & research techniques to formulate an appropriate model & disseminate information to the public. 12 References. S. The Profanity of Holy Cows

Author: Van Dyk, A C11 Dept Social Work U South Africa, Pretoria 0001

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61587893?accountid=14667

Abstract: Questions the success of South Africa's RDP (Reconstruction & Development Programme) & the value of utilizing RDP as a tool by which other social plans may be measured. Social plans from several nations serve as both negative & positive examples for the RDP. Implementation of the RDP is shown to have been hindered by several factors, including failure to communicate the plan's purpose & bureaucratic structures that cause delays & lack of access. The government must create a structure to maintain a developmental approach that focuses on the people of South Africa. Community development should focus on ways to hold the government & RDP officials accountable for goal attainment. 22 References. S. Jameson

Social Work and Politics

Author: Gray, M M A11 Dept Social Work U Natal, Durban 4001 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61518878?accountid=14667

Abstract: An examination of the political nature of social work in South Africa focuses on theoretical discourse. Debates within social work literature are classified as radical & traditional & are rooted in the divergence between liberalism & socialism. The term political as defined by each group represents the differing conceptualizations of the relation between social work & political responsibilities. A proactive role must be assumed by social workers to influence policy making & implementation. The key elements for social workers to social policy reform include analysis of legislation, formation of pressure & special interest groups, & discussion with political leaders. 19 References. S. Jameson

The Role of Social Work Management in the Empowerment of Communities and Clients

Author: Cronje, J I11 Dept Social Work U Stellenbosch, Cape Province Republic South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61494418?accountid=14667

Abstract: An examination of the relationship between social work management & South Africa's development program. In order to empower communities, a discussion of relevant technology that describes theoretical perspectives is necessary. A normative approach to empowering clients through developmental social welfare includes consideration of ethical morality, professional autonomy, & protection of the public. Guidelines for a managerial framework for empowerment-based practice are outlined, highlighting the importance of organizational culture & staff development. Social work management's contribution to a collaborative effort must be recognized & interdisciplinary cooperation emphasized. 11 References. S. Jameson

Social Work Practice in Cross-Cultural Situations: Some Guidelines for Practice

Author: Sikhitha, T M11 Dept Social Work U Venda, Thohoyandou South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61494425?accountid=14667

Abstract: Cross-cultural social work in South Africa is examined with a focus on challenges in practice. Examples of worker-client problems are discussed, eg, mistrust, denial of ethnicity, autoracism, & overidentification. Appropriate attitude is considered the key component to addressing these issues. Effective cross-cultural practice includes exploring one's own biases, accepting one's own cultural identity, & developing a wide range of responses. Suggestions are included for helping social workers stay sensitive to the effects of difference on their interactions with clients. Practitioners are encouraged to pursue the most professional intervention to deal with problems arising from such differences. 11 References. S. Jameson

The Use of Participatory Research to Facilitate a Psychological Rehabilitation Programme for Child Survivors of Violence in a South African Community

Author: Petersen, I1; Magwaza, A S; Pillay, Y G1 Dept Psychology U Durban-Westville, Private Bag X54001 4000 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61560428?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examines the development of a model for psychological rehabilitation programs for regions affected by violence in South Africa. A research project is evaluated that utilized a participatory research approach within a primary mental health care context. The project was conducted between 1991 & 1993 in two settlement areas in the Natal/KwaZulu region. Focus groups of preschool teachers from five schools discussed the effects of civil conflict on the psychological state of preschool children & themselves. Questionnaires evaluated posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) among children & assessments were also made of the children's drawings. Interventions included counseling for the teachers & training in counseling skills. It is concluded that primary care workers can effectively intervene with children with mild PTSD or can refer those with severe PTSD for more extensive mental health care. 20 References. S. Jameson

The Impact of Societal Factors on South African Social Workers' Experience of Occupational Stress

Author: Ross, E11 Dept Speech Pathology & Audiology U Witwatersrand, Johannesburg 2050 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61458584?accountid=14667

Abstract: Societal influences on South African social workers' experience of occupational stress are examined using questionnaire & interview data from 1,200 practitioners, who discussed the relation between macrosystem influences & work stress. Common themes articulated included concerns about the future of South Africa & of social welfare, socioeconomic factors, unsatisfactory work conditions, safety, lack of resources, rapid social & political change, cross-cultural issues, high workload, uncontrollable macrofactors, the nature of community, & housing. It is concluded that the broad sociocultural context strongly influences occupational stress. 18 References. S. Jameson

The Tsolo Violence and the Need for a Social Policy for Emergency Situations

Author: Brown, M J1; Sidzumo-Sanders, R; Vilikazi, C; Brown, H. A. Ferguson1 Dept Social Work U Transkei, Umtata

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61560397?accountid=14667

Abstract: The crisis event that occurred at Tsolo, South Africa, & the lack of sufficient responses to Tsolo's needs has prompted concerns for welfare provisions for those affected by emergency situations. Interviews were conducted with 35 children & 29 parents, all displaced as a result of the ongoing violence. It is concluded that only the basic needs of Tsolo refugees have been met. The inadequacies of current social welfare to cope with similar tragedies are highlighted. Strategies to implement an appropriate disaster policy to meet social welfare needs include development of a provincial disaster council & the preparation of supplies & financial reserves. 2 Tables, 4 References. S. Jameson

How South African Social Workers Cope with Occupational Stress

Author: Ross, E11 Dept Speech Pathology & Audiology U Witwatersrand, Johannesburg 2050 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61557789?accountid=14667

Abstract: Data from a national survey of how South African social workers cope with occupational stress show that of 637 respondents, 97% used individual system interventions (eg, physical, emotional, social, recreational, spiritual, & cognitive stress coping strategies), while 43% relied on work interventions. Thematic analysis of replies to open-ended questions indicates that despite the broad range of stress-coping strategies reported, few are actually used by social workers. 1 Table, 19 References. J. Sadler

Occupational Social Work in Profit-Driven Enterprises: Issues for Social Work Education in South Africa in the Late 1990s

Author: Woods, R1; Maenetja, T1 School Social Work U Witwatersrand, Johannesburg 2050 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61588312?accountid=14667

Abstract: An exploration of social work education issues focuses on data drawn from social work practice in the corporate world in South Africa. Informed by Hans-Georg Gadamer's hermeneutic approach to social inquiry, an operationalized knowledge-generation framework is developed. After identifying a series of pre-understandings about generic social work & social work practices in profit-driven enterprises, interviews held with occupational social workers (N = 9) were used to reformulate the pre-understandings. In second interviews (N = 4), questions based on revised understandings helped to clarify initial questions relating to accountability within the management model & the occupational social work arena. Recommendations are made for social work education concerning values, knowledge, & methods. 3 Tables, 13 References. J. Sadler

Participatory Research as a Procedure in Social Work Studies

Author: Strydom, H11 Dept Maatskaplike Werk Potchefstroomse U Christelike Hoer Onderwys, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61557737?accountid=14667

Abstract: Explores the use of participatory research in social work studies, in which the researcher's role may involve either observation or participation. The key stages in the research process are standardized: defining the problem & identifying objectives; selecting a field of study; gaining access to a study environment; forming & maintaining relationships; stipulating a role; gathering data; leaving the study environment; analyzing the data; & compiling the report. 23 References. The Nature and Management of Paradigms

Author: Sing, D11 Dept Public Administration U Durban-Westville, Private Bag X54001 4000 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61560077?accountid=14667

Abstract: Insights into the transition process for the social science profession in South Africa are offered, leading to the notion of a dynamic paradigm. After exploring the meaning of the paradigm & the fundamental assumptions, values, & beliefs associated with it as applied to the theory & practice of professions, it is noted that outdated South African paradigms determining political, social, & economic aspects of welfare must undergo a shift in the transitional period. New paradigms must be effectively managed through introducing constructive conflict, developing original ideas, contradicting opposing viewpoints, & planning for the future. 14 References. J. Sadler

The Reconstruction and Development Programme: A Beginning Discussion and Analysis for Social Work Policy

Author: Triegaardt, J D11 School Social Work U Witwatersrand, Johannesburg 2050 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61594592?accountid=14667

Abstract: An exploratory analysis of key issues relevant to social work policy outlined in the Reconstruction & Development Program (RDP), the platform of ideas promoted by the African National Congress in its 1994 election victory. Informed by D. G. Gil's (1990) theoretical approach to social policy, it is argued that the RDP's success depends on its critical, nonemotional, & rational application to policy issues. The RDP addresses the rights of marginalized South Africans, promotes justice & democracy, redistributes rights through shifts in politicoeconomic power bases, & balances domestic & global economic issues. The implementation of the RDP by the Nelson Mandela administration has involved budget cuts & retrenchments that affect the delivery of social work services. It is suggested that the administration maintain oversight on short-term planning in the human service organizations. 15 References. J. Sadler

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+Reconstruction+and+Development+Programme%3A+A+Beginning+Discussion+and+Analysis+for+Social+Work+Policy&amp;rft.au=Triegaardt%2C+J+D&amp;rft.aulast=Triegaardt&amp;rft.aufirst=J&amp;rft.date=1996-06-01&amp;rft.volume=32&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=142&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378054&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Social Workers and Social Policy: Related Functions and Skills in Practice

Author: Mazibuko, F N M11 Dept Social Work U Natal, Durban 4001 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61560025?accountid=14667

Abstract: A critical review of social work's contribution to development & shifts in social policy in South Africa evaluates the social worker's implementing vs generating roles in welfare policy. It is argued that social workers must demonstrate policy-related skills & competencies to effectively articulate an agenda of developmental social welfare & consolidate an integrated approach. A theoretical perspective of social policy suggests that success in social work practice targeted at social change, promotion of social advancement, self-reliance, & empowerment hinges on the active participation of social workers in exercising policy functions. 32 References. J. Sadler

Developmental Social Welfare in South Africa: A Theoretical Framework

Author: Lombard, A11 Dept Social Work U Pretoria, Brooklyn 0002 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61614834?accountid=14667

Abstract: An analysis of the African National Congress's 1996 Draft White Paper for Social Welfare builds on a theoretical framework for understanding the developmental context of social welfare in South Africa. It is suggested that developmental social welfare should focus on social development & be implemented with reference to a residual (conservative) vs institutional (liberal) model of social welfare. The primary policy objective of social development is the development of human resources through empowerment & the promotion of economic development where possible. After presenting the conceptual background for notions of social welfare in which social philanthropy, social work, social administration, & social development are all linked, South Africa's social development agenda is outlined using an institutional approach, articulating individualistic, communitarian, & governmental strategies, & matching service outcomes with target groups. 2 Figures, 8 References. J. Sadler

An Overview of the Characteristics of Self-Help Organisations amongst Blacks in South Africa -- A Historical Perspective

Author: Molefe, S F11 Dept Social Work U North, Sovenga 0727 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61608332?accountid=14667

Abstract: The historical role of self-help organizations in black South Africa is explored, focusing on both the traditional functions of the self-help system & its evolution as blacks move from rural to urban areas. Various models of traditional self-help organization are cited, including the khilebe & lejema (plowsharing) cooperatives in the Lobedu tribe. Because black families who have relocated in urban areas today are below the poverty level, most rely on income supplementation & the assistance of self-help organizations. Urban self-help organizations assume many forms, eg, tea meetings, fund-raising concerts, & burial societies. 17 References. J. Sadler

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61594544?accountid=14667

Abstract: Sketches South Africa's Youth Empowerment School (YES), a life & social skills training program implemented through group work with juvenile offenders. After noting the composition & structure of YES, group goals, themes, & activities are reviewed. A Commentary on the Article: 'Social Work: Adapt or Dye'

Author: Luvhengo, N R11 Dept Social Work U Venda, Thohoyandou South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61588273?accountid=14667

Abstract: A comment on M. Gray's editorial "Social Work: Adapt or Dye?" (1995) supports Gray's assessment of the problems of inadequate education, marginalization, & low salaries for South Africa's social work profession. A critical analysis of the role of social workers in determining their own profession is needed. Social workers must progress beyond the conventional individual social casework methodology & become more involved with social work in development & social change within nontraditional social work settings. 5 References. J. Sadler

Notes from Practice/Uit die praktyk: The Case History of 'Tumeka'

Author: Barr, L11 Groote Schuur Hospital, Cape Town South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61608308?accountid=14667

Abstract: A social worker's personal intervention in establishing the psychosocial background & providing counseling for a rural Xhosa woman named Tumeka who underwent heart transplant surgery in Cape Town, South Africa, is described. To supplement & enhance recuperation, the social intervention involved existential-humanistic therapy & planned adjustments to an urban lifestyle. 4 References. J. Sadler

The Importance of Community Development

Author: Gray, M M A11 Dept Social Work U Natal, Durban 4001 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61591980?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social workers in South Africa should commit themselves to the values & goals of community development (CD) for three reasons: it is the strategy best equipped to deal with poverty &, thus, to serve the communities most in need; it provides a way of redistributing social work services & resources to the urban & rural poor; & it is relevant to the South African social-political & economic context. While social workers should not focus on CD to the exclusion of their other social work activities, eg, clinical work, their traditional focus on the provision of individualized services should be balanced by CD. Potential barriers to social work involvement in CD programs are also discussed. 41 References. M. Maguire

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+Importance+of+Community+Development&amp;rft.au=Gray%2C+M+M+A&amp;rft.aulast=Gray&amp;rft.aufirst=M+M&amp;rft.date=1996-08-01&amp;rft.volume=32&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=193&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378054&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Ethical Implications of a Human Rights Culture for Social Work Practice

Author: Howes, M F11 Dept Social Work U Stellenbosch, Cape Province 7599 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61585675?accountid=14667

Abstract: The democratic & human rights transformations recently underway in South Africa necessitate reexamination of social work values, principles, & ethics. Since the transformation process will result in profound social change, social workers should begin to identify their shared professional values, improve their ethical decision-making skills, & reconsider how they have traditionally dealt with clients, collegues, & other professionals. At the same time, social work agencies should begin to ensure quality of service & develop strategies for risk management, paying particular attention to the following: informed consent forms, confidentiality, recording procedures, suicide prevention protocol, & supervision practices. 14 References. M. Maguire

The Indigenisation of Social Work Practice and Education in Africa: The Dilemma of Theory and Method

Author: Osei-Hwedie, K11 Dept Social Work U Botswana, Gaborone

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61591945?accountid=14667

Abstract: African social workers must develop educational & practical models that promote the type of development both practitioners & client systems can understand, afford, relate to, & control. But the path to such indigenization of social work practice is not an easy one. African social work educators have been arguing since 1973 that research should be expanded to create a distinctively African form of social work, yet experiments & research testing particular methods & intervention procedures have yet to appear in any significant way. To show why, key theoretical, conceptual, & methodologicl issues associated with indigenization are discussed, & a variety of questions about social work education & practice are raised. 35 References. M. Maguire

Promoting Competence in Community Work Practice through Supervision

Author: Veeran, D L1; Simpson, B1 Dept Social Work U Natal, Durban 4001 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61606063?accountid=14667

Abstract: Community work has become the preferred method of intervention among social workers in South Africa. New models for community work supervision have been developed that both build the capacity & promote the competence of social workers engaged in community work. After reviewing outdated perceptions of community work supervision, practical guidelines for facilitating this kind of social work supervision are presented: increase motivation, encourage autonomy, promote life-long learning, encourage thoughtful planning, & support commitment to social work values. Since supervision & community development are supportive processes essential to the development of workers & communities alike, the concepts integral to both -- democracy, development, empowerment, & participation -- are also identified. 1 Table, 22 References. M. Maguire

Policy Analysis as a Strategy of Welfare Policy Development: The White Paper Process

Author: Mazibuko, F N M11 Dept Social Work U Natal, Durban 4001 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61612309?accountid=14667

Abstract: In the mid-1980s, social workers critical of welfare policies formulated by South African bureaucrats began to organize themselves into resistance formations against proposed & existing welfare policies. These formations not only rejected many of the welfare policies of the time, but also identified the need for an alternative welfare system & began tackling the daunting tasks that faced the social work profession & the welfare sector in generating & shaping welfare policy. Considering the level of discontent, these formations also revealed that need for social workers & other stakeholders within the social welfare sector to become more involved in policy analysis & social planning. The significance of the White Paper policy analysis & recommendation process is considered. 17 References. M. Maguire

Are We Making Progress? The 1996 Child Care Bill and Some Fundamental Aspects of Practice and Procedure in the Children's Courts

Author: Matthias, C R11 Dept Social Work U Durban-Westville, 4000 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61555563?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examines three key matters affecting the functioning of South African children's courts: the child's right to be heard, the representation of the child, & the grounds for removing the child from his/her parents. The solutions proposed in the Child Care Amendment Bills of 1995 & 1996 are then evaluated in light of field research conducted in 1995 in 53 children's court jurisdictions. The data indicate that the Child Care Act as presently formulated still fails to deal effectively with the basic problems of a voice for the child, representation for the child, & constructive grounds for encouraging (wherever possible) only short-term removal of the child from parents or guardians. 5 References. M. Maguire

Beyond Marginalisation -- Youth Re-Integration

Author: Veeran, D L11 Dept Social Work U Natal, Durban 4001 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61557198?accountid=14667

Abstract: Structural factors associated with the process of youth marginalization in South Africa include urbanization & industrialization, as well as lack of money, education, employment, housing, & recreational facilities. Social factors associated with marginalization include the presence of child abuse & neglect, the disintegration of child-parent relationships, & the breakdown of family life in general. The challenges for social workers attempting to curtail the process of marginalization include changing atitudes about poverty, increasing educational provisions, assessing the impact of social & welfare policies on marginalized youth, & improving the role of women in South African society. 7 References. M. Maguire

Where Knowledge and Attitude Separate: Adolescent HIV/AIDS Knowledge Survey as Information for Social Work Training

Author: Coughlan, F J1; Coughlan, N S; Jameson, C P1 Dept Social Work Rhodes U, East London South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61557158?accountid=14667

Abstract: The government of South Africa has made a genuine commitment to human immunodeficiency virus/acquired immune deficiency syndrome (HIV/AIDS) education, as have several provinces & private enterprises, yet the education strategies adopted by some professions, notably social work, are not as effective as they could be. After reviewing the results of a survey documenting the HIV/AIDS-related knowledge & attitudes of 535 Grahamstown adolescents, the relevance of the survey data or the training of social work students is considered. Since the data indicate that adolescents possess the requisite information to protect themselves from HIV infection yet remain wary of risk-free contact with infected children, it is argued that social workers should be trained not only to transmit knowledge, but also to assist youth with the integration of knowledge & attitude. 6 Tables, 5 References. M. Maguire

The Female Medication Dependant: An Increasing Problem within the Field of Drug Dependency

Author: Hugo, E A K1; Erlank, E C1 Dept Social Work U Pretoria, Brooklyn 2002 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61585641?accountid=14667

Abstract: The abuse of prescribed & over-the-counter medications can be just as dangerous & life-threatening as the abuse of illegal drugs. Moreover, ignorance of the problem of medication dependency can render prevention- & treatment-related services ineffective. To ameliorate the problem of ignorance, survey data collected 1994/95 from 33 female medication dependents were used to compile a profile of the clientele of the Magaliesoord Center in South Africa. Based on this profile, 10 specific recommendations for prevention & treatment of medication dependency are presented. 2 Tables, 10 References. M. Maguire

Moral Theory for Social Work

Author: Gray, M M A11 Dept Social Work U Natal, Durban 4001 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61518938?accountid=14667

Abstract: Discusses conceptual issues related to ethical & moral theory for social work, arguing that there is an overemphasis on the principles approach, which oversimplifies ethical complexity & overemphasizes ethical codes at the expense of moral sensitivity, awareness, understanding, & reflection. While practice-relevant guidelines are useful & needed by social work as a practice profession, they are limited & do not themselves ensure ethical social work. A holistic, humanistic conception of morality is advocated that appreciates but does not stress the function of rules & principles. It involves ongoing critical moral reflection by social workers on their own values, commitments, & level of respect for others. Specific references are made to the South African context. 21 References. E. Blackwell

Poverty Alleviation and the State Maintenance Grant: Some Comments on the Lund Committee on Child and Family Support

Author: Vorster, J H1; Rossouw, H M1 Dept Sociology U Stellenbosch, Cape Province 7599 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61490248?accountid=14667

Abstract: Socioeconomic survey, in-depth interview, & statistical data from urban & rural communities in the Western Cape Province, South Africa, regarding the economic contribution of the State Maintenance Grant are examined in light of the 1996 Report of the Lund Committee on Child & Family Support, which proposes that the grant be phased out in favor of greater parental responsibility & a means-tested, flat-rate child support benefit for young children. Findings indicate that, if implemented, the Lund Committee's proposal will hurt children. It is demonstrated that the grant does not promote single-parent households, saves families from utter poverty, is needed by mothers of older as well as younger children, & cannot be replaced by private maintenance from fathers. 2 Tables, 1 Figure, 9 References. E. Blackwell

The Professional Contributions of Social Workers Graduated from the University of Stellenbosch, 1940-1989

Author: Botha, Narisscia J1; Cronje, Johan I1 Dept Maatskaplike Werk U Stellenbosch, Cape Province 7599 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61553655?accountid=14667

Abstract: To investigate the career paths of alumni from the Dept of Social Work at U of Stellenbosch, South Africa, questionnaire data were obtained from 364 graduates, 1940-1989. Slightly fewer than 50% pursued graduate study at some point, & about 80% have worked in their field of specialty. Almost 60% are employed by the state or traditional social welfare organizations, & many have published articles, books, or in books. Almost 41% worked in at least one other job outside of social work. Those who left social work cited work-related stress, financial considerations, changes in personal lifestyle, & violent behavior of clients as reasons. Special attention is given to cognitive & practical skills of social workers, eg, interview techniques, managerial expertise, & communicative ability. 24 References. M. Meeks

A Longitudinal Study of the Performance of Students Who Enrolled for the Bachelor of Arts (Social Work) Degree at the University of the North in 1991

Author: Molefe, S P11 Dept Social Work U North, Sovenga 0727 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61584284?accountid=14667

Abstract: Longitudinal data are used to analyze correlations between academic performance & sociodemographic variables for 32 undergraduate social work students at the U of the North (South Africa), 1991-1996. Students, age 20 at admission, were most likely to complete their degree the prescribed 4 years; those younger tended to take longer or dropped out. Successful academic performance (defined by program completion) was related to semiurban (vs rural & especially urban) area of origin, receipt of D & E matric symbols in secondary school, nonproblematic family circumstances, & community involvement. Entering students cited a desire to help people as their reason for wanting to be social workers & held fairly vaque ideas about what social work entails. 5 Tables, 7 References. E. Blackwell

Curriculum Development: Suggestions from Social Workers in KwaZulu Natal

Author: Van Rooyen, Colin A. J.11 Dept Social Work U Natal, Durban 4001 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61604547?accountid=14667

Abstract: Draws on open- & closed-ended mail questionnaire data from 90 registered social workers (85.5% female) KwaZulu Natal Province, South Africa, to determine their views on the ideal structure & framework for a relevant social work curriculum. Respondents (Rs) reported courses in case, group, & community work as the most useful in their current work & tended to favor integrated or method-based approaches to curriculum structure. Specialized, traditional, & case- & context-based approaches received little support. Many mentioned areas need more curricular attention, most notably legal issues. Rs favored the inclusion of fieldwork in every academic year. Other issues raised by Rs were presentation of academic material, stress management, internships, & student selection. 3 Tables, 2 Figures, 10 References. E. Blackwell

Experiences, Perspectives and Evaluation of Curriculum on Social Security as Part of the Harare School of Social Work

Author: Kaseke, E11 School Social Work U Zimbabwe, Mount Pleasant Harare

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61610370?accountid=14667

Abstract: Discusses social security provision in Zimbabwe, & evaluates the curriculum on social security at the Harare School of Social Work. Zimbabwe lacks a comprehensive system & relies on three major provision channels: the Pensions & other Benefits Scheme, welfare assistance, & workers' compensation; two other less-comprehensive schemes are noted, & their flaws outlined. The Harare School of Social Work's curriculum is designed to mirror actual practice & influence change in practice roles, reflecting a commitment to social work education above & beyond training. Social security issues are included, because much social work is related to the local structural problem of poverty. Students are first introduced to conceptualizations of social security & then related issues (eg, the negative impact of structural adjustment programs). Practice opportunities that prepare students to extend social security in creative ways are, however, still limited. 4 References. E. Blackwell

Family-Centred Residential Child and Youth Care: Towards a New Model

Author: Gaffley, M11 Leliebloem House, Cape Town South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61584232?accountid=14667

Abstract: Describes the efforts of the Leliebloem House, a private nonprofit residential center serving 84 children of troubled families in Cape Town, South Africa, to design & implement a working model for family support & reconstruction. Objectives include increasing staff skills & family participation at the center. A feasibility study of the model comprised questionnaires completed by 69 principals & child care staff at children's institutions & workshops with referral agencies & parents. Encouraging results led to implementation of a pilot program emphasizing family involvement through supportive, nonjudgmental relationships between clients & workers. The program has confirmed that children & families estranged by institutionalization can be brought together. Practical steps for involving families in residential programs are suggested. 14 References. E. Blackwell

Group Work with the Disadvantaged

Author: Hofmeyr, L11 Dept Social Work U Pretoria, Brooklyn 0002 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61590457?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examines how social workers in South Africa can use group work to alleviate global material, emotional, & sociocultural deprivation. After key skills for the group worker (eg, understanding group feelings, purposeful use of programs) are considered, elements of the group process are described: motivation, structuring, values, & norms, control, atmosphere, cohesiveness, & program planning. Phases of group development & their supervision are described from orientation to termination/transition. How groups for the disadvantaged can disrupt social isolation, build community, teach interpersonal & practical skills, & empower are stressed. 31 References. E. Blackwell

Peace Promotion in South African Schools: A Multi-Faceted Prevention Programme

Author: Kasiram, M I1; Keen, A W; Naidoo, C D1 Dept Social Work U Durban-Westville, Private Bag X54001 4000 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61604511?accountid=14667

Abstract: Describes a multifaceted peace-promotion program that uses an environmental approach & is designed for use in secondary schools. The project was developed in Durban-Westville, South Africa, in response to school staff requests for a permanent social worker to address problems of pregnancy, substance abuse, domestic discord, racial intolerance, & violence, & comprises three phases: (1) establishment of good working relationships with students & staff through committed social work & neutrality in school disputes; (2) administration of traditional case & group work services to students exhibiting violent behavior & development of a group violence education plan; & (3) involvement of parents & community members to improve school & home environments. It is hoped that such an ecological approach can alter the deeper values that influence violent & nonviolent behavior. 12 References. E. Blackwell

Social Work and Christianity: Complementarity or Conflict?

Author: Mupedziswa, R11 School Social Work U Zimbabwe, Mount Pleasant Harare

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61610337?accountid=14667

Abstract: The histories, value bases, philosophies, & ethical principles of social work & Christianity are traced, finding them compatible or complementary in numerous ways. Both emphasize compassion, tolerance, human welfare, & sanctity, beneficial behavioral change, spiritual needs, & salvation through personal relationships. Fields of potential conflict are also found, eg, differing views on human accountability, methods of science, professional vs spiritual intervention, & self-determination. Incompatibility is strongest between social workers & those Christian fundamentalists who oppose state welfare, emphasize sin over individual dignity, & believe in predestination. It is contended, however, that compatibility outweighs conflict, & social work is an offshoot of religion; collaboration between the two is advocated. 20 References. E. Blackwell

The RDP: Implications for Social Work Practice and Social Welfare Policy Development in South Africa

Author: Sewpaul, V11 Dept Social Work U Natal, Durban 4001 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61541407?accountid=14667

Abstract: Explores the Reconstruction & Development Programme (RDP), its relationship to social development theory, & its implications for social welfare policy in South Africa. A history of the social work field, including remedial & development aspects, is offered to highlight the need for the RDP as a new paradigm focusing on empowerment through social development rather than personal deficiency. It is argued that the RDP can translate into policy the principles of social development theory & undertake fundamental social change by incorporating social work methods into one comprehensive approach. The RDP is presented as a political economy approach including theories of community & social development, equally committed to goals of economic growth & social development. A review of recent welfare policy in South Africa, particularly the 1996 Draft White Paper for Social Welfare, reveals increasing incorporation of RDP priorities into a comprehensive social welfare policy. It is suggested that challenges to the new approach will include making social welfare policy more community-based & reorienting social work curricula & practices to better complement the RDP. 27 References. C. Ryan

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+RDP%3A+Implications+for+Social+Work+Practice+and+Social+Welfare+Policy+Development+in+South+Africa&amp;rft.au=Sewpaul%2C+V&amp;rft.aulast=Sewpaul&amp;rft.aufirst=V&amp;rft.date=1997-03-01&amp;rft.volume=33&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378054&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Social Work Educators and Practitioners: Partners in Social Development

Author: Lombard, A11 Dept Social Work U Pretoria, Brooklyn 0002 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61542109?accountid=14667

Abstract: Explores the potential for partnership & cooperation between South African social work educators & field practitioners, the strengths of each, their common ground, & challenges to partnership. It is argued that this cooperation is necessary to maintain control of the field & increase the efficiency & relevancy of social work practice & research. Practitioners provide firsthand observation of societal change, while universities transform field experience into universal theories & update & retrain fieldworkers with the latest research. It is suggested that educational goals are not always compatible with practical knowledge & skills. Establishing partnerships between educators & fieldworkers will require increased international cooperation & changes in undergraduate education, including the standardization of educational goals across universities, innovative placement programs, & enhanced multicultural & interdisciplinary approaches. 21 References. C. Ryan

The Professional Development of Social Workers

Author: Van Zyl, R.1; Botha, N J1 c/o Botha -- Dept Social Work U Stellenbosch, Matieland 7602 Cape Province South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61542056?accountid=14667

Abstract: A review of previous research shows that few South African social workers have taken responsibility for their own professional development, relying instead on traditional techniques of supervision & continuing academic education. It is argued that social workers must be proactive & seek out new forms of self-development to remain informed & competent. Many strategies are offered & explained. Supervision can be made more effective through the setting of clear personal goals; increased proactivity; & personal responsibility for effective supervision of self, peers, & groups. Consultation with other social work professionals can provide experienced social workers with specialized knowledge. Student supervision, professional libraries, journal clubs, membership & participation in professional associations, & research & publication are suggested as methods for professional self-development. 29 References. C. Ryan

Action Research and Consultation: Developing Collaborative and Participative Relationships with Communities

Author: Stevens, Leigh-Ann11 Dept Social Work U Natal, Durban 4001 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61541358?accountid=14667

Abstract: Action research & consultation approaches are examined as effective means for solving social work problems in a community development context. Action research is presented as a problem-solving, community-based method that focuses on participation & cooperation among practitioners & participants, resulting in participant empowerment. It is argued that action research complements current interest in social development because it values improvement & involvement. The action research model of intervention consists of sequential steps of action, observation, planning, & reflection. Consultation is an effective interactive method for facilitating the action research & intervention process. Guidelines for appropriate consultation practices in the action research framework are given. 3 Tables, 33 References. C. Ryan
