Guidelines for Implementing the Basic Assessment Process

Author: Fouche, C B1; Delport, C S L1 Dept Social Work Rand Afrikaans U, Auckland Park 2006 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61575368?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examines social work assessment as a process, & reviews critical elements for effective assessment. It is suggested that standardization of assessment practices across applications increases the accessibility & applicability of social work. The first phase of assessment is identified as the definition of context, consisting of client problems & needs, motivation & capacity for change, & environmental & cultural factors. Choosing an appropriate theoretical paradigm is the second phase of assessment. The last phase is the selection of an appropriate assessment technique, requiring knowledge such as the availability & usefulness of measuring instruments & the validity & reliability of the technique. Several assessment techniques are reviewed. 19 References. C. Ryan

Family Life and Work Stress among South African Social Workers

Author: Ross, Eleanor11 Dept Speech Pathology & Audiology U Witwatersrand, Johannesburg 2050 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61588111?accountid=14667

Abstract: Explores the relationship between family life & work stress, focusing on South African social workers. Previous research highlights increased sources of family stress, including higher divorce rates, changing gender norms, & the legalization of abortion. Stressors specific to South African families include economic recession, social unrest, mistrust of political management, rapid urbanization, & the influx of Western culture & values. Survey & scale data from 681 social workers revealed that they scored higher on cohesion, expressiveness, & lack of conflict scales than has been the case of other families. A second qualitative study of 50 respondents provided in-depth research on elements of the family environment that can exacerbate or ameliorate the experience of work stress, including children, marriage, & family cohesion. 2 Tables, 38 References. C. Ryan

Drug Abuse among Young Adult Criminals in a Prison Environment

Author: Fourie, D P11 Dept Social Work U Stellenbosch, Matieland 7602 Cape Province South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61588061?accountid=14667

Abstract: To determine the nature of substance abuse among young adult offenders in prison as a first step in the evaluative research method to develop a suitable rehabilitation program, 86 male inmates at Pollsmoor Command Area in South Africa completed a questionnaire. Findings indicate that (1) inmates' average age was 20:4; (2) 92% had used various kinds of drugs; (3) 20% not only had abused these drugs, but also displayed symptoms of addiction; & (4) only 4% had been sentenced for direct drug-related offenses, but 42% had committed a violent crime during which alcohol or drugs might have played a significant role. Thus prison authorities have a major rehabilitative role to play, & the feasibility of a special drug unit in the prison will be further researched. 3 Tables, 18 References. Adapted from the source document.

Fields of Interest and Values of a Group of Student Voluntary Community Workers

Author: Sennett, E1; Meyer, J C; Boshoff, S C; Burger, L1 Dept Psychology U Stellenbosch, Matieland 7602 Cape Province South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61542007?accountid=14667

Abstract: To analyze the values & fields of interest of South African student volunteers & nonvolunteering students, the Meyer Interest Questionnaire & the Vafirues Scale were administered to 46 student volunteers & 100 first-year undergraduates. Analysis revealed that male & female volunteers showed significantly higher interest in linguistics & were more humanistically & less scientifically inclined than their student counterparts. Female volunteers were significantly more interested in practical work & males placed lower priority on physical activity & ability utilization, contradicting traditional gender expectations. Volunteers valued personal development, spirituality, & altruism more & achievement & advancement less than nonvolunteer students. Implications for the development & recruitment of volunteer workers are discussed. 2 Tables, 21 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Quality of Life of Elderly Xhosa People in Transkei: A Study of Rural Xhosa

Author: Brown, Malcolm J1; Ferguson-Brown, Heather; Canca, Nolitha1 Dept Social Work U Transkei, Unitra South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61588019?accountid=14667

Abstract: Interviews were conducted with 80 elderly Xhosa people in 1995 in a rural sector of the Transkei, South Africa, who lived either in the community or a residential facility, to explore their family & social contacts, support systems, activities, preoccupations, concerns, & degree of life satisfaction. While 84% suffered from some chronic disabling illness, 46% evaluated their present life positively & described themselves as happy or all right. In contrast, 19% viewed life as having no happiness, & 23% wanted to die. Factors contributing to quality of life & areas for consideration & concern are discussed. 7 Tables, 2 References. Adapted from the source document.

Participatory Process in the Construction of a Model for Organisational Change in South African Welfare

Author: Collins, K J11 Dept Social Work U South Africa, Pretoria 0001

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61542316?accountid=14667

Abstract: Draws on J. Heron's (1992) mandala system & a participatory research approach to develop a model for organizational change in South African welfare. Heron's mandala identifies four distinct ways of knowing -- presentational, propositional, experiential, & practical -- & four modes of thought -- intuition, reflection, inflection, & feeling -- according to which social work can be understood. Key people (N = 12) from welfare agencies in Johannesburg participated in a 1995 collaborative project to plan new directions in social work, &, as a group task, engaged in theme discussions wherein data were fit into a mandala, which generated the model of experiential workshops with project members as facilitators. 1 Table, 8 Figures, 7 References. M. Nichols-Wagner

The Supervisory Role in the Fostering of Critical Self-Reflection Capacity in Social Workers

Author: Booley, S11 Dept Social Work U Western Cape, Bellville 7535 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61563278?accountid=14667

Abstract: Draws on J. Mezirow (1990) to explore the methods by which supervisors encourage critical self-reflection in social workers & help transform them into learners. The objectives, ethics, & rationale of encouraging critical self-reflection among learners are examined. Methodology, techniques, & aids by which supervisiors can teach critical self-reflection are discussed. It is concluded that supervisor-student communication is a critical factor in determining the success of these methods. 55 References. M. Nichols-Wagner

Social Workers Involved in Attitudinal Studies

Author: Strydom, Herman11 Dept Maatskaplike Werk Potchefstroom U Christian Higher Education, Transvaal South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61544951?accountid=14667

Abstract: Investigates social workers' perceptions of & involvement in attitudinal research, drawing on mail questionnaire data from 100 social workers in the Northwest Province of South Africa. Hindu Philosophy and Social Work

Author: Sewpaul, V11 Dept Social Work U Natal, Durban 4001 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61555606?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examines the relationship of the Hindu worldview to social work, asserting that Hinduism is far more esoteric than social work, & far less concerned with the material world. According to Hindu philosophy, yoga practices, which lead to self-realization & union with God, must be synthesized to bring about spiritual growth. Karma yoga (divine union through action) is identified as most relevant to social work practice. It is deemed critical for social workers working with Hindus to recognize the centrality of yoga & spiritual practices to their life philosophy. 18 References. M. Nichols-Wagner

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocabsshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Hindu+Philosophy+and+Social+Work&amp;rft.au=Sewpaul%2C+V&amp;rft.aulast=Sewpaul&amp;rft.aufirst=V&amp;rft.date=1997-06-01&amp;rft.volume=33&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=136&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378054&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Affirmative Action and Women Managers in the Social Work Profession

Author: Bailey, L R11 Dept Social Work U Durban-Westville, 4000 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61563324?accountid=14667

Abstract: After noting US, British, & South African perspectives on gender-equity policies, such employment practices & policies in social work agencies are examined, drawing on semistructured interview & questionnaire data from 60 women social work agency managers in South Africa. Results indicate that women managers experienced resistance to gender-equity practices, & organizational policies were vague & incoherent. Staff-development practices & funding for gender-equity initiatives are argued to be necessary, & other recommendations are given for the improvement of gender-equity practices & policies in social work agencies. 23 References. M. Nichols-Wagner

Experience of Routine Husband Absences in the South African Navy

Author: Van Breda, Adrian D

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61488132?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examines the psychological effects of routine husband absences on navy families in South Africa, drawing on questionnaire data from randomly selected navy members & wives (total N = 68). Results indicate that husbands & wives do not experience separation significantly differently, gender-role change is often a source of stress, predictability of separation has a great impact on its tolerance, & different types of separations are tolerated differently. Families at the highest risk for marriage problems are those with low status, young children, unpredictable separations, lack of social support, & difficulty adjusting to changing roles. It is concluded that the provision of social & professional support to these families can be helpful. 3 Tables, 20 References. M. Nichols-Wagner

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocabsshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Experience+of+Routine+Husband+Absences+in+the+South+African+Navy&amp;rft.au=Van+Breda%2C+Adrian+D&amp;rft.aulast=Van+Breda&amp;rft.aufirst=Adrian&amp;rft.date=1997-06-01&amp;rft.volume=33&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=154&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378054&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Youth Unemployment -- A Study in an Informal Settlement in Kwazulu-Natal

Author: Ransom, Brenda L1; Poswa, Thokozani; Van Rooyen, Colin A. J.1 c/o Van Rooyen -- Dept Social Work U Natal, Durban 4001 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61555645?accountid=14667

Abstract: Explores youth unemployment in Bhambayi, KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa, drawing on 1996 structured interview data from 69 young people, ages 15-35. Results indicate that the majority of respondents had financial dependents & little formal education or job skills training. Most felt powerless & impotent & were in favor of a community income-generating project; yet, findings suggest that most of them possess the skills to help themselves. It is concluded that cooperative youth projects that focus on empowerment, competence, & self-sufficiency would be appropriate for the region. 31 References. M. Nichols-Wagner

Protecting Children in Abusive Situations: A Case Study

Author: Simpson, B11 Dept Social Work U Natal, Durban 4001 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61566962?accountid=14667

Abstract: Uses a case study of failure to protect a sexually abused girl, age 12, in Durban to examine barriers to the protection of abused children in South Africa. Lack of training among workers in child protection units, worker apathy & burnout, & case overload are illustrated. A developmental approach to social welfare is advocated; further poverty needs to be addressed, & 24-hour services along with treatment & remedial services are necessary. It is concluded that the South African government must commit to child protection if the system is to be successful. 17 References. M. Nichols-Wagner

Human Rights and Ethics in the South African Society -- Implications for Social Work Management and Supervision

Author: Cronje, Johan11 Dept Social Work U Stellenbosch, Cape Province 7602 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61515729?accountid=14667

Abstract: Proposes the reinstatement of supervision in social work as a means of addressing increasing public criticism of the field. It is argued that a tradition of supervision for new social workers will increase productivity, accountability, & efficacy, thus allowing more efficient use of limited financial resources. Documentation of services would be increased & assignments would be more effectively prioritized. Supervision could also be used as a method of training & defense against legal challenges. Specific recommendations for the responsibilities of supervisors are given. M. Nichols-Wagner

Developmental Social Welfare: Challenges Facing South Africa

Author: Rankin, P11 Dept Social Work Potchefstroom U Christian Higher Education, Transvaal South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61507776?accountid=14667

Abstract: Considers challenges to the development of a new social welfare policy in South Africa, drawing on an analysis of The White Paper on Welfare (Ministry of Welfare, 1997). A development policy is proposed in this report that fits in the framework of the more general, national Reconstruction & Development Plan. To be successful, this plan must convince all players that developmental welfare is the best approach to South Africa's welfare problem. A system of constant monitoring, evaluation, & assessment will be required. The proposed system must identify needs & problems, clarify the role of social work, & provide adequate social work education. If these goals are achieved, the developmental approach may alleviate social conditions in South Africa. 22 References. D. M. Smith

Organisational Funding: A Developmental Perspective

Author: O'Brien, Frances11 Dept Social Work U Natal, Durban 4001 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61507737?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examines the funding of 30 nongovernmental organizations (NGOs) in South Africa that received funds from the National Nutrition & Social Development Programme to contribute to local social development, drawing on interview & observation data & record analysis. The NGOs submitted applications for projects such as the creation of food gardens, skills training, formal & informal education, health education, & socialization & food-for-work programs. Government funding is provided for food, administration, & development; additional funding has come from nongovernment sources, individual giving, foreign agencies, corporations, & trusts & foundations. Primary ingredients of the success of these NGOs include development of plans reflecting the agendas of their communities, a transparent organizational structure, & constant communication with other actors in this area. 1 Table, 1 Figure, 47 References. [. M. Smith

A Pragmatic Approach to Social Development. Part I

Author: Gray, M11 Dept Social Work U Natal, Durban 4001 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61507697?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examines the theoretical framework of social work practice in South Africa, drawing on a review of the first Developmental Social Work Coursework Master's Programme at the U of Natal (Durban). Social development is presented to students as a macropolicy perspective that offers an alternative to assist social workers to transcend their current roles. This perspective is most needed in poor communities in need of resource generation & distribution. The particular goals of social development are defined by the needs of specific communities, but generally include programs designed to meet social needs & enhance economic & political development. If successful, such programs can transform the role of social workers in South Africa. 1 Table, 5 Figures, 23 References. D. M. Smith

Training Social Workers in an Environment of Economic Reforms: The 'Mother' of All Challenges?

Author: Mupedziswe, Rodreck11 School Social Work U Zimbabwe, Mount Pleasant Harare

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61507653?accountid=14667

Abstract: Discusses the challenges of training social workers to assist in the economic development of African nations. The training institutions have always been hampered by a lack of resources, but have also been derailed in recent years by the introduction of poorly planned economic reform programs in some countries. The cost of training social workers has increased, while trainers & training facilities have been inadequate. These developments have affected the quality of students & their subsequent services. To reverse this situation, governments must alter their priorities & institutions devise more economical training strategies. 10 References. D. M. Smith

Computer-Based Communication: Using an Internet List for Communication between Social Work Academics in South Africa -- A Descriptive Account

Author: Van Rooyen, Colin A. J.11 Dept Social Work U Natal, Durban 4001 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61507604?accountid=14667

Abstract: Investigates the use of Internet mailing lists as a tool for social work educators in South Africa, drawing on the framework developed by E. J. Thomas (eg, 1989 [see abstract 90W11870]). According to Thomas's developmental phase model, the implementation development proceeds in two phases: analysis of problems & realization of solutions through technology. It is shown that this process functioned well in the creation of an Internet list that linked social workers throughout South Africa. This list was tested in a 6-month period in 1996, & formally announced at the Board Meeting of the Joint Universities Committee on Social Work Conference in Sept 1996. Use of the list has generated discussion of current policy, requests for information, announcements of journal contents, & feedback on events & meetings among a large proportion of social work academics in South Africa. 14 References. D. M. Smith

Cultural Unity and Diversity in Family Contexts

Author: Van Staden, S M11 Dept Maatskaplike Werk U Pretoria, Brooklyn 0002 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61515468?accountid=14667

Abstract: Culture-related parameters relevant for family therapists are discussed from an ecosystemic perspective. It is argued that, to account for similarities & differences between families, universalist & particularist approaches must be combined with ethnicity-based approaches to arrive at a multidimensional complex of cultural variables as described by Celia Jaes Falicov (1995 [see abstract 96W24331]). This multidimensional position seeks to address the individual complexities of worldviews, language, age, nationality, gender, etc, & to place them in a family framework based on four parameters: ecological context (how they live), migration factors (where they came from), life cycle (how & when they change), & organization (how they relate). Practical applications of this framework are discussed, focusing on cultural & life-cycle similarities among deprived families. It is concluded that the model, when applied critically & sensitively, will allow the therapist to describe individual as well as group processes in families. 1 Figure, 30 References. Adapted from the source document.

Assessment as a Basis for Family Maintenance Services

Author: Kruger, S P11 Dept Maatskaplike Werk U Stellenbosch, Matieland 7602 Cape Province South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61515427?accountid=14667

Abstract: Although the importance of primary & secondary strategies to prevent child neglect & family dysfunction is generally recognized in South Africa, family risk assessment procedures, on which secondary preventive strategies are based, are often inadequate. Research data gathered from 111 social workers in Western Cape Province are used to illustrate prerequisite concepts, instruments, & practical effects of risk assessment procedures. It is found that family assessment not only helps in defining therapeutic goals, but can also help determine the effects of intervention & success of the social program. It is concluded that social organizations need well-described preventive assessment policies, based on questionnaires, models, checklists, & baselines, that can be applied with the generally acknowledged goal of preserving family relations, but that accentuate possibly problematic families sufficiently to make timely intervention possible, especially in cases of substitute child care. 2 Tables, 1 Figure, 77 References. Adapted from the source document.

Transforming State Support for Children and Families in South Africa: Single Mother Households Footing the Bill?

Author: Vorster, Jan1; Rossouw, Hester1 Dept Sociology U Stellenbosch, Matieland 7602 Cape Province South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61515381?accountid=14667

Abstract: Describes the transition of the South African system of child support to a developmental model, highlighting some of the problems with implementing the new system in a context defined by neoliberal economics & its emphasis on budgetary constraints. Approved changes proposed by the Lund (Sweden) Committee on Child & Family Support are resulting in the replacement of the old state maintenance grant with a child support benefit. The new system is holistic & will cover more children, but it is argued that it will shift resources away from the poorest children & their caregivers, hitting single mothers & their children particularly hard. The argument for designing a support system based not on fiscal concern but on the socioeconomic rights guaranteed by South Africa's new constitution (& possibly financed by restructuring the national debt of the old regime) is considered. 41 References. E. Blackwell

Transracial Placements of Children in the Durban Metropolitan Area

Author: Ledderboge, U F11 Durban Child Welfare, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61515345?accountid=14667

Abstract: Draws on questionnaire & qualitative case file data on 50 families connected with cross-cultural support groups in Durban & Pinetown, South Africa, to assess the situation of children placed with parents of a different race after abandonment, removal from biological families because of mistreatment, or orphanage. Analysis finds that most of the adoptive/foster parents are white, middle-age parents of older children & have strong multiracial support networks. Both children & parents appear to benefit from transracial placement & rate the experience positively. Parents generally seek to address children's identity concerns & needs, often by providing them with multicultural settings & acquaintances. Problems were reported, however, mostly in the area of renegotiating family balances & inappropriate responses from the public (but rarely from extended family). Parents named love of children, interpersonal & financial resources, family member involvement, & social support as conditions that helped them meet challenges. It is concluded that children thrive when they are placed in stable, loving families, even when those families are of another race. 2 Tables, 24 References. E. Blackwell

Assessment of the Psycho-Social Needs of Clients with Physical Disabilities

Author: Green, S11 Dept Social Work U Stellenbosch, Matieland 7602 Cape Province South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61515313?accountid=14667

Abstract: A 1994 multidisciplinary evaluation of 52 persons with physical disabilities in & around the municipal district of Malmesbury, South Africa, was conducted to design an instrument & procedure for assessing the psychosocial functioning & needs of the rural disabled. Care, emotional, practical, & financial problems were most common; interpersonal & family problems were much less common. Most participants needed a caregiving assistant, & many had one they deemed competent. Depression was found in 36.5%, & loneliness was experienced by 19.2%, as was anxiety. Participants tended to use informal support from household family members & to a lesser extent, neighbors & friends, but not community-based assistance. It is concluded that social workers can link persons with disabilities with formal support services, & the assessment procedure used is valuable in their work. 6 Tables, 47 References. E. Blackwell

A Pragmatic Approach to Social Development. Part 2

Author: Gray, M11 Dept Social Work U Natal, Durban 4001 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61515267?accountid=14667

Abstract: (For Part 1 [1997], see abstract 98D11538.) Discusses the applicability of the theory of social development to social work practice in South Africa. The social development approach is contended to be relevant to South African contexts because it eschews the traditional overemphasis on individual & family casework by including meso- & macrolevel strategies such as policy analysis, community organizing, rural development, literacy & health promotion, action research, & programs to empower women. It involves a shift from remedial to preventive child welfare, creation of new outreach methods, & administrative/institutional reorganization. According to the social development model, the social worker becomes more involved in advocacy & ground-level community partnership & works cooperatively with practitioners from other disciplines. Social workers in South Africa are mostly receptive to this approach, but are cautious about accepting it as a panacea. 3 Figures, 29 References. Adapted from the source document.

Causes of Stress in Undergraduate Social Work Students

Author: Engelbrecht, L K1; Cronje, J I1 c/o Cronje Dept Maatskaplike Werk U Stellenbosch, Matieland 7602 Cape Province South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61515219?accountid=14667

Abstract: Noting that stress is a negative influence on field instruction & learning among many South African undergraduate social work students, a study was conducted among 60 3rd- & 4th-year social work students in Wellington, South Africa, identifying stress factors in three areas: personal circumstances, client contacts, & supervision-related problems. It is found that 10 of 32 possible stress factors, of which 50% were related to contacts with clients, were considered major by 75% of the students: new work environment, type of assigned work, supervisor evaluation for a grade, time management, disagreements with teachers & supervisors about work approaches, overly demanding clients, writing reports, professional decision making, personal finances, & lack of obvious results. It is concluded that the current habit of granting students 10-12 weeks to adapt to a new work environment is a key element of undergraduate education. Individually based approaches in dealing with stress are considered necessary. 2 Tables, 26 References. Adapted from the source document.

Empowering Women in Government in South Africa as a Tool towards Achieving Social Development Goals

Author: Letsebe, M A11 Office of the Deputy President of South Africa, mr Mbeki

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61442222?accountid=14667

Abstract: Based on personal experiences in working with women at all levels of government under the auspices of the Women's Development Foundation, explored is the feasibility of social work involvement in empowering women in government through collaborative work with women's structures, using training as a tool toward achieving development goals. A connection is pointed out among social work practice, the development needs of women in civil society, & those of women in government. The potential contribution of social workers in meeting these needs & thereby contributing to the achievement of social development goals is briefly outlined. The analysis is premised on the view held in social welfare of the importance of the relationship between welfare leadership & government bureaucracy in influencing their decisions for the achievement of social welfare & development goals, & conceptualized from a gender, development, & empowerment perspective. The concept of women in government is loosely used to refer to women in elective politics across all levels of government. 2 Tables, 13 References. Adapted from the source document.

Critique of the Policy Proposals of the Inter-Ministerial Committee on Young People at Risk

Author: Gray, M M A1; Sewpaul, V1 Dept of Social Work, U of Natal, Durban

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61442215?accountid=14667

Abstract: Analyzes the processes, influences, & outcome of the work conducted by the Inter-Ministerial Committee on Young People at Risk (IMC), a committee appointed by the government of South Africa in the early 1990s to address problems in the child & youth care system of that country. Drawing on D. Gil's (1992) framework, particular attention is paid to how policy issues are defined, the overt & covert objectives of the polities, their effects on the social structure, & the possible development of policy alternatives. It is suggested that the IMC's greatest innovation may lie in its proposal regarding professionalization & training for child & youth care workers. However, the IMC's work is hampered by several difficulties, including a lack of analysis of diverse theories concerning child & youth care, often contradictory assumptions at work in its value premises & a failure to situate the problem of youth at risk in wider social contexts. Despite these shortcomings, it is concluded that the IMC may yet contribute to the development & implementation of an integrated holistic framework & action plan for child welfare, if it can overcome bureaucratic hurdles & its reluctance to include all relevant stakeholders in discussions of policy proposals. 1 Table, 7 References. D. Ryfe

Transformation or Organized Fragmentation? Exploring the Way Forward with Social Worker Formations

Author: Mazibuko, F N M11 Dept of Social Work U of Natal, Durban

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61442211?accountid=14667

Abstract: Argues that social workers need to reexamine the status & relevance of the existing social worker formations in relation to the broader policy & operational frameworks, social workers' & client system needs, & the broader interests of the social work profession. It is suggested that social workers organize themselves into formidable structures that will act as mechanisms to serve their professional & practice-related interests, professional competence, work conditions, & participation in policy formulation. The argument is based on the assumption that there is a need for a well-organized mechanism in the social work profession, which would, among other things, enable social workers to engage in dialogue & refocus among themselves, as well as engage in appropriate partnerships with a range of other structures in social work training & education, social services, & continental & international social worker formations. An organized structure would be an important mechanism to promote cooperative problem solving on common issues, develop the character of the profession, allow space for political expression by social workers, & reduce the tendency in the profession to organize or come together on the basis of crisis intervention. Social work practice is not extinct; it has to refocus & reexamine its current traditions. 8 References. Adapted from the source document.

Fiscal Implications of the Transformation of Social Welfare

Author: Van der Berg, S11 Dept of Economics U of Stellenbosch, Stellenbosch

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61442203?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examines the deracialization in social assistance in South Africa, drawing on data concerning two cost drivers: benefit levels & number of beneficiaries. It is shown that the transformation of social assistance occurred earlier than that of the welfare system, & was fiscally more expensive. The equalization of benefit levels & expansion of coverage in the social assistance program increased spending on old-age pensions & disability grants. However, in the current period, these increases have ceased as racial parity has been achieved & the upper limit of coverage expansion has been met. The most difficult problem caused by the expansion of coverage concerns the fiscal sustainability of child & family maintenance grants. It is suggested that once this difficulty has been addressed, the growth of social assistance spending ought to abate. However, because the welfare system has not been restructured as quickly as the social assistance program, it is expected that growth in spending on these services will continue for some time. 1 Table, 1 Figure, 13 References. D. Ryfe

Trends in the South African Social Work Research Field

Author: Strydom, H11 Dept of Social Work Potchefstroom U for Christian Higher Education, Potchefstroom

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61442150?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examination of certain trends in the social work research field reveals that the relationship between research & the practice of social work has always been problematic. Many social workers still see research as something separate from practice. There is a lost tradition of research in social work, & many practitioners still rely on experience & intuition only. Besides historical developments & future perspectives on social work research, issues such as commitment to research, the research roles of the social worker, measurement of treatment effectiveness, & integration of research & practice are discussed. The role of research in policy formulation, the planning of services, & the transformation process are also delineated. Accountability, ethical issues, research-minded practice, research as preventive measure, & the training of students in research are also addressed. 43 References. Adapted from the source document.

Values, Transformation and Social Work in South Africa

Author: Van Niekerk, A A11 Dept of Philosophy Centre for Applied Ethics U Stellenbosch, Stellenbosch

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61442198?accountid=14667

Abstract: Considers problems related to the recent transformation of the values underlying the South African social work system & the relevance of the social work system to the wider transformation of values in South African society. It is suggested that the transition in South Africa from its apartheid past has precipitated a value crisis that is manifested in a variety of economic & social indicators. This crisis is defined as a situation in which South Africans do not appear to share enough common values so as to work together to achieve a value shift equitably & peacefully. These difficulties are exacerbated by the fact that there is no clear image of the proper extent of transformation of society. It is argued that social work may play a key role in resolving these difficulties because it is involved with the daily consequences of the value crisis, & it also has strong connections to the wider community. Social workers may play this role best by stressing the growth of different, rather than common, values. Of particular importance in this regard is the notion that welfare services cannot remain the sole responsibility of government, but must become a matter of individual & local actions. 25 References. D. Ryfe

Social Work and the Emerging Occupational Group of Community Developers

Author: Gray, M M A1; Wint, Eleanor1 Dept of Social Work U of Natal, Durban

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61442192?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examines the relationship between social work & the emerging occupation of community developers in South Africa, drawing on a variety of materials. This relationship became urgent largely as a consequence of a 1995 national conference on social welfare, which called for the creation of an umbrella body for social service personnel. Thus, social workers have been asked to share their traditional role as community developers with other professionals. This transformation has come at a time when social workers have become particularly demoralized by overwork & dysfunctions in the social service system. It is suggested that the greater proximity of social workers to community developers is likely to create more overlap & conflict & necessitates the development of new training programs in community development. Although the theory of community development that informs the occupation is sound, the practice of community developers will not be more successful than that of social workers unless a comprehensive poverty eradication strategy is devised by the government. It is concluded that social workers can emerge from this moment of crisis empowered if they accurately appraise their strengths & innovate new opportunities in the changed political & economic environment. 1 Table, 20 References. D. Ryfe

Coping in Sodom and Gomorrah -- Christianity and the Delivery of Social Welfare in South Africa

Author: Kinghorn, J11 Dept of Religion & the Programme for Value and Policy Studies U Stellenbosch

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61442185?accountid=14667

Abstract: Argues that religion impacts social welfare in South Africa not so much through its emphasis on morality & values as through its organizational structure, drawing on two case studies of the Dutch Reformed Church & the African Indigenous Churches movement. The organizational strength of religion lies in the social networks it fosters & facilitates. It is shown that strong networks of communities have been organized around these two churches. As primary mediators of contact with the wider social world, these churches are demonstrated to serve as key interpreters of meaning & function as a mobilizing institution for their members. This is true whether the church ministers to the white Afrikaaner community, as does the Dutch Reformed Church, or to the largely black community, as do the African Indigenous Churches. 1 Table, 3 References. D. Ryfe

Social Development and Social Welfare: South Africa in an International Context

Author: Midgley, J11 School of Social Welfare U of California, Berkeley

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61442178?accountid=14667

Abstract: Overviews the social development approach to social welfare in an analysis of the South African experience, arguing that progressive social change is best achieved through the creation of a dynamic developmental process. This process requires that economic & social policies be harmonized, people benefit directly from economic development, & social welfare programs contribute directly to economic development. Examples of relatively successful social development programs in Europe are briefly discussed. Although social development in South Africa has historically been directed by the apartheid regime, most scholars in the immediate posttransition period imagined that development would quickly transform into an egalitarian, participatory development system. However, conceptual & programmatic difficulties have hampered this transformation. It is concluded that South African scholars must address the relevant definitional & conceptual issues & closely analyze the implementation of the social development approach. 16 References. D. Ryfe

Social Work Education and Training: From Preparing for Apartheid Society to Training for a Developing Democracy

Author: McKendrick, B11 School of Social Work U of the Witwatersrand, Johannesburg

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61442172?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social work education in South Africa began in the 1920s, primarily in response to white poverty. Responses by church, state, & civil society organizations stressed a scientific methodology, college-level training, & a strict focus on the needs of white people. While some nonuniversity social work training was made available to black people, social work remained primarily a white profession. Although social work education was broadened in the 1960s with the creation of new black universities, the white advantage was perpetuated through a number of institutional mechanisms. In 1980, a council for social & associated workers began restructuring the social work field by extending the period of basic education, altering the structure & content of that education, & providing greater regulation of social work students. Even in the postapartheid environment, social workers' dual conception of their role as people- & society-oriented, their desire for professional status, & an abiding respect for the law perpetuated the unequal social work system. Challenges for transforming the institutional & cultural system of social work in the contemporary period are discussed. 25 References. D. Ryfe

NGOs and the Service Delivery Challenge

Author: Patel, L11 Social Development Consultancy, Johannesburg

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61442168?accountid=14667

Abstract: Overviews the impact of the postapartheid transition in South African on nongovernmental organizations (NGOs), drawing on a variety of sources. NGOs have traditionally been responsible for providing services & development programs as part of a wider social development delivery framework. In the postapartheid context, this role has been challenged by several difficulties, including funding crises & a loss of staff to government & industry. The government has met these challenges by instituting mechanisms to promote partnerships with NGOs as representatives of civil society. Recently, NGO representatives have served policy-making functions & have acted in an advisory capacity to governmental agencies. It is suggested that the capacity of NGOs to deliver services efficiently has become the primary criteria for continued donor support. In this context several recommentations are made for increasing the efficiency of NGOs, including the establishment of NGO delivery & funding partnerships. The creation of an NGO database would also assist in supporting partnerships by providing data for planning, evaluation, & monitoring assessments. 17 References. D. Ryfe

Social Stability and the Strategic Relevance of Health and Welfare in South Africa

Author: Van Delft, W11 Dept of Social Work, U of South Africa, Pretoria

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61442162?accountid=14667

Abstract: Considers the crucial role of health & welfare in maintaining the social stability of South Africa in the postapartheid context. It is suggested that, historically, when societies have confronted difficult social problems, they have responded by developing social-ordering mechanisms that empower social regulatory measures to address specific aspects of these problems. Health & welfare represent a crucial aspect of the current challenges facing South Africa. Realities connected to health & welfare include policy statements that reflect a particular ethos of intentions, the concrete health & welfare status of the population, & the ability of the society to respond to these issues. Health & welfare professionals occupy a crucial strategic role in South African society, because they are trained to address these realities. If citizens are not assisted to develop behaviors amenable to healthy & sustainable human development, then health & welfare services will continue to erode, with dramatic consequences for the health & stability of the society as a whole. It is concluded that for health & welfare professionals to perform their role, they must critically assess the thoughts, perceptions, & values that inform their work. 17 References. D. Ryfe

Changing Social Welfare Policy in South Africa

Author: Louw, L R11 School of Social Work U of Cape Town, Cape Town

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61442155?accountid=14667

Abstract: Discusses the process of social welfare policy change in South Africa in the postapartheid period, drawing on a review of policy as it existed prior to 1996. In this earlier period, the social welfare system was characterized by individualism, fragmentation, differentiation, & duplication. The process of reforming this system, begun in 1994, represents the first ever all-inclusive consultative process established in this sector. This process has been designed to achieve a cohesive national social welfare policy framework that achieves both efficiency & equity, based on principles of democracy, equity, nondiscrimination, human rights, sustainability, & partnership. Already this framework has produced significant changes in the social welfare system, including a fundamental shift from individual casework to developmental social welfare, creation of a new funding review mechanism, promotion of wider participation in the system, & greater sensitivity to the role of social security payments in reducing poverty. 27 References. D. Ryfe

Social Welfare in Southern Africa: The Need for Transformation

Author: Kaseke, E11 School Social Work U Zimbabwe, Kopje Harare

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61442539?accountid=14667

Abstract: In suggesting a transformation of social welfare systems in southern African nations, several criticisms are levied: (1) the systems' failure to target the individuals who would most benefit from their services; (2) governments' marginalization of social welfare systems; (3) limited stakeholder participation in social welfare policy; (4) such systems' inclination to be reactive; (5) social welfare's emphasis on the improvement of people's environments, rather than poverty relief; & (6) social welfare professionals' inadequate training. Social welfare systems are encouraged to adopt a more developmental orientation & expand the knowledge base of their professionals. Moreover, social welfare workers are implored to contribute to the creation of sustainable growth levels & become active in social policy. 4 References. J. W. Parker

Social Work in "Rainbow" Nations: Observations on a Troubled Relationship

Author: Bar-On, A A11 Dept Social Work U Botswana, Gaborone

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61442536?accountid=14667

Abstract: The extent to which social workers can pursue multicultural agendas & the availability of multicultural resources to social workers are investigated. Differences in schools of thought regarding the connection between cultural & moral relativism are discussed; whereas culturalists advocate noninterference, universalists support the position that morals transcend culture. It is asserted that a majority of current social workers favor a universalist approach to performing social work. An analysis of Western & African discourses of social work illustrates the discrepancy in each discourse's demand for social intervention, attributed to Western discourse's emphasis on the individual & African discourse's privileging of kinship relations. It is subsequently contended that social workers' rejection of particular cultural practices renders global acceptance of multiculturalism unlikely. It is concluded that social workers must emphasize meeting people's needs as defined by those people. 47 References. Adapted from the source document.

Self-Disclosure and Marital Satisfaction among Couples with Adolescent Children

Author: Greeff, A P1; Le Roux, J1 Dept Sielkunde U Stellenbosch

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61442530?accountid=14667

Abstract: Attempting to determine the relationship between self-disclosure (own & perceived disclosure of the spouse) & marital satisfaction of 31 South African couples with adolescent children, spouses were independently evaluated with the Expression of Emotion Scale (Balswick, J., 1986) & the Roach (A. J., et al, 1981) Marital Satisfaction Scale. Significant positive correlations were found between the following: (1) perceived self-disclosure of spouse & marital satisfaction of husbands & wives, (2) husband's evaluation of own self-disclosure & marital satisfaction, (3) husband's & wife's own evaluations of self-disclosure & perceived disclosure of spouse, (4) own evaluation of self-disclosure & marital satisfaction of partner, & (5) marital satisfaction experienced by each spouse. It was found that the husbands were perceived by their wives to disclose significantly less than wives were perceived by their husbands to disclose. 29 References. Adapted from the source document.

Achieving Balance and Wholeness through Spirituality: A Family Therapy Perspective

Author: Kasiram, M I11 Dept Social Work U Durban-Westville

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61442525?accountid=14667

Abstract: Incorporation of spirituality into family therapy as a means of procuring balance & wholeness is advocated, contending that spirituality functions as a mechanism for the release of stress & a means of advancing self-therapeutic processes. Several methods of applying spirituality to family therapy are discussed: (1) respecting individual articulations of spiritual beliefs; (2) acknowledging the fundamental truths of all religions; (3) employing spiritual readings to gain solace; (4) using prayer & meditation to invoke the intervention of divine beings in people's lives; (5) mapping inconsistencies in belief systems; (6) maintaining that individuals are manifestations of divine beings; & (7) emphasizing the presence of divine beings in all aspects of existence. It is concluded that family therapists must identify the "truths" that obstruct more objective examinations of the factors that affect people's lives. 11 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Experience of Imprisonment among White-Collar Criminals

Author: Gmeiner, A C1; Poppenpoel, M; Marais, L C1 Dept Psigiatriese Verpleegkunde Afrikaanse U

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61442519?accountid=14667

Abstract: Explores how the white-collar criminal experiences admission to prison, based on a qualitative, contextual research study of 5 such criminals, selected by means of purposive sampling. In-depth exploration into the experience of the white-collar criminal was achieved via a phenomenological interview method, yielding data that are subjected to descriptive analysis. Obstacles & facilitative aspects that influence the white-collar criminal's ability to integrate into the prison community are identified. 2 Tables, 12 References. Adapted from the source document.

Case Study of an Adult Survivor of Sexual Molestation

Author: Collins, K J1; Spies, G M1 Dept Social Work U South Africa, Pretoria

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61442514?accountid=14667

Abstract: Presents a case study of a woman's use of particular coping mechanisms to cope with the effects of childhood sexual molestation by her father. An ecosystemic approach was taken to her therapy, without which healing would not have been achieved. The individual's behavior & actions during therapy are explored in relation to the various stages of the therapeutic process, eg, acceptance of molestation, familiarization, & determination to be healed. Five coping mechanisms are identified: (1) increasing self-esteem & personal authority; (2) avoiding the expression of feelings & intimacy, (3) empowering herself through her sexuality, (4) creating an acceptable body image, & (5) providing parental support. Perceptions of the therapeutic process & ecosystemic approach are shared. 1 Figure, 28 References. J. W. Parker

The Relationship between Child and Youth Care and Social Work

Author: Gray, M M A1; Gannon, B1 Dept Social Work U Natal, Durban

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61442508?accountid=14667

Abstract: A transcription of a fictional conversation between two figures, Social Work & Child Care, is presented. The respective responsibilities of child & youth care & social work are differentiated by Child Care; the principal difference is identified as child & youth care workers' direct involvement in the daily lives of at-risk children. Although Social Work complains that social workers should be qualified to perform child & youth care, Child Care offers a historical overview of child & youth care in South Africa to demonstrate that social workers are inadequately trained to provide such care. The practices of South Africa's contemporary child & youth care system are defended. Social Work's suggestion that child & youth care workers require further specialization is repudiated by Child Care. Social Work expresses concern that the growing number of child & youth care workers will marginalize social workers. Social Work & Child Care conclude that additional social workers are needed in contemporary South Africa, & workers from both fields must become more cognizant of each other's responsibilities. 2 Figures, 28 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Function of Social Work in Successful Correctional Supervision

Author: van Staden, S M11 Dept Maatskaplike Werk U Pretoria

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61442502?accountid=14667

Abstract: Suggests an aid for the South African Dept of Correctional Services that can be implemented during presentencing assessments by social workers that may enhance the serving of the sentence & improve the success rate of correctional supervision. Belief Systems as an Obstacle to the Development of Rural Women and the Implications for Social Work Practice

Author: Mafokane11 U North, Sovenga

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61442494?accountid=14667

Abstract: Illustrates how belief systems, in this case, witchcraft, impede rural South African women's development, based on a case study of a woman accused of performing witchcraft in her village. It is contended that contemporary political organizations have used African people's belief systems to increase their popularity & authority. Arguing that rural women require peaceful conditions to initiate social change, social workers are implored to provide counseling to affected families & women, but to acknowledge African belief systems in providing this & other social services. A multidisciplinary approach to social services provision is recommended; specifically, multidisciplinary methods accelerate development & facilitate alleviation of poverty & disease. Social work academics are asked to increase the training of social work students, organize cross-disciplinary conferences to discuss the role of witchcraft in communities, & investigate the relationship between belief in witchcraft & social problems. 16 References. J. W. Parker

The Effects of Chronic Renal Failure on Marital Relationships

Author: Bezuidenhout, F J1; Potgieter, M C1 Dept Sociology U Port Elizabeth

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61443807?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examines the impact of chronic renal failure (CRF) on marital relationships in terms of meeting the psychosocial needs of the ill. Data from 34 CRF patients shows how it affects bonding between the marriage partners, spouse & parent role performance, & decision-making patterns. Adjustment to CRF is directly influenced by the nature & degree of support that patients receive from their marriage partners & family members. 29 References. Adapted from the source document.

Violence against Women in South Africa: An Analysis of Media Coverage

Author: Gray, M M A1; Sathiparsad, R1 Dept Social Work U Natal, Durban 4001 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61443801?accountid=14667

Abstract: Explores violence, particularly against women, as one of the single most important social issues facing social workers in South Africa. While there are centers & advice desks for abused women, their work has been hampered by the lack of community-based resources to help these women & their families. A content analysis of media coverage, Jan-May 1997, reveals a growing impatience with government responses, both from the police & the legal system, & pleas for community action & reformed measures to deal with both perpetrators & survivors of rape & domestic violence. 1 Figure, 20 References. Adapted from the source document.

Food Policy: Managing Drought and the Environment in Botswana

Author: Osei-Hwedie, K11 Dept Social Work U Botswana, Gaborone

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61443793?accountid=14667

Abstract: Botswana is a semi-arid, drought-prone, land-locked country with limited potential for arable agriculture, though the prospects for beef production & wildlife are excellent. It is argued, thus, that social policy relating to agriculture & food production must reconcile national needs & aspirations with the limitations of the natural world, balancing conflicting environmental, socioeconomic, & political concerns. The competition between humans, cattle, & wildlife for limited resources must be taken into account. Botswana's food policies & associated programs must be shaped by environmental conditions, particularly drought. 35 References. Adapted from the source document.

Abortion: A Study of Final-Year Social Work Students' Responses to Abortion-Related Issues

Author: Van Rooyen, C. A. J.11 Dept Social Work U Natal, Durban 4001 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61443785?accountid=14667

Abstract: Discusses the issue of abortion in South Africa with reference to social work, reporting on research that explored the opinions of 70 final-year social work students from two universities in KwaZulu Natal regarding abortion & related issues. It was assumed that social work students' opinions about abortion would stem from a range of beliefs & experiences. However, this was not the case. Their assumptions did not extend beyond the basic issues, reflecting little knowledge of relatively new & complex social-work-related issues surrounding abortion. 1 Table, 3 Figures, 15 References. Adapted from the source document.

Neutrality in the Face of Trauma

Author: Kasiram, M11 Dept Social Work U Durban-Westville, Private Bag X54001 4000 South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61443777?accountid=14667

Abstract: The family therapy unit at the U of Durban-Westville, South Africa, receives numerous referrals from families that face terror & trauma. An enormous challenge to individual & team therapists has been that of maintaining behavioral neutrality, both attitudinally & actively. To deal with the truth behind the trauma has proved to be overwhelming, in many instances, for both families & therapists. Here, an attempt is made to address questions & concerns that encourage team exchange that feed into existing experiences & provide therapeutic guidance. 12 References. Adapted from the source document.

Community-Based (Mental Health) Care: A Justification for Social Work Involvement in Botswana

Author: Moroka, Tirelo11 Dept Social Work U Botswana

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61480518?accountid=14667

Abstract: The deinstitutionalization process in Botswana has resulted in persons with severe & persistent mental illness being treated in the community. Social workers in Botswana are not playing a prominent role in the mental health treatment system, which, among other factors, has resulted in both high relapse rates & persons moving between the hospital & community, despite the integration of mental health in primary health care. Here, the critical role played by social workers in community-based care is addressed, & it is contended that their involvement rather than exclusion would result in a reduction in the "revolving door syndrome" & "falling between the cracks." This involvement is also seen as justified by social work's historical role & professional knowledge & practice base, which will enhance the multidisciplinary focus in the prevention of mental illness & promotion of mental health at the community level. 50 References. Adapted from the source document.

Community Practice: Opportunities for Community Building

Author: Green, S11 Dept Social Work U Stellenbosch

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61440657?accountid=14667

Abstract: Argues that social work must focus on community practices rather than individual-based therapy to address structural problems associated with low-income families, using semistructured interview data from 94 adult members of a feeding project in Stellenbosch, South Africa. Demographic data & information on literacy, employment, usage of the project's resources, perceived social problems in the community, & external support networks (ie, household family members, informal resources outside the family, & professional community resources) were gathered. Results confirm the need to increase the community's capacity to provide a basic safety net for families & children; implications for social work practitioners are addressed, & possible programs to empower & build communities are illustrated with examples. 19 References. S. Paul

Service Rendering to the Female Adult Survivor of Child Sexual Abuse

Author: Spies, G M1; O'Neil, M A; Collins, K J1 U South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61480495?accountid=14667

Abstract: Discusses the effects of child sexual abuse on adult survivors & aspects of the healing process. It is argued that sexual abuse may significantly influence children's sense of self & affect their development. Effects in the areas of self-esteem & personal power, the expression of emotions, intimacy, sexuality, body awareness, & childbearing & parenting are found pervasive; however, it is also asserted that not all effects need to be present in each individual victim. Seven phases of the healing process, patterned spirally rather than linearly, are distinguished: (1) believing it happened & still has effects, (2) the emergency stage, in which the truth about the abuse takes shape, (3) disclosure about what happened, (4) denial, (5) anger toward the perpetrator, (6) grieving for the losses caused by the abuse, & (7) resolution to move on. It is stressed that the healing process is unpredictable & does not conform to preset timetables. 7 References. Adapted from the source document.

Professional Challenges for South African Social Workers: Response to Recent Political Changes

Author: Ntusi, T M11 Dept Social Work U Transkei, Umtata

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61480478?accountid=14667

Abstract: Challenges for social work practitioners in postapartheid South Africa are outlined. Involvement in national social policy making is deemed imperative, arguing that the present government's acknowledgment of the skills & insights provided by the social work profession obligates social workers to contribute to policy development & to encourage attitudes of participatory democracy rather than civil disobedience among their clienteles. Subsequently, it is asserted that social workers must play an active role in the redefinition of "disadvantage." Although the shift in focus from individual problems toward community problems is deemed encouraging, it is contended that disadvantage is still primarily related to material poverty, whereas it should include ecological & broader environmental issues (eg, access to clean water) as well. The need to institutionalize welfare, so it is accessible to all population groups rather than as a limited residual provision, is addressed. Implications for social work education are addressed, eg, the teaching of policy planning & implementation skills, introduction to special fields (eg, the elderly), emphasis on cultural & ethnic diversity, & training in policy practice as a method of intervention. 15 References. S. Paul

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Professional+Challenges+for+South+African+Social+Workers%3A+Response+to+Recent+Political+Changes&amp;rft.au=Ntusi%2C+T+M&amp;rft.aulast=Ntusi&amp;rft.aufirst=T&amp;rft.date=1998-12-01&amp;rft.volume=34&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=380&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378054&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The Content and Evaluation of a Bereavement Counselling Programme for Parents after the Death of a Child

Author: Strydom, H1; Fourie, J1 Dept Social Work Potchefstroom U Christian Higher Education

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61440651?accountid=14667

Abstract: Focuses on the development of a bereavement-counseling program for parents who have lost a child through death. From an original needs assessment of 76 bereaved parents, 9 were selected for inclusion in the group work program. A further needs assessment was done to ascertain these parents' specific needs. The aim of the study, the research design & procedures followed, as well as the definition of certain terms are outlined. Aspects of the planning of the program in group context are explained. Quantitative & qualitative evaluations of the program were conducted via questionnaires. 1 Table, 2 Figures, 18 References. Adapted from the source document.

Marital or Relationship Stressors and Parents' Worries about Children in the Community of Kayamandi, Stellenbosch

Author: Boshoff, S C1; Van der Merwe, A. P.; Kotze, H F; Van Rooyen, J W1 Centre Student Counselling U Stellenbosch

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61440646?accountid=14667

Abstract: Investigates the frequency of selected marital or relationship stressors as well as the worries that parents have about children in the township community of Kayamandi in Stellenbosch, South Africa, using survey data from a stratified sample of 240 residents, ages 18-64. Results revealed the social roots of many problems & the subsequent need for a systems approach to family enrichment. It is recommended that family & mental health practitioners should, inter alia, assist troubled families to contextualize their problems. Practitioners should also ensure that remedial & preventive programs are being designed & implemented to act synergistically with broader reconstruction & development efforts. 3 Tables, 11 References. Adapted from the source document.

Home Visits: An Integral Part of Family Preservation Services

Author: Kruger, S11 Dept Maatskaplike Werk U Stellenbosch

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61480463?accountid=14667

Abstract: Discusses the use of home visits in family work in South Africa, using data from 111 social workers in West Cape Province. The shift from group-oriented to individual-oriented social work practices is historically related to the decrease in visits to the client's family home. It is observed that home visits, especially for family assessment, are presently being reinstated, primarily in social work concerning children & seniors. The advantages of home visits (eg, better assessment of the client's environment & interaction with family members) are enumerated, & the special skills & strategies the social worker needs for home visits (ie, diplomatic & assertive behavior, organizing skills, contract making, planning, & adaptability) are discussed. Common factors that inhibit home visits (eg, time pressure, confidentiality, & safety problems) are identified; it is asserted that social work agencies must overcome these problems to provide their clients with optimal assessment options &, thus, care. 1 Table, 1 Figure, 21 References. S. Paul

Preparing Social Work Students for a Corrupt Work Environment

Author: Brown, M J11 Dept Social Work U Transkei, Umtata

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61480447?accountid=14667

Abstract: The high occurrence of corruption among social workers in South Africa is addressed, focusing on the situation in Transkei, a former independent homeland that is now part of Eastern Cape province. Common corruption strategies are described, eg, bribery & failure to notify government agencies of deaths. It is noted that the local Dept of Welfare tends to have an indulgent attitude toward corruption, & the local people, including social workers, have traditionally viewed corruption as an adequate way to fleece the unpopular apartheid government. Ways for new social workers to deal with corrupt colleagues & to refuse to participate in corrupt practices are outlined, arguing that the vulnerability of young workers' professional positions may be counterbalanced by the early involvement of an attorney. Implications for social work education are discussed. 3 References. S. Paul

The Use of Disciplinary and Escapism Methods for Coping with the Behavioural Problems of a Child Suffering from Tourette Syndrome

Author: Davis, L11 Dept of Criminology at the U of Pretoria, Pretoria

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61668340?accountid=14667

Abstract: Data obtained over a 3-year period of participation in a support group for parents of children with Tourette syndrome are drawn on to explore coping, specifically, the use of disciplinary & escapism strategies, by 15 of these parents. Analysis indicates that a majority of respondents (Rs) believed that rewarding good behavior served little purpose; Rs used a variety of punishments (eg, withdrawing certain privileges); no R enforced rigid disciplinary regulations; & corporal punishment was deemed ineffective. Additional strategies Rs used to deal with their children's behavior included withdrawing during arguments, accepting responsibility for arguments, confronting the sufferer on a regular basis, & participating in extramural activities. All Rs expressed concern regarding the appropriateness of their disciplinary & escapism strategies; however, understanding the effectiveness of such strategies is important for both parents & social workers. 1 Figure, 7 References. J. W. Parker

Forensic Social Work: With Special Reference to the Forensic Social Work Service of the SAPS

Author: Stutterheim, E1; Weyers, M L1 Social Work Service of the South African Police Service (SAPS), Pretoria

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61650018?accountid=14667

Abstract: The nature & implementation of forensic social work in contemporary South Africa are studied in terms of four primary functions: (1) systematically evaluating individuals involved in criminal proceedings & presenting the findings to judicial authorities; (2) providing expert testimony in judicial proceedings; (3) examining civil cases & presenting the findings in court; & (4) offering recommendations to judicial authorities regarding sentencing or court orders. An overview of forensic social work in the South African Police Service (SAPS) discusses studies that prompted the establishment of the discipline & its implementation process. It is concluded that social workers require additional training in providing expert testimony & an improved service delivery system. 1 Table, 39 References. J. W. Parker

Healing Families When Nations Crumble

Author: Kasiram, M I11 Dept of Social Work at the U of Durban-Westville, Durban

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61644935?accountid=14667

Abstract: Contends that the social, political, & economic turmoil in contemporary South Africa requires family therapists to adopt multisystemic approaches. Specific effects of economic & political change & increased crime & violence on families are addressed, & several intervention strategies for family therapists are presented: (1) implementing macro-, meso-, & microstrategies; (2) perceiving therapist-family relations differently; (3) addressing families' spiritual systems; (4) periodically withdrawing from the therapy environment to evaluate oneself; (5) utilizing therapeutic teams comprising various professionals; (6) emphasizing solution-focused work; & (7) encouraging families to celebrate change. It is concluded that South African family therapists must alter their attitudes toward working with professionals from other disciplines. 19 References. J. W. Parker

The Matrix of Social Work Practice: Implications for the Transformation of Social Work Education

Author: Green, S11 Dept of Social Work at the U of Stellenbosch, Stellenbosch

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61638167?accountid=14667

Abstract: The requirements for instructional programs for social work education & the utility of the developmental research model in creating such programs in South Africa are explored. An outcome-based education model that emphasizes assessment, planning, implementation, & reflection is recommended. The various phases included in the model's development are reviewed, along with the material conditions & operational steps of the analysis, development, & evaluation phases. Social work educators are urged to recognize the practical aspects of social work, engage in more critical thinking about social work education, & refrain from conflating theory with empirical data. It is concluded that social work educators must collaborate, share research findings, & provide support for other professionals. 2 Figures, 30 References. J. W. Parker

Indigenisation of a School Social Work Model for Rural Communities in South Africa

Author: Mabetoa, M11 Dept of Welfare & Population Development

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61647991?accountid=14667

Abstract: It is asserted that the education of South African children in rural communities is hindered by poor social & economic conditions; consequently, an indigenized school social work model is advocated to expand education to rural communities. Several factors (eg, social welfare policy, social work practice approaches, & community needs) considered in the school-community-pupil relations model require reconsideration for the indigenized model. The findings from an experimental study involving 120 students from two rural schools that implemented the indigenized model are discussed. Three principal aspects of the indigenized model are identified: (1) The school is envisioned as the center of community development. (2) Change in the community, school, & students is encouraged. (3) Different approaches to social, economic, & political issues are utilized. It is concluded that the indigenized model has effected several educational benefits in the experimental institutions & has implications for improving teaching & learning conditions. 1 Table, 2 Figures, 24 References. J. W. Parker

Street Children: A Working Definition?

Author: Veeran, D L11 Dept of Social Work at the U of Natal, Durban

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61619779?accountid=14667

Abstract: Argues that a working definition of street children is needed to determine which factors contribute to this problem. The shortcomings of definitions of street children offered by nongovernmental organizations, UNICEF, & various researchers are identified; nonetheless, it is noted that several scholars have differentiated between "children on the street" & "children of the street." Relevant literature is reviewed to determine the characteristics of the different categories of street children, whether they prefer to be called "homeless" or "street children," & the multiple push/pull factors that contribute to children's decisions to leave their homes. It is concluded that a holistic approach to the street children problem is ultimately required. 1 Table, 33 References. J. W. Parker
