The Mourning Experience of Parents after the Death of a Child

Author: Strydom, H1; Fourie, J1 Dept of Social Work at the Potchefstroom U for Christian Higher Education, Potchefstroom

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61628743?accountid=14667

Abstract: Following a review of the relevant literature, quantitative & qualitative data were obtained during structured interviews with 76 South African parents whose children had died to explore factors contributing to the intensity of parents' mourning experiences. Findings regarding the effects of cause of death, duration of illness, parents' & child's age at child's death, involved parent's & child's sex, parent's marital relationship status, educational achievement of the parent, parent's occupation, the presence of previous losses, religion, & presence at child's death are presented. The effects of who notified the parents of their child's death, & how, on bereavement intensity are also considered. Results demonstrate the tendency of bereaved parents to withdraw from society, the role of the community in the mourning process, & the need for parents to contact others with similar experiences. Although most participants reported that the intensity of mourning decreased over time, the effects of the child's death were profound. 40 References. Adapted from the source document.

Writing for a Journal: Blood, Sweat, and Tears

Author: Gray, M M A11 Dept of Social Work at the U of Natal, Durban

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61645792?accountid=14667

Abstract: Several recommendations for social workers seeking to publish their work in scholarly journals are offered, drawing on personal experience reviewing such submissions. The common assumption that only the author is interested in his or her research is repudiated. Anne Lamott's (1995) approach to writing & revising papers for publication is discussed. The issue of whether narrative styles are appropriate for empirical research papers is addressed, & various stylistic elements are summarized. The acceptance & rejection rates of four journals that publish social work empirical research are posted. 3 Figures, 2 References. J. W. Parker

Learning Needs in Supervision

Author: Makondo, M G1; Van der Westhuizen, C. H. J.1 Dept of Social Work at the U of Pretoria, Pretoria

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61671123?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social workers (N = 50) integrated into the South African National Defense Force (SANDF) completed field surveys to determine their learning needs & expectations about the educational function of supervision. The principal finding was that the participants were more accustomed to academic supervision than work-oriented supervision. Several factors that limited participants' interaction & expectations about supervision are identified: (1) The military refused to accept client confidentiality. (2) Social workers lacked guidance in producing reports & financing programs. (3) Social workers heavily outnumbered supervisors. (4) There were limited job opportunities. (5) Supervisors prevented social workers from becoming autonomous. Recommendations for improving supervision in the SANDF are offered. 12 References. J. W. Parker

Transforming Social Work Education in South Africa: A Contextual and Empowerment Issue

Author: Lombard, A11 Dept Social Work, U Pretoria, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61619704?accountid=14667

Abstract: Inspired by comments about the education of South African social work practitioners in the 1997 Ministry of Welfare & Population Development policy document, "White Paper for Social Welfare," it is proposed that social work training should focus on contextualized issues of social development. Adaptation of the theoretical framework of social development implies that all social work is "developmental social work" &, in terms of social welfare, transcends the traditional dichotomy between residual & institutional approaches to welfare. Subsequently, national & international contexts for developmental social work are discussed, & possibilities to operationalize contextualized developmental social work on a variety of intervention levels & with different skills, strategies, & categories of social workers are indicated. Implications for social work education include training aimed at different theoretical expertise levels for different categories of workers & curricular reforms aimed at familiarizing students with various facets of social developmental work in an environment that integrates theoretical notions & social work practice. 18 References. S. Paul

The Community Worker and Language Constructivism in the Needs Assessment Phase

Author: Van der Berg, C1; Collins, K; O'Neil, M A1 Dept Maatskaplike Werk, U South Africa, Pretoria

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61624931?accountid=14667

Abstract: Following a discussion about the importance of open & clear dialogical communication between social workers & the communities in which they work, especially in the needs assessment phase of community development, the usefulness of language constructivism in the social work context is addressed. Language constructivism is based on the premise that people construct their realities through language; communicative interaction is essential in the process of reframing these realities & thus solving perceived problems. In this communicative reframing process, the community worker is viewed as the facilitator of communication. Elements of conversation strategies for community workers assessing community needs with & for the clients are presented, & five theoretical principles, drawn from family therapy experiences & adapted to the community work context, are identified: (1) Social organization is defined by speech. (2) Meaning is constructed socially & intersubjectively. (3) The therapeutic system attempts to identify & subsequently solve problems. (4) Change is the creation of new meaning through dialogue. (5) The therapist functions as a master conversation artist in this process. 21 References.

The Nature and Application of Social Marketing: A Community Work Perspective

Author: Weyers, M L11 Dept Social Work, Potchesfstroom U CHE, Transvaal, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61634931?accountid=14667

Abstract: The concept of social marketing is explained, & the benefits of social marketing in community work in South Africa are discussed. Four components of social marketing are distinguished, ie, product, promotion, place, & price; a distinction is also made between the public relations approach, which focuses on communication to facilitate relations between an organization & the public, & the marketing approach, which states that social causes & services should be marketed just as are products in the for-profit industry. Following A. Lombard, M. L. Weyers, & J. H. Schoeman (1991), six characteristic variables (eg, basic perception of the nature of the community & typical goals that will be pursued) with which to conceptualize a practice model for social marketing are described. Considerations as to when & how to use social marketing are presented, & how social marketing can be applied in South Africa (eg, marketing special events) is explored. 1 Table, 29 References. S. Paul

The Role Played by the Family as a Support System for the Elderly and the Challenges of Caregiving

Author: Mokone, J M11 Dept Social Work, U North, Sovenga, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61641560?accountid=14667

Abstract: The role of the family in caring for the elderly in South Africa is addressed. It is argued that the common idea that black families are usually able & willing to take care of their elderly is untrue, especially in urban environments; yet, because of this stereotype, insufficient services are provided to this large population sector. Findings from several studies (eg, Choi, N. G., 1996) on caregiving to the elderly by family members are reviewed, & the particular challenges associated with black elderly in North Province described. To ease the burden on informal caregivers without forcing clients to be institutionalized, several intervention approaches are identified, including the provision of part-time home health care services, caregiver support programs, respite care, & day care & luncheon clubs. 12 References. S. Paul

Social Work in the New South Africa: Which Way for Justice and Development?

Author: Brown, H Ferguson1; Partab, R1 Dept Social Work, U Transkei, Unitra, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61614231?accountid=14667

Abstract: To establish the extent to which social work agencies in South Africa use the new paradigm of the social development approach to fight for justice & against social inequality & abuses of power, a study was conducted among six governmental & 15 nongovernmental agencies in different parts of the country. Telephone questionnaire data were used to examine agencies' activities on the micro- (with individuals & families), mezzo- (with groups & neighborhoods), & macro- (with the wider community & the state) levels. It was found that, although most agencies do some development & justice work, especially on the mezzolevel, most resources go toward counseling, group work, & therapeutic practice. Especially the macrolevel is considered underrepresented, particularly in governmental agencies; strategies to improve the situation (eg, more focus on social action & policy analysis) are proposed. 3 Tables, 28 References. Adapted from the source document.

Perception of Mental Illness amongst Black Communities

Author: Mojalefa, S R1; Van Staden, S M1 c/o Van Staden -- Dept Social Work, U Pretoria, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61608089?accountid=14667

Abstract: To ascertain how mental illness is perceived in Northern Sotho-, Ndebele-, or Zulu-speaking black communities in Southern Lebowa (South Africa), interviews were conducted with psychiatric patients, their key relatives & employers, traditional doctors & faith healers, & community psychiatric nurses (total N = 57). Common beliefs about the source of mental illness are described, based on literature on the subject (eg, Cheetham, R. S. W., & Cheetham, R. J., 1976) as well as personal experiences, & main aspects of the local beliefs (eg, the formulation of tokolosi by a witch) are explained. Findings show that 90+% of respondents (excepting psychiatric nurses) believe that mental illness, especially mafufunyane (comparable to schizophrenia/psychosis), is caused by witchcraft; treatment by traditional & faith healers was therefore usually preferred. Suggestions for improving the treatment of mental illness in the area include cooperation between medical & traditional doctors & the organization of conferences & lectures in which different approaches are discussed. 15 References. Adapted from the source document.

Drug Abuse amongst High School Pupils

Author: Terblanche, S S1; Venter, D1 Dept Social Work, U Port Elizabeth, Cape Province, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61483649?accountid=14667

Abstract: To determine which personal, social, & environmental factors contribute most to drug (including alcohol & nicotine) (ab)use among adolescents in South Africa, a combined qualitative & quantitative study was conducted among 410 high school students, ages 12-23, in northern Port Elizabeth, where drug abuse is relatively common. Subjects (Ss) completed a questionnaire incorporating responses to a focus group interview with representatives of six high schools in the same area; it was found that loneliness & boredom were the most important personal reasons for drug abuse, whereas availability of drugs in the neighborhood was the main social factor. Alcohol & nicotine were abused (used 3+ times a week or binged on weekends) by some 15% of Ss, & 7% used illegal drugs. A statistically significant correlation between satisfaction with one's family & absence of drug abuse was observed. Correlations between drug abuse on the one hand, & native language (English or Afrikaans) & grade level on the other, are also indicated. 12 Tables, 16 References. Adapted from the source document.

The "Environment" in Developmental Social Work and Social Work Education

Author: Van Rooyen, C. A. J. C.11 Office Community Outreach/Service Learning, Faculty Community & Development Disciplines, U Natal, Durban, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61595183?accountid=14667

Abstract: It is argued that South African social work must reconceptualize the notion of "environment" to validate the social development paradigm central in recent social policy. The social sciences have traditionally defined environment in terms of interpersonal & institutional interactions, or in an anthropocentric (the person in the environment) way, focusing on "elitist" topics such as conservation & wilderness preservation; a more holistic & inclusive approach that views the environment as all components of the physical (natural) & social (built) life space that impact those who live in it is deemed more appropriate. In such a notion, the concept of sustainability, ie, a system's ability to maintain itself, & the related notion of sustainable development are central. For social work, implications include a reconceptualization of the notion of the client system in which the total life space of that system is incorporated & sustainable development is a central issue at all times. Some examples are provided. The need to include broad environmental issues in social work education is also addressed. Adapted from the source document.

Youth Unemployment -- A Study in an Informal Settlement in Kwazulu Natal

Author: Ransom, Brenda L1; Poswa, Thokozani; Van Rooyen, Colin A. J.1 c/o Van Rooyen -- Dept Social Work, U Natal, Durban, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61664228?accountid=14667

Abstract: Data obtained via semistructured interviews & participatory techniques from a sample of unemployed, young adult, non-heads of household (N = 33 females & 36 males, ages 15-35) in Bhambayi (KwaZulu Natal), an informal settlement in the Durban area, are drawn on to describe the needs & resources of the large unemployed youth population in South Africa. Typical respondent profiles are sketched; household composition, educational careers, employment history, & personal perceptions of unemployment are described. It is concluded that common Western perceptions of the status of young adults cannot be applied to the context of Bhambayi, where children are left with adult responsibilities at a relatively early age. Young adults in settlements such as Bhambayi need structural help to develop the numerous, albeit informally acquired, resources available to them. 32 References. S. Paul

Entering the Developmental Welfare Arena: Foundation Field Practice for Social Work Students

Author: Woods, Ronald11 School Social Work, U Witwatersrand, Johannesburg, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61651768?accountid=14667

Abstract: Describes a field instruction program for 1st-year social work students at U of the Witwatersrand in Johannesburg, highlighting ways that social work education & practice can relate to the sociopolitical realities of postapartheid South Africa while adhering to historical & international principles of the discipline. The field instruction program is organized according to four main principles: (1) consolidating students' passion for social justice, (2) helping students focus on people's strengths, (3) developing a social work sensibility, & (4) developing a research attitude & skills. Examples of activities that incorporate these principles are provided, accompanying theoretical courses & students' evaluations of the program are presented, & recommendations for future developments are made. 1 Figure, 23 References. S. Paul

The Development of Policy Guidelines for Shelters in Response to the Needs of Street Children

Author: Veeran, D L11 Dept Social Work, U Natal, Durban, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61635810?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examines extant South African policies concerning street children, highlighting their effects on service delivery & program implementation. Qualitative data are offered from a survey of direct service organizations, key informants, & street children (total N = 23) in Durban. It is asserted that service organizations are hampered by legislative, financial, organizational, & administrative factors, & more insight in & acceptance of street children's motivations & plans is needed to improve service delivery. More coordination on micro-, mezzo-, & macrolevels is deemed essential; policy guidelines for each level are formulated. Existing projects in South America (the Bosconia Project) & the Philippines (Lingap Centres) are commended as state-funded programs that respond to children's specific needs. 4 Tables, 1 Figure, 36 References. S. Paul

Directions from the East? Reflections on a Visit to Asian Social Work Training Institutions

Author: Drower, Sandra J11 School Social Work, U Witwatersrand, Johannesburg, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61618046?accountid=14667

Abstract: Argues that South Africa is, in many respects, a developing country & should, therefore, look at other (postcolonial) developing countries rather than at examples in the industrialized Western world for the (re)formulation of its social work policies & (training) practices. The developmental community work conducted in social work educational centers in Manila (Philippines); Mumbai (India); Penang (Malaysia); & Jakarta (Indonesia) is described & related to South African realities. Although social & organizational circumstances at these four centers differ greatly & not all practices can be easily transferred, seven important principles for the successful establishment of developmental social work in South Africa are derived from the Asian examples: (1) using the community as point of departure for intervention, (2) developing an Afrocentric social work paradigm, (3) guarding against the "academization" of social work, (4) redefining the concept of the professional social worker & its accompanying notions of status, (5) emphasizing people's strengths & resources, (6) developing professional structures, & (7) scrupulously observing the effects of policy changes on (tertiary-level) training programs. 15 References. S. Paul

Operationalising Developmental Social Work: The Implementation of an HIV/AIDS Project

Author: Sewpaul, Vishanthie1; Rollins, Nigel1 Dept Social Work, U Natal, Durban, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61633808?accountid=14667

Abstract: The implementation of an HIV/AIDS (human immunodeficiency virus/acquired immune deficiency syndrome) project in a hospital in Durban, South Africa, is described, with special attention to the social-developmental principles on which the project is based. The project focuses on establishing & consolidating self-help groups & community support networks for HIV-positive (HIV+) mothers & their HIV+ babies; a 13-person group is now well-established & claims to have achieved the creation of a peer support network, training workshops for members, AIDS education & awareness programs, preparation for home-based care, advocacy & lobby functions, a financial baby adoption project, skills training & income generation, student training, & participatory research aims. Main obstacles encountered by the group's mothers, primarily in relationships with male partners, are also described. 30 References. S. Paul

Assertiveness Training for the Prisoner

Author: Van Staden, S M1; Greyling, P1 Dept Maatskaplike Werk, U Pretoria, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61613380?accountid=14667

Abstract: Arguing that many behavioral problems among prisoners are related to poor interpersonal & communicative skills that may be caused by underassertiveness, an experiment was conducted among 40 white male prisoners in the Zonderwater Medium A prison in South Africa. Experimental subjects (Ss) participated in eight 3-hour assertiveness training workshop sessions; the control group received no training. Results were encouraging: on the Rathus Assertiveness Schedule & the Assertion Inventory, experimental Ss indicated that their assertiveness had increased significantly. Limitations of the study are discussed & recommendations made for future research & practice. 3 Figures, 26 References. S. Paul

Conducting Research with Street Children in South Africa: Practical Hints for Researchers

Author: Beams, J1; Wait, J1 Dept Psychology, U Stellenbosch, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61618107?accountid=14667

Abstract: Based on an ongoing qualitative research project among street children in South Africa, recommendations for researchers attempting to study street children are formulated. Accurately selecting literature from a large body of publications, establishing criteria & a definition for the study group, gaining access to the subjects, gaining the trust & cooperation of local authorities & the community, cooperating with police, making optimal use of weather circumstances, anticipating & adequately reacting to the children's behavior, & minimizing influence of personal factors are discussed. It is stressed throughout that working with street children may result in relatively little reliable input & a host of problems to deal with, thus necessitating a guilt-free & optimistic attitude. 28 References. S. Paul

Preparing Social Work Students for a Corrupt Work Environment

Author: Brown, M J11 U Transkei, Umtata

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61657034?accountid=14667

Abstract: Noting that corruption is a very real & common occurrence among social workers in Transkei & other parts of South Africa, the need to prepare social work students for a corrupt work environment is addressed. Although it is acknowledged that corruption may occur on an individual basis, it is stressed that most social work corruption involves teams or whole departments. Main modes of corruptive operations are identified (ie, creating fictitious applicants, requiring bribes for application processing, blackmailing illegal fund recipients, ignoring formal death notifications, delaying transfer of funds, & transferring only partial payments to recipients), & ways in which new social workers become involved in corrupt operations are described. 3 References. Adapted from the source document.

Child Abuse and Neglect: Social Work Experience at Tygerberg Hospital

Author: Louw, Helene M1; Van Schalkwyk, Hester J. S.; Barnes, Joe M; Dhansay, Sayeeda; Schaaf, H Simon1 Dept Social Work, Tygerberg Hospital, Cape Province, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61660120?accountid=14667

Abstract: Describes the social work experience in a tertiary care hospital in response to the greater awareness of child abuse & the importance of a central register for every institution or district managing cases of child abuse. Survey data from the comprehensive register of all suspected cases of abuse in children under age 18 & cases of severe malnutrition kept at the Social Work Dept at Tygerberg Hospital (TBH) in the Western Cape Province, South Africa, 1994/95, show that 586 children with suspected child abuse were referred; of these, 246 (42%) were evaluated for child sexual abuse, 213 (36%) for physical abuse, & 127 (22%) for severe malnutrition & neglect. Social workers from TBH were involved for a median duration of 1-2 months for physically abused & malnourished children & 2-3 months for sexual abuse cases. A total of 5,545 hours were spent on interviews, arrangements for child safety, completing notification & referral reports, & preparing evidence for court & preparing children for court proceedings during this period. The magnitude of serious child abuse is extensive & more than the present infrastructure can handle. More social workers functioning in well-trained & supervised teams & placed suitably in the service network, notably in the outlying areas, are urgently needed. 7 Tables, 9 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Child+Abuse+and+Neglect%3A+Social+Work+Experience+at+Tygerberg+Hospital&amp;rft.au=Louw%2C+Helene+M%3BVan+Schalkwyk%2C+Hester+J.+S.%3BBarnes%2C+Joe+M%3BDhansay%2C+Sayeeda%3BSchaaf%2C+H+Simon&amp;rft.aulast=Louw&amp;rft.aufirst=Helene&amp;rft.date=1999-10-01&amp;rft.volume=35&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=301&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378054&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Social Welfare Policy Practice: Influences, Perspectives, Approaches

Author: Weekes, M S11 Dept Social Work, U Stellenbosch, Cape Province, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61663762?accountid=14667

Abstract: Demonstrates the influence of social theories & philosophies & perspectives on social policy, & describes the variety of decision-making models that can be used. In addition, three approaches to social policy practice are compared to identify the one most relevant to policy practice in developing societies. Use of a policy model approach to policy practice in South Africa is advocated in light of the apparent need for a comprehensive rational decision-making basis & its usefulness as a tool for comparative social policy research. 2 Figures, 21 References. Adapted from the source document.

On the Raising of Emotional Consciousness in Children

Author: Venter, E H1; Schoeman, J P1 Dept Maatskaplike, U Pretoria, Brooklyn, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61626526?accountid=14667

Abstract: Painful experiences in childhood often lead to emotional numbness in the interest of self-protection, indicating that emotional functioning is occurring on a subverbal level &, hence, is a healthy, productive process that implies emotional empathy. The emotional link between parents & children allows parents to read their children's emotions, which exist on five levels of functioning integral to successful emotional development: raising of consciousness, correlating emotional development & intimacy, empathy & self-reflection, facilitation of identification & verbalization of childhood emotions, & establishment of boundaries. 1 Table, 2 Figures, 20 References. A. Cohen-Siegel

The Effective Utilisation of Volunteers

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61660159?accountid=14667

Abstract: Explores the effective utilization of volunteers in hospices, drawing on questionnaire data from 53 such volunteers to ascertain the who, why, & how of volunteer participation. Healing the Healer

Author: Kasiram, M I11 Dept Social Work, U Durban-Westville, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61653718?accountid=14667

Abstract: Discusses occupational stress in social work in postapartheid South Africa. Macro- & mesolevel stressors are delineated, along with stress manifestations, eg, lack of motivation, eating disorders, & substance abuse. Suggestions for reducing social worker stress are offered, eg, honest appraisal, eating right, & positive thinking. 20 References. A. Cohen-Siegel.

The Effect of Marital Violence on Children in Their Middle Childhood Years

Author: Strydom, C1; Prinsloo, C E1 Dept Maatskaplike Werk, U Pretoria, Brooklyn, South Afrika

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61615339?accountid=14667

Abstract: In looking at the effect of marital violence on children, especially children in their middle childhood years, examined is the use of play therapy techniques in outcome assessments. This exploratory & descriptive research method, strongly empirically based, is a good method for determining the effects of violence. Approaches include systems theory acknowledging the role of the mother, father (actor), & child. Also discussed are the effects of marital violence on the physical, emotional, social, moral, & cognitive development of the child. Forms of Gestalt therapy utilized in treating the violence-prone family include holism, homeostasis, contact boundaries, figure-background, consciousness, here-&-now therapy, & polarities. 27 References. A. Cohen-Siegel

Crime Prevention in Schools: A Multi-Disciplinary Intervention Research Project

Author: Gray, M M A11 Dept Social Work, U Newcastle, New South Wales, Australia

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61653757?accountid=14667

Abstract: Describes the Crime Prevention in School Project, which brings together a multidisciplinary group of academics & researchers to develop & implement an intervention research model through direct services, organizational networking, & policy advocacy & research. The academics are drawn from a newly formed Faculty of Community & Development Disciplines at the U of Natal in Durban, South Africa, that comprises professional & academic disciplines such as psychology, anthropology, social work, architecture, town planning, adult education, education, nursing, & development studies. The research project forms part of a broader initiative to introduce service learning into the university curriculum. Adapted form the source document.

The Marketing Challenges of Non-Profit Organizations Involved in the Provision of Social Services

Author: Terblanche, N S11 Dept Business Management, U Stellenbosch, Cape Province, South Afrika

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61639074?accountid=14667

Abstract: Nonprofit organizations exist at the margins of the market economy, & the changing world requires nonprofits to start thinking commercially; to ensure their continued survival, they must start marketing themselves. Factors leading to the adoption of marketing techniques in nonprofits include increasing privatization, decreased support, increased competition, increasing numbers, & few tax incentives. The marketing task of the nonprofit is twofold: it must attract volunteers & donors. Commonsense marketing techniques include thanking donors quickly, offering welcome packages, setting up hotlines, & holding special events. 1 Figure, 1 Chart, 26 References. A. Cohen-Siegel

Author: Doran, Lorraine11 Child Welfare Society, Wynberg, Cape Town, South Africa

Abstract: An overview of the Eye of the Child (Isolabantwana) community-based child protection program in South Africa is presented, discussing its conceptual bases & process. The Welfare Function of the South African Government before and after Apartheid

Author: Van Eeden, E S; Ryke, E H; De Necker, I. C. M.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61583339?accountid=14667

Abstract: It is argued that the 1994 South African government altered the welfare service of the country, following an ideology that favored social developmental lines & differed greatly in its distribution of welfare from the way welfare was distributed in the past. It is shown that during apartheid, different governmental departments handled the distribution of welfare services to different races, with white welfare recipients getting more aid than members of black, colored, or Indian groups. Current policies are held to reverse these patterns, with previously disadvantaged groups becoming the targets of increased aid. 1 Table. D. Wiebel

The Inner-City Street Child: A Profile of the Dilemma and Some Guidelines

Author: Smit, G1; Liebenberg, L1 Dept Educational Psychology & Specialized Education, U Stellenbosch, Cape Province, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61626927?accountid=14667

Abstract: Research conducted over a 4-month period in Cape Town, South Africa, recording various incidents with street children (under age 18) is used to identify & determine possible means of improving the problems associated with this population, eg, street dynamics, families, & education. The use of street workers, coordinated by trained teams or individual social workers, that are familiar with the community services available in the area & can serve as a link between children & the services, is recommended. Modeled after Santiago, Chile, a system of removing children from the street & holding them in special facilities until their parents or schools come for them is also suggested. 12 References. D. A Social Constructionist Approach to Social Work Education in South Africa: Some Practical Considerations

Author: Simpson, B11 Dept Social Work, U Natal, Durban, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61657422?accountid=14667

Abstract: Though a belief in the scientific method as the only valid approach to knowledge has dominated Western thinking & significantly influenced the rest of the world, the concept of a single source of truth or understanding is increasingly being questioned. Social work practitioners complain that much social work theory is irrelevant as they are constantly faced with a lack of certainty, multiple perspectives, & diversity. How should social work education respond to this? It is suggested here that social constructionism provides an attractive alternative to the scientific paradigm. After placing the relationship between social work education & the scientific method in its historical context, an overview is provided of social constructionism. The application of social constructionism to educational aims, teaching methods, & choice of syllabus, as well as the challenges that this presents, is discussed, with specific reference to the South African case. It is argued that such an approach would help students to develop an appreciation of & an ability to deal sensitively with the complexities of human problems. 24 References. Adapted from the source document.

Three Communities' Knowledge, Attitudes and Behaviour regarding Suicide

Author: Engelbrecht, M C1; Van Vuuren, S. J. E. J.1 Centre Health Systems Research & Development, UOFS, Bloemfontein, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61652525?accountid=14667

Abstract: Amid social & political change & a corresponding increase in the suicide rate in South Africa, explored here are knowledge, attitudes, & behavior regarding suicide among 200 African & 50 Coloured respondents randomly selected from Heidedal & Mangaung, two residential areas in greater Bloemfontein. Interview data obtained in 1998 revealed that respondents appeared to have negative attitudes toward suicide, but indicated that the community has sympathy for people who try to kill themselves & that there should be a service in the community to support people in an emotional crisis. Financial & relationship problems were cited as most likely to cause a person to contemplate suicide. 3 Tables, 9 References. Adapted from the source document.

Truth and the Social Services

Author: Loffell, J

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61678208?accountid=14667

Abstract: A submission made by the Greater Johannesburg Welfare, Social Service & Development Forum (GJWSSDF) to South Africa's Truth & Reconciliation Commission is provided in an abridged form. Apologies for the GJWSSDF's cooperation with policies of apartheid, even when those policies compromised the GJWSSDF's social services values, are expressed. The way apartheid was allowed to influence the GJWSSDF's performance of its duties is reviewed, looking at the separation of welfare policies by race, & legislation & structures set up within the social services by the apartheid government. How the GJWSSDF's own personnel practices & training were influenced by apartheid is discussed, as are the use of the social services by the national security establishment & the discrimination practiced within social service worker organizations. It is noted that many services were only provided to blacks in an inferior form. Since the new government of 1994 came into power, social services programs have been democratically reformed, with steps being taken to prevent the reemergence of discriminatory practices. 14 References. D. Weibel

Factors Influencing Child Abuse and Neglect Behaviour by Social Workers in the Northern Province, South Africa

Author: Peltzer, K1; Phaswana, N1 Dept Psychology, U North, Sovenga, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61665356?accountid=14667

Abstract: A survey of 103 social workers, ages 23-59, in South Africa's Northern Province, was undertaken to determine patterns in reporting child abuse & neglect behavior. It was found that most Ss used their own discretion in deciding whether to report suspected abuse. The most common reasons for deciding not to make a report included a lack of evidence, distrust of the child, the feeling the child was no longer in danger, a fear of the perpetrator's reaction, a sense the perpetrator had made amends, family pressure, & the view that the situation could be adequately handled by the social worker with no outside help. A link between social workers' discretion & the underreporting of child abuse is posited. 6 Tables, 12 References. D. Weibel

Empowerment: Observations on Mental Health in Sub-Saharan Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61648964?accountid=14667

Abstract: It is argued that the social & economic history of the African continent has contributed to the disempowerment of its people, adversely impacting the field of mental health. Cultural Diversity and Development Needs in South Africa: Implications for Social Work Education

Author: Strydom, H11 Dept Maatskaplike Werk, Potchefstroomse U Christelike Hoer Onderwys, Republic South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61667620?accountid=14667

Abstract: Discusses the cultural diversity of the South African population & the important role that the social worker plays as practician & educator. Emphasis is placed on the demands of the current practice & the equipping of the social worker. Certain curricular requirements that are of importance in the planning of social work training are also discussed. Using E. J. Thomas's (eg, 1981) developmental research & utilization model as a guide, postal questionnaires were sent to universities, Hugenot Coll, & practicing social workers of the northwest province. The developmental needs of the South African society & how universities can specifically meet these needs are also discussed. 3 Figures, 42 References. Adapted from the source document.

Social Work and the New Social Service Professions in South Africa

Author: Gray, M11 Dept Social Work, U Newcastle, New South Wales, Australia

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61621813?accountid=14667

Abstract: It is held that with the implementation of South Africa's new government in 1994, the circumstances of social workers began to worsen both because of the denigration of social work, which was thought to have been government-run & therefore allied with apartheid, & because of the adoption of a new developmental welfare paradigm for human resource planning. The withdrawal of governmental support for social services is reported, as is the rise of bodies like the Council for Social Service Professions (CSSP), described as focusing on social development rather than on individual casework. Some positive outcomes for social workers resulting from the formation of the CSSP are discussed, but it is concluded that the near dismissal of casework-based social work as a viable resource is regrettable. 37 References. D. Weibel

Seeking the Friendly Face of Justice: Community Assistance in the Family Court

Author: Burman, S1; Swanepoel, L1 Centre Socio-Legal Research, U Cape Town, Rosebank, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61458305?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article discusses how well a Pilot Project Family Court established in Cape Town, South Africa, to provide urgently needed judicial services to families at a reasonable cost, has met its goal. Although the services of divorce, maintenance, family violence, & children's courts are planned, only the divorce section of the court has begun operation. A major goal of establishing this court, one of five in South Africa, has been to make it user-friendly. This article, based on detailed monitoring, examines how the court has interacted with its users, whether plans have been followed, & what problems have occurred, & makes a preliminary analysis of how the varied expectations & cultural norms of the employees & volunteers have mediated the effectiveness of the court. Judging from the responses of spontaneous thanks & little gifts to the volunteers from those they assisted, it is concluded that the Family Court has succeeded in becoming user-friendly; however, the functioning of the Helpdesk could be improved. L. A. Hoffman

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Seeking+the+Friendly+Face+of+Justice%3A+Community+Assistance+in+the+Family+Court&amp;rft.au=Burman%2C+S%3BSwanepoel%2C+L&amp;rft.aulast=Burman&amp;rft.aufirst=S&amp;rft.date=2000-06-01&amp;rft.volume=36&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=111&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378054&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Enhancing a Human Rights Culture through Social Work Practice and Training

Author: Lombard, A11 Dept Social Work, U Pretoria, Brooklyn, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61457576?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper discusses the impact of apartheid in South Africa on the welfare sector & thus on the violation of human rights within welfare services; it also positions current social work practice & training to protect human rights & to develop a human rights culture in South Africa. The Constitutional Court (CC), the Truth & Reconciliation Commission (TRC), & the South African Human Rights Commission (SAHRC) were established to aid in the healing process & the building of national unity, & to recognize & rectify human rights violations. The work of these bodies to uncover & heal the abuses of the past, the restructuring of the welfare system to meet the needs of all races & classes, & the restructuring of social work professional development & practice is discussed. It is concluded that the welfare sector is contributing to South African culture, & that the majority of social service workers & their organizations have committed themselves to a just & democratic welfare system that promotes the dignity & well-being of all citizens. L. A. Hoffman

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Enhancing+a+Human+Rights+Culture+through+Social+Work+Practice+and+Training&amp;rft.au=Lombard%2C+A&amp;rft.aulast=Lombard&amp;rft.aufirst=A&amp;rft.date=2000-06-01&amp;rft.volume=36&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=124&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378054&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The South African National Crime Prevention Strategy: Overview and Contextual Analysis

Author: Van Aswegen, W F11 Dept Sociology, U Stellenbosch, Cape Province, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/60366061?accountid=14667

Abstract: The article provides an overview of the main interventions proposed in the South African National Crime Prevention Strategy (NCPS) as well as a discussion of the aims & principles of the strategy in the context of sociological/criminological theories of crime, philosophical theories of punishment, & patterns & strategies for controlling crime in Western societies. The main themes addressed are crime & human rights, crime control vs crime prevention, crime as security issue vs crime as social issue, retributive justice vs restorative justice, & community-based crime prevention & criminal justice. 23 References. What Do Children's Homes Staff Let Parents Do?: An International Comparison

Author: Coughlan, F1; Ainsworth, F1 Dept Social Work, Rhodes U, East London, UK

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61457583?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article reports the results of an exploratory cross-national study of how the staff of Children's Homes help to maintain parent/child connectedness & what they allow parents to do for their children while they are in out-of-home care. The data were gathered from three Children's Homes in the US & one in South Africa. This cross-national comparison is a rare, if not unique, type of study. Discussion of the findings from this study includes consideration of possible language & cultural factors influencing the results & highlights some of the challenges in doing cross-national studies that include countries with very different educational & literacy levels. Finally the paper indicates what efforts have been made by the South African Home to respond to the findings &, in so doing, illustrates the value of comparative research for improved intervention. 2 Tables, 20 References. Adapted from the source document.

Investigating the Lives of Children with Disabilities in the Qwaqwa Region: Implications for Service Provision in a Rural Context

Author: Thejane, T1; Muthukrishna, N1 Eastern Seaboard Assoc Tertiary Institutions

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61457910?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study investigated the factors that impact on the lives of rural children with disabilities & their families. Seventeen children with disabilities were selected through a process of purposive sampling from three areas in the Qwaqwa region: Mabolela, Makgalan, & Bolata. This was a qualitative study. The research method was the semi-structured interview. The main caregiver in each of the families was interviewed. The findings in the study indicate that, despite the fact that various pieces of legislation & policy documents in South Africa since 1994 make special reference to the protection of the rights of children with disabilities, the rights of the children investigated in this study continue to be violated. The study reveals the urgent need to address barriers to learning & development that these children are experiencing; these barriers are located largely in the system. This study has implications for planning services to address the needs of children with disabilities in this rural context. 18 References. Adapted from the source document.

An Analysis of the Capacity Building Programme for Senior and Middle Management of the National and Provincial Departments of Social Welfare

Author: Cameron, R11 Dept Political Studies, U Cape Town, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61458315?accountid=14667

Abstract: The Dept of Welfare has received much adverse publicity about the nondelivery of services & its inability to distribute welfare grants. Welfare Director-General, Angela Bester, told the Welfare Portfolio Committee that the reason for the department's failure to distribute funds &, where it had, to check they were properly used, was that they did not have the capacity, in particular, skilled staff, to do the job (Business Day 2 March 2000). The New Minister of Welfare, Zola Skweyiya, has also complained about organizational deficiencies in the department. It can be seen that the issue of capacity is a burning problem. Here a look is taken at this issue, focusing on a recent capacity-building program for senior & middle managers of departments of welfare at both the provincial & national levels. The objective of this article is to provide a critical overview of the program & look at how it contributed to capacity building within the national & provincial departments of welfare. Recommendations for improving capacity are made. 8 References. Adapted from the source document.

Part One: Social Work Political Participation: A South African Study

Author: Gray, M M A1; Van Rooyen, C. A. J. C.1 Dept Social Work, U Newcastle, New South Wales, Australia

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61457728?accountid=14667

Abstract: Reports a study that examined the political participation of social workers in KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa. Social workers involve themselves politically by implementing policy, influencing policymakers, & changing policy through responding to pending legislation, serving in policy-making structures, pressure groups, & lobbying efforts. Questionnaire data were obtained from 482 social workers in KwaZulu-Natal to see if they considered their efforts since 1994 effective. While 90.5% of the respondents indicated that they study current & new welfare legislation, the findings suggest a varying degree of interest in the various new policies. Since social work is committed to social justice, social change, & social improvement, social workers need to influence policy more effectively. To do so, they must become more politically minded & politically active. 4 Figures, 11 References. L. A. Hoffman

The Traumatic Onset of Disabling Injury in a Marriage Partner: Self-Reports of the Experience by Able-Bodied Spouses

Author: Levor, K D1; Jansen, P1 Dept Psychology, U Witwatersrand, Johannesburg, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61504281?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study explored the physical & emotional adjustment faced by female spouses of individuals who had suffered a traumatic brain injury (TBI, n = 10) or a spinal cord injury (SCI, n = 5). Results of this preliminary investigation show that the sequelae of brain damage & SCI necessitate major psychosocial changes for the injured partner & spouse. Spouses of TBI victims cited their injured partner's change in personality as a serious problem, while partners of SCI sufferers identified depression in the injured spouse as a major difficulty. At the same time able-bodied spouses also reported attempts to cope with their own feelings of loneliness, depression, frustration, & stress. In the current study, issues such as time since injury, length of marriage, or whether the injured spouse had returned to work were not seen as mitigating factors. Seventy percent of all the spouses expressed fears for what the future might hold. The study confirms previous findings that the stress of living with a TBI or SCI victim can increase over time. It is suggested that there is a strong need for ongoing community counseling services & support systems for these subgroups. 4 Tables, 22 References. Adapted from the source document.

Social Work in South Africa: In Search of Early Role Models

Author: Hough, Mike

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61495025?accountid=14667

Abstract: Hough highlights role models in social work in South Africa whom students could revere. Hough's career in social work started in 1939 as a student of the U of Stellenbosch. He started the first school of social work for blacks in South Africa in 1945 & remained there until it was closed in 1960. He was instrumental in starting the Oppenheimer School of Social Work in Lusaka & the School of Social Work in Salisbury, Rhodesia. When he returned to South Africa, he joined the Dept of Social Work at the U of Fort Hare & remained there until his retirement in 1984. Among his beliefs were that the social worker's job was not to change society, but to improve situations, eg, to address juvenile delinquency, poverty, & other social problems. L. A. Hoffman

Psychosocial Issues Surrounding Cleft Lip and Palate

Author: Ross, E11 Dept Speech Pathology & Audiology, U Witwatersrand, Johannesburg, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61468131?accountid=14667

Abstract: The many destructive myths surrounding congenital malformations of the face & oral cavity are often difficult to eradicate, & tend to plague the lives of individuals with clefts, their parents, & families (McWilliams & Witzet 1994). The extra stresses posed by these stereotypes may be especially marked during the school years & may lead to withdrawal, altered interpersonal relationships, & lowered self-esteem. A well-informed counselor is often in a unique position to provide information that may modify some of these harmful beliefs & help to overcome these barriers to a full & satisfying life. Orthodontists & plastic, reconstructive, & maxillo-facial surgeons fulfill a vital function in repairing the cleft lip/palate & associated physical structures, while speech therapists enable these persons to acquire communication skills. Social workers & psychologists can assist affected persons & their families to come to terms with the many psychosocial issues surrounding the experience of a cleft. In addition, support groups such as Cleftpals can help parents to cope with a child who is physically different. Other members of the craniofacial team include the pediatrician, otolaryngologist, dietician, & geneticist. A final point is that with a combined team approach, involving all relevant parties, the prognosis for successful psychosocial development of the child with a cleft lip/palate would appear to be achievable in the majority of cases. Moreover, infants who begin life with strong support & guidance & have that extra assistance through adolescence, are more likely to enter adulthood with better psychosocial skills than those who struggle alone (McWilliams 1997). 27 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Cross-Cultural Ravine: Why the Bridge Is Necessary, and How to Go about Building It

Author: Jonker, C1; Cronje, J I1 Dept Social Work, U Stellenbosch, Matieland, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61492372?accountid=14667

Abstract: Aims at addressing the increasing demand for effective multicultural competence within the South African social service sector. The authors stress the importance of cross-cultural competence as an inherent element in both social work practice & theory in order to provide relevant & appropriate services that are responsive to the needs & problems experienced by South Africans. A tricomponential model was suggested in which various value, skill, & knowledge elements were identified & applied to the supervision relationship between supervisor & social work student -- thus arguing that supervision be used as a tool for enhancing the cross-cultural competence of social workers from the onset of their involvement in practice education. In doing so, principles were identified on which cross-cultural competence is based, while the threats that serve to impede or limit this competence were also identified. 25 References. Adapted from the source document.

A School-Based Intervention Programme for Refugee Children

Author: Searle, Cathy1; Skinner, Donald1 Trauma Centre Victims Violence & Torture, Cape Town, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61470967?accountid=14667

Abstract: Since the borders of South Africa opened, Cape Town has seen an influx of people, including increasing numbers of children. The government offers refugees a safe haven & the right to work, but the load of direct services & assistance mostly falls onto NGOs such as the Trauma Centre. At the request of teachers, a therapeutic activity group, to assist children in working through their traumatic experiences, was established at a school within one accommodation site for refugees. The program consisted of eight 90-minute sessions, each focusing on a different theme. It was done alongside workshops with teachers to assist them in coping with refugee children. The program was evaluated principally by observations during the group sessions & records of teachers of the behavioral problems manifested by the children. These showed a general positive response, mostly in the areas of reduction of anxiety symptoms & increased social confidence. 9 References. Adapted from the source document.

Transforming "Postgraduate" Offerings

Author: Kasiram, M I11 Dept Social Work, U Durban-Westville, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61526845?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social work programs, whether at undergraduate or postgraduate level, must be context relevant (Van Rooyen 1996). The call for relevance, transformation, & change has become almost desperate as we enter the new millennium, with the government also heeding this call via the White Paper for Welfare (1997). This paper will discuss research findings in order to facilitate the planning of feasible programs at postgraduate level. Two sets of research data will be presented: (1) current postgraduate programs at universities; & (2) expressed educational & learning needs of practitioners in the field of social work. The author will thereafter summarize key concerns/issues that need to be addressed in attempting to reconcile the developmental paradigm with future postgraduate programs. Amongst the variety of factors that need to be considered when planning modules will be marketing of the program, accreditation, inter- & intra-university collaboration, territoriality, & financial constraints. These will be highlighted briefly to stimulate communication & problem solving. 12 References. Adapted from the source document.

Intimacy in Counselling: Beyond the Boundaries of a Professional Relationship

Author: Smith, Patrick J D11 School Social Work, U Cape Town, Rondebosch, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61439513?accountid=14667

Abstract: The concept of "intimacy" in counseling is a complex though sensitive one. In this article, the concept is defined & two opposing views presented about intimacy between the client & the helping professional in the counseling relationship. The effects of intimacy between clients & helping professionals are considered & some of the ethical/legal implications discussed. Finally, the author examines the reasons for the silence surrounding the phenomenon & recommendations are made to prevent misconduct. 22 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Professional Status of Social Work

Author: Lombard, A11 Dept Social Work, U Pretoria, Brooklyn, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61458465?accountid=14667

Abstract: Noting that accountability issues are increasingly & negatively affecting the social work profession in South Africa, the professional status of social work is outlined & contextualized. The changing status of social work from nonprofessional to that of a full-fledged profession in the course of the 20th century is described, using S. E. Spiro et al (1998) as a reference, & contextual factors influencing this status (ie, the sociopolitical climate, legal standing, professional location, & classification & declassification solutions to social problems) are addressed. Issues related to professional conduct are further identified as one of the main factors affecting the (perception of) professional status. Common misconduct & malpractice behaviors are discussed, & important areas of conduct liability for social workers are listed. National statistics on complaints against social workers from 1980-1999 are presented & illustrated with examples in order to design adequate risk management strategies. The development of intervention strategies, continuous professional development, & liability insurance are deemed important aspects of risk management that should be part of the skill repertoire of every social worker. 3 Tables, 18 References. S. Paul

Probation Officers' Testimony and Sentence Recommendations in Pre-Sentence Investigations for Juvenile Offenders

Author: Green, Sulina1; Lennox, L T1 Dept Maatskaplike Werk, U Stellenbosch, Cape Province, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61458471?accountid=14667

Abstract: Growing demands are placed on probation officers to act as sources of information during adjudication processes & to provide the criminal courts in South Africa with appropriate sentence options for juvenile offenders in the context of the current juvenile crime situation, participatory law, & reform in the South African welfare & legal system. In this study, the role of the probation officer in the sentencing of juvenile offenders was evaluated during 1999 by magistrates in the Cape Peninsula. The advisory & executive role of probation officers in criminal courts was confirmed. In addition to knowledge of forensic social work, probation officers need to have legal knowledge. In determining sentence recommendations, they need to take into account the same aspects as judicial officials & apply the principles upon which the allotment of punishment is based. The sentence recommendation is a result of the conclusions of the presentence investigation & the expert opinion of the probation officer about this. However, probation officers should not take their status as expert witnesses in criminal courts for granted. Before they are allowed to act as expert witnesses in criminal courts, probation officers need to be declared as such by courts as well as meet other requirements. 6 Figures, 28 References. Adapted from the source document.

Trying to Read the Writing on the Wall: Immediate and Imminent Impact of National Policy

Author: Coughlan, F11 Dept Social Work, Rhodes U, East London, UK

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61458482?accountid=14667

Abstract: The impact of new national welfare work policies on social work in South Africa is discussed, focusing on social work education, the need to adapt to the developmental work paradigm, & political issues. Elements of the 1995 Social Work Amendment Act & of the 1997 government White Paper for Social Welfare that affect social work & social work education are outlined, focusing on the erosion of the social work profession in favor of other sectors of welfare work (eg, child & youth work), & arguing that the social work profession needs more organizational force in order to gain political clout & influence future decisions. Curriculum changes in welfare work training programs, which aim at a better demarcation of different professions, are reviewed critically. It is asserted that the stricter formal delimitation of occupations results in the loss of integration, & that social work tends to be singled out due to its traditional differences with developmental work & other fields in which the developmental perspective has been the dominant paradigm. A better professional organization & renewed attempts to integrate aspects of developmental work are deemed necessary in order to prevent the future redundancy of social work. 25 References. S. Paul

The Baby and the Bath Water: The Dilemma of Modern Social Work in Africa

Author: Jacques, Gloria11 Dept Social Work, U Botswana, Gaborone

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61459239?accountid=14667

Abstract: Discusses how work in South Africa can integrate the new paradigm of social development, including the related notions of radicalization, indigenization, authentization, participation, & empowerment. It is described how social workers must select those approaches from the available range of techniques & modalities that best match their clients; in developing Africa, the networks of relationships, extended families, clans, & village groupings are deemed more important in most environments than the dominant Western concept of the individual. However, the rapid spread in (primarily urban) South Africa of modern Western lifestyles is also discussed, & it is argued that South African social workers must be able to use both contexts. A holistic practice system, which respects both the status of the individual & the importance of social networks by integrating dominant Western approaches focusing on individual autonomy with a social development perspective focusing on traditional & rural realities, is proposed. It is asserted that only such a reconceptualization of social work may prevent the profession from becoming irrelevant in the developing world. 48 References. S. Paul

Social Work Intervention with Sex Workers: Prostitutes' Perspective on Reality

Author: Engelbrecht, L K1; Williams, T1 Dept Maatskaplike Werk, Hugenote Coll, Wellington

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61459255?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social work intervention with sex workers requires expert input. Intervention will only be successful if the social worker is familiar with the facts & subculture of sex work. The sex worker will also only be willing to respond to a social worker if she experiences acceptance & feels that the social worker is not trying to influence her choice of career. Research indicates that intervention has to focus on the enhancement of living conditions & the quality of life of a sex worker, rather than on rehabilitation. 1 Figure, 33 References. Adapted from the source document.

Validation of an Ecological Approach to Domestic Violence against Women

Author: Schoeman, H P1; Ferreira, S B1 Dept Maatskaplike Werk, U Vrystaat, Bloemfontein

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/60376320?accountid=14667

Abstract: An analysis of violence against women in cohabiting & marital relationships is undertaken from an ecological perspective, in order to specify a scientifically founded approach for social work service relative to this phenomenon. A linear approach to violence has been replaced with a more comprehensive, holistic perspective, which brings about an assessment of social problems & needs in interactional terms, ie, that violence is a result of maladjustment in the person & environment relationship. The phenomenon is approached as a symptom of dysfunctioning in the ecological system & as a result of the mutually influencing interactional processes that take place between the individual system & the ecological context. A variety of multifactoral, circular causal factors are identified by analyzing four levels of the ecological system: individual, family, social structural, & sociocultural. The mutual influence between levels is also examined. The analysis concludes that holistic, integrated, & circular service rendering with reference to the phenomenon can be maintained. 3 Figures, 69 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Application of Relationship Marketing in Non-Profit Organisations Involved in the Provision of Social Services

Author: Terblanche, N S11 Dept Business Management, U Stellenbosch, Cape Province, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61482840?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examines the benefits of applying the concept of relationship marketing to nonprofit social service organizations. A description of the concept of relationship marketing as used in the business world notes that it focuses on the development & maintenance of mutually satisfying long-term relationships with customers/other stakeholders through the essential components of concern, commitment, trust, & satisfaction. Suggestions are made for applying relationship marketing to nonprofit organizations in terms of developing relationships with different stakeholder groups, such as donors, volunteers, politicians, local authorities, & the media. It is argued that relationship marketing can be the key to acquiring & maintaining long-term relationships that provide the human, financial, & emotional resources that are crucial for an organization's continuing success, especially since nonprofit organizations must compete for donors & volunteers with an increasing number of other worthwhile causes. 1 Table, 4 Figures, 30 References. J. Lindroth

Sexual Harassment in the South African Police Service: A Situation Analysis, Preventive Measures and Guidelines for Addressing Sexual Harassment

Author: Green, Sulina1; Retief, Rita1 Dept Social Work, U Stellenbosch, Cape Province, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61528658?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examines the prevalence & impact of the sexual harassment of female employees in the South African Police Service (SAPS) & evaluates the effectiveness of policies designed to prevent its occurrence & address complaints. Data for the exploratory study were obtained from questionnaires completed anonymously by 104 female SAPS employees. Demographic characteristics of the respondents are described. The findings show that co-workers were the primary group of employers responsible for various types of harassment, ranging from sexual teasing, to actual/attempted rape, & threats regarding the female worker's job status. It was indicated that the average offender was most apt to be a repeat offender who harassed multiple females simultaneously. Most of the women who had experienced harassment were unsure of how to react & the effects of the experience varied depending upon the nature of the response to victimization as well as the employee's psychological make-up. Suggestions are made for effectively implementing existing sexual harassment policies & providing a training program for all SAPS employees. 5 Tables, 26 References. J. Lindroth

A Social Work Perspective on Stuttering

Author: Ross, Eleanor11 Dept Speech Pathology & Audiology, U Witwatersrand, Johannesburg, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61529849?accountid=14667

Abstract: Stuttering is a complex, multidimensional fluency disorder that has both overt & covert dimensions. The overt dimension refers to the visible & audible aspects of stuttering, whereas the covert dimension includes the feelings of the person who stutters as well as the feelings evoked in listeners. This paper addresses the covert aspect with particular reference to the psychosocial issues likely to occur during the childhood, adolescent, & adulthood stages of the life cycle. Emphasis is placed on the need for clinicians to focus not only on the disordered speech. Counseling can play a significant role in helping persons who stutter to confront their attitudes, beliefs, & fears regarding their stuttering behavior. Counselors can also modify the environment in terms of the way significant others feel & behave in relation to the stutterer. 24 References. Adapted from the source document.

Assistance for the Primary Child of the Alcoholic

Author: De Beer, Nelene1; Joubert, J M C1 Dept Maatskaplike Werk, U Pretoria, Brooklyn, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61482859?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article provides a brief outline on the impact of alcoholism on the family & children of the alcoholic. Guidelines are also provided on means to support & help the primary child of the alcoholic to cope with the realities of parental alcoholism. Alcoholism has been a problematic phenomenon in society for many years. It is also an ongoing occurrence in spite of the negative impact that it has on the alcoholic, the family of the alcoholic, & society. A contributing factor to alcoholism is that the addictive nature of alcohol is not recognized. It is not perceived as a drug & is, therefore, freely available. Latham & Napier (1992:1137) state that three to six people are negatively affected by a single person's alcohol abuse. Alcoholism is also the third most frequent health problem in the world (Kaplan, Sadock & Grebb, 1994:525). It is also well known that there is a positive reference between alcohol abuse & car accidents, abuse & molestation of children, family violence, assault, rape, murder, burglary, & theft. It must also be kept in mind that the alcoholic family often displays characteristics of a dysfunctional family & that alcoholism can be perceived as a family disease. The child of the alcoholic is directly influenced by parental alcoholism & is at great risk of experiencing problems with his/her social functioning. The need of the alcoholic's child for support & help by a professional is, therefore, apparent. 2 Tables, 28 References. Adapted from the source document.

The AIDS Crisis and Orphan Care in Zimbabwe

Author: Kaseke, Edwin1; Gumbo, Perpetua1 School Social Work, Harare

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61528695?accountid=14667

Abstract: The paper observes that the AIDS crisis in Zimbabwe has resulted in an unprecedentedly huge increase in the number of orphans. The magnitude of the problem of orphans warrants going beyond conventional responses to the care & protection of orphans. The paper, therefore, discusses these conventional responses & a new initiative, namely, the community-based orphan care program. The paper also observes that, although the community-based care program has been fairly successful in the few districts where it has been introduced, the general state of poverty is undermining the effectiveness of the program. 11 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Transition to Work: Professional Social Workers in Their First Year of Practice

Author: Matlhabe, Damaria11 School Social Work, U Witwatersrand, Johannesburg, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61492417?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social Work manpower research has aimed chiefly at "the student" or "the professional practitioner," but little investigation has focused on the transition from student to beginning practitioner. Although social work education aims to develop knowledge & skills in helping clients to cope with change, academic social work departments cannot assume that social work students are able, because of their professional training, to cope with major life decisions & transitions in their own lives. The transition to work is a critical one, since if it does not occur satisfactorily, new entrants to the profession will either drop out of practice or fail to operate at their optimum capacity. These new workers are a group who transport current educational doctrines into current social work practice. They are the fledgling group to whom the community looks to assess returns on its maturing financial investments in education. What happens to the new graduates in their transition from student to beginning practitioner is the concern of this paper & the year following upon graduation is the specific point of focus. 1 Figure, 20 References. The Socioeconomic Status of HIV/AIDS Patients in the Northwest Province

Author: Kotze, G J1; Roux, A A; Wessels, C C1 U Christelike Hoer Onderwys, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/60426731?accountid=14667

Abstract: As a result of a lack of funds & facilities for the care of HIV victims in South Africa, the accent increasingly falls on home care & on the responsibility of the family as the support system for patients. The question is however raised whether families always are financially & otherwise able & have the capacity to care for their family members according to the demands made on them by the illness. In an attempt to provide an answer to these questions, this article will focus on the socioeconomic position of HIV patients in the Northwest Province. Specific attention will be given to income & expense patterns, while housing situations such as over-habitation & the size of households will also be investigated. The eventual conclusion arrived at is that poverty situations play a prominent role that affects not only the patient but also each member of the household. 7 Tables, 12 References. Adapted from the source document.

Confidentiality: Investigating the Impact of Breaches of Confidentiality on Teenage Children in Care

Author: Collett van Rooyen, Colin1; Engelbrecht, A N1 Office Community Outreach & Service Learning, U Natal, Durban, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61445441?accountid=14667

Abstract: Reports on a study of the impact of breaches in confidentiality on teenagers in care. Data were obtained from interviews with 25 girls, 13 to 19 years old, who were living at a residential care institution in Durban, South Africa. The study was intended to determine the kinds & frequency of confidentiality breaches, as well as the effects of breaches on the girls' relationships with staff members. The relevant literature is reviewed & ethical issues surrounding the study are discussed. The findings showed that the majority of the respondents had experienced breaches of their confidentiality that resulted in mistrust, feeling "bad," & anger. These feelings had a definite negative impact on the willingness of the teens to confide in staff members. Childcare workers were viewed as being most likely to reveal confidences; therefore, the girls were reluctant to tell them about problems they were experiencing. The implications of the findings are discussed & recommendations are made for areas of future research. 22 References. J. Lindroth
