Notes form Practice

Author: [Unknown]

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61480532?accountid=14667

Abstract: The evaluation of playforms with deaf children is done through a gestalt therapeutic approach. The aim was to bring the deaf child in contact with his feelings & so to enable the child to handle unfinished business in a non-verbal way. A theoretical exploration of the gestalt approach, the deaf culture, & playforms was done in order to use this in the therapeutic process with each child. There was a better understanding of the deaf child's unique process, feeling, & fears through the use of a multi-professional team in the preassessment. The exploratory research method was used. Suggested playmediums & forms were described & implemented during the empirical study. 17 References. Adapted from the source document.

Abstract: The field of social work in South Africa appears to have stagnated. A Needs Assessment for a Relationship-Guidance Programme for Partners in a Gay Male Relationship

Author: Keevy, C1; Alpaslan, A H1 Dept Social Development Professions, U Port Elizabeth

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61475755?accountid=14667

Abstract: The lack of indigenous research-based literature on relationship-guidance programs for partners in a gay male relationship necessitates a needs assessment in this regard. A research project adopting a qualitative paradigm was undertaken that included an empirical study with samples of gay male couples. Its aim was to perform a needs assessment for guidance programs by focusing, inter alia, on whether they could benefit these couples' relationships, what they should include, who should present them, & in what format. The study's principal results indicated that such a program would aid gay partners with regard to a variety of issues raised by them. The findings also provide tentative guidelines for such programs, which are badly needed by gay men & service professionals alike. 1 Table, 30 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Means Test for Social Assistance Grants and Its Recent Evolution

Author: Van der Berg, S11 Dept Economics, U Stellenbosch, Cape Province, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61466368?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article analyzes the means tests used in South Africa in social assistance programs, particularly disability assistance & pensions for the elderly. After first discussing problems with the apartheid-era means tests, focus shifts to how the creation of the unified means test, a combination of means tests & benefits analysis, has affected social assistance programs. The article then explores the effectiveness of means tests in appropriating money & explains the amendments drawn up in 1998. 4 Tables. E. Miller

Working with Black SLE Patients: A Challenge to Medical Social Work

Author: Modisane, D S1; Carbonatto, C L1 Dept Social Work, U Pretoria, Brooklyn, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61473923?accountid=14667

Abstract: Results are reported of a study conducted at an outpatient clinic in South Africa, discussing the experiences & psychological impact of a connective tissue disease, Systemic Lupus Erythematomus (SLE), on black patients & their families. An overview of SLE & its symptoms & complications is followed by discussion of the disease's psychological impact & the influence of medical social workers in this area. The pathology of the disease in various parts of the body is explained. E. Miller

Child and Youth Care Work -- The Motivations, Personal Perspectives, Ideals and Expectations of Practitioners and Policy-Makers

Author: De Kock, Desiree11 Programme Group: Management & Development, Technikon South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61480145?accountid=14667

Abstract: Child & youth care work is a newly recognized service in the field of social welfare. Qualitative research was done to identify the motivations, personal perspectives, ideals, & expectations of practitioners in this occupation, as well as the unique contribution of child & youth care work to social welfare. The main characteristics distinguishing child & youth care workers from other service deliverers are that they work in the life space of children & their families & they spend long hours with the children. The expectations & personal perspectives of child & youth care workers & policymakers regarding professionalization, better working conditions, & formal training in this field are explored in conclusion. 3 Tables, 60 References. Adapted from the source document.

Creative Teaching: A Case Study

Author: Gray, Mel11 Dept Social Work, U Newcastle, New South Wales, Australia

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61474459?accountid=14667

Abstract: The paper reports on a student project that combined the author's creative interests in social work teaching & photography. The common ground between social work & photography was demonstrated through an audiovisual presentation titled An Alternative View of Durban, which was presented at the Annual Congress of the Photographic Society of Southern Africa (PSSA) held in Durban in 1996. The show, based on the case study of the women of Block A K, was first presented at the IASSW Congress in Washington, DC, in 1992, & the accompanying paper was published in the International Journal of Social Work in 1994. The text is presented here. 1 Reference. Adapted from the source document.

Peer Sexual Harassment and Peer Violence: South African Children at Risk

Author: Fineran, Susan1; Bennett, Larry; Sacco, Terry1 School Social Work, Boston U, MA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61475723?accountid=14667

Abstract: Data from a 1997 study are drawn on to describe the incidence of & interrelationships among peer sexual harassment, physical violence, & sexual violence (SH, PV, & SV, respectively) in a nonprobability sample of 261 South African high school students, ages 14-17. Results indicate that 79% of the respondents (Rs) report experiencing some sort of SH by peers & 78% report perpetrating SH against peers at school. Girls experienced a higher frequency of SH & PV than boys. A power scale measuring male dominance found that boys scored significantly higher than girls on the endorsement of male social role power & perpetrated significantly more SH, PV, & SV than girls. Girls found these experiences to be significantly more threatening than did boys. Also more than boys, girls reported experiencing significantly more SH from peers they did not know & peers whom they had dated; they also experienced more PV & SV from peers they had dated. 4 Tables, 51 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Peer+Sexual+Harassment+and+Peer+Violence%3A+South+African+Children+at+Risk&amp;rft.au=Fineran%2C+Susan%3BBennett%2C+Larry%3BSacco%2C+Terry&amp;rft.aulast=Fineran&amp;rft.aufirst=Susan&amp;rft.date=2001-08-01&amp;rft.volume=37&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=211&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378054&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

A Framework for the Practice of Group Supervision

Author: Thabathi, L J V1; Mamasela, S C1 Dept Social Work, U Pretoria, Brooklyn, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61524768?accountid=14667

Abstract: Outlines a framework for the practice of group supervision, drawing on mail questionnaire data from 30 social workers in the Northern Province, South Africa. The benefits of group vs individual supervision are discussed, & the educational, administrative, supportive, motivational, personality enrichment, & modeling functions of group supervision are outlined. The organization, methods, & phases of group supervision sessions are detailed. 1 Table, 1 Figure, 15 References. K. Hyatt Stewart

Suicide and Self-Destructive Behavior in Adolescence: A Gestalt Therapeutic Guideline

Author: Swanepoel, G1; Joubert, J M C1 Dept Maatskaplike Werk, U Pretoria, Brooklyn, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61529935?accountid=14667

Abstract: This research study is concerned with exploring suicide-oriented behaviors that manifest during adolescence. The goal of this study was to determine the impact of a gestalt therapeutic guideline by using projective techniques to create alternative behavior for the self-destructive ways in which these adolescents are trying to communicate their messages & express themselves emotionally. In order to achieve this goal, projective techniques within the gestalt approach such as drawings, clay, music, role-play, & the diary were used. Applied research was used to make the results applicable in practice & to provide solutions & alternatives for this behavior. Two South African respondents were selected with a goal-directed sample, with which six individual gestalt therapeutic sessions each was held. A research hypothesis was made namely that, if a gestalt therapeutic guideline can be done with the potential adolescent who will commit suicide where he or she can be empowered to be self supportive, express self-destructive feelings, & identify alternative behavior for it, then he or she will be able to feel less hopeless, helpless, & depressed & be less inclined to end his or her life. Pre- & posttests were done with the aid of the ISO-30 measurement scale to determine the impact & success of the guideline, with reference to the suicide-oriented adolescent's behavior & thoughts. The research results from the therapeutic intervention as well as the ISO-30 scale confirmed the hypothesis as true. The adolescents were very suicide-oriented & blocked in regard to alternatives for their self-destructive behavior at the start of the sessions. After the gestalt guideline was done, a fundamental decrease in feelings of helplessness & suicide orientation was observed. The cardinal influence & value of a preventional gestalt guideline is evident in terms of addressing suicidal behavior during adolescence. 1 Figure, 14 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Suicide+and+Self-Destructive+Behavior+in+Adolescence%3A+A+Gestalt+Therapeutic+Guideline&amp;rft.au=Swanepoel%2C+G%3BJoubert%2C+J+M+C&amp;rft.aulast=Swanepoel&amp;rft.aufirst=G&amp;rft.date=2001-08-01&amp;rft.volume=37&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=231&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378054&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Suicide+and+Self-Destructive+Behavior+in+Adolescence%3A+A+Gestalt+Therapeutic+Guideline&amp;rft.au=Swanepoel%2C+G%3BJoubert%2C+J+M+C&amp;rft.aulast=Swanepoel&amp;rft.aufirst=G&amp;rft.date=2001-08-01&amp;rft.volume=37&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=231&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378054&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Enhancing Culture Sensitive Social Work Practice: Religious and Ethical Aspects of the New Reproductive Technologies (NRTS)

Author: Sewpaul, V11 Centre Social Work, School Anthropology & Psychology, U Natal, Durban, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61476976?accountid=14667

Abstract: Offers guidelines for social workers involved with couples making decisions about the use of new reproductive technologies (NRTs) that may conflict with their personal religious or cultural beliefs. Different NRTs are reviewed, & attitudes toward their use are examined in 24 South African couples, comprising Hindus, African traditional religion adherents, & Christians of African, Indian, Coloured, & white ethnicities; 12 religious leaders were also interviewed. Implications for the development of an ethical & culturally sensitive social work practice are discussed. 27 References. K. Hyatt Stewart

AIDS and Gender: The African Reality

Author: Laird, Siobhan11 School Oriental & African Studies, U London, UK

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61474923?accountid=14667

Abstract: In sub-Saharan Africa, the AIDS epidemic is escalating in its rate of spread through heterosexual intercourse. The narrowly prescribed gender roles of most African women in conjunction with their socioeconomic disempowerment make them particularly vulnerable to AIDS infection. Women's inability to negotiate their sexual relations with men is ignored by the Western-style AIDS awareness campaigns dominant in the sub-Saharan region. This paper examines some of the counterstrategies formulated by Africans themselves to protect women from the HIV & AIDS epidemic. 27 References. Adapted from the source document.

Substance Abuse among Rural Female High School Learners in the Northern Province

Author: Malaka, D W11 Social Work Dept, U North, Sovenga, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61467537?accountid=14667

Abstract: The girl child seldom attracts the attention of alcohol, tobacco, & other drug (ATOD) researchers & practitioners, yet the chances of her exposure & vulnerability to substances are equal to those of male children. Where such substances are brewed & retailed at home, she, as part of the family system, may suffer doubly; first as a participant & second as a victim. Researchers in particular usually concentrate on male children as these are easy to find on the street, in prison, or even in shebeens & bar lounges, while the girl child seems inconspicuous. Becker (1994) aptly commented that, when a problem & its constituency are invisible to the majority of the public, how can a rural state develop the necessary support not only to acknowledge the problem & the need, but to develop excellence in the state's prevention & treatment services' as well. This paper focuses on the girl child as a participant (imbiber) & victim (the abused) of AOTD in the Northern Province of the Republic of South Africa. 6 Tables, 32 References. Adapted from the source document.

Perspectives on Inter-Professional Collaboration: Mediation

Author: Coughlan, Felicity1; Tatchell, D1 Dept Social Work, Rhodes U, East London, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61467550?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study, which used semistructured interviews with 5 social workers & 5 attorneys in South Africa, seeks to explore ways in which mediation as a process of interprofessional collaboration could be better exploited. Access was gained to the respondents by using the nonprobability snowball sampling method to access social workers & attorneys who would consider divorce as an area of specialization or expertise. The researcher was unable to access any member of either profession who held mediation as central to their strategy for divorces. Most of those interviewed indicated they used mediation skills when working with their clients, but did not formally encourage or engage in a full mediation process. The study found that the family advocate could be a key in encouraging increased use of mediation & that the possibility of providing legislation for mandatory mediation should not be too readily dismissed. Comediation may enhance the capacity of the professions to work together & may address some of the role or territory disputes that work against mediation. The study also found that the two professions do not have a good working knowledge of each other & that the relationship is characterized by mistrust & uncertainty. 20 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Perspectives+on+Inter-Professional+Collaboration%3A+Mediation&amp;rft.au=Coughlan%2C+Felicity%3BTatchell%2C+D&amp;rft.aulast=Coughlan&amp;rft.aufirst=Felicity&amp;rft.date=2001-08-01&amp;rft.volume=37&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=278&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378054&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Economic Globalisation and Social Policy Reform: Social Work Curricula in the South African Context

Author: Sewpaul, V11 School Anthropology & Psychology, Centre Social Work, U Natal, Durban, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61475917?accountid=14667

Abstract: Surveys social work schools in South Africa to determine if the curricula question the relationship among current welfare formulations & the relationship between economic globalization & social policy reforms required by the IMF & World Bank. The disastrous African experience with structural adjustment programs is addressed. It is argued that social work curricula need to include economics & globalization to understand the poverty-generating structures of society & to formulate responses that will reduce poverty. 48 References. Coalitions: A Practice Framework for Sustainable Development

Author: Lombard, A1; Janse van Rensburg, Annette1 Dept Social Work, U Pretoria, Brooklyn, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61441902?accountid=14667

Abstract: Since social service organizations require resource mobilization to form developmental & integrated services, mechanisms in South Africa to form & sustain partnerships between government, the private sector, & nongovernmental organizations are being formulated at the request of the UN. As a practice framework for sustainable development, offered is a continuum utilizing concepts such as networks, cooperation, coordination, collaboration, & coalition to explain the levels of partnership intensity. Caution is needed to maintain equal partnerships because the government, as a purchaser of services, is at a different collaborative relation & is better balanced by strong relationships among NGOs. Consortium 2000 is presented as a case study to illustrate the views presented in this framework. 2 Figures, 24 References. L. A. Hoffman

Enough, Soon Enough? Changes in Residential Care

Author: Coughlan, Felicity11 Dept Social Work, Rhodes U, Grahamstown, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61474675?accountid=14667

Abstract: Explores whether private sector residential care for young people in South Africa is exhibiting the same stresses as that in the public sector. Ten private residential care facilities were surveyed in 1998 as a baseline. Findings confirm that private facilities face similar challenges as public ones, including racial integration, but staff members are better trained than their public counterparts, even though they are lower paid. Administrators support government policy changes, but already challenged workloads & resources are restricting their achievement. Despite good performance, the unequal & delayed implementation of the financing policy is threatening these private organizations. 1 Table, 9 References. L. A. Hoffman

Perceived Needs of Disability Grant Recipients in a Semi-Rural South African Area

Author: Frieg, A1; Hendry, J A1 Dept Physiotherapy, Faculty Health Sciences, U Stellenbosch, Cape Province, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61425108?accountid=14667

Abstract: In light of new South African initiatives to re-register beneficiaries of disability grants to determine needs-driven assistance & shift part of the planning, implementation, & evaluation of programs from professionals to persons with disabilities & their representative organizations, this study considers the needs of persons with disabilities in a South African community. Questionnaire data gathered in 1999 indicate that recipients consider their grants insufficient & that they faced economic hardship. In many cases, entire families depended on the grant for their support. Also identified are other areas of need that support the belief that communities should raise awareness of disability & promote support-group activities for persons with disabilities & their families. 4 Tables, 20 References. L. A. Hoffman

Monitoring an Early Childhood Development Programme: From Guessing to Knowing

Author: de Wet, M1; Kherehloa, T; Masheane, M; Botes, L1 Dept Sociology, U Orange Free State, Bloemfontein, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61474687?accountid=14667

Abstract: The Home Instruction Foundation (HIF), which implemented the Home Instruction Preparatory Programme for Pre-School Youngsters (Hippy), & researchers from the Dept of Sociology at the U Orange Free State collaborated in designing enrollment forms & progress reports for the Hippy program. These served as monitoring devices & to collect baseline information for evaluation activities. Two important trends were identified in the data. The first was that the poor performances of the participants in the third month of the program indicated that they experienced problems in this phase of the program. The second main finding was that participants from the Soutpan area performed markedly better than participants from the Botshabelo area. This is ascribed to various socioeconomic factors & demographic realities. These findings may enhance the management & planning of these program or similar program in the area of early childhood development. 1 Table, 7 Figures, 8 References. Adapted from the source document.

Participatory Action Research as a Model for Use in Health Research

Author: Strydom, H11 Maatskaplike Werk, Skool Psigo-sosiale Gedragswetenskappe, Pu Cho

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61521988?accountid=14667

Abstract: In Participatory Action Research, the focus is on the involvement & participation of all the role players in the particular research project. Up to this stage, uncertainty exists about the relationship between community development & the PAR model. Eventually in this model, the process of community work & the research process take hands, & the boundaries between them become vague. PAR is widely endorsed as consistent with health professionals' commitment to social justice -- PAR promises to connect local action to large-scale, progressive social change. The researcher remains responsible for the research process & the community worker should act on the recommendations of the researcher to improve the quality of life in the particular community. In this article the appropriate terminology has been defined; the characteristics, the process, & the data-collection techniques of the PAR model identified; & the advantages & disadvantages of the model evaluated. 34 References. Adapted from the source document.

Partnering for Success: Marrying Social Work with Religion and Culture

Author: Kasiram, M I1; Partab, R1 School Sport Science & Social Work, U Durban-Westville, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61474625?accountid=14667

Abstract: The authors, from the social work discipline in the Faculty of Health Sciences, formed a partnership with the Faculty of Humanities, specifically, with the School of Religion & Culture, a merger that may seem unlikely. According to Robinson & Daigle (2000:26), unfamiliar mergers can be as potentially successful as those which are more conventionally likely. It appears that it is not the participating disciplines/departments but the core ingredients of partnering that interplay to culminate in successful partnering. Postgraduate Theology students have joined Social Work postgraduate students in the Family Therapy & Practice module. As a result of this union, other meaningful liaisons have been born. The discipline & faculty marriage has been consummated, producing a healthy hybrid of students. Tough developmental hurdles are expected, but this article attempts to encourage further academic debate to help equip us to meet the challenge of partnering for profit. 11 References. Adapted from the source document.

Retaining Volunteers in African Communities with Specific Reference to the Cancer Association of South Africa

Author: Lombard, Antoinette1; Modise, V M1 Dept Social Work, U Pretoria

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61553330?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article reports on a study on the retention of volunteers for CANSA in African communities. While social workers had no problem recruiting volunteers for CANSA to assist in service rendering, it was difficult to retain them. From the research findings, as well as an in-depth literature study, it was concluded that in order to retain volunteers, there are specific processes & factors that need to be taken into account before & after volunteers are recruited. 29 References. The Use of Innovative Interventions with Adolescent Children of Alcoholics

Author: Kruger, Sorette1; Venter, Nioma1 Dept Maatskaplike Werk, U Stellenbosch

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61449825?accountid=14667

Abstract: The research described in the article links the classical adaptive behavior of children of alcoholics with possible underlying emotional reactions. As a result of these intensive feelings adolescents are at risk of developing maladaptive behavior, which has the potential to affect their social adjustment negatively. Intra- & interrelationships are negatively affected, which needs to be combated through the development of a positive self-image as well as effective life skills. Social work must intervene proactively. Due to the typical feelings & emotional needs of adolescents, this is best done through peer group intervention with the focus on self-help. Sharing of feelings & experiences & the incorporation of relevant knowledge builds up resilience against the possible negative effect of parental alcoholism. Practical strategies & activities to be utilized during peer group intervention are discussed. The therapeutic value of art therapy, psycho-drama, sculpting & biblio-therapy, among others, is described. 1 Figure, 34 References. Adapted from the source document.

A Programme for Empowering Rural Women: Considerations for Social Work Education

Author: Sathiparsad, R11 Centre Social Work, School Anthropology & Psychology, U Natal

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61506330?accountid=14667

Abstract: Women, specifically rural women, have often been discriminated against, undermined, & disempowered with regard to their roles & their rightful places in society. The process of empowering women requires attitudinal change, gender sensitivity & the active promotion of dignity, self-esteem, & the well-being of women. It is encouraging to note that the transformation process has resulted in conscious efforts being made to address the problems facing women & to improve the overall status of women. The White Paper for Social Welfare (1997) clearly acknowledges that, in addition to their roles in the family, women in rural communities contribute voluntary time to social & development programs. However, they are disadvantaged by policies of the past, which keep them isolated & deny them access to social & economic opportunities that could improve their lives. The document highlights the urgency of the need to build capacity & to promote the advancement of women at all levels in society via comprehensive & integrated services. In keeping with the needs outlined above, this paper presents a pilot program implemented & evaluated with women in a rural area, Vulamehlo, situated to the south of Durban. Feedback from the participants relating to their experiences of the program are discussed & some considerations for social work education are presented. 2 Tables, 15 References. Adapted from the source document.

Grieving through Culture and Community: A South African Perspective

Author: Kasiram, M I1; Partab, R1 U Durban, Westville

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61479790?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article considers the use of culture & community to promote both individual & community grieving & healing in South Africa. The uniqueness of the nation's ubuntu philosophy ("We are who we are through others"), enshrined in many cultural mores, provides the basis for this. The healing power of community & culture finds expression in the following sources: Physical & financial support; Cultural & emotional support; Spiritual support. Despite technological advancements, South Africans have not regressed humanistically (Bernard et al, 1996). Instead many South Africans have become caring of one another & have embraced the varied & conflicting behaviors & emotions associated with death & loss. 15 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Experiences of Female Victims in Violence Prevention Social Services: Professions and Instances

Author: Shoeman, H P1; Ferreira, S B1 Dept Maatskaplike Werk, U Vrystatt, Bloemfontein

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61449833?accountid=14667

Abstract: Female victims of relationship violence experiences of service rendering structures & professions & the implications thereof for social work service rendering, are analyzed. Empirical data are drawn from a quantitative & qualitative national survey on violence against women in cohabiting & marital relationships. Specific attention is paid to participants' utilization of & encounters with service rendering structures & professions. Based on the analysis, implications for social work with specific reference to the utilization & implementation of social work methods for both the prevention & the treatment of the phenomenon, are indicated. 2 Tables, 1 Appendix, 43 References. Adolescents: Typically Developing Siblings and Siblings with Severe Disability

Author: Harty, M1; Alant, E; Opperman, S1 Centre Augmentative & Alternative Communication, U Pretoria

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61504781?accountid=14667

Abstract: The aim of this study was to establish adolescents' perceptions of their siblings with a severe disability as well as the degree & type of social support they utilize. Seventeen adolescents with siblings with a severe disability were interviewed using a semistructured interview. A control group of adolescents with normal functioning siblings also took part in the research project as it is essential to distinguish between perceptions & attitudes that are characteristic of sibling relations in general & those that are a direct result of the presence of a sibling with a severe disability. Interviews were conducted with 25 adolescents ages 12-16. The data were analyzed in a qualitative manner according to 9 categories. Results showed that guilt feelings were more frequently experienced among the adolescents with siblings with a severe disability & these subjects tended not to freely express their feelings about their sibling with a disability. Among the control group the majority of the adolescents had a positive cognitive appraisal of their normal functioning siblings, although these adolescents did express ambivalent emotions toward the sibling relationship. 3 Tables, 24 References. Adapted from the source document.

Revisiting Paulo Freire as a Theoretical Base for Participatory Practices for Social Workers

Author: Schenck, R11 Dept Social Work, U South Africa, Pretoria

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61553382?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper revisits the work of the Brazilian pedagogue, Paolo Freire, & considers the possible impact of his theories for social workers & other helping professionals, particularly in relation to participatory practices. Freire had an enormous influence; some might say his ideas produced a paradigm shift in professionals' perceptions about people, specifically those who were regarded as poor & oppressed. It also became clear that Freire's ideas were a watershed in thinking in various fields & disciplines in different countries. Godono (1998:30) refers to a "before & after" Freire & indicates that Freire's work has been read, discussed, & applied by thousands of people in a great variety of disciplines. Freire's ideas are particularly important for social workers who attempt to facilitate participatory processes with individuals, couples & families, groups, & communities. 18 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Consequences of Vehicle Hijacking

Author: Davis, Linda11 Dept Criminology, U Pretoria

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61430691?accountid=14667

Abstract: The aim of this exposition is to shed some light on the position of trauma victims of vehicle hijacking experience, to emphasize the far-reaching consequences of this priority crime, & to highlight some of the problems that are experienced with currently available support. This is done in the hope that such information will not only broaden the knowledge of social workers, but also encourage them & others in the helping professions to treat victims of vehicle hijacking in the same way as other victims of violent crimes. 17 References. Adapted from the source document.

Promoting Positive Human-Animal Interaction: The Role of the Social Worker in the Multidisciplinary Team

Author: Van Heerden, M1; Du Preez, M. S. E.1 Dept Social Work, U Pretoria

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61506652?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social work is identified as one of 23 disciplines involved in the study field of human-animal interaction. The therapeutic & developmental value of positive interaction with companion animals has been extensively researched since the early 1980s. Social work focuses on, among other things, the bond between people & their environment. More than half of all families have one or more companion animals, which makes animals an important part of the environment. Social work also strives to improve the quality of life of the community. Companion animals can fulfil different needs for different target groups & are therefore important role players in the pursuit of a better quality of life for individuals, groups, & communities. The role of the social worker in the multidisciplinary team can be divided into five main areas: the aim of social work intervention, the roles of the social worker, target groups in social work, the needs of people, & approaches toward rendering aid. Recommendations are made by which the social worker can promote positive human-animal interaction through multidisciplinary cooperation. 2 Tables, 74 References. Adapted from the source document.

Striving for Synergy: Gender Analysis and Indigenous Social Work Practice in South Africa

Author: Hochfeld, Tessa11 Centre Social Work, U Witwatersrand

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61522131?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article argues that excellent social work practice is not possible in the current South African context without taking into account the issue of gender. First, the meaning of "gender analysis" is explored. The historical roots of the gender disparity in South Africa are traced & the current status of women is outlined. Gender analysis is shown to be a useful tool to understand the developmental issues that are being faced today, & compelling reasons for incorporating gender into social work practice are explored in the context of contemporary South Africa. Resonance between gender analysis & indigenous social work practice are explored & clarified, & the relevance of gender analysis for indigenous practice is affirmed. The article concludes with a discussion of some of the possible reasons for the seeming absence of gender analysis in contemporary indigenous practice. 32 References. Adapted from the source document.

An Exploration of the Factors Which Promote and Impede Correctional Supervision Effectiveness with Regard to Juvenile or Young Offenders

Author: Clarke-McLeod, P G1; Van Zyl, C.1 Dept Social Development, Rhodes U, Grahamstown

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61553807?accountid=14667

Abstract: Explores fundamentals of correctional supervision as an alternative to standard prison sentencing for young offenders in South Africa. Crime rates among young South Africans has been steadily rising, & the effectiveness of imprisonment as a means of punishment has been undergoing increasingly intense scrutiny. Prison sentencing in South Africa is increasingly viewed as a waste of assets whereby the young offender is given no support or means to reintegrate into society. The costs associated with keeping a single prisoner go far beyond what the costs that would apply to educating the same individual. Therefore, there is increasing emphasis placed on correctional supervision as a constructive means of disciplining a young offender while making him or her a more positive, engaged, & valuable member of society. The offender is generally kept under house arrest & made to perform a series of services deemed useful to the community. Empirical studies have demonstrated that while certain challenges arise in administering this correctional tactic, the overall results have been positive in rehabilitating young offenders. It is suggested that social workers & other multidisciplinary professionals pool their resources in order to make correctional supervision a successful program. 83 References. C. Brunski

Social Work Research on the Feelings and Perceptions of AIDS Patients in a South African Clinic

Author: Strydom, Herman11 School Psycho-Social Behavioural Sciences, Division Social Work, U Christian Higher Education, Potchefstroom

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61508361?accountid=14667

Abstract: Qualitatively examines the feelings of patients in a South African AIDS/HIV clinic through interviews & observation. Patients were observed as being glad to see each other in the clinic & were judged as being mutually supportive. Conversation between the subjects covered virtually every facet of life connected to HIV/AIDS. One-on-one semistructured interview data offer a general portrait of patient perceptions & understandings in relation to their condition & the way that their condition is viewed by the rest of the society. 43 References. Rising to the Challenge: The Critical Role of Social Workers in the Face of the HIV/AIDS Pandemic

Author: Saloner, Kerry L11 School Social Work, U Witwatersrand, Johannesburg

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61450147?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper discusses the critical role that the social worker has to play in the current HIV/AIDS context. The writer will specifically examine the social worker's role in sharing her skills, knowledge, & attitudes (hereon SKAs) with different professional bodies. In examining this role, it becomes apparent that the professional SKAs of social workers are insufficient to go around & reach all who are in need. His/her role cannot, therefore, purely be one of treatment provider or problem-oriented interventionist. In order to effectively redistribute some of the relevant SKA of the profession, more time & energy need to be channeled into his/her role as educator & skills disseminator. The dissemination of such SKAs may better equip lay & professional people to meet the critical needs of many isolated & alienated South Africans. 22 References. Adapted from the source document.

Part One: Guidelines for the Use of Metaphor in Social Work Management of Sexually Molested Children

Author: Oelofse, Mev M1; Weyers, M L1 c/o Weyers -- Skool Psigo-Sosiale Gedragswetenskappe, Potchefstroomse U Christian Higher Education

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61522200?accountid=14667

Abstract: Background: Due to the high incidence of child sexual abuse in South Africa & an increasing number of cases being reported to social work institutions, practitioners have come under pressure to deliver more effective therapeutic services to especially the victims of such circumstances. Their interventions have, however, been hampered by two factors: the absence of well-grounded treatment programs & a lack of therapeutic techniques & aids that would meet local needs. Objectives: To develop a treatment program that could be used as a guideline for intervention & to determine the usefulness of metaphors as therapeutic tools in the application of this program. Method: The research encompassed the establishment of a tentative treatment program & its testing & refinement through multiple case studies. These cases covered 107+ children that were allocated to the researcher while she was working at the Welcome Child Guidance Clinic, 1992-1999. The development & testing of metaphors formed an integral part of this process. The results that were obtained will be covered in two separate papers, one pertaining to the program itself & the other to the use of metaphors. Part 1 shows that the program was found to be an effective instrument in the delivery of therapeutic services. It especially gave structure to a complex process & ensured that all relevant issues would be covered in a systematic albeit unobtrusive way. 1 Diagram, 35 References. Adapted from the source document.

Developing Cultural Awareness in Human Service Professionals: A Personal Journey

Author: Sturgeon, Shona11 Dept Social Development, U Cape Town

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61506678?accountid=14667

Abstract: In order to function appropriately & sensitively in a rapidly changing multicultural/racial society such as South Africa, human service professionals must be aware of their own life experiences & how these have contributed to the development of their prejudices. This awareness also sensitizes them to the development of prejudice, & therefore promotes a better understanding & tolerance of the prejudice of others, & the way that this prejudice can be altered. Students in the Dept of Social Development are required to write an "Ethnic Autobiography," tracing their life history in terms of their awareness & experience of their own & other ethnic groups, how this awareness was developed & their current attitudes. This experience forms the experiential component of a module on antidiscriminatory practice & is described by students as a very powerful & sensitizing experience. 5 References. Adapted from the source document.

Community Participation: Rhetoric or Reality?

Author: Raniga, Tanusha1; Simpson, Barbara1 Centre Social Work, U Natal

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61537757?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper examines community participation in relation to an abortive attempt to establish a community garden project in an informal settlement on the Dolphin Coast of South Africa. Examining what went wrong in this project & making suggestions for avoiding these problems in the future will hopefully contribute to improved intervention strategies. The paper begins with a brief overview of the literature concerning community participation & highlights some of the difficulties associated with its definition. This provides the context for understanding community participation in the garden project. It then describes the community garden project & outlines the research process that was used to evaluate community participation in this project. The results of this research study revealed that, although community participation was valued in principle, its practical application was lacking. Reasons for this are advanced & the implications of this for practice are discussed. 23 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Strengths Perspective in Social Work: Lessons from Practice

Author: Gray, Mel1; Collett van Rooyen, Colin A. J.1 School Social Sciences, U Newcastle, New South Wales, Australia

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61555954?accountid=14667

Abstract: The paper provides an overview of the strengths perspective in social work, which offers a critical, radical approach to practice in the sense that, among other things, it questions (1) the dominant deficits-based mental health paradigm, which pigeonholes people in terms of pathology & assigns them disempowermg labels; (2) antioppressive practice models that construe clients as oppressed & immediately engender feelings of powerlessness; & (3) rigid mindsets such as positivism, ardent feminism, & structuralism that lead practitioners to approach the helping situation with preconceived ideas that influence the way they listen to, hear, & interpret the client's story & thus the way they design their interventions. It reviews the domains in which strength-based approaches have taken hold from individual counseling, such as solution-focused brief therapy, to community interventions, such as assets-based community development, & narrative approaches which span both the individual & community, to policy where proactive policies, such as family preservation policies, reflect their influence. The paper then examines its relevance, drawing on lessons from practice. 24 References. Adapted from the source document.

Social Workers' Evaluation of the Residential Care System Project-Go in Gauteng Province

Author: Mashego, Poppy K1; Lombard, Antionette1 Dept Social Work, U Pretoria

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61550347?accountid=14667

Abstract: The transformation of the child & youth care system in conjunction with Project-Go, the unblocking of the residential care system, has laid a cornerstone for the development of a family-based & child-friendly approach to service delivery. The motivation behind protecting children's rights includes a reemphasis of the need to move away from the traditional pathology-based & deficits-based models toward the developmental & strengths-based approach. This article reports on a study conducted in the Gauteng province, South Africa, among probation officers & social workers that are working with children & youths in residential care facilities. The study assumed that if social workers have a clear knowledge & understanding of, & a positive attitude toward, the Project-Go concept & process, implementation would then be successful in improving the lives of children, youths, & families. The research findings indicated that social workers have a clear knowledge & understanding of the concept & process of Project-Go, that they support the principles & philosophy of this concept & share the same values & beliefs about family preservation & family reunification. However, some social workers have very specific perceptions & concerns with regard to the planning, design, & implementation of Project-Go. The article concludes with specific recommendations in this regard. 2 Tables, 20 Figures, 17 References. Adapted from the source document.

Story of the Life Satisfaction of a Group of Retired Domestic Workers in South Africa: A Qualitative Study

Author: Cronje, Elsje M11 Dept Psychology, U South Africa, Pretoria

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/60473612?accountid=14667

Abstract: The story of the life satisfaction of a group of elderly, black, South African retired women who had worked as domestic workers is told in different voices. On the basis of previous research, I had expected that black women in a low-status occupation would not have a significant measure of life satisfaction, but I was surprised by their degree of life satisfaction, their sense of meaningfulness, their feelings of achievement, & their pride in themselves & their children. For most of these women, their church activities are very important & enjoyable, & the well-being of their children & grandchildren is also very important to them -- many are involved with the care of their grandchildren. Most of them live with their children &/or other relatives, & feel, in their contributions to the household & the care of the grandchildren, that they are still useful. In spite of the "triple jeopardy" (age, poverty, & ethnicity) that confronts elderly blacks, these women display a strong resilience. 1 Figure, 62 References. Adapted from the source document.

A Model for the Use of Metaphor in Social Work Management of Sexually Molested Children

Author: Oelofse, Mev M1; Weyers, M L1 c/o Weyers -- Skool Psigo-Sosiale Gedragswetenskappe, Potchefstroomse U Christian Higher Education

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61553866?accountid=14667

Abstract: Background: Due to the high incidence of child sexual abuse in South Africa & an increasing number of cases being reported to social worker institutions, practitioners have come under pressure to deliver more effective therapeutic services, especially to victims. Their interventions have, however, been hampered by two factors: the absence of well-grounded treatment programs & a lack of therapeutic techniques & aids that would meet local needs. Objectives: To develop a treatment program that could be used as a guideline for intervention & to determine the usefulness of metaphors as therapeutic tools in the application of this program. Method: The research encompassed the establishment of a tentative treatment program & its testing & refinement through multiple case studies. These cases covered more than 107 children who were allocated to the researcher while she was working at the Welcome Child Guidance Clinic, 1992-1999. The development & testing of metaphors formed an integral part of this process. The results that were obtained are covered in two separate papers; Part I covered the program itself. In Part II, results of the use of metaphors are discussed, concluding that they were effective in the establishment of a therapeutic relationship, in helping children to cope with feelings of guilt & shame, & in addressing irrational thoughts & emotional pain. They were also useful in helping them to internalize new knowledge & insight, master new skills, & develop a new feeling of self worth. 1 Diagram, 23 References. Adapted from the source document.

Resource and Support Programmes for Poor Families in a Rural Residential Area

Author: Green, Sulina1; Kruger, Sorette P1 Dept Social Work, U Stellenbosch

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61500931?accountid=14667

Abstract: Under the current social, economic, & political changes in South Africa, poor families experience many different problems that affect their daily functioning & it becomes more demanding for them to meet their basic caring responsibilities without the assistance of other systems in the community. They need the support of formal systems such as churches, schools, welfare agencies, & community resources, as well as informal systems such as their family & friends. These are crucial for promoting & maintaining the quality of these families' daily lives (Sviridoff & Ryan, 1997; Unger & Powell, 1990). In this paper, some attempts to improve the quality of family life made by a welfare agency where final-year social work students are placed for their fieldwork are explained. At this welfare agency the students were working in projects specifically aimed at building the strengths of poor families. A theoretical overview of how these projects were planned & implemented will be presented. Where applicable, practical illustrations or examples will be given. 25 References. Adapted from the source document.

Theories and Models Serving as a Basis for the Design of an HIV/AIDS Prevention Programme for Students

Author: Strydom, H1; Strydom, C1 School Psychosocial Behavioural Sciences, Potchefstroom U Christian Higher Education

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61500773?accountid=14667

Abstract: Presents a summary of features that make for the success or failure of an HIV prevention campaign & offers suggestions for the use of peer leadership in such campaigns. Various behavioral models, including the Health Belief Model, the AIDS Risk Reduction Model, the Stages of Change Model, & the Theory of Reasoned Actions Model, all advance the idea that the perceived risks & benefits of behavioral change predict the likelihood of a given behavioral change & assist in behavioral interventions. Drawing on these models, the most successful & powerful strategies for the implementation of a successful HIV prevention program are identified, including proper definition of goals, an ability to reach out to diversity, promotion of life-skills, focus on health, emphasis on open communication, proper training of facilitators, & mutual acceptance of the prevention program. 5 Figures, 23 References. C. Brunski

Needs and Expectations of Field Instructors in Practice Education

Author: Strydom, M11 Dept Social Work, U Stellenbosch

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61500806?accountid=14667

Abstract: Addresses the relationship between social work field instructors, the students engaged in field practice education, the hosting welfare organization, & the training institution. If the interplay between these parties & the specific needs & expectations of field instructors were more deeply understood, there would be a lesser turnover in field instructors as well as a higher degree of achievement reached by instructors & students. The field instructor is seen as balanced between two systems -- the training institution & the welfare organization hosting the practice education program. It is noted that, especially during social crisis, the social worker feels a primary duty to the welfare institution & a secondary duty to the training institution. Increased workloads means that field instructors are often incapable of meeting the demands of their training duties, & the level of field education goes down. This, in turn, makes for a weakened wave of younger social workers, a situation that can work in its own way to prolong the period of crisis the welfare organization is attempting to cope with. Systematic improvement of the field instructor's compensation, communication with the training institution, benefits, & other support mechanisms might radically improve strained field training resources & conditions. 29 References. C. Brunski

The Importance of Peer Counselling in Helping to Change Attitudes of Persons with Disabilities

Author: Hlongwane, N M11 Spinal Unit, Conradie Hospital

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61480897?accountid=14667

Abstract: Arguing that peer counseling is an essential component of the rehabilitation process for persons with disabilities, described is a program in South Africa in which former patients are used as assistants to rehabilitation therapists working with new patients. Establishment of a common background experience & identification by new rehabilitation patients of an earlier patient as a model of the advantages & promises of rehabilitation are powerful facets of the patient's ability to accept his or her personal disability & adapt to a new way of life. Peer counseling at the Conradie Hospital's spinal unit, founded on a tier-system that strives to make the closest approximation possible between patients & peer counselors in regards to language, shared disability, etc, has been subject to evaluation that demonstrates through comparative case studies that those patients who had peer counseling as part of their rehabilitation regime tended to adapt more fully to their disabilities & continue productive activities in comparison to those who had not had peer counseling. 9 References. C. Brunski

Indigenous Practice -- Some Informed Guesses. Self Evident and Possible

Author: Osei-Hwedie, Kwaku11 U Botswana

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61550649?accountid=14667

Abstract: Explores the indigenization of social work in Africa as a possible way to make its efforts more credible & effective in assisting development. African societies could apply their own theories, models, values, & processes to the professional practice of social work. This would allow social work to become more relevant as it is connected to the cultural & socioeconomic realities of each area. Within Africa, social work would focus more on community & social development than on individuals. It is debated whether Africans can break from the influences of colonialism, but it is argued that the majority of Africans have only superficial contact outside their societies are not as Westernized as some would argue (Bar-On 1999, 2002). Western education & analytical processes can assist in deconstructing Western social work models & in finding an indigenous or local perspective in social work practice. 1 Figure, 32 References. Adapted from the source document.

Cross-Cultural Practice and the Indigenisation of African Social Work

Author: Gray, Mel1; Allegritti, Inta1 School Social Sciences, U Newcastle, New South Wales, Australia

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61538087?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper examines the issues involved in developing indigenous social work practice & speculates about some of the reasons why this is of ongoing importance to African social work writers. Among other things, we argue (1) that social work is a Western invention & a product of modernity while indigenization is a postmodern notion; (2) that the difference between Western & African understanding of culture is an integral aspect of the indigenization debate; & (3) that an historical perspective is needed to understand both past & present influences like colonization & globalization respectively. In developing these arguments further, several themes are addressed, ie, the difference between Western & African values & the lasting impact of colonialism on Africa; the cultural basis of indigenization & the notion that culture is more central than values (which simultaneously inform, flow from & mould culture); indigenization as cross-cultural practice & the need for dialogical (postmodernist) rather than existing (modernist) models; & indigenization as a form of resistance & a medium for transformation from externally imposed to locally developed models of practice & solutions. We begin with a brief introduction to the international literature on indigenization & then present an overview of Southern African literature on the indigenization debate, the source of most of the African indigenization literature, before moving to our central thesis relating to indigenization as cross-cultural practice. We end with several proposals as to how indigenous practice models in Africa might be developed. 53 References. Adapted from the source document.

Indigenous Knowledge and Practice in HIV/AIDS Education and Prevention with Particular Reference to Women

Author: Malherbe, Blanche R11 Dept Social Work, Huguenot Coll, Wellington

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61481036?accountid=14667

Abstract: Approaches the crisis of the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) & acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) pandemic in Africa & its impact on women, with the assumption that prevention must be emphasized since the costs of treatment are too overwhelming (Kellerman, 2000; Whiteside & Sunder, 2000). This paper is concerned with education at the local level & with primary prevention. High levels of sexually transmitted diseases (STDs), rape & violent sex, unwillingness to use condoms, risky contraception practices, poverty, & the low status of women contribute to the high risk of a severe HIV/AIDS epidemic in South Africa. Informed & responsible behavior of high-risk groups is key to preventing HIV transmission. AIDS education could include sex health education, behavior change interventions, voluntary HIV counseling & testing, encouragement of condom use, & screening for STDs & tuberculosis. Indigenous knowledge & the socioeconomic & cultural realities of women's lives should be considered in prevention programs. 3 Figures, 39 References. L. A. Hoffman

Mac-Social Work: The Routinisation of Professional Activity

Author: Leveridge, Martin11 School Health & Social Care, U Teesside, Middlesbrough, UK

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61501282?accountid=14667

Abstract: Argues that social work practice in Local Authority Social Service Depts (SSDs) in the UK has become routinized, the social worker's role has become that of a technician, & this impacts the rights of service-users. Within a context of political change, four historical trends are identified as leading to this situation: (1) use of the term "social worker" as a Local Authority job title; (2) pressures to increase the control of professional workers in SSDs, in particular through the use of forms; (3) the disjunction between practice & theory; & (4) emergence of counseling as a separate profession. Visiting students on placement & working with part-time students in the classroom, I have been struck in recent years by the restricted view social workers appear to have of their role, & by the way in which they see their work as increasingly constrained by form-filling. It is nothing new for social workers to complain about paperwork, lack of resources, or the attitude of their managers, but this seemed to have been compounded by the way in which reforms to social services for the old, sick, & disabled (Community Care) have been implemented, & by a defensive reaction from agencies to enquiries & criticism. This paper seeks to outline the issues on which further research might be based & to identify how qualifying programs might seek to broaden the horizons for their students. 29 References. Adapted from the source document.

Issues in Defining "Universal Social Work": Comparing Social Work in South Africa and Australia

Author: Gray, Mel1; Fook, Jan1 School Social Sciences, U Newcastle, New South Wales, Australia

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61550683?accountid=14667

Abstract: In this paper, we discuss the issues involved in making generalizations about social work across different contexts by comparing the development of social welfare & the practice of social work in South Africa & Australia. Given that the idea of the profession is, to some extent, constructed in historical, social, & cultural contexts, we next look at what this means for the idea of a universal definition of the social work profession & its implications for indigenous practice. We argue that while the discourse of social work might be similar across countries, the actual form & expression its practice takes may be quite variable. We end by appealing for a grounded approach where flexibility allows for relevant & appropriate practice responsive to local contexts yet still allows for accountability, connectivity, & a common professional identity across countries in the belief that "because the form that social work takes is so intimately related to any society's or country's goals for itself & its people, its values, its mores, it is inevitable that forms of social work should differ from country to country, & that its patterns of social work education should differ from country to country" (Smalley, 1968:163). 1 Table, 72 References. Adapted from the source document.

Feminist and Ethical Aspects of the Assisted Reproductive Technologies (Arts): Challenges for Social Work

Author: Sewpaul, V11 Centre Social Work, U Natal, Durban

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61508577?accountid=14667

Abstract: All forms of assisted or new reproductive techniques, such as artificial insemination by husband (AIH), artificial insemination by donor (AID), donor eggs, surrogacy, the gamete intra-fallopian transfer (GIFT), & in vitro fertilization (IVF), have one thing in common. They all effectively separate reproduction from sexual intercourse. Snowden, Mitchell, & Snowden (1983:6) asserted that this simple statement "raises social, moral, & ethical questions which go far beyond the technological & medical considerations that have received most of the publicity to date." Medical technologies do not develop in a vacuum. They reflect complex moral & social issues that scientists are reluctant to debate. These technologies do not merely reflect the social, cultural, & political contexts of their development. Their uses in society have quite profound biological, psychological, & sociocultural repercussions that far exceed the complexities of the technologies themselves. This paper addresses some of the debates around the feminist & ethical aspects of the new reproductive technologies. 2 Appendixes, 66 References. Adapted from the source document.

Accountability in Social Care: A Conceptual Analysis

Author: van Niekerk, Anton11 Sentrum Toegepaste Etiek, U Stellenbosch

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61556308?accountid=14667

Abstract: In this article, the concept of "accountability" is submitted to a philosophical conceptual analysis, pertaining, in particular, to its relevance for social work. The author argues that the concept gains actuality in our current situation because of the increase in violent & white-collar crime, but also because accountability is an inevitable desideratum of a process of democratization. He analyzes the concept with reference to its meaning in the close interaction between individual & community, the tension between autonomy & limitless freedom, the moral demand that acts be universalizable, & the need for a self-critical attitude. He goes on to analyze the similarities & differences between accountability & responsibility, drawing on work done by Hans Jonas on responsibility. He concludes with remarks on the instances/parties to whom social workers are accountable, &, in this connection, distinguishes between five kinds of accountability, viz. administrative, political, collegial, professional, & moral. 11 References. Adapted from the source document.

Standards for Social Work Qualifications in South Africa

Author: Lombard, Antoinette1; Grobbelaar, Margaret; Pruis, Santie1 Committee Education & Training, U Pretoria, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61550735?accountid=14667

Abstract: Outlines the new guidelines for quality assurance in social work in South Africa, highlighting the creation of the South African Qualifications Authority (SAQA) & the formulation of an integrated National Qualifications Framework to develop national standards & qualifications in terms of education & training. The development of Standards Generating Bodies (SGBs) empowered to develop, approve, & oversee the enforcement of these standards are described, including their membership, meetings, financing, consultation with stakeholders, & submission of qualifications. The components of & requirements for obtaining five distinct social work qualifications are outlined: the FET certificate in Social Auxiliary Work; the Bachelor of Social Work, Structure Master of Social Work, Research Master of Social Work, & Doctor of Social Work. Educational & associated professional assessment criteria & standards for each qualification are reviewed. 4 Tables, 12 References. K. Hyatt Stewart

Urbanization: An Interdisciplinary Approach to a Complex Phenomenon

Author: van der Merwe, Izak1; Bekker, Simon1 Dept Geography, U Stellenbosch

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61504757?accountid=14667

Abstract: On account of the complexity & universal character of the urbanization process, many academic disciplines, including social work, focus on this phenomenon. Accordingly, definitions tend to diverge, & the key concepts & research methodologies of the various disciplines are typically at variance with one another. Such a situation makes interdisciplinary & comparative international studies on urbanization challenging to execute. One such comparative study has been initiated by the U of Stellenbosch, South Africa, & Bordeaux, France, promoting both interdisciplinary as well as intercontinental cooperation. The potential success of this interdisciplinary analysis arises mainly from the openness of concepts & methodologies as well as the judicious choice of cities. In addition, the selection of central questions & of shared themes appears to be important. This paper will reflect on these issues by considering aspects of a recently launched interdisciplinary & international research program. Some perspective, however, is needed beforehand on the two relevant concepts of interdisciplinarity & urbanization. 11 References. Adapted from the source document.

Indigenous Practice: Some Informed Guesses -- Self-Evident but Impossible

Author: Bar-On, Arnon11 Dept Social Work, U Botswana, Gaborone

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61519399?accountid=14667

Abstract: Ever since Western social work was exported to Africa, an ongoing debate has been taking place on whether it fits the African context. Most of this debate, however, has revolved around Western social work's techniques rather than on its ends, which, being predicated on Western values, are likely to be alien to many Africans. The article outlines the arguments why Africa might require a form of social work of its own & the chances of such indigenization taking place. It concludes, however, that while indigenization may be a desirable end, it is probably impossible unless African social workers can engage in reflective learning with their clients. 1 Table, 91 References. Adapted from the source document.

Participation, Civil Society and Social Work Practice

Author: Gathiram, Neeta11 School Sport Science & Social Work, U Durban, Westville

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61547898?accountid=14667

Abstract: A major goal of democratizing South Africa is to increase the participation of politically & economically disenfranchised populations in civic activities that can lead to their empowerment. Described here are developmental interventions initiated at the local, provincial, & national levels to increase citizen participation. The goals of such social welfare intervention & the importance of their working in conjunction with local communities are discussed, along with the immediate & long-term benefits of increased civil society participation. The key role of social workers in such programs is highlighted, & particular implications for practice are considered, focusing on human resource development through volunteer mobilization & education. 27 References. K. Hyatt Stewart

Stigmatisation of HIV-Positive Members of the Workforce

Author: Nowell, J H1; van der Merwe, R. P.1 Dept Industrial & Organizational Psychology, U Port Elizabeth

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61547942?accountid=14667

Abstract: The rate at which the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)/acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) pandemic is spreading throughout the world, especially Africa, is alarming. Although Africa contains only about 12% of the world's population, it contains over 70% of HIV-infected individuals. It is estimated that over 10% of the South African population is HIV-positive (Addison, 2001). This pandemic is a threat to the economy, individual workers, & society in general (House, Eicken & Gray, 1995). Social implications of HIV/AIDS include fear, prejudice, discrimination, hysteria, stigmatization & other irrational responses from members of society (Herek & Glunt, 1988; House et al, 1995). For the purpose of this study, "stigmatization" refers to the irrational responses (including fear, attitudes, & prejudicial behavior) by co-workers &/or superiors in the work environment toward HIV-positive individuals. 2 Tables, 1 Figure, 20 References. Adapted from the source document.

HIV/AIDS and South African Adolescents: Attitudes and Information Needs

Author: Strydom, H11 School Psychosocial Behavioural Sciences, Potchefstroom U Christian Higher Education

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61506001?accountid=14667

Abstract: HIV/AIDS is by far the most serious health hazard of our time & by far the biggest current crisis in South Africa. Prevention of the disease by way of communicating correct knowledge & information, in order to change individuals' & communities' attitudes & sexual behavior, is of vital importance. This exploratory study utilized a purposive, non-probability sampling technique to administer questionnaires to adolescents throughout the North West Province. The aim of the study was to assess attitudes & needs for information of high school pupils on various aspects of HIV/AIDS in order to draw up recommendations for a prospective program to educate adolescents & influence their attitudes toward HIV/AIDS. It was found that adolescents had an urgent need for more knowledge & information on sexuality & HIV/AIDS, that the idea of condoms has taken on with adolescents, & that they have a fair to positive attitude toward the problem. It is recommended that a program be developed to educate adolescents about sexuality & HIV/AIDS in an objective & factual manner. Outsiders should be utilized to implement such a program. Material & facilities like videos, films, flip charts, books, & posters, are indispensable in any such program. It is vital to indigenize such a program for use under South African circumstances -- one that can be adapted to the facilities of all schools. 6 Tables, 39 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Impact of Gestalt Play Techniques on the Aggression Level of Diabetic Children

Author: Doorgapershad, M1; Bauling, H1 U Pretoria

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61534812?accountid=14667

Abstract: The study was undertaken to investigate the impact of gestalt group work play techniques on the aggression levels of diabetic children ages 8-12. The motivation for the study came from the researcher's interactions at the out-patient clinic at Addington Hospital, where staff indicated a need for group work sessions with patients at the juvenile diabetic clinic. The health team who managed the children also encountered the aggression. These two aspects offered an opportunity for the researcher to investigate the effect of gestalt group work play techniques on the aggression levels of these children. The sample consisted of two boys & two girls who attended the diabetic out-patient clinic at Parklands Hospital. The researcher selected techniques that allowed support & security for the group members as they experimented with new behaviors. A comparison of pre-test & post-test results offers a strong recommendation for inclusion of gestalt group work play techniques as part of the holistic treatment of juvenile diabetics. 15 References. Adapted from the source document.

Combating Child Labour -- A South African Challenge

Author: Veeran, D. L. (Vasintha)11 Centre Social Work, School Psychology, U Natal, Durban

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61506289?accountid=14667

Abstract: After outlining difficulties with defining & measuring child labor, efforts to combat this problem in South Africa are examined. The determinants of child labor are identified, distinguishing between internal & external factors; the relationship between compulsory schooling & child labor laws is also explored. An integrated approach to eradicating child labor at the international level is outlined, & specific applications to the South African situation are discussed. Focus is on the creation of the Child Labour Inter-Sectoral Group in 1998; its contributions to policy making, legislation, program implementation, & social mobilization are reviewed. 24 References. K. Hyatt Stewart

Women and Social Development: Global Opportunities for Gender-Conscious Transformation in the New Millennium

Author: Jones, Norma S C1; Perry, Tonya E1 School Social Work, Howard U, Washington

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61498281?accountid=14667

Abstract: The struggle for women's liberation from male domination transcends barriers related to social class, culture, race, & nationality. Indeed, throughout the world, women in both industrialized & developing countries are working toward the elimination of social & economic inequalities. The universal issues facing women must be recognized & affirmed by social & political planners in the formulation of progressive development policies & programs consistent with the challenges of the new century. This conceptual paper will explore critical issues related to the role of women in social development & highlight opportunities for gender system transformation associated with projected social & structural developments of the new millennium. The paper will begin with an overview of the status of women in the world, followed by a discussion of critical issues related to women in social development, & a review of strategies implemented by the world's women to achieve gender equality. A summary of selected approaches to gender-inclusive development policies & an outline of a multi-systemic approach to woman-centered development will be offered. The authors conclude by outlining global recommendations for progressive, woman-centered politics of social development. 1 Table, 46 References. Adapted from the source document.
