The Relevance of Feminism in Modern Social Work

Author: Makofane, M D M11 U North

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61505143?accountid=14667

Abstract: The aim of this paper is to present the perceptions of social work educators on the relevance of feminism in the undergraduate curriculum. An exploratory pilot study was conducted among ten social work educators from four universities (two in Gauteng & two in Limpopo province) on factors that motivate educators to incorporate feminism in the curriculum. Purposive sampling was employed to select educators who are involved in teaching direct practice with individuals & groups. Unstructured interviews were used to elicit qualitative data from the respondents. The major findings revealed that educators have divergent opinions on the incorporation of feminism in social work training. Even though the results are inconclusive, different views expressed by educators necessitate future in-depth research in this area. 1 Table, 21 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Relationship between Child Sexual, Physical, Psychological, Emotional and Ritualistic Abuse among High School Students in the Northern Province, South Africa

Author: Madu, S N1; Peltzer, K1 Dept Psychology, U North, Sovenga

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/60468992?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study is an investigation into the relationship between child sexual, physical, psychological, emotional, & ritualistic abuse among high school students in the Northern Province (South Africa). Gender & urban-rural differences are also examined in relation to child sexual abuse. The method of secondary data analysis was used to analyze the same data used by Madu & Peltzer (1998, 2000) & Madu, Peltzer, & Mashego (1998). Logistic Regression Analysis shows that among all the participants, child sexual abuse correlates positively with psychological & emotional forms of child abuse. No gender correlated significantly with child sexual abuse. Chi-Square analysis for village-urban difference shows that child sexual abuse occurs more often in the urban areas than in the villages. The authors conclude that mental health workers & social workers should take note of the above relationship in planning preventive & therapeutic strategies for victims of child abuse in the area. 1 Table, 75 References. Adapted from the source document.

Child Sexual Abuse as a Precursor to Prostitution

Author: Saffy, Jacqueline11 Dept Criminology, U Pretoria

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61546569?accountid=14667

Abstract: The child as a victim of sexual abuse has recently received deliberated attention within the South African context. In the study undertaken, the immediate as well as long-term effect of such abuse was investigated with the pertinent intent of identifying a link between child sexual abuse & the involvement in prostitution. Utilizing a qualitative approach, 20 prostitutes were interviewed & their experiences & opinions with respect to the circumstances surrounding their childhood abuse as well as the effects thereof documented. With reasons such as fear of their perpetrator, feelings of helplessness, & a fear of causing a break up of the family, disclosure of the abuse was not apparent in any of the respondents. Thus the extent of the effects of child sexual abuse could be described as being directly associated with, & causative of the individual's late adaptation in life. Emotional effects, the most frequently reported effect of sexual abuse, physical injuries, which all respondents reported having experiences & social withdrawal on both micro & macro levels were evident. In the light of these far-reaching & detrimental effects associated with child sexual abuse, as related to the choice to become involved in prostitution, the need for South Africa to address this issue is highlighted. 23 References. Adapted from the source document.

Perspectives of Elderly Blacks on Institutional Care

Author: Ryke, Elma1; Ngiba, Tiny; Strydom, Herman1 Potchefstroom U Christian Higher Education

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/60488971?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article reports on the perspectives of black elderly persons regarding where they believe persons such as themselves should stay, where they themselves would like to stay, & where their families & children would like them to stay. Their knowledge of alternative care & their consideration of ever living an in old-age home are also discussed. It was found that the indigenous support system for caring for elderly people in their communities by their children is still practiced & preferred by the elderly, but not significantly so by the younger generation. It became clear from the study that old-age homes were still a rather new & largely unacceptable concept to elderly black persons. 5 Tables, 15 References. Adapted from the source document.

What Do Residents of Informal Settlements Think Social Workers Should Do: Voices from Bhambayi

Author: Simpson, Barbara11 Centre Social Work, U Natal

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61497702?accountid=14667

Abstract: In 1992 the Center for Social Work at the U of Natal established a community-based student unit at Bhambayi, an informal settlement some 25 km north of the Durban city center. Senior social work students, under the supervision of a member of the academic staff, offer a much needed social work service to this unique community. Students offer a variety of social work services. Individual casework services focus primarily on helping people to access grants & pensions & on specialist services for epilepsy, mental illness, & mental handicaps. Child abuse, custody disputes, & relationship problems are also dealt with. A children's club provides a weekly meeting for primary school children & offers them the opportunity to socialize, learn arts & crafts, & to develop life skills. Community education programs have been very successful, with the community participating enthusiastically in fun days, clean-up days, & awareness programs. The challenges of doing social work in a community such as this have been great -- periodic outbreaks of violence, community conflicts, & what often seems like community apathy impact negatively on service delivery. One of the greatest frustrations for students working in Bhambayi has been what appears to be unrealistic expectations of what social work can achieve. Some people, for example, have openly stated that they are not prepared to volunteer to help with community projects unless there is payment involved, while others have stated that income-generating groups take too long to establish & are not worth the effort. This paper describes a research study that was carried out to determine what the residents of Bhambayi thought about social work -- what problems they thought social workers should deal with & how they believed social workers should address these problems. 17 References. Adapted from the source document.

Social Development: Good Practice Guidelines

Author: Green, S1; Nieman, A1 Dept Social Work, U Stellenbosch

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61505176?accountid=14667

Abstract: Faced by increasing pressure on resources, stringent policy requirements, & pervasive poverty affecting communities, welfare organizations & social workers in South Africa are forced to consider changing the way they operate. This article is based on a study that was undertaken to determine practical guidelines to help social workers & welfare organizations to implement & run social development programs. An in-depth literature study as well as the findings of the qualitative research undertaken, proved that success can be achieved by adhering to certain good practice criteria which the researchers identified. These criteria, considered as guideposts, could be helpful to practitioners contemplating instituting social development projects. 5 Tables, 1 Figure, 42 References. Adapted from the source document.

An Investigation in Relation to Performance Evaluation of Social Workers in Welfare Organizations

Author: Malherbe, B R1; Van Bosch, K L1 Program Maatskaplike Werk, Hugenote Koll Wellington

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61498323?accountid=14667

Abstract: Although performance appraisal is critical to the effective management of a welfare organization the performance appraisal of social workers are often neglected, implemented incorrectly or regarded within a negative light. This exploratory/descriptive study aimed to set scientifically grounded guidelines for the implementation of performance appraisal with regard to social workers. The idea was not to provide comprehensive guidelines regarding every aspect for performance appraisal, but to identify gaps & problems which may be studied in future research. Through questionnaires the perceptions of performance appraisal by 38 social workers & four social work managers were tested & described. It seemed that performance appraisal of social workers is geared towards development, & that social workers & social work managers do benefit from performance appraisal. Social workers were of the opinion that performance appraisal should be employed to identify gaps & development areas in equipping social workers professionally. 6 Figures, 29 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Experience of Successful Transition from a Children's Home to Independent Living

Author: Muller, Karl S1; Jansen van Rensburg, Madri S.; Makobe, M K1 SOS Children's Villages, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61554848?accountid=14667

Abstract: The research explores the experience of growing up in a children's home, as well as the experience of having to make a transition from a children's home to society. It wants to know from individuals who have lived this experience, what they believe aided them in attaining success, & what has hindered their strivings. In consultation with SOS Children's Villages, the researchers chose to follow a positive ethos similar to Cooperrider's Appreciative Inquiry (Hammond, 1996). Appreciative Inquiry is a theory of organizational change that focuses on "what works" rather than traditional "what is broken" models of problem solving (Hammond, 1996). The underlying assumptions of Appreciative Inquiry are (1) in every society, organization, or group, something works, & (2) what we focus on becomes our reality (Hammond, 1996:4). Consequently, the present research is aimed at learning "what works" from the experience of those that have grown up in their villages. 45 References. Adapted from the source document.

Author: Engelbrecht, L K1; Theron, S M1 Dept Maatskaplike Werk, U Stellenbosch

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61507582?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social work managers are becoming increasingly involved in financial planning & control of welfare organizations due to the fact that successful management of a welfare organization does not only revolve around the quality of social work services. Entrepreneurship in Africa: Social Work Challenges for Human, Social and Economic Development

Author: Lombard, Antionette11 Dept Social Work, U Pretoria

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61501276?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper argues that the entrepreneurial road in the African context cannot be isolated from the context of poverty. In order to alleviate poverty, three strategies are presented that may be applied by social work to achieve social development: (1) individualist strategies; (2) communitarian strategies; & (3) government strategies. These strategies are used to discuss the integration of human, social, & economic capital development in proceeding with the development of entrepreneurship. The findings of a qualitative study support the theoretical argument that social work can facilitate human, social, & economic development through a process of developing entrepreneurship. The author contends that a change of perception of who the poor in Africa actually are is needed in order to alleviate poverty in Africa through the entrepreneurial challenge. E. Sanchez

A Participatory Action Research Approach to Ageing in a Particular Community in the North-West Province of South Africa

Author: Strydom, H11 School Psycho-Social Behavioural Sciences, Division Social Work, Potchefstroom U Christian Higher Education

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61450288?accountid=14667

Abstract: In the Participatory Action Research model (the PAR model), research & action to solve a particular problem in a specific community take place simultaneously (Schurink, 1998:405-418; Strydom, 2001:379-392). The PAR model aims at combining research with direct service delivery for the benefit of the community. Health scientists, & specifically psychosocial behavioral scientists, encounter a philosophical dilemma in the sense that they have to do research according to the requirements of the first world, but in the same time they have to adhere to the requirements of developing countries. In developing countries terminology such as cost effectiveness, utility, limited funds, capacity building, developmental approach, the speedy solution to problems, & positive short-term reaction is important in research (White Paper on Social Welfare, 1997). Participatory action research can be seen as the health sciences' response to & acknowledgement of their involvement with social justice -- this model can enhance change from local action to full-scale social change (Healy, 2001:93). It reports on the unfolding of one section of the social work profession's response to the Farm Dwellers project. This article is limited to the aging people on these particular farms & especially their aging status, advanced aging, & future perspective. 39 References. Adapted from the source document.

Reflections on the Experiences and Needs of Adolescents Who Have Attempted Suicide: A Qualitative Study

Author: Aspaslan, A H11 Dept Social Development Professions, U Port Elizabeth

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61481353?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article outlines a research study concerning suicide attempts of adolescents. A brief overview of the different phases in the qualitative research is given with specific reference to the manner in which they were employed in this study. Biographical profiles of the participants in this research; reasons for the suicide attempts; feelings prior to the suicide attempt; feelings during the suicide attempt; & feelings after the suicide attempt are tabulated. Furthermore, recommendations on alternative &/or complementary support desired by the adolescents after a suicide attempt are related. The author contends that educational, health, welfare, religious, & parental systems play a crucial role in the prevention of suicide & attempted suicide. 5 Tables, 42 References. E. Sanchez

An Integrative Family Therapy Model with Stepfamilies

Author: Kapp, T; Jacobs, L J

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61507615?accountid=14667

Abstract: By using an integrative family therapy model, this article addresses the multiple problems a stepfamily may encounter. The stepfamily is a rapidly growing family structure in modern society. The stepfamily's unique problems, for instance, life-cycle discrepancies & loyalty conflicts, begin when they start functioning together as a family. The problematic foundation of a stepfamily & its unique composition require a specific therapeutic method that will take the complexities of those families into account. The researchers used the integrative family therapy model of David C. Olsen. This model is constructed out of six accredited methods in the field of family therapy: the problem solving, structural, interactional, cognitive, multigenerational, & object-relation methods. 2 Diagrams, 19 References. Adapted from the source document.

Exploring the Probation Officer's Role in Victim Support and Empowerment

Author: Steyn, Francois11 Centre Health Systems Research & Development, U Free State, Bloemfontein

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61450294?accountid=14667

Abstract: In the past, victims of crime have been profoundly neglected. Not only were they to a large extent excluded from criminal justice procedure, but assistance & support services & programs were scarce. The plight of victims to be recognized in the administration of justice resulted in the establishment of various support & empowerment programs & initiatives. Some of these programs & services are rooted in the philosophy of restorative justice & realize practically through, among others, victim-offender mediation. This article aims to briefly highlight the need for victim support services, conceptualize these services within the paradigm of restorative justice, & more specifically explores the probation officer's role in the rendering thereof. In this endeavor, findings of a recently finalized study regarding the training needs of probation officers in the Free State serve to substantiate the conclusions arrived at. 9 References. Adapted from the source document.

A Conversation between the One-Way Mirror and the Couch: Insight versus Reframing

Author: Verster, Barbara

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61523461?accountid=14667

Abstract: In this article, the author compares & discusses two different kinds of therapeutic interventions: insight & reframing. She contends that in the field of psychiatry insight seems to be the preferred therapeutic intervention. Additionally, she uses a case she encountered in her practice to illustrate the benefits of reframing. 14 References. E. Sanchez

Culture: Social Work's New Deluge?

Author: Bar-On, Arnon11 Dept Social Work, U Botswana, Gaborone

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61431868?accountid=14667

Abstract: An examination of the search for social work interventions suited to a specific location like Africa focuses on goals, culture, education, & need. Three models for developing interventions for special locales -- authentization, localization, & indigenization -- are examined, noting that indigenization is currently the most popular. Various interpretations of indigenization are explored, along with arguments supporting setting-specific social work; the centrality of culture to social work practice; the Eurocentric nature of most formal social work knowledge; challenges related to cultural differences; dangers posed by a fixation on culture; barriers to appropriate social work practice stemming from African culture; & characteristics of social work in Africa that differentiates it from that in the West. Although social work models designed for Western environments are often unsuitable for other population groups, it is argued that a distinctive African brand of social work already exists among field-level practitioners. Emphasis is placed on the need to bring together practitioners, researchers, & policymakers to reflect on what constitutes effective practice in specific situations. 61 References. J. Lindroth

Towards Culturally Sensitive Social Work Practice: Re-Examining Cross-Cultural Social Work

Author: Gray, Mel1; Allegritti, Inta1 School Social Sciences, U Newcastle, New South Wales, Australia

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/60479527?accountid=14667

Abstract: In this paper we stress the importance of cross-cultural or intercultural dialogue within the indigenization debate. To this end, we explore the notion of culture further & examine how we might begin to articulate particular cultures, such as Australian, African, & North American culture. We argue that, while there might be such a thing as a dominant Australian, African, & North American culture, in truth these comprise a host of minority cultures which may or may not conform to the dominant culture or, if they do, there are varying degrees of conformity & harmony between cultures. As Dean (2001:624) observed, the reality is that ".we live in a multiethnic, multiracial, multiclass society." Having developed certain ideas about culture, we offer our ideas about Australian culture. We then examine the literature on "cross-cultural social work" & the idea of "cultural competence." Our purpose is first to build on earlier work on "cross-cultural social work" which identified the need to consider the interest of African social workers in finding ways to articulate how indigenous cultures differed from dominant Western culture as a first step in devising indigenous approaches to social work practice (Gray & Allegritti, 2002; Gray & Fook, 2002). Secondly, in the light of existing sociological & social work literature on this subject, in this paper we examine some implications of current thinking on culture for social work practice. 54 References. Adapted from the source document.

Transracial Placements: Identities and Needs of South African "Rainbow Families"

Author: Ledderboge, U F1; Collett van Rooyen, Colin1 Durban Children's Society

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61498616?accountid=14667

Abstract: Reports on a follow-up study of the transracial placement of children in the Durban area of South Africa. Information was obtained from questionnaires completed by 42 parents & 42 social workers & personal interviews with 18 families. The results showed that most of the parents are married & love children. The majority of the children had been abandoned & one-third of them have special needs. Parents expressed a desire to be thoroughly informed about the child's disabilities. All respondents reported that transracial parenting is challenging & most indicated a need for help dealing with various incidents. Social workers also expressed a need for developmental help in their supervisory/consultative capacity. It was found that the children's basic needs are being adequately met. All of the children have contact with other persons of their ethnic background; however, most are still too young to have developed either culture competence or an ethnic identity. It was recommended that transracial placements be continued when no "inracial" placements are available. Recommendations are made for ways to improve the process. 9 References. J. Lindroth

Stories of Identity in a Multicultural Children's Home

Author: Muller, Karl1; Nieuwoudt, Johan1 SOS Children's Villages, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61547603?accountid=14667

Abstract: The aim of this research is to allow adolescents to share their stories of identity construction. These adolescents all live in a children's home that adheres to the philosophy of multiculturalism. Thus, in this children's home children are placed by need & some children have caregivers from cultures different from their own. A qualitative-empirical methodology was followed to unfold the meaning of participants' experiences of constructing their identity in a multicultural children's home. Triangulation was employed in both data collection & analysis. The children's stories confirmed the construct of identity as described in relevant literature. Specific themes related to identity construction in a multicultural children's homes involve: possible cultural confusion, an inside/outside orientation to life in the village, & cultural tolerance shown by the children. 40 References. Exploring the Role of Spirituality in the Lives of Poor Black Women

Author: Kruger, Sorette1; Williams, Rochelle1 Dept Social Work, U Stellenbosch

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/60473381?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article aims to highlight the recent emphasis placed on the role of spirituality in social work intervention & to link it to joint research between staff from the U of Gotenborg, Sweden, & the Dept Social Work, U of Stellenbosch. The research project, stretching over a three-year period, entails a community study focusing on the lives of women & children in black townships in South Africa. It investigates their everyday life, family life, social networks, & strategies for survival in the midst of severe poverty. The overall goal of the research is to utilize the knowledge gained towards empowering these women & children. One aspect which is being investigated, & on which this article focuses, is the role of spirituality in the lives of these women & to what extent it plays a role in their survival in spite of severe poverty. 1 Table, 24 References. Access to the Child Support Grant: Are the Batho Pele Principles Working?

Author: Charles, M A1; Matthias, C R1 Dept Social Work & Population Development, Durban

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61513418?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article presents an analysis of some primary data relevant to the Child Support Grant (hereafter referred to as the CSG). Specifically, this article provides an evaluation of the degree to which the Batho Pele principles are being implemented in order to facilitate access to the grant. This article reports the findings of a study in KwaZulu Natal in which the researcher observed the extent to which the Batho Pele principles were applied by clerks when they processed CSG applications. In addition, the researcher obtained data from applicants on their perceptions about treatment by clerks &, more generally, their experiences in applying for the CSG. In order to place the study results in context, the following will be discussed in this article: important features of the CSG; relevant aspects of the Batho Pele principles; the methodology of the study & the results of the study are discussed. 27 References. Adapted from the source document.

Social Work in South Africa: Quo Vadis?

Author: Naidoo, S1; Kasiram, M1 School Social Work, U Durban, Westville

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61514565?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper reports on research to examine the exodus of social workers from South Africa & how the profession is viewing & managing this. In addition respondents were given the opportunity to suggest solutions to the phenomenon & indeed contribute to the future survival of the profession. Several sample groups were used to provide a comprehensive view of problems & solutions/suggestions in accord with a systems perspective & triangulation with the use of multiple methods/sample groups (Babbie & Mouton, 1998). 4 Tables, 19 References. Adapted from the source document.

A Life Skills Awareness Project for Grade 7 Learners on Substance Abuse and HIV/AIDS: An Intervention Research Project

Author: Malaka, D W11 U of the North

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61547660?accountid=14667

Abstract: The primary aim of this study was to develop & implement a comprehensive & integrated substance abuse & HIV/AIDS primary prevention program suitable for Grade 7 learners in three selected schools. Subsequently, the pilot study was assessed & adjusted to make it suitable for all schools in the Limpopo Province. The objectives of the study were: to provide information & change the attitudes of young people on drugs & HIV/AIDS; to explore the knowledge & attitudes of young people on teenage pregnancy; to provide opportunities to abused youths to talk to counselors; & to provide opportunities to young learners to talk about their fears, experiences, & the myths they harbor on sexual matters. 2 Tables, 1 Appendix, 32 References. Adapted from the source document.

Principle Ethics and the Ethic of Care: Can They Go Together?

Author: Sevenhuijsen, Selma11 Utrecht U, Netherlands

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61480294?accountid=14667

Abstract: The scientific study of ethics has produced a variety of approaches that use different core concepts & also have different practical procedures to deal with moral dilemmas in social service provision (Widdershoven, 2000). In this article two of these approaches are discussed: principle ethics & the ethic of care. In the first two sections the main characteristics of these two approaches are described briefly. The last section discusses the question of their compatibility. 15 References. Adapted from the source document.

Strengths-Focused Intervention: The New Approach of the Social Work Service of the South African Police Service (SAPS)

Author: Stutterheim, Erika1; Weyers, Mike1 Social Work Services, South African Police Service

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61511911?accountid=14667

Abstract: Discusses the operationalized version of social work's strengths approach adopted by the social work service of the South African Police Service. The historical factors that necessitated the development of a new approach broken down into two periods, the South African Police, 1952-1995, as social work became part of the police organization & SAPS 1995-present, when SAPS became one the larger employers of social workers in South Africa. The nature & practical implications of the approach are discussed, outlining five principles & the goals & objectives of strengths-based intervention. The utility of this approach for social workers in the armed forces & occupational social work in general are touched on. 1 Table, 1 Figure, 29 References. J. Zendejas

The Appropriateness and Necessity of Short-Term Therapy in the Context of the Employee Assistance Programme

Author: Taute, Florinda11 Dept Social Work, U Pretoria

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61453830?accountid=14667

Abstract: Critically examines the concept of short-term therapy in the employee assistance program (EAP) context. The assumptions & beliefs of brief therapy that distinguish it from other kinds of therapies are considered: it is a time-bound, solution-focused, & goal-oriented approach. Short-term therapy can be used to address job stress, marital problems, interpersonal problems, emotional stress, & early-stage substance abuse. Attention turns to the role of client homework in brief therapy, providing the techniques, homework plan for each session, & types of presenting problems. Short-term therapy is deemed useful for EAPs because it is cost-effective & its time-limited nature is advantageous to employer & employee. 23 References. J. Zendejas

An Investigation into the Determinants of Job Satisfaction and the Improvement of Quality of Work Life of Grassroots Social Workers

Author: Malherbe, Blanche R1; Hendriks, Elma1 Dept Social Work, Huguenot Coll Wellington

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61518072?accountid=14667

Abstract: Explores the determinants of job satisfaction for grassroots social workers, drawing on a literature review that served as a basis for developing a questionnaire given to 22 social workers in South Africa. Job satisfaction is defined before looking at the organizational factors underpinning it: work content, remuneration, promotion opportunities, working environment, leadership & management style, & group factors. How the supervisor can impact social worker job satisfaction is addressed, along with how to improve social worker quality of working life. Findings indicate that work content is positively experienced by respondents, & they gave the highest priority to adequate & fair remuneration, while attaching the greatest value to supervisor attitude & recognition of their good work. Briefly, programs able to address the issue of grassroots social worker job satisfaction are discussed. 5 Tables, 44 References. J. Zendejas

Exploring Articulation and Partnering of Social Work Programmes at the University of Durban-Westville (UDW) and North London (UNL)

Author: Kasiram, M1; Partab, R; Lawrence, S; Dustin, D1 School Social Work, U Durban-Westville

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61535938?accountid=14667

Abstract: Discusses the potential for partnering between two social work departments in South Africa & England, drawing on 2000/01 questionnaire data from 117 students at each university. Student investment in study & program evaluation are measured. A key difference between the two universities is their socioeconomic, political, & cultural contexts; similarities are also touched on. While students were basically satisfied with their programs, their suggestions for change must be given careful consideration. Differences between programs suggest that partnering is limited but possible. Practice education emerged as one area of possible collaboration, & student-student & educator-educator partnering might be worth considering as well. Special time & staff are recommended for the purpose of promoting exchange & collaboration. 2 Tables, 22 References. J. Zendejas

The Danger of HIV Infection for Girlfriends and Wives

Author: Ackermann, L11 Dept Sociology, Faculty Humanities, U Free State

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/60519618?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examines the underlying social dynamics putting women at risk of HIV infection, drawing on in-depth semistructured interview data from HIV+ women, ages 19-46, in Bloemfontein, South Africa. Findings indicate that respondents lacked information on HIV. For the most part, these women contracted HIV from a partner in a stable, loving relationships characterized by infidelity & a lack of open communication regarding sexual matters. Changing behavior requires that people realize the need to change, know which behavior to change, intend to change, have a positive attitude toward change, have necessary support, believe in their ability, understand how to perform the new behavior, perceive more benefits from the new behavior, & have the skills to perform the new behavior. 14 References. J. Zendejas

HIVism: A Pervasive System of Oppression

Author: Francis, Dennis11 School Education, Natal U

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61542139?accountid=14667

Abstract: Per Hardiman & Jackson's (1997) & Young's (2000) framework, the treatment of people with HIV/AIDS by those without the condition is deemed oppression, ie, HIVism. The concepts of stigma, prejudice, discrimination, & oppression are scrutinized. Qualitative focus group data on the perceptions & experiences of 9 people with HIV/AIDS, ages 26-39, in Durban, South Africa, reveal the presence of negative labels & stereotypes, unprovoked attacks on person & property, institutional discrimination & exclusion, internalized acceptance of HIVism by victims, & horizontal HIVism. 28 References. J. Zendejas

Transsexualism -- An Investigation

Author: Kotze, C J1; Labuschagne, C W1 Dept Psychology Education, Faculty Humanities, U Free State

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61562406?accountid=14667

Abstract: Given the dearth of research on the topic, transsexualism is explored to raise public awareness of the phenomenon, particularly with respect to its misclassification as homosexuality, bisexuality, transvestism, or hermaphroditism. Transsexualism is not a psychiatric disorder & is typically genetic in origin. Drawing on self-structured questionnaire, interview, & autobiographical data from 4 transsexuals in South Africa, explored are the characteristics of transsexualism; distinctions between transsexualism & homosexuality, bisexuality, transvestism, or hermaphroditism; & the transsexual experience in terms of adjustment & acceptance. Recommendations are suggested for making transsexuals' lives better & future research directions outlined. 22 References. J. Zendejas

Personal and Interpersonal Effects of a Life Skills Programme on Grade 7 Learners

Author: Bender, C J Gerda1; Lombard, Antoinette1 Dept Curriculum Studies, U Pretoria

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61561899?accountid=14667

Abstract: Develops & implements an outcomes-based life skills program for Grade 7 students, ages 12-16, at a traditionally African school. At issue is determining whether such a program influences learner personal & interpersonal development in the senior phase. A nonparametric statistical test of pre- & posttest questionnaire data indicate that the program had a statistically highly significant impact on the personal & interpersonal life skills development of these learners. Some future research suggestions are made, along with recommendations for school programs, which are seen to fit into the overall context of education support services. 5 Tables, 1 Figure, 48 References. J. Zendejas

School Substance Abuse Policy

Author: Green, Sulina1; Luitjies, Raelene; Strydom, Marianne; Williams, Rochelle C1 Dept Voorsitter, U Stellenbosch

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61453823?accountid=14667

Abstract: Substance abuse amongst the youth is a growing concern in South Africa. There is also a need for schools to formulate a policy & to design programmes to deal with substance abuse in schools. The aim of this paper is to present some of the perceptions of learners on the relevance of formulating a policy for substance abuse in school. The rest of the paper is devoted to a problem-solving model which can be used in the process of policy formulation. Recommendations are made that can be used by schools when formulating a policy for substance abuse. 3 Tables, 14 References. Adapted from the source document.

Assessment of a Community: Promoting an Equitable Society through Inclusion and Empowerment

Author: Nel, Hanna1; Roestenburg, Wim1 Dept Social Work, Rand Afrikaans U, Auckland Park

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61561371?accountid=14667

Abstract: To adhere to the new developmental welfare policy of South Africa, the Department of Social Work at the Rand Afrikaans University (South Africa) in co-operation with the African Self-Help Association (ASHA), a non-profit organisation, conducted a needs assessment for Soweto among all the families connected with the 40 preschool creches of ASHA. Findings from participatory action research indicated a need for four different programmes: programmes for preschool children; programmes to enhance community leadership; family enrichment programmes; & special delivery programmes regarding HIV/AIDS, disability, crime & violence, illiteracy, poverty alleviation & substance abuse. Through the principle of inclusion, people took ownership of these programmes, which in turn had an empowering effect on them. 2 Tables, 1 Figure, 24 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Use of Narrative Principles to Community Development

Author: Reyneke, R P11 Dept Maatskaplike Werk, U Vrystaat, Bloemfontein

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61496844?accountid=14667

Abstract: The main focus of this article is on the motivation of communities to become part of their own development. In order for development to take place, communities should be guided beyond their own negativity & helplessness. In doing this, attention is given among others to the constructivist paradigm, self-empowerment & underlying post-modern assumptions & principles of the narrative working method. Although the narrative method is primarily used in therapy, the assumptions & principles are also applied in the context of community development. Practical strategies to be utilised during the application of narrative principles are discussed & the value of this working method described. 42 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Development of Consumer-Based Marketing Strategies of Centurion Community Services

Author: Naude, Mev C1; Terblanche, L S1 Dept Maatskaplike Werk, U Pretoria

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61561300?accountid=14667

Abstract: Centurion Community Services (CCS), a social service agency situated in Lyttelton, Pretoria, was founded in February 1999. The geographical area where services were rendered over the past four years has been transformed from a once quiet rural scene to a densely populated urban area. The founding of CCS testifies to a pro-active step to address anticipated social problems associated with urbanisation. A qualitative study was launched with the aim to assess the community's perception concerning CCS & whether this service is able to fulfill the needs & wants of the community with a view of development of guidelines for a consumer-based marketing strategy. A schedule covering the seven critical areas of decision-making in a marketing strategy had been developed & utilised as a data collection instrument to collect data from respondents, who have all been beneficiaries in one way or another of this service. It was found that a strategic planning process should be implemented in order to obtain clarity regarding the vision & mission of the organization; a marketing plan (which includes the strategic analysis, the SWOT analysis, marketing objectives & marketing strategy) should be applied extensively. A number of recommendations regarding critical decision making areas were also formulated. 5 Tables, 21 References. Adapted from the source document.

Problems Rural Social Workers Experience

Author: Schenck, Rinie11 Dept Social Work, UNISA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61541809?accountid=14667

Abstract: The research was an exploratory study of the views & experiences of 45 social workers related to their work & working conditions in rural communities. This article describes the research results around aspects regarding problems that social workers experience when working in rural communities eg, problems of the rural community that the social worker needs to attend to & problems the social workers experience connected to their work situation in rural areas. It is hoped that this study will bring about an awareness & concern for the rural people & rural social workers who have to take up the challenges. 5 Tables, 31 References. Can We Legislate for Prevention and Early Intervention Services for Children? An Analysis of Aspects of the 2002 Draft Children's Bill

Author: Matthias, Carmel R11 School Social Work, U KwaZulu-Natal

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61562018?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article provides an explanation & critical analysis of the prevention & early intervention provisions in the South African Law Commission's 2002 Draft Children's Bill. In addition, the inter-sectoral approach provided for in the Draft Bill & the proposed national policy framework are evaluated. Innovative recommendations that would allow child & family courts to issue early intervention orders are discussed. It is contended in the article that of the prevention & early intervention provisions in the Draft Bill were to be translated into legislation, this could produce significant consequences. It would cause a fundamental shift in balance between proactive & reactive social work services for children in South Africa. 17 References. Adapted from the source document.

A Situation Analysis of Hospitalised Physically Abused Pre-School Children in South Africa: Contributing Social Factors

Author: Green, Sulina1; Hartweg, Janine1 Dept Social Work, U Stellenbosch

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61540023?accountid=14667

Abstract: The experience of physical abuse is a traumatic event, which is so intense & frightening that it overwhelms the child's ability to cope with his/her normal developmental tasks. The goal of the study was to expand social workers' knowledge of the social circumstances of physically abused preschool children who are hospitalised, & to offer guidelines for professionals from a variety of disciplines to identify & assess physical abuse. To obtain the goals, the objectives were threefold: first to present demographic data on children with intentional physical injuries & their families; second, to describe the experiences of the perpetrators & circumstances under which the abuse took place; & third, to determine how social workers assess children who are suspected of having been physically abused. The study was conducted at the Red Cross Children's Hospital in Cape Town, South Africa. Both qualitative & quantitative methods were applied. The diagnoses reported were drawn from a sample of preschool aged children presenting with intentional physical injuries at the hospital over a four month period, interviews with four perpetrators using set guidelines, & conducting a survey with four of the social workers employed at the hospital using a self-completion questionnaire. The findings offered demographic details of the abused children & confirmed that children under the age of six were the most vulnerable age group to be subjected to physical abuse. Head injuries & gunshot wounds were the most frequent occurring physical injuries in this sample, indicating gang activities, effects of poverty & substance misuse. Four case studies are presented following the interviews with the perpetrators/parents, which give a situation analysis of these social circumstances under which the abuse took place. The social circumstances under which the physical abuse took place, & criteria used for assessment can be used as a framework for professionals rendering services to children. 1 Table, 1 Figure, 30 References. Adapted from the source document.

Condom Use and HIV/AIDS: Precautionary Behaviour among Botswana Youth

Author: Osei-Hwedie, Kwaku1; Namutosi, Rachel1 U Botswana

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61433754?accountid=14667

Abstract: The article is based on a research study of a random sample of 250 young people aged between 12 & 18 years attending private secondary schools in Gaborone. The main focus was to assess young peoples' attitudes towards & knowledge of HIV/AIDS precautionary behaviour, & the link between certain behaviours such as inconsistent use of condoms & HIV infection. It is evident that young people are very knowledgeable about precautions against HIV/AIDS, & the relationships between certain behaviours & HIV infection. However, this awareness does not necessarily translate into a change in sexual behaviour. 7 Tables, 21 References. Adapted from the source document.

Operationalising a Competence Model of Supervision to Empower Social Workers and Students in South Africa

Author: Engelbrecht, L K11 Dept Social Work, U Stellenbosch

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61535357?accountid=14667

Abstract: The purpose of this article is to demonstrate, with reference to the work of Guttman, Eisikovits & Maluccio (1988), how a competence model of supervision for social workers & students in South Africa can be operationalised. This will be done by showing the relevance of a competence model for supervision in South Africa & by explaining, with reference to outcomes-based & empowerment supervision, the rationale behind the operationalisation of the competence model. The competence model will then be conceptualised so as to provide a theoretical foundation for the model. The operationalisation of the competence model is demonstrated by defining outcomes-based supervision, explaining the relevant principles of outcomes-based supervision, defining empowerment supervision, indicating the differences between traditional & empowerment supervision, & by clarifying the relevant principles of empowerment. 1 Table, 36 References. Adapted from the source document.

Ethics and Deconstruction (Part 1)

Author: Sewpaul, V11 Centre Social Work, U KwaZulu Natal, Durban, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61561941?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper elucidates the importance of emancipatory education to social work education & training, identifies the objectives & underlying epistemologies of a course on Human Behaviour & the Social Environment, & emphasizes the importance of negotiating relationships for the creation of a participatory & emancipatory approach to education. It reflects the application of Habermas's (1996) theory of communicative action & discourse ethics to complex issues including HIV/AIDS & the relationship between race, class & gender & the relationship of these to issues of power, privilege, status & access to resources in the South African context. The incorporation of creative, experiential & empowerment-based teaching/learning strategies are central to the development of critical consciousness in students, & for facilitating effective & meaningful citizen participation among students. The paper also highlights the potentially damaging, albeit unintended, consequences of such teaching strategies. 33 References. Adapted from the source document.

Challenges for Building Partnerships in Social Development

Author: Lombard, A1; Preez, J du1 Dept Social Work, U Pretoria, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61542342?accountid=14667

Abstract: The primary goal of partnerships in social development is to strategically join efforts to reduce poverty, address inequalities & social injustices through the redistribution of resources, & through social & economic development programmes. This can only be achieved when there is a true commitment from all partners involved to take up the challenges of building partnerships which could provide a negotiated framework for a partnership strategy for social development. These challenges include understanding the changing role of the state, redefining partnerships, empowerment of NGOs to be service deliverers & advocates, the creation of an enabling environment, recognition & balancing of social development partners' strengths & weaknesses, an agreement on the social development agenda & a plan for sustainable social development. Although a partnership strategy for social development needs to be in place to provide broad guidelines, each kind & level of partnership need to be uniquely negotiated, planned, designed & maintained. These issues are considered here in the South African context. 24 References. Adapted from the source document.

Partnerships: Marrying the Strengths and Resources of Diverse Interest Groups

Author: Gray, M1; Crofts, P1 School Social Sciences, U Newcastle, New South Wales, Australia

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61497117?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper explores the growing importance of partnership development within the social services sector in Australia. It proposes that the social, political & economic factors giving rise to shifting priorities in this newly named "third" sector are encapsulated in the notion of social entrepreneurship being given impetus by the Federal Government's policy of mutual obligation, the findings of the Welfare Reform Group & the consequent Australians Working Together program. It argues that community development is the ideal strategy for partnership development that fits well with the strengths perspective, where the emphasis is on mutual engagement in an equal relationship such that the collective assets & resources of the collaborating partners can be harnessed for the good of the community. The parallels between partnerships & human relationships are outlined & the role of the key sectors of community, business, government & non-government in the provision of social services are discussed. The paper ends with a discussion of community-business partnership development. Partnerships are seen to offer social workers with opportunities & challenges in the development of creative & innovative programmes aimed at social improvement. 3 Figures, 42 References. Adapted from the source document.

Teaching and Learning in the Violent Neighbourhoods of the Cape Flats

Author: Bailey, A C1; Collins, K J1 U Cape Town, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61562529?accountid=14667

Abstract: This research consists of the presentation & analysis of focus group data obtained from a non-probability sample of foundation phase teachers from a primary school in a middle-class community on the Cape Flats. Like other communities in this area, the ordinary citizen is subjected to constant territorial gang wars, with the ever-present danger of being caught in the sudden crossfire of a violent uprising. Violence exists not only on the boundaries of school children's areas, but also intrudes into the schools, including the school playground. Cognisant of the difficulties of teaching & learning in a perpetually unstable environment, a local non-profit organisation, Think Twice, provides training programs in life skills in a pilot project called Circle Time to schools. Prior to this study, the programs had not been evaluated. Think Twice consequently committed itself to researching program effectiveness & to involve the teachers who are presenters of the programs as co-researchers in the generation of data. Using a participatory design, the research aims to: 1) identify the precise need for life skills programs in schools; & 2) institute relevant changes to the programs in collaborative action. The researcher-facilitator is a representative of the organisation which designs & provides the training programs. 22 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Integration of Disabled People into the Open Labour Market: A Social Work Perspective

Author: Naude, L1; Delport, C S L1 Dept Social Work, U Pretoria, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61536030?accountid=14667

Abstract: It has been established that people with disabilities are in most cases excluded from society & major activities in society such as social recreation & employment in the open labor market. Only 1% of people with disabilities in South Africa are working in the open labor market. Only some of the 99% who do not work receive a small grant from the state, which is their only form of income (White Paper on Integrated National Disability Strategy 1997:2-3). It is an objective of the South African government to achieve equity in the open labor market. As little research has formally been done regarding the attitudes, perceptions & needs of employers regarding the integrating of people with disabilities into the labor market, the subject of this study is relatively new. The researchers have therefore conducted an exploratory research study to explore employment possibilities for people with disabilities, the attitudes, perceptions & needs of employers as well as barriers that prevent the employment of disabled people. On the basis of this information the researchers have described guidelines for a training program for employers to integrate people with disabilities into the open labor market. 31 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Attitudes of Older South Africans towards Euthanasia

Author: De Vos, H M1; le Roux, M C; Nortje, N1 Dept Psychology, U Stellenbosch, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61562473?accountid=14667

Abstract: The purpose of this study was to determine the attitudes of older South African adults (65 years & older) towards euthanasia. The subjects of the study were people 65 years of age & older who resided in homes for the aged within the rural & urban areas of the Cape Town Metropolis. An equal number of subjects from the African, Coloured & European communities were randomly selected. A biographical questionnaire, the Euthanasia Attitude Scale & the Purpose In Life Test were administered. The influence of four variables -- age, ethnicity, meaning in life & health -- was investigated. A Pearson correlation coefficient analysis & a one-way ANOVA analysis were used. Age was the only variable found to have a significant correlation with euthanasia. The findings are discussed & certain recommendations are made. 6 Tables, 44 References. Adapted from the source document.

AIDS and Bereavement in South Africa

Author: Demmer, C11 Dept Health Sciences, Lehman Coll, City U New York

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61511940?accountid=14667

Abstract: AIDS is the leading cause of death in South Africa & attention needs to be focused on the needs of countless individuals who grieve AIDS-related deaths. Social workers must be prepared to assist those who grieve AIDS-related losses, especially children, women, & the elderly. AIDS-related bereavement must be understood in terms of the complex social, political, & economic factors inherent in South African society. Strategies are suggested for addressing AIDS-related bereavement in the local context. 101 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Psycho-Social Circumstances of Car Guards: Interventive Roles of the Social Worker

Author: Strydom, H1; Strydom, C1 Division Social Work, School Psycho-Social Behavioural Sciences, Potchefstroom U Christian Higher Education, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61561990?accountid=14667

Abstract: In South Africa unemployment is a major problem & many people are desperate to make an earnest living & are prepared to do any job as long as it brings in enough money for a roof over their heads & food on the table. Crime has become a major social problem within the South African society & motor vehicle thefts & car burglaries are high on the list of crime statistics. Police & security protection services are unable to keep guard over all the parking areas & informal car guards did not provide the answer. To address this problem, car watch organisations were introduced in the city centres. Social workers should identify those people who are especially vulnerable, including car guards, & ensure that their abilities & potential are developed & strengthened. The objective of the research project was to study the survival skills of car guards relating to their economic & social circumstances. The phenomena of difficult customers, dangerous & harsh working conditions, & poor remuneration were investigated. A qualitative study accompanied by a phenomenological research design was implemented for the study. Field research & specifically in-depth personal interviewing & naturalistic observation were used as research procedures. 8 Tables, 38 References. Adapted from the source document.

Emancipatory Citizenship Education in Action: Creative Teaching/Learning Options (Part 2)

Author: Sewpaul, V11 Centre Social Work, U KwaZulu Natal, Durban, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61526647?accountid=14667

Abstract: This is the second part of a two-part series on "Emancipatory citizenship education in action ," with a focus on the use of creative teaching & learning options with a group of students taking a course on Human Behavior & the Social Environment. The student-centered teaching/learning strategies described in this paper allow students to actively engage in discourses of difference of various types, to develop an understanding of & respect for diversities, to develop self-awareness, & awareness of self in relation to the broader sociopolitical & cultural world. The premise is that the development of such awareness & reflexivity, serves as a precursor to the recognition of the need to work toward change in structural conditions that maintain people in disadvantaged, marginalized & excluded positions. 18 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Community Work Services of the Private Welfare Sector: A Profile with Implications

Author: Van den Berg, A. M.1; Weyers, M L1 c/o Weyers -- Vakgroep Maatskaplike, Skool Psigo-Sosiale Gedragswetenskappe, Noordwes-U, Potchefstroomkampus, Suid-Afrika

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61433772?accountid=14667

Abstract: The practical implications of the significant changes in social & welfare policy that occurred from 1994 to 1999, are as yet unknown. This is mainly due to the lack of empirical research data on this issue. This deficiency was partly addressed in a study on the nature of the private welfare sector's community work services in the North West Province during 2000. The aim of the study was to compile a profile of the Province's community work services & to utilize this profile in the formulation of guidelines for improved future service delivery. In the study, both community work theory & the South African social & welfare policies were used in the development of a classification framework for community work services. This framework formed the basis of a questionnaire that was sent to all private welfare organisations in the Province. The collected data was analysed &, together with policy dictates, used for the development of guidelines. It was firstly found that there was a discernable move towards targeting policy designated client systems. However, the services did still not fully comply with policy requirements or South Africa's considerable development needs. Certain deficiencies in the service delivery process were also identified. Therefore, guidelines for addressing both these imbalances & deficiencies were formulated. it was thirdly found that the new classification framework could be constructively used in both further research & in practice. 5 Tables, 6 Diagrams, 46 References. Adapted from the source document.

Divorce in South Africa: An Overview

Author: Ackerman, L11 Dept Sociology, Faculty Humanities, U Free State, Bloemfontein, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61540552?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article provides an overview of South African divorce figures given for the past five years. The various ways in which divorce figures can be expressed are considered, with specific reference to South Africa. When studying the crude divorce rate, two things become apparent. Firstly, the South African crude divorce rate is relatively low when compared to various other countries (contrary to the popular belief that South Africa has one of the highest divorce rates in the world) &, secondly, the South African divorce rate is rising & will probably continue to rise. In conclusion, it is argued that various macro social forces are likely to increase the number of divorces in the near future. 5 Tables, 1 Figure, 23 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Adult Unmarried Tswana Woman's Perceptions of Marriage

Author: Erasmus, A1; Ryke, E H1 c/o Ryke -- Noordwes-U, Potchefstroom, Suid-Afrika

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61433769?accountid=14667

Abstract: The objective of this article is to explore & describe the adult unmarried Tswana woman's perceptions of marriage in order to contribute to the development of indigenous knowledge as a basis for culture congruent marriage preparation services. For these purposes a qualitative, exploratory research study has been undertaken. Thirty-two Tswana women, who met all the set criteria, were included in the study by means of purposive sampling. An in-depth exploration of the perceptions of unmarried mature Tswana women was undertaken by utilising the semi-structured method of interviewing. Relevant data were analysed by means of descriptive analysis as described by Tesch. A variety of factors that influence the adult unmarried Tswana woman's perceptions of marriage, such as the traditional & changing role & status of the married woman, the high divorce rate, the bogadi- & stay at in-lawscustom, & the Tswana woman's expectation of a spouse, have been identified. In this article the findings of this study are presented & discussed, & recommendations regarding culture congruent marriage preparation services made. 30 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Knowledge of Social Workers in Private Practice regarding Human Sexuality and Sex Therapy

Author: Craig, E1; Preez, M. S. E. du1 Dept Social Work, U Pretoria, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61542294?accountid=14667

Abstract: Sexual problems or dysfunctions remain one of the prominent reasons for marital & relationship problems. Sexuality is, however, only one of many components of a marriage or of a committed relationship. Relationship problems & sexual problems are often interlinked. The fact that sexual problems are often only symptoms of deeper relationship issues makes the social worker the ideal person to treat these sexual problems from a holistic perspective & within a relationship context. The nature of this research study thus evolved from the presumed lack of knowledge of social workers in private practice, & who specialise in couples therapy, regarding human sexuality & sex therapy. A qualitative research approach is used & applied research was conducted. An exploratory research design is utilised & a selfconstructed, mailed questionnaire was used as method of data collection. This research study found that the respondents answered only 58.53% of the knowledge-based questions correctly, thereby confirming their suspected lack of knowledge regarding human sexuality & sex therapy. The research results indicated a need for specialised education & training of social workers in the field of human sexuality & sex therapy. 2 Figures, 1 Appendix, 11 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Benefits of Music Therapy and Group Therapy with Drug Abuse Clients

Author: Kruger, S P1; Pieterse, L1 Dept Maatskaplike Werk, U Stellenbosch, Suid-Afrika

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61540508?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study is based on the question: What does social group work & music therapy have in common? When utilized during intervention aimed at the drug dependent client, the advantages of the different methods augment to the definite benefit of the client. Both strategies aim to improve the client's communication skills, his capacity to deal with resistance, anger control & other negative feelings. Social group work as well as music therapy enhances the exploration of & expression of suppressed feelings & as such motivates socialisation. With music providing the much needed relaxing & bonding factor, the drug dependent person feels more comfortable in the group, free to express feelings & therefore more motivated towards treatment. Following a theoretical motivation, the authors provide useful guidelines for utilizing specific music to gain specific results during group work with drug dependant persons. 7 Tables, 35 References. Adapted from the source document.

Retirement Villages and Related Care Services: Perceptions, Preferences and Needs of Elderly Consumers and Providers in Cape Town

Author: Froneman, C A1; van Huyssteen, M. K. R.; van der Merwe, I. J.1 Dept Geography & Environmental Studies, U Stellenbosch, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61518357?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article describes the findings of a study in the Cape Metropolitan Area & its fringe districts of the perceptions, preferences & needs of elderly persons & the views of housing providers for the elderly regarding retirement housing & related care services. Interviews were conducted with 228 sampled elderly persons in neighbourhoods with a high concentration of the elderly & in selected retirement villages in the study area. The views of experts on retirement housing & role players in the field of elderly care were elicited separately. The basic preferences of the elderly can be summarized as: renting residential units instead of buying them; no luxuries such as therapy services; safety considerations incorporated in the design of the interior of the units; being able to use their own furniture in the units; primary health care offered; availability of recreational facilities; good corporate management; & accessibility to essential general services (in terms of the location of the village). These findings are considered for consumers in different cultural & socio-economic groups & are also compared with the views of developers, housing providers & other role players. It is contended that -- given the Government's new policy on housing & care for the elderly -- the findings may assist the providers of retirement housing & related care services to understand the diversity of needs of the South African mature retirement market & to provide facilities & services accordingly. 2 Tables, 2 Figures, 14 References. Adapted from the source document.

Advancing through Retreating: Self-Care among Helping Practitioners

Author: Layton, E1; Collins, K1 Dept Social Development, U Cape Town, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61542241?accountid=14667

Abstract: The research was conducted in Cape Town amongst a non-probability sample of 16 helping practitioners who are also retreatants. A literature review describes the value of retreats & retreating & informs the empirical study. The review supports the view that helping practitioners have not only the ability but also a duty to care for themselves. The empirical research explores respondents' perceptions & explanations of their retreating experience, using their own words. Six themes surrounding the meaning of retreating emerged from the data. A discussion of findings identifies the efficacy of retreating as a self-care tool among helping practitioners. Retreatants yearn for recuperative silence & reflective opportunities that remedy the stresses & pace of modern living. By retreating, they experience not only an avoidance of burnout but also an enhancement of functioning & well-being. The tools used on retreat have as much value outside the retreat setting as in it. Eight recommendations encourage the development of self-awareness & self-care practices related to retreating, including making space for this development in the workplace. 2 Tables, 19 References. Adapted from the source document.

Social Workers in Management: Work/Family Stress and Issues of Self-Care

Author: Narayan, G Suraj11 School Social Work, U KwaZulu-Natal, Durban

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61378199?accountid=14667

Abstract: Traditional approaches to stress adopt a narrow and individualistic perspective with little attention paid to the wider organisational, social, political and family factors involved. The intersect of all these factors as well as the symptoms of stress that social work managers experienced were examined as part of a broader study of women in management and occupational stress. The sample consisted of 30 women managers from diverse racial backgrounds. Ten of these managers were social workers. Both private and public organisations with local, national and international status were included in this study. Organisational contributors to occupational stress have been identified as follows: logistical constraints, career development, relationships at work, role in organisation, organisational structure and extra-organisational forces. The social factors, which impacted on the social work manager's experience of stress, were racism and gender discrimination. The following sources of stress at the work/family interface were identified: domestic pressures, parental stress, marital discord, bi-cultural role conflict, and spill-over of job/stress into family life. Adapted from the source document.

A Needs Assessment for a Management Training Programme for Staff Officers and Are Managers in the South African National Defence Force (SANDF) Social Work Directorate

Author: Pitse, C A1; Taute, F M1 c/o Taute -- Dept Social Work, U Pretoria, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61386962?accountid=14667

Abstract: Management is a process that requires both art and skill to be efficient and effective in service rendering. The goal of the study was to explore the need for a management training programme for staff officers and area managers in the SANDF Social Work Directorate in order to make recommendations for the development of a management training programme. This exploratory study utilised qualitative and quantitative methodology. No sampling was done as the entire population was used for the study. The staff officers and area managers in the nine provinces in South Africa, within the SANDF, Social Work Directorate, were used as the population in the study. The study clearly indicates that a formal management training programme is critical within the ANDF Social Work Directorate. It is recommended that a formal management training programme should be implemented within the SANDF Social Work Directorate to address the management needs identified in this empirical study. Various identified experts should be utilised in the provision of training. Adapted from the source document.

Protecting Children Where It Matters Most: In Their Families and Their Neighbourhoods

Author: September, R L11 Child & Youth Research & Training Programme, U Western Cape, Bellville, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61335463?accountid=14667

Abstract: Globally, there has been a growing tendency to make civil society the primary participant and beneficiary of community-based intervention. In South Africa, since the publication of the White Paper for Social Welfare (1997), with its emphasis on developmental social welfare services, many social welfare agencies have been recognising the benefits of working in partnership with local communities. In the field of child protection, it has long been recognised and accepted that formal child and family welfare services will never be able to respond adequately to the increasing number and diverse range of child protection issues and challenges presenting in communities on a daily basis. The Child and Youth Research and Training Programme (CYRTP) (previously the Institute for Child and Family Development) at the University of the Western Cape has introduced a neighbourhood-based child protection approach in a number of neighbourhoods around the country. This approach is aimed at building stronger families and communities to safeguard children. Important lessons are emerging from the implementing neighbourhoods. The aim of this article is to report on these experiences and to share some of the lessons learnt. Adapted from the source document.

A Solution-Building Metaphorical Concept for Direct Social Work with Children: An Exploratory Study

Author: Van Der Merwe, M11 Dept Social Work, U Stellenbosch

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61387102?accountid=14667

Abstract: As a practicing social worker the researcher was interested in a specific metaphorical concept that was used in a private context during direct social work intervention with children. The metaphorical concept was subjected to methodological analysis to determine and describe its applicability with the aim of adding to the body of knowledge regarding the use of metaphors in direct work with children from a solution-focused perspective. The underlying metatheory was social constructionism with specific reference to solution-focused and strengths-based social work practice. It was found that the particular metaphorical concept had specific functions that could be linked to solution-building questions and play actions. Adaptions to the basic metaphor were observed when it was used as part of sensory play, biblioplay and to enhance posttraumatic play. Adapted from the source document.

Post-Adoption Reunion: A South African Perspective

Author: Scordilis, M1; Becker, L1 c/o Becker -- Dept Social Development, U Cape Town, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61361432?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article explores the adoptee's desire for and experience of reunion with the birth mother, from within a psychoanalytic framework and within the South African context. The study was conducted from within a non-probability framework and is an empirical, ethnographic study with a predominantly qualitative, inductive approach, which is exploratory and descriptive in nature. The quantitative research provides width to the in-depth, qualitative data and takes the form of a content analysis of the adoption register of a Cape Town-based adoption agency. This aspect of the study employed an in-depth, face-to-face, unstructured interviewing technique, followed by an interview schedule. The quantitative sample is comprised of 207 contacts in the post-adoption register of Cape Town Child Welfare while the qualitative sample is comprised of eight adult adoptees, who experienced face-to-face reunion with the birth mother. The conclusion drawn from the study is that the adoptee's desire for reunion is a health-promoting process, which is motivated by both external, social factors as well as intrapsychic forces. The process of reunion enables the adoptee to establish a new sense of self and assists in placing the adoptee within an historical and biological narrative The adoptee, whilst seeking to reclaim the 'lost object', does so as a means of reclaiming and completing the self, the development of which was disturbed as a result of premature interruption of the primary infant-mother bond. The value of reunion does not lie in the 'success" or outcome of the reunion, but in the process or personal "journey" of the adoptee. Adapted from the source document.

Translated title not available

Author: Strydom, H1; Cronje, F J; Roux, A A; Strydom, C; Wessels, C C1 Potchefstroom kampus Noordwes-U

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61371593?accountid=14667

Abstract: The social elaboration of HIV/AIDS & poverty gain momentum on a daily basis & has an influence on all levels of South African society. In this article the applicable terminology is defined & a theoretical perspective on poverty & HIV/AIDS given. The relationship between HIV/AIDS & poverty is discussed in depth as well as the impact of HIV/AIDS & poverty on South African society. Matters such as life expectancy, illiteracy, family life, orphans, grandparents, the extended family, & housing are discussed. Some macro issues of the problem of HIV/AIDS & poverty such as the work place, joblessness, migration, education, health services, the economy & the role of tradition are also scrutinized. The article concludes with a section on possible solutions for the problem, on both micro & macro level. Adapted from the source document.
