An Exploratory Study on Day Labourers in Elardus Park Pretoria

Author: Schenck, R1; Louw, H1 Dept Social Work, U South Africa, Pretoria

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61374205?accountid=14667

Abstract: On Barnard Street, Elardus Park in Pretoria men are standing, raising a finger or miming a skill to attract the attention of potential employers. It is also common to see men swarm around a car, pointing to themselves in an effort to get noticed and thus hired. This study deals with these people, who are day labourers leading a difficult life as they manage to survive in an entrepreneurial way. Their main need is to access work more easily. Skills training would make this possible. Social work could make a contribution in this respect. Adapted from the source document.

People with Disabilities and Nature Tourism: A South Africa Case Study

Author: Dippenaar, Stephanie1; Kotze, Nico1 Dept Geography, U North, Sovenga

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61347557?accountid=14667

Abstract: Almost seven percent of the total population of South Africa are disabled, according to Statistics South Africa. Of this group, 21% are physically disabled. A lack of recreational opportunities is listed as one of the major sources of stress for this group. The accessibility of parks and reserves in the Limpopo Province for wheelchair-bound people is investigated in this case study. The province has a rich natural heritage as well as an abundance of wilderness areas, and although ecotourism already plays an important role in the economic development of the province, it is still under-utilised. To evaluate parks and reserves in the province in terms of their accessibility to people with disabilities, especially those confined to wheelchairs, a model was developed with a set of criteria against which tourism venues could be tested. Values ranging from three for full accessibility to zero for total inaccessibility were allocated and used to evaluate the parks and reserves in the study area. An average value was calculated for each venue. These averages were finally tested against the accessibility index to determine the extent to which the park or reserve is accessible to people with disabilities. Adapted from the source document.

Globalization and the New Partnership for Africa's Development (NEPAD): Relevance for Social Work

Author: Sewpaul, V11 Centre Social Work, U KwaZulu-Natal

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61378671?accountid=14667

Abstract: The neo-liberal ideology that underscores the New Partnership for Africa's Development (NEPAD), rather than providing strategies for the salvation of Africa holds the possibility for further marginalisation of the poor, for entrenching inequality, and for worsening the plight of the most vulnerable of our society. Social workers are expected to work against poverty, and towards sustainable people-centred development. Yet, macro economic policies and strategies seem to be designed to work against these objectives. NEPAD, instead of representing the interests and the will of the African people, serves more the interests of the world capitalistic order, with African leaders capitulating to the demands of the G8 and to the international financial institutions. Despite their active roles in perpetuating poverty and inequality, there is the protest from government that the welfare sector, and social work more specifically, lacks the skills and expertise to achieve the objectives of poverty alleviation and sustainable development. As social work educators and practitioners, we need to critically interrogate those factors that impact the welfare sector and social work, and that deny people the opportunities for survival, let alone gainful and healthy living. As international social work and global movements around anti-oppressive practice, human rights and social justice evolve, social work must meet its ethical obligations in respect of collective responsibility and collective action. Adapted from the source document.

Poverty Alleviation: The Need for a Knowledgeable, Active and Empowered Civil Society

Author: Gathiram, N11 School Social Work, U KwaZulu-Natal, Durban, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61382635?accountid=14667

Abstract: Many poverty alleviation programmes have been established in South Africa in an effort to overcome poverty and inequality. This paper explores reasons as to why the problem has worsened, despite all these efforts. An overview of the literature suggests that most of these programmes are project based, with a focus on financial gain and the development of technical skills. The success of these projects has been limited. The author argues that the focus on these 'hard' issues is insufficient in dealing with poverty, given the history and context in which it is occurring in South Africa. The neo-liberal macro-economic policy undermines the success of projects. It could in fact sustain poverty and the status quo. It is argued that poverty cannot be overcome without a knowledgeable, active and empowered civil society. People's capacity needs to be developed to challenge the economic, political and social organisation of society. It is recommended that interventions be more holistic and skills for social empowerment be strengthened. Conscientisation, organising for collective action and skills for transforming policy frameworks are considered important. A list of components vital for social empowerment is presented. Recommendations are made that research be undertaken to explore ways in which these components could be operationalised as key performance indicators in the evaluation of programmes. Adapted from the source document.

Mamphele Ramphele and Xhosa Culture: Some Insights on Culture, Self-Determination and Human Rights for South African Social Work

Author: Allegritti, I1; Gray, M1 U Newcastle, New South Wales, Australia

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61346324?accountid=14667

Abstract: The authors continue the debate about indigenous social work following on from previous work where they identified the importance of culture in the indigenisation process (Gray & Allegritti, 2002, 2003; Gray, 2003). They suggested that it was important to articulate African culture and the way in which it differed from Western culture. To this end, this paper draws on the work of Ramphele (2002), which examines traditional Xhosa practices such as imbeleko and the power of the ancestors in African culture. Ways in which African men establish their identity and masculinity are explored and the implications of these cultural practices for social work are discussed. Using the example of self-determination, which in social work is said to be a universal value, the authors highlight the difference between a local cultural practice which stresses ancestral power and self-determination in social work which values individual autonomy. They point to the importance of universal human rights as a safeguard against unjust traditional ways and suggest that, since South Africa is a signatory to international human rights charters, African writers need to debate the justness of their traditional practices in an increasingly globalising world, especially those which impact on women in an unjust way. Adapted from the source document.

Perspectives on the Community Education Model of Social Work: Implications for Education and Practice

Author: Engelbrecht, L K11 Dept Social Work, U Stellenbosch

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61347488?accountid=14667

Abstract: The purpose of this paper is to construct perspectives on community education as a model of community work by unpacking the knowledge of community education that exists in social work, and packaging it in the context of social work's response to contemporary risk issues, in order to identify implications for social work education and practice. This is done by motivating and addressing the risk issues by means of community education, exploring the roots of the community education model, examining the relationship between community development and community work, analysing the theoretical foundation of the community education model, and by conceptualising an ideal type of community education. Core concepts of community education arising from these contexts are also elucidated. Adapted from the source document.

A Critical View of Diversion Programmes in Context of Restorative Justice

Author: Shearar, A1; Graser, R1 Dept Social Development, U Cape Town, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61351882?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article describes the background and purpose of life-skills diversion programmes for young offenders and then critically explores to what extent they currently endorse the principles of restorative justice to which the new South African child justice system aspires. Since the advent of the life-skills programmes for youths at risk, the child justice system has evolved into a comprehensive piece of legislation called the Child Justice Bill (Bill 49[2002]). Central to this Bill is the promotion of restorative justice, which seeks to repair damage caused by crime by returning criminal cases to the main players: the victim, the offender and the community. Through a process of negotiation, these players agree on appropriate solutions which include (1) restitution, (2) reconciliation following an acknowledgement of the circumstances around the offence and its impact, and (3) an acceptance of responsibility by the offender leading to reintegration into the community. Diversion options from criminal justice procedures are the key to installing restorative justice for crimes committed by young offenders. To date the most popular form of diversion has been life-skills programmes for youths at risk, but it is not evident to what extent this meets the criteria inherent in the philosophy of restorative justice. Adapted from the source document.

Theories of Adolescent Substance Use and Abuse

Author: Brandt, C J1; Delport, C S L1 Dept Social Work, U Pretoria, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61352480?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article reviews nine different theories regarding adolescent substance use and abuse. Amongst these theories the following are emphasised: (a) substance specific cognitives, (b) social learning processes, (c) commitment to conventional values and (d) intra-personal processes. Some similarities and differences among these theories as well as the conceptual boundaries of each theory are addressed. In order to integrate these theories and to explain the etiology of youth substance use and abuse, a framework or model is presented to the reader. Adapted from the source document.

Translated title not available

Author: Strydom, H1; Mynhardt, K1 Skool Psigo-Sosiale Gedragswetenskappe, Vakgroep Maatskaplike Werk, Potchefstroomkampus Noorwes-U Potchefstroom, Suid-Afrika

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61369414?accountid=14667

Abstract: Research was undertaken to determine the needs of adolescents & their experience of the death of their parents due to AIDS. AIDS is a still growing pandemic that is eliminating thousands of lives in South Africa, whilst influencing the lives of relatives in a dramatic manner. Adolescents, in this particular unique stage of life, suffer most from the consequences of this disease. It is of special significance to adolescents when one or both of their parents die due to AIDS-related causes. Adolescents have unique physical & emotional needs & when a parent or parents die, a vacuum is created in the fulfillment of their needs. In this study, some guidelines for an intervention programme, for adolescents who lost a parent or both parents due to AIDS, are suggested in order to empower adolescents to cope with the situation & to deal with the losses that they have to deal with. Community-based care & the buddy system are but two current social work programmes that can partly be incorporated into this specific programme. Adapted from the source document.

Cognitive Behavioural Therapy in South Africa: Counsellors' Experiences following a Training Programme

Author: Kagee, A1; Suh, E.-J.; Naidoo, A V1 Dept Psychology, Stellenbosch U, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61331535?accountid=14667

Abstract: Many South African communities experience high levels of violence and other phenomena that potentially provoke symptoms of traumatic stress among residents. Cognitive behaviour therapy (CBT) has been demonstrated to be an effective psychological intervention to ameliorate symptoms of trauma, but is seldom practised in South African community mental health settings. In order to determine the barriers to implementing CBT, 12 credentialed community counsellors participated in a two-day training workshop focused on CBT. Counsellors were asked to implement CBT with their clients who presented with symptoms of PTSD. The counsellors were then asked to complete a questionnaire six-months after the training workshop in order to identify the barriers they experienced in implementing the treatment model. The chief barriers that counsellors identified included high workload and limited time, unsuitable clients, client drop out, and an inappropriate match between the counsellor's theoretical paradigm and the CBT model. These results are considered in the context of community mental health care in post-apartheid South Africa. Adapted from the source document.

Social Work Meets the Silver Screen

Author: Rothman, Jack11 School Public Affairs, U California, Los Angeles

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61351864?accountid=14667

Abstract: The author describes a study involving filmmaking and the film industry. Although departing from typical social work subject matter, the project draws on social work values and uses related social science methods and theoretical concepts. Film is a force that influences the basic attitudes and behaviour of millions of people around the world. The medium has the potential to disseminate social work values and aims widely, if appropriately addressed. Adapted from the source document.

A Postmodern Critique of the Sacssp's Draft Code of Ethics

Author: Holscher, D

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61365848?accountid=14667

Abstract: The article explores the relevance of postmodernism for a debate on ethics and morality in contemporary South African welfare, thus providing a critique of the SACSSP's draft Code of Ethics. It is argued that a future code of ethics needs to engage with the systemic nature of social injustice in South Africa. The setting of standards and codes has to become a discursive process around a non-essentialist document. Existing ethical concerns and principles in social work are important to retain, but this has to be complemented with an acknowledgement of the contextual and relational nature of morality and, therefore, of morally responsible practice. Adapted from the source document.

The Implementation of a Deiversion Programme for Juvenile Offenders: Problem Areas and 'Pitfalls'

Author: Cupido, M; Kritzinger, A; Van Aswegen, F

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61396111?accountid=14667

Abstract: Diversion is currently one of the popular options in attempts to address juvenile crime. As currently practised it often involves restorative justice principles as well as elements of traditional rehabilitation programmes. Restorative justice and diversion programmes have now become accepted in South Africa as an integral part of dealing with young offenders. Based on qualitative research this paper examines the problems and pitfalls experienced in the implementation of one specific diversion programme. Some of the most important problems include lack of communication between officials, sporadic attendance of the programme, lack of commitment to complete assignments, composition of the groups, time constraints on sessions and parents' expectations regarding the goal and outcome of the programme. The main conclusion drawn from this study is that, while the principles of restorative justice and diversion may be attractive in itself, this does not ensure the successful implementation of programmes. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+Implementation+of+a+Deiversion+Programme+for+Juvenile+Offenders%3A+Problem+Areas+and+%27Pitfalls%27&amp;rft.au=Cupido%2C+M%3BKritzinger%2C+A%3BVan+Aswegen%2C+F&amp;rft.aulast=Cupido&amp;rft.aufirst=M&amp;rft.date=2005-08-01&amp;rft.volume=41&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=251&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378054&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Towards Social Work Intervention in Rural Schools: Perspectives of Educators

Author: Sathiparsad, R; Taylor, M

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61368193?accountid=14667

Abstract: The article discusses interdisciplinary research across Social Work and Community Health. The research, undertaken in Ugu North, a rural area in Southern Kwa-Zulu Natal, aimed at understanding challenges faced by educators, problems presented by learners and educators views on social work intervention in schools. The results raise questions regarding the consequences for learners, families and communities who have no access to social work and other support services. While theoretically, social work students are taught to bridge the gap between schools and communities, the channels for facilitating this process are unclear. The authors motivate for a multi-disciplinary partnership approach to the provision of social work services at schools and a commitment from the relevant sectors to contribute to providing healthy learning environments. Adapted from the source document.

Caring for AIDS Orphans: The Experiences of Elderly Grandmother Caregivers and AIDS Orphans

Author: Alpaslan, AH; Mabutho, S L

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61394770?accountid=14667

Abstract: AIDS-related deaths of parents have resulted in children being orphaned in large numbers, especially in Botswana, which is one of the countries in Africa affected most severely by this pandemic. Care and guidance of these orphaned children is of great importance, if nations are to be assured of capable leadership in the future. The aim of this research endeavour was to explore and describe the experiences relating to the care of AIDS orphans from the perspective of both the caregivers (elderly grandmothers) and the AIDS orphans in their care. A qualitative approach was used following an explorative, descriptive and contextual research design. The study was conducted in Francistown, a city in the northern part of Botswana, which is known to be the hardest hit by HIV/AIDS. Data were collected by means of semistructured interviews with two groups of stakeholders. Purposive sampling was used to frame a sample of AIDS orphans and elderly grandmother caregivers. Adapted from the source document.

Development of a Holistic Approach to Assisting Families with an Alzheimer's Sufferer

Author: Anstey, I; Anstey, M

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61387025?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article canvases the diagnosis and treatment of Alzheimer's disease (AD), and proposes a holistic support regime for patients, carers and families. The development of services for Alzheimer's patients and their families in the Nelson Mandela Metropole since 1991 is outlined. Based on the expressed needs of families of AD sufferers specific support systems were identified, fund raising undertaken and projects initiated to offer respite to those in need of assistance. The article offers insights into the nature and treatment of AD and how, based on a query from a single family, a system of services can be developed for a community off a small resource base. Adapted from the source document.

A Structural Social Justice Approach to Family Policy: A Critique of the Draft South African Family Policy

Author: Sewpaul, Vishanthie11 School Social Work & Community Development, Howard Coll, Durban, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61390466?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper argues that the draft January 2005 National Family Policy is rooted in a conservative and residual framework and that it is uninformed by an analysis of how factors such as race, class and gender intersect to influence access to power, privilege, status and resources in contemporary South Africa. Neither does the Policy pay attention to how neoliberal capitalism and market-induced inequality is impacting family living. The assertion is that policy for family living must be rooted in a structural, social justice approach. The paper presents a situational analysis of South Africa post 1994, with a specific focus on the impact of neo-liberal capitalism. Against this contemporary socio-economic background, the paper critiques the draft National Family Policy and concludes with advocacy for universal social security provision in the form of a basic income grant for all South Africans. Adapted from the source document.

Mobilising Faith-Based Organisations for Social Development through a Participatory Action Research (PAR) Process

Author: Swart, I11 Dept Practical Theology & Missiology, U Stellenbosch, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61347646?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article gives a critical account of a participatory action research process through which the researchers have aimed to mobilise the faith-based sector for social development action in selected local communities. After highlighting a number of key features, the article describes in some detail the multifaceted methodology applied in the research process and the eventual diffusion of the research results. The article concludes by recognising that, whilst the process has been successful in achieving a certain degree of conscientisation and empowerment, these two aspects remain strategically important in an ongoing PAR initiative. The article finally stresses in particular the importance of the theoretical paradigm of social development in this regard. Adapted from the source document.

Abortion As a Moral Dilemma in South Africa

Author: Humpel, H S1; Strydom, H1 Dept Gesondheid, Potchefstroom Hospital, Noordwes Provinsie

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61354252?accountid=14667

Abstract: Abortion not only implies the termination of a pregnancy & does not solve the problem regarding unwelcome pregnancy as such. A study on abortion shows that it involves all facets of human life & that it has become a moral dilemma in South Africa, as is the case worldwide. Throughout history abortion has evoked moral questions that cannot be answered haphazardly. Abortion has become part & parcel of the ethos of present society & indicates moral decay that cannot be ignored. In order to understand abortion as a moral dilemma, the development of the incidence of abortion from the earliest time to the present liberalized abortion legislation should be kept in mind. Knowledge of the reality & morality of abortion is essential, seeing that one cannot dissociate oneself from it. It not only involves the broad community. Every individual can be confronted by it in one way or another & be faced with unanswered questions. Adapted from the source document.

Funding Strategies: Surviving Imperial Intentions, Protean Policies and Ruthless Reality

Author: Smit, Andre de V11 Dept Social Development, U Cape Town, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61352328?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article briefly considers the concept of funding strategy and chronicles the national intentions of ever-changing funding policies and their subsequent failure. In the main though, the article deals with the ruthless reality that faces the private welfare sector in its quest to stay afloat financially. It is based on a comprehensive survey of 232 organizations that receive funds from the Community Chest of the Western Cape. The results reveal both pleasing and some very worrying trends related to corporate governance, financial management, fund raising, funding sources, project/operational funding and development and sustainability. It also reports on varying perceptions of funding policies, funding sources and future funding trends. Adapted from the source document.

Posttraumatic Stress Symptoms in Emergency Service Ambulance Personnel

Author: Stewart, Jackie1; Swartz, Leslie1 Trauma Centre Survivors Violence & Torture, Cape Town, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61358686?accountid=14667

Abstract: The study reports on psychological factors and posttraumatic stress disorder amongst emergency service ambulance personnel (ESAP) in the Western Cape province of South Africa. Ninety-nine ESAP completed a demographic questionnaire and the Harvard Trauma Questionnaire. Possible PTSD prevalence level was estimated at 6.67%, which was low in comparison to international findings. Chi-squared (kh 2 ) test revealed a significant association between PTSD and home language of respondents (p-value = 0.00059). Fisher Exact test revealed a significant association between PTSD and attendance of recent debriefing (p-value = 0.042). Results must be interpreted with caution because of the small sample sizes, but a starting point has been made for further research into this neglected area in South Africa. Adapted from the source document.

The Relationship between HIV/AIDS and Poverty: The Case of Three Administrative Areas in the Transkei

Author: Mashologu-Kuse, Thobeka11 Dept Social Work, Nelson Mandela Metropolitan U, Port Elizabeth, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61379307?accountid=14667

Abstract: The aim of the study was to establish whether there is a relationship between HIV/AIDS and poverty in three administrative areas, EMbekweni, EBaziya and EMhlakulo, in the Transkei region of the Eastern Cape. It aimed at establishing the extent of poverty of people who are HIV/AIDS infected and affected, how they are coping in their poverty-stricken environments and how the affected can be assisted to offer the necessary support to those living with HIV/AIDS. Ninety respondents, thirty from each administrative area, were identified and interviewed for the research study. The results of the study endorsed the hypothesis that there is a relationship between HIV/AIDS and poverty. Adapted from the source document.

The Stress of Caring: the Manifestation of Stress in the Nurse-Patient Relationship

Author: Schoombee, Johannes Christiaan1; van der Merwe, Johanna Marie; Kruger, Lou-Marie1 Dept Psychology, U Stellenbosch, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61351599?accountid=14667

Abstract: Several studies have shown that nursing professionals in South Africa suffer from high levels of stress and are at increased risk of burnout. The authors contend that it is important for mental health professionals in South Africa to understand the experiences of nurses, since they have to provide support to these workers. Eight maternity ward health-care workers in a state hospital in the Western Cape were interviewed. The grounded theory analysis yielded three major but related issues. Participants experienced their work of taking care of patients as extremely stressful. Moreover, hierarchies in the hospital seemed to be very important for nursing staff. Finally, many of the interviewees reported that patients who were regarded to be out of control or disobedient often elicited aggressive thoughts, feelings and even actions in nursing staff. It was argued that the central underlying concept to all three core categories is the concept of power. Adapted from the source document.

Perceptions of Clients Counselled at a Trauma Centre

Author: Williams, F1; Collins, K J1 Dept Social Development, U Cape Town, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61352068?accountid=14667

Abstract: This research consists of evaluation with 20 clients who had been involved in a traumatic event and who had completed trauma counselling at The Trauma Centre for Survivors of Violence and Torture in Cape Town in the previous six months. The report also contains relevant literature on trauma and trauma counselling. Two research questions formed the basis of the study, namely: (1) how the respondents experienced the trauma counselling they had received, and (2) how they felt that the counselling assisted them with achieving post-traumatic growth. To answer these research questions, a combination of qualitative and quantitative methods was used. From the results of the study it can be concluded that all of the respondents had a positive counselling experience. The second important finding was that 90% of the respondents discussed other issues besides the trauma in their counselling and they felt that trauma counselling had indeed assisted them with achieving growth in self-awareness. Adapted from the source document.

A Human Potential Development Perspective for Community Work

Author: Reynecke, R P11 Dept Social Work, U Free State, Bloemfontein, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61390855?accountid=14667

Abstract: It is reasoned that community work projects are not always sustainable because of a lack of human development. The people that form part of projects need additional capacity-building. This should not be only in the form of technical skills, should also focus especially on life skills. This means that social workers should integrate the satisfaction of concrete needs and abstract (psychological) development by means of community work. It therefore calls for a discussion regarding the nature of community work, the human potential development approach and life skills training as the basis for community empowerment. Adapted from the source document.

Street Children: A Study of the after-Care Services Provided by Street-Wise (Durban)

Author: Shabalala, B1; Gathiram, N1 c/o Gathiram -- School Social Work & Community Development, U KwaZulu-Natal, Durban, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61335763?accountid=14667

Abstract: The paper focuses on a study of an after-care programme provided to street children by Street-Wise (Durban). This preliminary study indicated that, although Street-Wise had been successful in keeping the child at home, they are struggling to implement the programme. The interventions used were found to be inadequate in dealing with the magnitude of poverty which was cited as the primary factor that drove the child onto the street. It is recommended that intervention should be multi-dimensional and target the micro, mezzo and macro systems. For effective service delivery there has to be a partnership involving Street-Wise, governmental and locally-based organisations where the children reside. Adapted from the source document.

Enhancing the Measurement Properties of the Heimler Scale of Social Functioning through Extending Its Response Range

Author: van Breda, A D11 Military Health Research Centre, South African National Defence Force, Pretoria, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61353449?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper presents comparative validation data for the original three-point response range version of the Heimler Scale of Social Functioning (HSSF) and a new five-point response range version. Three samples of one thousand soldiers in the South African National Defence Force were used for this study. Increasing the response range of the HSSF improved the reliability of the scale, but had only a very small impact on the instrument's construct and criterion-related validities. The author concludes that the content validity of the HSSF may be flawed and recommends a revision of the item sample of the instrument. Adapted from the source document.

A Review of Child Protection Services in South Africa: State of the Art Policies in Need of Implementation

Author: September, R L11 Instit Child & Family Development, U Western Cape, Bellville, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61353408?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper reports on the outcomes of a review on the status of the child protection system in the nine provincial departments of social development in South Africa. It focuses on the problems inherent in the system, its strengths and limitations, suggests possible solutions, and makes recommendations for policy implementation. The review was conducted by the Child and Youth Research and Training Programme (CYRTP) at the University of the Western Cape. It involved a participatory research design to facilitate an in-depth review process as well as a developmental process to include a problem-solving element focusing on solutions to address the identified limitations and challenges. The review report, including comprehensive recommendations, was presented to the relevant provincial and national Directors and the two Director Generals' in the national Department of Social Development. Adapted from the source document.

A Comparison of Demographic Characteristics and Family Influences in a Sample of Pregnant and Non-Pregnant Black African Teenagers

Author: Tefera, A1; Petersen, I; Govender, K1 Dept Health, KwaZulu-Natal

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61382380?accountid=14667

Abstract: A non-equivalent sample of 288 pregnant and non-pregnant Black African teenagers was compared with regard to demographic characteristics and family-level influences in Durban, South Africa. The demographic risk factors found to be associated with the presence of adolescent pregnancy included increasing age, low socio-economic status, absence of one or both parents, and poor academic achievement, with the most predictive being increasing age and low educational level of the mother. With regard to family-level influences, an authoritarian family decision-making style emerged as having a protective effect against teenage pregnancy. Adapted from the source document.

Evaluating the Immune Systems of HIV/AIDS Patients

Author: Roux, A1; Kotze, G; Strydom, H1 Vakgroep: Maatskaplike Werk, Skool Psigo-sosiale Gedragswetenskappe, Noordwes-U, Potchefstroom, Suid-Afrika

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61352246?accountid=14667

Abstract: As a result of the HIV/AIDS problem, the Faculty of Health Sciences undertook to investigate the immune systems of HIV/AIDS patients in the Potchefstroom health district. One of the aims were to improve the sense of well-being & quality of life of these patients by means of a group work intervention programme. To evaluate the effect of the programme, Affectometer 2 (AFM) by Kammann & Flett (1983) was used. The results obtained by this evaluation showed that the group work programme brought about a significant difference in the sense of well-being & quality of life of these patients. Adapted from the source document.

The Human Development Situation of Johannesburg's Youth

Author: Noyoo, N1; Patel, L; Loffell, J1 Centre Social Development Africa, U Johannesburg, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61376155?accountid=14667

Abstract: The question of South Africa's youth remains quite contentious even after eleven years of democratic rule in the country. This group still grapples with many social ills due to its marginalised status. Despite efforts by both government and civil society aimed at reversing the negative trends affecting this population, its overall living circumstances remain precarious. The present discussion revisits the plight of the youth by proffering a synoptic account of a larger study that had examined the human development situation of the youth in Johannesburg. It throws some light on the situation of young people in Johannesburg, whilst making reference to empirical evidence that was elicited via a number of research tools. It concludes by making mention of the outcomes of the previous study that were contained in a report as recommendations for intervention. Adapted from the source document.

The Power of Biography: Shifting the Boundaries of Knowledge through Emancipatory Pedagogy and Critical Consciousness

Author: Sewpaul, V11 Centre Social Work, U KwaZulu-Natal, Howard Coll Campus, Durban, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61356607?accountid=14667

Abstract: Based on lessons derived from my own biography, the main argument of this paper is that critical reflection on one's social and political realities and the capacity to develop action strategies consequent upon these reflections constitute central elements in shifting the boundaries of knowledge among students. Critical reflection allows for deconstruction and reconstruction of identities and for possibilities of engaging in constructive action. Emancipatory pedagogy raises important issues regarding the way we construct our identities within particular historical, cultural and social relations with the aim of contributing to a more democratic life. Applying the experiential and emancipatory pedagogies of Freire, Gramsci and Giroux, this paper describes my efforts to develop critical consciousness among students. Adapted from the source document.

Experiences of South African Social Workers in the United Kingdom

Author: Naidoo, S1; Kasiram, M1 School Social Work & Community Development, U KwaZulu-Natal, Durban, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61378145?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article addresses the exodus of social workers from South Africa and its consequences for the future of the profession. It is the second report on a study conducted with three sample groups, with findings in respect of the first two groups having been reported earlier (Naidoo & Kasiram, 2003). This report analyses results from the sample of social workers who are practising in the United Kingdom. Among the benefits enjoyed by the group abroad, safe working conditions, excellent pay commensurate with other professionals with a four year degree, good working benefits, management support and opportunity for continuing professional development are mentioned. However, there were concerns expressed regarding racism from colleagues and clients, the dull English weather, limited accommodation and feeling culturally and spiritually unfulfilled that prompted them to plan to return to South Africa but not to practise social work! This loss is a concern facing the profession. Adapted from the source document.

Plumbing the Brain Drain of South African Social Workers Migrating to the UK: Challenges for Social Service Providers

Author: Engelbrecht, L K11 Dept Social Work, Stellenbosch U, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61368783?accountid=14667

Abstract: In its first decade of democracy South Africa lost a considerable number of its social workers to the United Kingdom. In general the reality of this fact and its impact are acknowledged both informally and officially. However, little empirical or comprehensive data is available on the phenomenon and its implications. Research on the migration of South African social workers to the United Kingdom was consequently undertaken to uncover generalisations and identify challenges that social service providers will need to meet in future if South African social workers are to be retained in the country. A sample consisting of 65 South Africans currently practising as social workers in the UK was investigated. The key finding of the research was that the social workers who migrated to the UK represent a lost generation, who may not easily be regained for social service delivery in South Africa. The challenges that local service providers will need to meet in order to retain the generation of remaining and prospective social workers in South Africa are presented as the other side of the effect of the brain drain phenomenon on local social work. These challenges entail, among other things, that social service providers need to establish a culture of healthy human resource management, including practices aimed at collective retention strategies that are sustainable and proactive. Adapted from the source document.

The Process of Psychotherapy for Helping Professionals: The Role of Empirical Findings to Guide Practice

Author: Kagee, A11 Dept Psychology, Stellenbosch U, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61381707?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper is an articulation of a process model of psychotherapy that may serve to guide the practice of social workers, psychologists and other helping professionals. It begins by sketching a contextual paradigm within which the practice of therapy is located. A rationale for the process is then offered, after which the course of therapy is described from the beginning to the end. The process is divided into the beginning, middle, and end stages. However, these divisions are cited mainly for organisational purposes. Further miscellaneous factors are identified that may affect the process of therapy. Adapted from the source document.

Social Capital and Social Development

Author: Nieman, A11 Dept Social Work, Stellenbosch U, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61331575?accountid=14667

Abstract: The article examines social capital in terms of its relevance for the fields of social work and social welfare. The different forms, levels and benefits for individuals and communities are discussed. This is done to establish whether and how social capital could be harnessed for the purpose of enhancing social development efforts. The rationale for social development and identifying certain elements considered as good practice criteria for success, as part of community development programmes, are highlighted. These elements, namely participation, groups and training, potentially already contain "bundles" of social capital. Applying them could provide fertile ground for the development and cultivation of social capital, thus contributing to the success and sustainability of such programmes. Adapted from the source document.

Evaluating Various Community Services of the Potchefstroom Service Center for the Aged

Author: Strydom, H1; Roux, A A1 Skool Psigo-Sosiale Gedragswetenskappe: Afdeling Maatskaplike Werk, Potchefstroomkampus, Noordwes-U, Suid-Afrika

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61378587?accountid=14667

Abstract: The study reported on a needs assessment done in the greater Potchefstroom area with the aim to evaluate the various community services of the Potchefstroom Service Centre for the Aged. This study ascertained why some aged people are not members of the service centre & what kinds of services are preferred by members & non-members of the service centre. Some recommendations had also been made regarding steps to be taken by the Potchefstroom Service Centre for the Aged in order to still improve the current services offered. Adapted from the source document.

Challenges Experienced by Grandparents Raising Grandchildren: An Exploratory Study

Author: Mokone, J M11 Dept Social Work, U Limpopo, Sovenga, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61390365?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper focuses on challenges experienced by grandparents raising grandchildren. An exploratory study was conducted in Mankweng Township, Limpopo. The aims of the study were to determine the factors that lead grandparents to assume parenting roles, to explore the challenges that grandparents raising grandchildren face and to examine the support systems they utilise to cope with the challenges imposed on them. Semi-structured qualitative face-to-face interviews were conducted with twelve grandparents who had volunteered to participate in this study. The respondents had mixed feelings about having the responsibility of parenting their grandchildren. On the one hand, they cherished having their grandchildren around them, being able to ensure that their grandchildren's needs were catered for and being engaged in activities in which their grandchildren were participating, such as sports and education. However, financial problems and disappointment in their own children were identified as some of the major concerns that had a negative influence on their attitude to this situation. Implications of the findings are discussed. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Challenges+Experienced+by+Grandparents+Raising+Grandchildren%3A+An+Exploratory+Study&amp;rft.au=Mokone%2C+J+M&amp;rft.aulast=Mokone&amp;rft.aufirst=J&amp;rft.date=2006-06-01&amp;rft.volume=42&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=187&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378054&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The Shaky High Moral Ground of Postmodernist "Ethics"

Author: Gray, M1; Lovat, T1 U Newcastle, New South Wales, Australia

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61377705?accountid=14667

Abstract: The paper takes as its starting point the paradoxical question of whether postmodernism can have a moral, ethical and values base. It explores the murky waters of postmodern relativism, which works against professions such as social work taking a strong ethical stance against injustice. It explores some philosophical arguments supporting the search for moral universals, no matter how minimal they might be, and advocates the enduring utility of ethical codes, despite their limitations. By its very nature ethics has a transcendent quality and Habermas's groundbreaking ethical schema is described for its enduring fit with the Western philosophical tradition and its compatibility with social work thinking on ethics. Adapted from the source document.

Statutory Social Services: An Integral Part of Developmental Social Welfare Service Delivery

Author: Lombard, A1; Kleijn, W C1 Dept Social Work & Criminology, U Pretoria, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61351257?accountid=14667

Abstract: The developmental social welfare policy mandates a developmental approach to all social service delivery, including statutory interventions which form part of protection services. This article intends to open a debate not on whether statutory social services can or should be developmental, but on how to provide these services within a developmental approach and what the challenges are to achieve this, given practice realities. Adapted from the source document.

The Application of a Large Group Intervention Method Based on the Asset-Based Approach: A Repositioning of Training in Community Development

Author: Nel, J B S11 Dept Social Work, U Johannesburg, Auckland Park, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61376857?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article describes a large group practice intervention based on the assets-based approach to community development (ABCD) (Kretzmann & McKnight, 1993). It also explains how postgraduate students were trained in this approach, how this approach was applied in different urban and rural communities and how the outcomes were evaluated on a preliminary basis. The differentiation between community processes and techniques that are future and capacity-oriented and those that are deficiency- based will receive special attention. ABCD was found to be energising in nature in that it mobilises people towards self-reliant community development. Adapted from the source document.

Poverty, Development and Disability

Author: Gathiram, N11 School Social Work & Community Development, U KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61372495?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper focuses on the disproportionate rate of poverty amongst persons with disability and their families. In South Africa poverty is rife in the general population and communities are underdeveloped with few resources and services. The environment lacks the support and opportunities that persons with disabilities need to enhance their functioning and quality of life as productive members of society. The author argues that in these poor communities there has to be synergy with mainstream development and those developments that are specific for persons with disabilities. It is proposed that integration of disability services into all development programmes at community level is essential, given the South African context. Integration of disability services into all development programmes is a cost-effective approach to deal with poverty and disability in resource-poor settings. Challenges in implementing these recommendations are discussed. Adapted from the source document.

The Role of the Social Worker's Personality as Well as the External Environment in the Successful Management of a Private Practice

Author: Bloem, C H M1; Delport, C S L1 U Pretoria

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61381574?accountid=14667

Abstract: In order to manage a private practice successfully, a social worker must not only have the necessary knowledge & skills to his disposal; he must also be able to analyse his own unique personality & the environment in which he functions as well as the interplay between these internal & external elements. The aim of this article is thus to discuss the nature & role of the social worker's personality & the manifestation thereof as internal element as well as the environment as external element & the importance thereof in social work private practice. In this context specific emphasis will be on a discussion regarding the entrepreneurial personality & emotional intelligence as internal elements & the environment & the continuous changes in the environment as external elements. Adapted from the source document.

The Perception of the Professional Self of Social Workers in Private Practice

Author: Davidson, C1; Schenck, C J1 c/o Schenck -- Dept Social Work, UNISA, Pretoria, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61346815?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social work in South Africa appears to have low status and a negative "welfare" image. The general public seems to regard social workers and the profession with disdain and for the most part is ignorant of what social workers do apart from handing out grants and removing children from their families. This exploratory research focuses on social workers in private practice -- how they view their professional selves, the factors that contribute to the development of their professional selves and the factors that hinder or facilitate this development. Adapted from the source document.

Proactive Stress Management: The Nature, Effect and Implications of the South African Police Service's "Managing Stress Effectively" Programme

Author: Williams, H M1; Weyers, M L1 South African Police Service, Pretoria

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61354141?accountid=14667

Abstract: The work of police officials is generally regarded as highly stressful. Because of this and other factors, the SAPS's Social Work Service developed the proactive "Managing Stress Effectively" programme to improve personnel's practical stress-management strategies and techniques. This programme's effect was measured by means of six measurement scales in a research project that involved 384 experimental and comparison group members and 32 presenters. The measurements showed that it had a significant effect on the respondents' behaviour and changed their personal and professional lives in a very positive manner. This result implies that the programme in its current or adapted form could be used as an effective instrument in addressing stress-related problems in other occupational and generic social work settings. Adapted from the source document.

The Use of the Personal Narrative in Social Work with the Elderly

Author: Howes, F11 Dept Social Work, Stellenbosch U, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61382158?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article describes how a lifespan approach to personality, with its developmental stages, and constructionism have broadened the knowledge base of social work practice. This has also enlarged interventive knowledge by adding the constructed narrative as a tool at the disposal of the social worker. The narrative directs the interventive process. In social work with the elderly reminiscence and life review are important elements. Narrative therapy can successfully accommodate these elements. Adapted from the source document.

An Insight into Recidivism among Male Awaiting-Trial Youth Offenders and the Implications for Practice

Author: Gxubane, T11 Dept Social Development, U Cape Town, Rondebosch, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61390634?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article outlines and describes major variables associated with recidivism and the rehabilitation of male awaiting-trial youth offenders. It is based on a study that was undertaken by the author to investigate the problem specifically from the perspective of awaiting-trial juvenile recidivists. Findings in the study revealed that financial gain, drug addiction and peer pressure were the major driving forces and motivating factors that influenced the respondents to become repeatedly involved in criminal behaviour. Lack of a stable source of income, denial of readmission at school, rejection by family and friends, and lack of a stable home and accommodation were some of the major factors that made reintegration into the community difficult for the respondents during the period after their previous release. Reintegration and after-care services were identified as areas that are grossly neglected in the field of probation and in social work services generally. In view of the key findings of the study, recommendations are outlined with regard to proposed strategies for the management and control of recidivism among male awaiting-trial youth offenders. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.atitle=An+Insight+into+Recidivism+among+Male+Awaiting-Trial+Youth+Offenders+and+the+Implications+for+Practice&amp;rft.au=Gxubane%2C+T&amp;rft.aulast=Gxubane&amp;rft.aufirst=T&amp;rft.date=2006-08-01&amp;rft.volume=42&amp;rft.issue=3-4&amp;rft.spage=307&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378054&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Experience of Grandmothers as Kinship Caregiver (Family Foster Parent)

Author: van Rensburg, D1; Green, S1 c/o Green -- Dept Maatskaplike Werk, U Stellenbosch, Suid-Afrika

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61351605?accountid=14667

Abstract: An exploratory study with a descriptive design has been used in order to gain a better understanding of the experience of grandmothers as kinship caregiver (family foster parent) for their grandchildren. The increase in the number of grandmothers who are acting as kinship caregivers, as well as the shortage of indigenous literature on this phenomenon in South Africa, were the motivation for the study. The aim of the study is to provide some guidelines to social workers for service rendering to these grandmothers & foster children. The study presents a profile of the grandmother as kinship caregiver as well as the foster child in Kayamandi. The findings of the study show that the experiences of the grandmother as kinship caregiver are marked with mixed feelings, but are overall a positive experience. The recommendations focus mainly on grandmothers' need for social & material support. Adapted from the source document.

Exploring Unplanned Pregnancy amongst University Students

Author: Naidoo, P1; Kasiram, M1 Dept Student Counselling, Westville Campus, U KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61357245?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article reports on a study conducted to explore an increase in the incidence of unplanned pregnancy among students at the University of KwaZulu-Natal (Westville Campus). Results point to irregular or no knowledge or use of contraceptives. An important finding was that, despite being educated about sexual risk-taking behaviour and HIV/AIDS, students were unable to negotiate safer sexual practices because they feared losing their partners should they take "control" in the sexual relationship. Abortion was the first choice to deal with anticipated academic, financial and emotional problems brought on by the pregnancy. The results are of particular value to student support and academic sectors of the University of KwaZulu-Natal in planning programmes for students, especially the Department of Student Counselling and the University health clinic. Results may also be extrapolated for use by other educational institutions. Adapted from the source document.

The Eight Habits of Highly Effective Community Social Workers: A South African Perspective

Author: Weyers, M L11 School Psychosocial Behavioural Sciences: Social Work Division, North-West U, Potchefstroom, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61379115?accountid=14667

Abstract: The article contains the results of a study that had the basic aim of answering the question: "What makes effective community social workers effective?" It utilised the constant comparative research method to analyse the contents of community work/developmental social work articles contained in the two accredited South African social work journals. The analysis produced a total of 8 "habits of effectiveness". This set of habits can form a credo that should guide a community social worker's service delivery and also provide a list of criteria against which their current habits could be judged and inappropriate (i.e. "bad") ones be identified. Adapted from the source document.

Power, Discourse and Ideology: Challenging Essentialist Notions of Race and Identity in Institutions of Higher Learning in South Africa

Author: Sewpaul, V11 Centre Social Work, U KwaZulu-Natal, Howard Coll Campus, Durban, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61352049?accountid=14667

Abstract: Given the impact of colonialism and apartheid, there is no denial that a Western hegemony has become inscribed into South African academic institutions. There is, unarguably, a need for an emancipatory pedagogy that addresses local and national context specific realities, especially in a discipline such as social work. Drawing on the writings of Paulo Friere and Henry Giroux, I argue that such a scholarship must strive towards deepening democracy. Whether or not such a scholarship ought to be exclusively framed as "Afrocentric" shaped by and inscribed with "an African Identity", as advocated by eminent South African academics are the central issues that I deal with in this paper. Adapted from the source document.

Social Services in Cape Town: An Analysis Using the Political Ethics of Care

Author: Bozalek, V1; Henderson, N; Lambert, W; Collins, K; Green, S1 Stellenbosch , South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61386794?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article uses the political ethics of care as a moral framework to examine the findings of a joint research project involving social work students at three higher education institutions in the Western Cape Province. The students interviewed social service providers at 51 service points in Cape Town. This paper offers some preliminary observations with regard to these social service settings in Cape Town, resulting from this exploratory research project on welfare service provision. The provision of services are analysed from Tronto's (1993) ethic of care framework incorporating attentiveness, responsibility and competence. This study highlights the fact that, while service providers are attentive to service users' needs and construct these needs as structural, the services they deliver are not directly addressing these needs. It is also apparent that fiscal constraints premised on neoliberal principles have negatively affected the responsibility and competence within care as a social and moral practice in service delivery. Adapted from the source document.

Lay Forums in Child Welfare

Author: Schmid, J11 Faculty Social Work, Wilfrid Laurier U, Kitchener-Waterloo

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61357841?accountid=14667

Abstract: There are two broad traditions of working with families within Western systems of child welfare: consensual approaches within the "family service" and "community care" models, and adversarial approaches in the "child protection" model. South African child welfare falls primarily into the latter category. There is some agreement that conflict-based approaches limit the effectiveness of child welfare outcomes for both service users and providers. Strategies which promote consensual decision-making are increasingly being sought, and this is reflected in the new South African Children's Act (2005), which makes provision for the use of lay forums in particular situations. Against the backdrop of Freymond and Cameron's (2006) child welfare models, this paper discusses the use of these "intermediary structures" in Western child welfare systems and critiques the provisions made for their use in the Children's Act (2005). The writer argues that lay forums (whether these are methods successfully used in "first world" countries or local Indigenous approaches) can make an important contribution to child welfare in South Africa. Adapted from the source document.

Families of Street Children in the Transkei: A Developmental Perspective

Author: Mashologu-Kuse, T11 Dept Social Work, Nelson Mandela Metropolitan U, Port Elizabeth, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61349661?accountid=14667

Abstract: The phenomenon of street children was until recently alien in African society, especially in a rural traditional society like that of the Transkei. Traditionally, children were taken care of by their biological parents or the extended kin, should the parents for some reason fail to execute this function. No children were found wanting in the streets. The presence of children in the streets of Umthatha prompted the inquisitiveness of the researcher to conduct this study in order to identify the characteristics of families of these street boys. The article is based on a research study of a random sample of thirty (30) families, whose boys, aged between ten and seventeen (10-17), were inmates of a street shelter in Umthatha. The aim of the study was to determine the general characteristics of families of street children in the Transkei region of the Eastern Cape Province. Results of the study point to family disorganisation as the main characteristic of these families. Adapted from the source document.

A Critique of the South African National Life-Skills and HIV/AIDS School Policy: Lessons for Policy Adjustment

Author: Raniga, T11 School Social Work & Community Development, U KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61379380?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper documents research (in progress) on the extent to which school principals were aware of the National HIV/AIDS School Policy (Department of Education, 1999). The paper presents the empirical findings of a quantitative audit undertaken at 74 secondary schools in the eThekwini region, in KwaZulu-Natal. Four key themes form the central premise of the paper: the extent of awareness of the HIV/AIDS School-based Policy; the challenges experienced by schools in the implementation of the Policy; the lack of institutional capacity at school level to deal with the problem of HIV/AIDS and the disparity that exists between the institutional capacity of urban schools as compared to rural schools with regard to the implementation of the Policy. The paper concludes that there is a need to broaden the scope of social work intervention in schools. Adapted from the source document.

Translated title not available

Author: Geyer, L S1; Strydom, H1 Vakgroep Maatskaplike Werk, Noordwes-U, Potchefstroomkampus, Suid-Afrika

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61347529?accountid=14667

Abstract: The purpose of this article is (a) to identify the strengths of alcohol dependent elderly people through empirical & literature studies & (b) to identify the qualities of a strengths perspective for application in empowerment-oriented group work. Fifty-six (N=56) alcohol dependent elderly people & twenty-seven (N=27) social work practitioners were identified through non-probability sampling techniques at registered treatment centres, the Christelike Afhanklikheidsdiens (CAD) & Christelike Afhanklikheidsbediening (CAB) Interviews & a literature study were undertaken for data collection purposes. The results show that the strengths perspective holds various advantages for the elderly, while disadvantages were also identified. It was found that a strengths perspective could be implemented in group work services with the mentioned clients, as it entails age-old values of social work. Recommendations for practice & further research needs are included. Adapted from the source document.

Separating Social Welfare Services and Social Welfare Grants: Challenges and Opportunities

Author: September, R L11 Instit Child & Family Development, U Western Cape, Bellville, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61380482?accountid=14667

Abstract: Historically in South Africa social security benefits, most commonly known as social welfare grants, which are payable to targeted beneficiaries on a means-tested basis, have been administered by the Welfare Department, since 2000 called the Department of Social Development. During 2004 the national Department of Social Development made a landmark decision to separate its core functions of social security and social welfare services. Although the welfare sector generally responded positively, the separation also raised key challenges. The expanded social welfare grants programme especially impacts upon an already ailing child welfare system. The separation presents an important opportunity to refocus the agenda of social welfare services without social security. Previously, almost the entire budget for the Department was based primarily on the cost of social security to vulnerable groups that is, children, elderly people and people with disabilities living in poverty, as well as grants for children in foster care. Although these important functions are now provided by two different systems within the same department, it remains crucial that they are carefully aligned, so that the beneficiaries can rely on an efficient and comprehensive programme of social welfare services. In this paper the author reflects on some of the opportunities and challenges presented by the new system of welfare delivery. Adapted from the source document.

Afro-Centrism: The Challenge of Social Development

Author: Osei-Hwedie, K11 Dept Social Work, U Botswana, Gaboron

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61362208?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social development has ushered in an ideology emphasising equality of all people, social justice, human rights, access to services, opportunities and resources, and more importantly, the new drive towards poverty reduction. However, social development as a community-driven process takes place within a national and international context. Thus, in the African context, despite the efforts to use local knowledge, norms, values, skills and technology, social development must take into account external factors that affect local development. The article, therefore, discusses the challenges of social development based on African values. It also examines the prospects of balancing local and foreign values, and norms that often seem contradictory. For example, can social development be reconceptualised with botho or ubuntu ('humanness') as a core organising principle in a neo-liberal political and economic context? Adapted from the source document.

Perceptions of Relationship Violence: A Youth Perspective

Author: Pretorius, B M L1; Terblanche, S S; Tshiwula, J L1 Dept Social Development Professions, Nelson Mandela Metropolitan U

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61373890?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article seeks to privilege a youth perspective on relationship violence, given the critique that existing programmes tend to represent adult views. By representing youth perspectives, the article makes a specific contribution to social work research that places the spotlight on preventive interventions that are more aligned to actual perceptions of youth. The qualitative study was conducted as part of a three-phase doctoral study and focuses on a specific theme regarding 'youth perceptions of relationship violence' that emerged during the thematic analysis of 58 youth narratives. From the data it emerged that youths, based on direct or vicarious experiences, are unsure of boundaries in relation to the ambiguities and contradictions they perceive as being inherent in violence within relationship spaces. It is recommended that the perceptions articulated by youths themselves can be used as markers to inform development of effective programmes for relationship violence prevention. Adapted from the source document.

Family Disorganization and Mental Health in a South African Mining Community

Author: Chenga, C1; Cronje, F1 U Kent, UK

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61382724?accountid=14667

Abstract: Most of the communities around South African mines are synonymous with poor family structures by virtue of the nature of the mining environment. Family disorganisation within the mining communities is a symptom of the migrant labour system, poverty and unemployment, HIV/AIDS and a poor infrastructure. The impact of family disorganisation on mental health is a burning and relevant subject which has been ignored to a huge extent when dealing with issues related to mining communities. This article is based on qualitative research undertaken in mining communities around a platinum mine in the North-West Province in South Africa. Adapted from the source document.

Translated title not available

Author: Strydom, C1; Nogueira, L; Roux, A A1 Skool Psigo-sosiale Gedragswetenskappe, Potchefstroomkampus, Noordwes-U, Suid-Afrika

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61354278?accountid=14667

Abstract: HIV/AIDS is mainly a health problem, but it has social & economic implications worldwide & is seen as a pandemic that affects South Africa negatively. The agricultural labour force, specifically the farm worker community, is also negatively affected by the pandemic. However, few research reports are available pertaining to this problem in this section of the population The researcher therefore investigated the attitudes & level of knowledge of the farm worker community with regard to HIV/AIDS. During the investigation it was established that knowledge was lacking & misperceptions about the HI virus prevailed among the farm workers. The investigation showed that it was thus essential to change their attitudes & that the social worker could play an important role in this regard. Adapted from the source document.

Social Capital, Support Networks and Black Elderly Persons

Author: Howes, F11 Dept Social Work, Stellenbosch U, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61352914?accountid=14667

Abstract: As social capital plays a pivotal role in the social welfare policy of the Western Cape, this article examines the nature of social capital and social networks. It explores the social networks of Black elderly persons in Kayamandi, Stellenbosch, to determine the state of social capital in that community. The findings indicate that bonding social capital and bridging social capital is present in the community, but linking social capital is very low. It is recommended that this age cohort be used to enlarge social capital in that community. Adapted from the source document.

The Prevalence of Unwanted Sexual Experiences among Belgian and South African Students

Author: Revell, A1; Vansteenwegen, A; Nicholas, L1 Instit Familiale Seksuologische Wetenschappen, Faculteit Geneeskunde, Katholieke U Leuven, Belgium

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61386704?accountid=14667

Abstract: Given the extent of the problem of child sexual abuse (CSA) in South Africa, there is a need for more international comparative research to facilitate international awareness of this problem. This study compared the unwanted sexual experiences of 1,081 South African and 2,608 Belgian first-year university students. The Early Sexual Experience Checklist (ESEC) (Miller, Johnson & Johnson, 1991) was administered to all consenting first-year university students attending an orientation programme at a Belgian and a South African University. Of the respondents 21% indicated that they had had unwanted sexual experiences before their 16th birthday (39.2% South Africans and 13.5% Belgians). Most respondents indicated that the unwanted experiences happened only once (66% of Belgians and 59% of South Africans). Adapted from the source document.

Factors Hindering the Successful Outcome of Rural Community Projects

Author: Makofane, Mankwane1; Gray, Mel M.A.1 University of Limpopo, Turfloop, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61352620?accountid=14667

Abstract: Little socio-economic development has occurred in most rural areas in the Limpopo Province twelve years after the advent of democracy. This paper is based on an exploratory descriptive study conducted among fourth-year students at the University of the North now the University of Limpopo who live in impoverished rural communities. Focus group interviews were conducted with 21 participants. The findings suggest that most community members have not benefited from income-generating projects, some of which have collapsed for various reasons. Nonetheless, the villagers' spirit of ubuntu motivates them to volunteer in projects that cater for vulnerable groups, such as children, the elderly and people living with HIV and AIDS. Adapted from the source document.

Community Development Workers: Four lessons from International Experience of Community-Based Workers

Author: Van Rooyen, Deidre11 Centre for Development Support, Unversity of the Free State, Bloemfontein, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61362296?accountid=14667

Abstract: The South African government initiated a Community Development Worker Project in 2003. The aim of these workers is to maintain direct contact with people where they live, and to assist in rendering development initiatives embedded in communities. Although the current documentation provides an overview of what is expected of these workers, the question remains what one can learn from international experiences in relation to having a cadre of dispersed and locally accessible pool of community-based workers. This article highlights these important lessons, which should be taken into account in the conceptualisation of the role of community development workers. Adapted from the source document.

The Socio-Economic Reality of Being a Day Labourer in Pretoria

Author: Blaauw, Derick1; Pretorius, A M; Schenck, C J1 Department of Economics, University of Johannesburg, Johannesburg, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61351675?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper portrays the socio-economic conditions experienced by day labourers operating in Pretoria. These day labourers were black, mostly male, young, low skilled, earned low and uncertain levels of income, and worked under harsh conditions. Although most of them were physically removed from their families, they deemed them important enough to try to maintain ties with them. While away from home, they relied on fellow day labourers for social support and interaction. Governmental grants and transfers are important for the survival of day labourers' dependants. Results of this study are compared with similar studies conducted in the United States. Adapted from the source document.
