The Socio-Emotional Experiences of Older Persons with Visual Impairments

Author: Meyer, Tania1; Green, S1 Department of Social Work, Stellenbosch University, Stellenbosch, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61369522?accountid=14667

Abstract: Given the intense effect visual impairment has on the quality of life of older persons, there is an increased awareness in social work of the growing need and demand for support services for older persons who are visually impaired. The study explores the socio-emotional experiences of these persons from a life stage and ecological perspective. The investigation shows that visual impairment severely influences the daily functioning of older persons. The findings indicate the need for preventative services, assessment of the influence of visual impairment on the socio-emotional functioning of older persons, and social work interventions at individual, family and community levels. Adapted from the source document.

Introducing Life Maps as Technique in a Social Group Work Programme for Young Adults Living with HIV/AIDS

Author: Strydom, Herman1; Herbst, A G1 Social Work Division, School for Psycho-Social Behavioural Sciences, North-West University, Potchefstroom Campus, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61331741?accountid=14667

Abstract: Although the life map technique has been used in general social work practice for the past fourteen years, it has never been described or researched. The motivation for this study is to describe this technique. Given the extent of the HIV/AIDS pandemic in South Africa and globally, the technique was build into a social group work programme for young adults living with HIV/AIDS which was implemented in the Free State Province of South Africa. Following an experimental design and utilising a standardised measuring instrument, the general contentment of both the experimental and control groups was measured to evaluate the effectiveness of the programme. The experimental group's general contentment increased by 10.7%, while the control group's general contentment decreased by 1.3%. Adapted from the source document.

Researching the Role of Race in Young Biracial Adults' Identity Construction: Exploring Implications for Transracial Adoptions

Author: Fancis, Dennis11 School of Social Science Education, Faculty of Education, University of KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61383660?accountid=14667

Abstract: Transracial adoption, has been met with controversy in both South Africa and abroad. Although this article does not report research on transracial adoption, it draws on the insights of research on nine Indian-White biracial young adults to explore implications for the transracial adoption debate. Findings from this study indicate parallels between transracial adoptees and biracial individuals and that influences on racial identity are broader than the family and challenge the misconception that unless White foster parents are "carefully trained", they cannot provide Black children with the necessary skills for coping in a racist society. Adapted from the source document.

An Evaluation of the Impact of a Life Skills Programme in the Workplace

Author: Taute, Florinda11 Department of Social Work and Criminology, University of Pretoria, Pretoria, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61386695?accountid=14667

Abstract: It is indispensable for social workers to evaluate their interventions to ascertain whether they are effective and lead to change. The Life Skills programme was implemented at a tertiary institution. In this quantitative research a quasi-experimental design with a one-group pre-test post-test experiment and a pre-test self-constructed questionnaire were administered to measure respondents' knowledge, skills and attitudes. Forty-six of the 71 respondents (65%) completed the post-test questionnaire six months after attendance of the programme. Results showed that Life Skills training could enhance adults' social functioning irrespective of age, gender, marital status or qualifications. Adapted from the source document.

The Impact of Social Welfare Policies on Social Development in South Africa: An NGO Perspective

Author: Lombard, Antoinette11 Department of Social Work and Criminology, University of Pretoria, Pretoria, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61389000?accountid=14667

Abstract: The adoption of the White Paper for Social Welfare (1997) earmarked the commitment of the social welfare sector to impact on social development goals in South Africa. As policy frameworks the Integrated Social Service Delivery Model & the Policy on Financial Awards to Service Providers reveal great strengths to this effect. However, critical challenges remain to take the social welfare sector forward in delivering on its social development agenda. To fast-track service delivery requires the social welfare sector to redefine its developmental context & focus, guided by clear terminology & policy directions for implementation, monitoring & evaluation. Adapted from the source document.

"A Short History of Time": Charting the Contribution of Social Development Service Delivery to Enhance Child Justice 1996-2006

Author: Sloth-Nielsen, Julia11 Faculty of Law, University of the Western Cape, Bellville, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61368496?accountid=14667

Abstract: By charting the contribution of social development service delivery to enhance child justice from 1996 to 2006, this article argues that the contribution of the social development sector to child justice has been substantial. An array of developments in relation to assessment, diversion, pre-trial incarceration & the residential care system, & probation are described. It is therefore concluded that, although the Child Justice Bill has not been finalized in Parliament, social welfare services to children in trouble with the law have expanded to the extent that there has now an identifiable, developmentally appropriate & more progressive child justice system. Adapted from the source document.

An Adapted Intervention Research Model: Suggestions for Research and Practice

Author: Strydom, Herman1; Steyn, M M; Strydom, C1 School for Pscyho-Social Behavioral Sciences: Section Social Work, Potchefstroom Campus of the North-West University, Potschefstroom, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61381460?accountid=14667

Abstract: Two of the existing models for development & evaluation of interventions were discussed, namely the Developmental Research & Utilization Model (DR&U) & the Intervention Research Model (IR). After detailed investigation & discussion of these two models, the authors of this article would like to suggest an Adapted Intervention Research Model (AIR) that can perhaps assist in making the task of prospective researchers easier by adding another model that can be utilized. The AIR model exists of seven phases, namely problem delimitation, methodology, analysis, development, evaluation, adaptation & dissemination. Each phase again consists of various steps. Adapted from the source document.

Multicultural Aspects of Supervision: Considerations for South African Supervisors in the Helping Professions

Author: Kagee, Ashraf11 Department of Psychology, Stellenbosch University, Stellenbosch, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61368872?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper examines the literature pertaining to multicultural supervision in the helping professions & applies it to relationships between clinical supervisors & their supervisees in the helping professions in South Africa. An operational definition of this form of clinical exchange is offered & a summary of existing models is presented. Various problems inherent in multicultural supervision are described & tentative recommendations are offered. It is argued that the dynamics of power & hegemony are more salient variables in determining the nature of the multicultural supervisory relationship than the reductionist concepts of race & ethnicity. Finally, implications for future research in the area are identified. Adapted from the source document.

Conservation of Resources: A Primary Intervention for Continuous Traumatics Stress in South Africa: A Case Study

Author: Van der Merwe, Mariette1; Kassan-Newton, K1 Department of Social Work, Stellenbosch University, Stellenbosch, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61377853?accountid=14667

Abstract: Within the context of continuous traumatic stress in South Africa, the Conservation of Resources (COR) theory offers a transdisciplinary approach with which other mainstream approaches can be incorporated. In this article the South African situation is profiled, to contextualize the need for an alternative approach in a society where multiple traumatic occurrences are common. By applying COR to a case study, an intervention framework emerged, which focuses on assessment of variables & resources, loss & gain spirals, & designing COR intervention strategies. This article is exploratory & descriptive, & the framework for intervention that evolved is offered as a basis for further research. Adapted from the source document.

Awakening to the Transpersonal Paradigm: Discerning Transcendent Experiences from Pathology

Author: Bhagwan, Raisuyah11 Department of Child and Youth Care, Durban University of Technology, Durban, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61377614?accountid=14667

Abstract: Until recently social work has ignored the spiritual, transpersonal & transcendental needs of human nature. As interest in spirituality grows, clients' needs to aspire towards psycho-spiritual growth & their experiences of the transpersonal may become more common in the therapeutic context. This article applies Ken Wilber's model of transpersonal development & incorporates concepts of the transpersonal paradigm in order to shed light on transpersonal experiences & trans-egoic development. It presents an overview of transpersonal experiences & highlights the dilemma in discerning healthy spiritual experience from pathology because of the similarities in features. Using two case examples, this paper provides guidelines on how to broaden an understanding of the client's experience & distinguish it from dysfunction. Adapted from the source document.

The Experiences of Adolescents Orphaned by HIV/AIDs-Related Conditions

Author: Louw, Lynette1; Joubert, JMC1 Department of Social Work and Criminology, University of Pretoria, Pretoria, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61347795?accountid=14667

Abstract: Children bear a considerable part of the brunt of the social impact of HIV & AIDS. Children who often watched their parents die alone & in pain are left in a world where AIDS has unraveled the traditional safety nets such as the extended family. In situations of poverty, adult responsibilities within households are often shifted to children. This article provides information on the experiences of adolescents orphaned by HIV/AIDS related conditions. Adapted from the source document.

The Responsiveness of Sexual Offenders to a Therapeutic Group Work Programme at Westville Medium B Prison

Author: Mathe, Sibonsile11 School of Social Work & Community Development, University of KwaZulu-Natal, Howard College, Durban, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61351825?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article reports on a study that evaluated the responsiveness of juvenile sexual offenders to a cognitive-behavioral group work program developed & implemented by the researcher. The study was based on the premise that by working with the perpetrators of sexual crimes, one is protecting hundreds of lives from further harm. The research findings revealed that there was positive improvement in the offenders' self-concepts, attitude towards women, & cognitions. Based on the outcomes of the evaluation, recommendations are made with regard to further adaptation, development & implementation of the program & the need for staff training in this field. Adapted from the source document.

Interpreting Users' Experiences of Service Delivery in the Western Cape Using a Normative Framework

Author: Bozalek, Vivienne1; Lambert, Wesley1 Department of Social Work, University of the Western Cape, Bellville, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61351980?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study reports on service users' experiences of service delivery during a period of socio-economic transformation. Tronto's (1993) political care ethic, Fraser's (1989) juridical-administrative-therapeutic needs interpretation politics and Everitt and Hardiker's (1996) good enough practice model are used as a normative framework to judge service users' experiences in relation to the adequacy of service delivery which they described to be "good" and "not so good". Service users' experiences were drawn from a triangulation of participant observations, qualitative interviews and questionnaires that were administered to them by social work students at a university in the Western Cape during their fieldwork placements in Cape Town. Adapted from the source document.

Social Work: A Social Partner in Economic Development

Author: Lombard, Antoinette11 Department of Social Work and Criminology, University of Pretoria, Pretoria, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61371789?accountid=14667

Abstract: The social and economic nature of poverty calls for an integrated approach to human, social and economic development. Social work impacts both directly and indirectly on economic development. Challenges for social work to contribute towards economic development are embedded in attitude, vision and capacity. The paper concludes that the engagement of social work in economic development should be recognised as a specialised field in social work. This will not only be in line with a developmental social welfare policy shift to a sustainable livelihood approach, but will also firmly position social work as a social partner contributing to the achievement of national social developmental goals. Adapted from the source document.

A New Children's Act for South Africa: Making it Work for Children and Families

Author: September, Roseline11 Faculty of Community Health Sciences, University of the Western Cape, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61347601?accountid=14667

Abstract: The apartheid state's brutality and atrocities perpetrated against black children and youths during the 1970s and 1980s focused both national and international attention on the plight of South Africa's children. Today, the post-apartheid government's extraordinary focus on children's rights can probably be attributed to the sustained social mobilisation and relentless efforts of child rights activists. This paper discusses the role of these activists in developing the new Children's Act, 38 of 2005. It highlights the centrality of the objectives and values inherent in the legislation and discusses issues and obstacles which may impede the implementation of the Act. Adapted from the source document.

Children's Homes and Foster Care: Challenging Dominant Discourses in South African Social Work Practice

Author: Perumal, Nevashnee1; Kasiram, Madhu1 Pitermaritzburg Child and Family Welfare Society

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61373841?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article addresses key concerns surrounding dominant views of foster care being the best alternative care option for vulnerable children in South Africa. Legislation, policies and infrastructure all support this position, yet family life in South Africa is being corroded by, amongst other factors, HIV/AIDS and poverty. The authors cite both ecological and structural theoretical perspectives in furthering this debate. Adapted from the source document.

The Psychological Implications of the Closing of a Mine for Workers and Their Families

Author: Strydom, Herman1; Herbst, Alida1 Social Work Division, School for Psychosocial Behavioural Sciences, North-West University, Potchefstroom Campus, Potchefstroom, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61356881?accountid=14667

Abstract: Although the findings of this study cannot necessarily be generalised to all similar populations, this article indicates the psychosocial implications of the closing down of a mine for the workers and their families. This study can act as a blueprint for studying similar situations that might arise elsewhere in South Africa. The article focuses on the project planning, the data of the psychosocial situation analysis, the social group work sessions, the data from the questionnaires that were completed at the end of the women's day, and the existing strengths in the community. Adapted from the source document.

A Comparison of Subjective Quality-of-Life Indicators Across Domains of Jewish Seniors Living in the Community

Author: Parton, Sue1; Green, Sulina1 Department of Social Work, University of Stellenbosch, Stellenbosch, South AFrica

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61368461?accountid=14667

Abstract: In line with the UN policy of active ageing and projected population ageing trends, the Older Persons Act (2006) sees a marked shift away from residential care for the aged to that of independent community living. Using systems theory as the theoretical framework, this article sets out to compare the quality-of-life indicators across various domains that enable the independent living of Jewish seniors. The aim of this study is thus to provide guidelines for social work intervention with Jewish seniors by gaining a better understanding of the determinants that promote the quality of their lives. Adapted from the source document.

Triangulation in Social Work Research: The Theory and Examples of its Practical Application

Author: Weyers, Mike1; Strydom, Herman; Huisamen, Arnel1 Social Work Division, School for Psychosocial Behavioural Sciences, North-West University, Potchefstroom, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61356718?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social work researchers in South Africa are often faced with the daunting task of having to analyse complex phenomena without an abundant supply of resources and standardised measuring instruments. This has necessitated a rethink of the way in which local research is done and to find a route that would meet both the demands of science and accommodate the constraints of research practice. One such route is the use of triangulation. In this article the nature, advantages and disadvantages of triangulation will be explored. It will also be illustrated with a research project undertaken by Police Social Work Services. Adapted from the source document.

The African Worldview as the Basis of Practice in the Helping Professions

Author: Thabede, Dumisani11 Dept Social Work, U Venda, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61367833?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article discusses the African worldview as the basis of practice in the helping professions, with particular reference to social work practice. The article points out beliefs and practices that a helping professional should take into account when dealing with African clients. The main thrust in this discourse is that African cultural beliefs inform the behavior of African clients, particularly when Africans face psycho-social challenges that life presents to them. Helping professionals should know African cultural beliefs in order to appreciate what informs the behavior of African clients. Adapted from the source document.

Theoretical Concerns in Applying the Diagnosis of PTSD to Persons with HIV and AIDS

Author: Kagee, Ashraf11 Dept Social Work, U Stellenbosch, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61361817?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article advances the argument that a diagnosis with HIV is inappropriately regarded as traumatic and that to a large extent the shift in diagnostic criteria from the DSM-III-R to the DSM-IV has played a role in the expanding definition of what might be regarded as a traumatic event. The notion of conceptual bracket creep is offered to account for the ever-increasing number of events that may qualify as traumatic. The article concludes that persons diagnosed with HIV require help in living with their condition, accessing treatment, and dealing with social stigma instead of being regarded as traumatized. Adapted from the source document.

The Scope of Financial Literacy Education: A Poverty Alleviation Tool in Social Work?

Author: Engelbrecht, Lambert11 Dept Social Work, U Stellenbosch, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61361868?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article aims to develop an understanding of the scope of financial literacy education by addressing the question whether the social work profession could contribute to the financial literacy education of vulnerable people. The contribution of social work to financial literacy education could be substantiated, based on the profession's theoretical foundation. Financial literacy education should be facilitated by social workers as a poverty alleviation tool by linking financially vulnerable people and significant providers of financial education. Adapted from the source document.

The Role of Supervisors in the South African Police Service in the Successful Utilisation of the Employee Assistance Programme

Author: de Winnaar, Edith1; Taute, Florinda1 Dept Social Work & Criminology, U Pretoria, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61361406?accountid=14667

Abstract: It is evident in practice that supervisors in the SAPS are often unable to identify troubled employees early enough and subsequently to refer them to the Employee Assistance Programme (EAP). It also happens that the supervisor wants to fulfill the role of a social worker in assessing the troubled employee and address his/her problems. When members are eventually referred to the EAP, their problems are already in an advanced state, which complicates the management of the problem and in turn leads to long-term intervention. This article focuses on an investigation into, and a description of, the role, knowledge and attitudes of supervisors in the SAPS, with regard to utilization of the EAP. Adapted from the source document.

The Reality of Practice: Demands and Challenges of Practice for Beginning Social Workers

Author: Herbst, Adri1; Strydom, Herman1 Noordwes-U Potchefstroomkampus, Suid-Afrika

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61400897?accountid=14667

Abstract: The transition from student to full-time employee is a transformation process, involving various challenges for young professionals like social workers. This article explores the fears, expectations, challenges and dreams of 16 young social workers shortly before, and six months after entering practice. A quantitative-qualitative combined questionnaire was completed by final year social work students of the North-West University, Potchefstroom Campus. Issues related to practice entry, the gap between training and practice, orientation of new staff and challenges of the South African welfare context were explored. Their recommendations should be considered by training institutions and welfare organizations. Adapted from the source document.

The Rejection of Adults and the Demands that the So-Called Desirability of Prosecution Reports Have to Meet

Author: Vergottini, Elizabeth1; Weyers, Mike1 Dept Maatskaplike Ontwikkeling, Noordwes-U, Potchefstroomkampus, Suid-Afrika

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61400933?accountid=14667

Abstract: Due to South Africa's high crime rate and the overcrowding of correctional facilities, the utilization of so-called desirability of prosecution reports in the diversion of youths has become general practice. A new trend, however, is an increase in the requests for similar reports for adults. A study found that, although some magistrates and control prosecutors did not know that diversion could be used for adults, nearly all viewed it as a very promising new mechanism. The research also produced guidelines for the selection of appropriate offenders and for the issues that should be covered in the probation officers report. Adapted from the source document.

The Role of Social Work in Kinship Foster Care

Author: Delport, Janine1; Roux, Adri; Rankin, Pedro1 Skool Psigo-Sosiale Gedragswetenskappe, Noordwes-U, Potchefstroomkampus, Suid-Afrika

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61393015?accountid=14667

Abstract: The aim of this article is to determine the nature and extent of kinship foster care in the North-West Province. The task of the social worker in respect to the kinship foster career is studied. A self-structured questionnaire was used for data collecting purposes. Fifty questionnaires were sent to social workers in the North-West province, working with kinship foster careers. The results (N = 24) show the state of existing programs and the opinions of social workers on topics that could be discussed during a social group work program to train kinship foster careers. Recommendations are provided. Adapted from the source document.

Globalisation, Western Hegemony and Chinese Particularism: Implications for Social Work and Social Policy

Author: Sewpaul, Vishanthie11 School Social Work & Community Development, U KwaZulu-Natal, Howard Coll Campus, Durban, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61356656?accountid=14667

Abstract: In this article I deal with China's increasing integration into the world order and I contest the stereotypical dichotomy between the East and the West. The challenges that China's phenomenological developments and contradictions -- in the economic, socio-political and cultural spheres -- pose for social workers are specifically addressed. I call for social workers to represent "voice" in China as they advocate broader public interests and people's development in the face of growing inequality consequent upon China's neoliberal capitalist practices. Adapted from the source document.

Outcome of Adoptions: Have Couples Realised Their Dream?

Author: van Delft, Wilfred1; van Delft, Trudie1 Dept Social Work, U South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61361598?accountid=14667

Abstract: By using a questionnaire and a qualitative research approach, 35 couples who adopted a baby over the period 1989 to 2003 were asked to comment on questions relating to issues such as experience of motherliness, fatherliness, acceptance by the extended family and wider community, and general psychosocial functioning of their children. The results indicate that the majority of parents have realized their dream of having a child and forming part of a well-functioning family. A matter of concern is the high prevalence of attention deficit disorder and reading problems among adopted children. Although the children receive therapy, this issue requires in-depth investigation. Adapted from the source document.

Challenges That the Referral System Poses to Care Giving As Exemplified by the Kanye Community Home-Based Care (CHBC) Programme in Botswana

Author: Kang'ethe, Simon11 BONEPWA, Botswana

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61358576?accountid=14667

Abstract: The research was qualitative and exploratory, and included all the 140 registered primary caregivers and five CHBC nurses. Two slightly different interview guides were used as research instruments for caregivers and nurses. Findings indicate that the poor state of the Seventh Day Adventist (SDA) referral hospital, lack of referral information flow among service providers, the skeletal nature of some service providers, inadequate care package facilities in the clinics, inadequate human resources in health facilities and lack of transport facilities adversely affect caregivers' referral capacity and process. Government and care organisations have been urged to work towards improving the referral system. Adapted from the source document.

Conceptual Research on the Term Facilitation: Reducing an Elephant to Chewable Chunks

Author: Schenck, Rinie1; Louw, Huma1 Dept Social Work, U South Africa, Pretoria

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61387008?accountid=14667

Abstract: The aim of the article was to explore the meanings of the concept of facilitation, identify the key facilitating actions/behaviours of the facilitator, the potential/purpose of these actions and to provide a theoretical foundation for explaining and understanding facilitation. A conceptual research process was followed as described by Friedl, De Vos and Fouche (2002). Conceptual research is not research by concepts but on concepts to be able to explore the meanings, theory and actions of the concept. The results indicated that principles of people-centred thinking underpins facilitation and requires of the facilitator to act as co-learner on the persons/people's journey to change/transformation. Adapted from the source document.

The Social Work Research Module(s) from a Social Welfare Perspective

Author: Strydom, Herman11 School Psycho-Social Behavioural Sciences: Section Social Work, North-West U, Potchefstroom, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61381810?accountid=14667

Abstract: Nesearch has always been neglected in social work service delivery and in the training of social workers, whether in case work, group work or community work. Although most social workers agree on the importance of research for everyday functioning in practice and for the standing of the profession amongst other professions, there is still no agreement on what should be included or excluded in the research module(s). The aim of this study is to ascertain the reasons for the hesitation among students and lecturers to study or present the research module(s), the content of these modules and whether students should execute individual or group projects. Adapted from the source document.

Reflections of a Trauma Counsellor: Theory Meets Practice

Author: Williams, Fatima11 Dept Social Development, U Cape Town, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61354090?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper is a reflection of a crisis counselling session where the counsellor experienced post-traumatic symptoms during the session. The writer describes her experience and attempts to explain it through theory on counter-transference and the Intersubjective Approach to therapy. The paper also refers to the debate about the value of debriefing and further discusses the common symptoms of exposure to trauma. By raising vicarious trauma as a concept, the writer attempts to ask questions around the effects on counsellors of working with traumatised clients. Adapted from the source document.

Toward Meaningful Civic Engagement: A Case Study of Civil Society Participation in Legislative Reform

Author: Allan, Karen1; Forrester, Chris; Patel, Leila1 c/o Forrester -- Centre Social Development Africa, U Johannesburg

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61358216?accountid=14667

Abstract: A participatory approach to policy and legislative reform is being implemented in contemporary South Africa. Views about its success are diverse and point to the complexity of making participatory models work in practice. This article is based on a case study of civil society participation in the development of the Children's Bill. It critically appraises the nature and scope of civil society participation in the various stages of the development of the legislation. Recommendations are made to promote meaningful participation in future legislative processes that could contribute to local and international best practice on civic engagement. Adapted from the source document.

Pursuing a Social Development Agenda in the Context of Globalisation: A South African Perspective

Author: Triegaardt, Jean11 Dept Social Work, U Johannesburg, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61769519?accountid=14667

Abstract: After 1994 South Africa experienced changes as a consequence of the force of globalisation, and national socio-economic policies. Constitutional imperatives called for a just and equitable society. The democratically elected government inherited a fragile economy with large debt, slow economic growth, increasing unemployment rates and unacceptable levels of poverty. Socio-economic policies have been targeted towards achieving macro-economic stability, increasing access to education, health and social security. The purpose of this paper is to analyse policies with respect to social development initiatives, the gains that have been achieved and the challenges that remain for poverty-stricken South Africans within a globalised environment. Adapted from the source document.

"Deserving" Children, "Undeserving" Mothers? Multiple Perspectives on the Child Support Grant

Author: Holscher, Dorothee1; Kasiram, Madhu; Sathiparsad, Reshma1 School Social Work & Community Development, U KwaZulu-Natal, Howard Coll Campus, Durban, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61357993?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study explores public perceptions of the Child Support Grant (CSG). An exploratory-descriptive study was conducted with a sample of 140 social workers, social work students and social service volunteers, using qualitative and quantitative research methodologies. The study found gaps in participants' knowledge around poverty, gender inequality in South Africa and the CSG itself Residual notions of welfare dominated, as did prejudices against poor, unmarried and sexually active young women. These views were balanced with some recognition of the CSG's potential as a social development strategy. Further research and revisiting the content and thrust of curricula in welfare is recommended. Adapted from the source document.

Parents' Experiences regarding the Coming-Out Process of a Gay or Lesbian Child

Author: Alpaslan, Assim1; Johnston, Theresa; Goliath, Veonna1 Dept Social Work, U South Africa, Pretoria

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61384072?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article discusses parents' experiences regarding the coming-out process of a gay or lesbian child as revealed through a research project undertaken within a qualitative paradigm. From the semi-structured interviews conducted with a sample of parents of gay/lesbian children, data were gathered on their experiences, feelings and emotional reactions relating to the coming out of their gay/lesbian child. Factors that helped and complicated the process for parents to accept their child's homosexuality were identified and the participants gave advice to other parents on coping with a child's coming out. Recommendations, focusing specifically on further and future research, are provided. Adapted from the source document.

Using Adventure to Increase the Emotional Intelligence of the Poor

Author: Reyneke, Roelf11 Dept Social Work, U Free State, Bloemfontein, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61383598?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article redefines poverty and demonstrates the way in which adventure programmes can be used to empower the poor so that they can become well-adjusted and well-motivated citizens. The techniques that are discussed focus on the development of emotional intelligence (EQ) and employ the experiential learning theory in the form of cooperative games, problem solving, communication and trust activities. The literature study shows that adventure-based work can be helpful in the fight against poverty as it provides a method for training, empowering and motivating people. These techniques may be used in order to develop EQ, which could lead to the overall empowerment of individuals, groups and communities. Adapted from the source document.

Translated title not available

Author: Daniels, Doria1; Nel, Elizette1 Dept Opvoedkundige Sielkunde, U Stellenbosch, Suid-Afrika

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61336142?accountid=14667

Abstract: Motherhood is a complex & unique experience. The practice of motherhood can be further complicated when the mother is young, unmarried, poor & with limited formal education. This article reports on an exploratory study that was undertaken with six teenage mothers from a low socio-economic township in the Western Cape on their needs for support. We argued that the perspectives of teenage mothers on the support structures that they need are necessary for any meaningful support programmes to be implemented in such communities. Their narratives sketch a life that is typified by a continuous fight by the teenage mother to navigate her community effectively, & to survive. Adapted from the source document.

Relapsing after Treatment: Exploring the Experiences of Chemically Addicted Adolescents

Author: van der Westhuizen, Marichen1; de jager, Marianna1 Huguenot Coll, Wellington, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61375055?accountid=14667

Abstract: The increase in treatment demands and the high relapse rate for adolescent chemical addiction were the motivation for this research, conducted for a master's degree at the University of South Africa. A qualitative study formed the foundation for a better understanding of the relapse experiences of chemically addicted adolescents. The findings indicate that chemically addicted adolescents are able to describe the precipitating factors to relapses, as well as their aftercare needs. The conclusion was that the social work profession should adapt to the special needs of chemically addicted adolescents, in order to prevent relapses. Adapted from the source document.

Outcomes-Based Assessment: Necessary Evil or Transformative Potential?

Author: Bozalek, Vivienne11 U Western Cape, Bellville, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61352549?accountid=14667

Abstract: In this article I reflect on the development of a module with a dual purpose: that of incorporating the exit-level outcomes and their associated assessment criteria of the BSW degree and of engaging in an assessment of one learner, in order to become a registered assessor with SAQA. I outline the integration of the specific outcomes and associated assessment criteria into the curriculum. I discuss how I planned, prepared, conducted, evaluated, provided feedback and reviewed the assessment. Finally, I consider the strengths and weaknesses of outcomes-based assessment both from the perspective of the implications for the curriculum and for assessment of students. Adapted from the source document.

Experiences of Students, Service Delivery Organisations and Community Members of Service Delivery to a Disadvantaged Community by Social Work Students

Author: Strydom, Corinne1; Greeff, Minrie; Wessels, Cornelia; van der Walt, Engela; Schutte, Paul J1 Department of Social Work, Potchefstroom Campus of the North-West University, Potchefstroom, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61338441?accountid=14667

Abstract: As part of the practical training in Social Work, fourth-year students render services to a disadvantaged community at a service delivery organisation. Valuable services are offered to the community, but there is no feedback system to evaluate the quality of these services. The objectives of this research were to explore this placement as experienced by the students themselves, the organisations linked to this service delivery, and the community members to whom they delivered services, and then to make recommendations. An exploratory descriptive qualitative research design was used, utilising focus groups with the students and organisations, and individuals. Adapted from the source document.

Faith-Based Organisations in the Context of Social Welfare and Development in South Africa: Towards a Conceptualisation

Author: van der Merwe, Willie1; Swart, Ignatius; Hendriks, Jurgens1 Service and Witness, General Synod, Dutch Reformed Church, Hatfield, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61356357?accountid=14667

Abstract: In South Africa much is expected of faith-based organisations (FBOs) in the struggle against poverty and HIV and AIDS. However, no clear policies are in place to ensure that FBOs can commit themselves to social welfare and development programmes without compromising their identity as faith-based organisations. A typology of religious characteristics that was developed by Sider and Unruh is used to explore different ways to conceptualise FBOs in the South African context. This typology defines FBOs in terms of their connection to a faith community, and the realisation of this connection in their operational structures and the religious content of their programmes. Adapted from the source document.

An Evaluation of a Community Leadership Training Programme in Soweto

Author: Nel, Hanna11 Department of Social Work, University of Johannesburg, Johannesburg, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61338387?accountid=14667

Abstract: The article describes a partnership initiative between the Department of Social Work of the University of Johannesburg and a non-governmental organisation, the African Self-Help Association (ASHA), situated in Soweto. The purpose of the partnership was to help ASHA transform its preschool centres into 40 one-stop community centres through a community leadership training programme, within the context of the developmental welfare policy of South Africa. The results of the training programme showed that, amongst other aspects, the programme contributed to a participatory management style, personal and professional skills, and the establishment of projects in the community. Adapted from the source document.

Indebtedness of Financially Vulnerable Households: What Do Social Workers Do?

Author: Engelbrecht, Lambert11 Department of Social Work, Stellenbosch University, Stellenbosch, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61390322?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article reports on research grappling with the question on what social workers, working within a social development paradigm, do to assist households who are caught in a debt trap. A combined qualitative and quantitative exploratory study was conducted with 74 registered social workers rendering services to 10 951 households and representing an NGO delivering developmental social work services in South Africa. The key finding with corresponding recommendations to social workers is that intervention focusing specifically on the indebtedness of financially vulnerable households is much needed, but sorely neglected, in developmental social work services. Adapted from the source document.

Perspectives of Parents on the Implementation of the National Life-Skills and HIV/AIDS Education Programme in Secondary Schools in Ethekwini, Kwazulu-Natal

Author: Raniga, Tanusha11 School of Social Work and Community Development, University of KwaZulu-Natal, Durban, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61364287?accountid=14667

Abstract: Increasing attention is being paid to the role of parents as sexuality educators in the light of growing HIV infection rates among school-going youth. This paper presents empirical evidence from one phase of a larger study which used qualitative methodology to evaluate the National Life-Skills and HIV/AIDS education programme implemented in three selected schools in the eThekwini region, KwaZulu-Natal. This paper deliberates on the perspectives of parents on the integration of sexuality programmes in schools. Recommendations are made for schools to be established as "one-stop care centres" and the inclusion of social workers in schools. Adapted from the source document.

A Place in Society? Strengthening Livelihood Opportunities for Street Children -- A Rights-Based Approach

Author: Trent, John1; von Kotze, Astrid1 School of Social Work & Community Development, University of KwaZulu-Natal, Durban, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61369510?accountid=14667

Abstract: Street children within the eThekwini (Durban) municipality are largely regarded as a nuisance and the dominant response to their emergence is attempts to remove them. In most cases the children have no say in the planning of their futures. This article is based on a rights-based approach that involved two groups of street children in generating information about their daily livelihood activities and the risks they confront in securing a livelihood. Based on the findings, the article makes strategic and practical recommendations to improve street-based interventions, and suggests a set of tools and indicators for measuring the success of a more rights-based approach to working with street children. Adapted from the source document.

Author: Perumal, Nevashnee1; Kasiram, Madhu1 Pietermaritzburg Child and Family Welfare Society, Pietermaritzburg, KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61384062?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper reports on an exploratory study to hear the voices of children and their caregivers in respect of foster care and living in a children's home so that practice may be accordingly guided. Framing the results using ecological and structural theoretical perspectives, structural deficiencies in South African child care practice are exposed whilst highlighting the goodness of fit that needs to exist across concentric spheres of interrelationship in child and family life, a challenging and oft times daunting undertaking in child placement. An Examination of the Importance of Pre-Abortion Counselling

Author: Strydom, Herman1; Humpel, Susan1 School of Psycho-Social Behavioural Sciences, Potchefstroom Campus, North-West University, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61358703?accountid=14667

Abstract: An unwanted pregnancy poses a life crisis for a woman who does not see her way clear to accepting pregnancy, birth or raising a child. Crisis intervention is regarded as the obvious model for pre-abortion counselling. The nature and essence of pre-abortion counselling, the purpose and value of pre-abortion counselling, the after-effects and the meaningfulness of pre-abortion counselling were studied. Pre-abortion counselling can succeed in making the pregnant woman aware of alternatives and enables her to make an informed and responsible decision regarding the termination of her pregnancy. Adapted from the source document.

"From RDP to Gear to Post-Polokwane". The ANC and the Provision of Social Security for Post-Apartheid South Africa

Author: Visser, Wessel11 Dept History, U Stellenbosch, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61361444?accountid=14667

Abstract: Prior to South Africa's first democratic election in 1994 the ANC adopted the Reconstruction and Development Programme (RDP) -- a programme that contained elements of social security. However, the RDP soon ran into trouble. From the beginning the government lacked the capacity to implement it. Therefore the government embraced a neo-liberal conservative macro-economic strategy -- Growth, Employment and Redistribution, or GEAR. Tensions between the Mbeki faction and COSATU supporters within the ANC, inter alia over GEAR policies, culminated at the party's national convention in Polokwane in December 2007 when President Mbeki was ousted as ANC president. Under the new presidency of Jacob Zuma South Africa is probably bound to see a revised, strongly labor-biased and developing state welfare and social security policy. Adapted from the source document.

The Spending Patterns of the Old-Age Pension by the Frail Elderly

Author: Strydom, Herman1; Strydom, Corienne1 School Psycho-Social Behavioral Sciences, Division Social Work, North-West U, Potchefstroom, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61396683?accountid=14667

Abstract: The article is about a specific old-age home that delivers certain community outreach services besides the services to the residents of the old-age home. Staff members and researchers realised that the elderly in their care had very little to spend on themselves despite receiving pensions and that a large percentage of participants could not account for their monthly expenditure. Financial problems were evident as there was no food in the home, the home smelled of urine and filth, dirty laundry and bed linen were evident, and windows were without curtains. Adapted from the source document.

Women's Experience of Lack of Sexual Desire in Relationships, and Implications for Intervention

Author: Durr, Elzabe11 Dept Social Work, U Stellenbosch, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61343444?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article reports the results of a study that aimed to explore women's lived experience of low sexual desire in marriage or partnership. The findings indicate that a decline in desire is a normal occurrence in lengthy relationships, even when those are loving and emotionally satisfying, but that many women remain sexually desirous of men other than their partners. Nearly all women, for a multitude of reasons, continue to accommodate their partners' sexual needs, even when having no desire themselves, resulting in differing levels of discomfort. Several suggestions for the clinician are made for the management of this situation. Adapted from the source document.

Women's Experiences of Reporting Rape to the Police: A Qualitative Study

Author: du Plessis, Nina1; Kagee, Ashraf; Maw, Anastasia1 Dept Psychology, Stellenbosch U, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61393054?accountid=14667

Abstract: Many survivors of rape experience secondary traumatization when they report their experience to the police. By means of qualitative interviews the authors explored the experiences of 16 women of reporting rape to the police in the Western Cape. Most participants reported being dissatisfied with the manner in which they were treated or the way in which their cases were handled by the South African Police Service (SAPS). These findings are similar to those of a similar study conducted over 10 years ago, which suggests that despite government efforts to improve services provided to rape survivors, very little appears to have changed. Adapted from the source document.

Bridging the Great Divide: Modifying Traumatic Memories

Author: van der Merwe, Mariette11 Dept Social Work, U Stellenbosch, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61396729?accountid=14667

Abstract: Traumatic memories are typically fragmented and accessing such memories can be complicated due to the oscillation between frightening re-experience and repression of traumatic material. In this process the mind engages traumatic memory, anxiety is generated and the mind disengages the traumatic memory. Traumatized victims as well as professionals who intervene should have a good understanding of the process of memory shifting where implicit memories are accessed to form a verbal narrative. In this article the focus is on memory work from a constructive narrative perspective to bridge the divide between situationally accessible and verbally accessible memories in traumatized persons. Adapted from the source document.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61367868?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article is a summary of three different research projects conducted with the 4th-level Social Work students at Unisa to determine the socio-economic realities and traumatic experiences that may impact on the throughput rate of the students. Recognition of Prior Learning (RPL) and Support: Are the Learning Needs of RPL First-Year Students Different?

Author: Dykes, Glynnis Zena11 Dept Social Work, U Western Cape, Bellville, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61366342?accountid=14667

Abstract: The SA White Paper on Education and Training (1995) denotes learner support as both a principle of open learning and part of the quality assurance assessment. This article seeks to explore the experiences and learning needs of Social Work students in both access groups: RPL and traditional access students. The outcome determines whether any fundamental differences exist and whether these indicate an imperative on the part of the academic institution to provide particular learning support. Themes emerged related to their learning needs and expectations as well as the kinds of support that would assist in making their first year a success. Adapted from the source document.

Forensic Social Work Is a New Field in South Africa. There Is a Growing Need to Utilize Experts in Courts, but Social Workers Are Not Trained to Provide in this Need

Author: Strydom, Corinne11 Noordwes-U, Potchefstroom, Suid-Afrika

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61392065?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study investigated the availability of forensic training for social workers at seventeen universities in order to develop guidelines for forensic training programs. The universities agreed that statutory social work forms part of the duty of social workers but that the existing training does not prepare them for effective services to the courts. The universities regard forensic social work as a specialized field, which requires, post-graduate training. Adapted from the source document.

Employee Assistance Programmes: Their Rationale, Basic Principles and Essential Elements

Author: Mogorosi, Lobelo11 Dept Social Work, U Venda, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61350228?accountid=14667

Abstract: Occupational social work (sometimes referred to as social work at the workplace) is a specialization area within the profession, which uses the Employee Assistance Programme (EAP) as a model of practice. EAPs are work-based support services aimed at helping employees deal with personal or work problems, impacting on their work performance. Some programs are externally contracted by either the employers, unions or both. The paper focuses on three aspects of EAPs: commonly given reasons why such programs are established; programs' basic principles and their 12 essential elements. The paper ends with an example of program development. Adapted from the source document.

Evaluation of Employee Assistance Programmes: Theoretical Guidelines for Practice

Author: Sithole, Selo1; Khorombi, Nndivhuwo1 Dept Social Work, U Limpopo, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61360994?accountid=14667

Abstract: Evaluation is the sine qua non of best practice in Employee Assistance Programmes (EAPs). There are different models of employee assistance program evaluation. Each model specifies the kind of data, answers and criteria that the evaluator wants. Evaluation should not be a haphazard exercise conducted because it is imperative. Consideration must be given to the goals and objectives to be met. It is important for the person undertaking an evaluation to know the menu to choose from, as each model has a specific focus and protocols. Adapted from the source document.

Combating Conflict in the Workplace: The Content and Effect of a Conflict Management and Assertiveness Training Programme

Author: Williams, Marili1; Weyers, Mike1 SAPS, Pretoria

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61354695?accountid=14667

Abstract: The high incidence rates of interpersonal conflict, bullying, gender and race based harassment and verbal abuse in the South African workplace requires a social work response. This article looks at how one employer, the South African Police Service, addressed this issue through the development and successful presentation of a conflict management and assertiveness training program to its employees. The lessons they learned could be used by social workers in other occupational settings and generic practice to develop equally effective interventions. Adapted from the source document.

Factors that Hinder the Utilisation of the Employee Assistance Programme in the Department of Labour

Author: Taute, Florinda1; Manzini, Kelly1 Dept Social Work & Criminology, U Pretoria, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61354787?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study was aimed at investigating factors that hinder utilization of the Employee Assistance Program in the Department of Labor, South Africa. The study took into account the fact that the efforts to train supervisors in order to increase EAP awareness amongst employees and improve program accessibility through an outsourced and decentralized service have proved ineffective. Findings indicate that there are various factors discouraging employees from consulting the EAP. This study enabled the researchers to make recommendations to the Department of Labour on specific factors that need to be addressed to ensure optimal and effective utilization of the EAP. Adapted from the source document.

A Critical Analysis of the Prevalence and nature of Employee Assistance Programmes in the Eastern Cape Buffalo City Municipal Area

Author: Govender, Thiloshni; Terblanche, Lourie

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61367791?accountid=14667

Abstract: EAPs have existed in South Africa for a number of decades and have been steadily evolving. This study attempted to provide a critical analysis of EAPs in the Buffalo City Municipal Area to establish prevalence, examine the nature of EAPs and to benchmark against standards developed by the Employee Assistance Professionals Association of South Africa (EAP A -SA). The purpose of this article is to obtain reliable data on EAPs in order to enable to benchmark other existing and newly implemented employee assistance programs against such existing data base in order to enhance the quality of employee assistance programs in practice. Adapted from the source document.

The Influence of Family Dynamics on the Productivity of Working Mothers in a Motor Company in South Africa

Author: Rickert, Liesl1; Taute, Florinda1 Dept Social Work & Criminology, U Pretoria, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61368822?accountid=14667

Abstract: Even though roles within the family and workplace are in a constant state of change, it is still expected of women to be primarily responsible for family matters. It is often an exhausting challenge to nurture both a family and career. This article focuses on the perceptions, experience and meaning that the working mother has on the influence of her family dynamics on productivity in a motor company in South Africa. The systems in which the working mother is involved in will also be discussed. A number of recommendations are made to employers to enhance the productivity levels of working mothers. Adapted from the source document.

An Impact and Cost-Benefit Analysis of an Employee Assistance Programme at a South African Bank

Author: Orren, Cammy1; Terblanche, Lourie1 Dept Social Work & Criminology, U Pretoria

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61354653?accountid=14667

Abstract: South African Employee Assistance Program (EAP) practitioners often lack evidence on the impact and cost benefit of EAPs. Research was undertaken through means of an impact and cost-benefit study in a South African banking institution. The aim of the study was to evaluate the impact of Employee Assistance Program (EAP) intervention on several work performance indicators of formally referred employees and to determine the cost benefit of these. The main findings were that the EAP had a positive impact on the work performance of formally referred EAP clients, and that there was a cost benefit for the organization. Adapted from the source document.

Teaching Employees Money Management Skills and Showing a Profit in the Process: Lessons from a Financial Literacy Course

Author: Huisamen, Arnel1; Weyers, Mike1 SAPS

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61376515?accountid=14667

Abstract: The purpose of this article is to describe the lessons that both occupational social workers and those in other settings could learn from the development, utilization and verification of a financial literacy course. This course, entitled "Be Money Wise", was developed by Police Social Work Services and implemented as part of the basic training of student constables. In-depth research showed that it had a significant effect on recipients and produced a high return on the employer's investment. The course and its results could be used as a basis to extend this type of service to other social work fields. Adapted from the source document.

The Need for Bereavement Support Programmes in the Workplace

Author: Naidoo, Vanagree1; Delport, Rina1 Dept Social Work & Criminology, U Pretoria, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61336948?accountid=14667

Abstract: Death in the workplace can be a difficult challenge to deal with on both a personal and a professional level. The aim of this article is therefore to provide a brief theoretical background on employee bereavement, its impact in the workplace and bereavement support within the workplace, and to report on the results of an empirical study on the need for a bereavement support program at a healthcare institution. The findings indicated a need for a bereavement support program in the workplace with recommendations regarding the implementation of such a program. Adapted from the source document.

A Profile of an "Ideal" HIV and AIDS Workplace Programme: Theory and Practice

Author: Naude, Annemarie1; Weyers, Mike1 Social Work Division, School Psychosocial Behavioral Sciences, North-West U, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61383783?accountid=14667

Abstract: The HIV and AIDS epidemic has had a significant effect on South Africa's workforce. In response most major employers as well as government departments have developed some or other type of HIV and AIDS workplace program. Recently a need arose for a set of criteria against which these programs could be benchmarked. This led to the development of the profile of an "ideal" HIV/AIDS workplace program as outlined in this article. The profile is based on an analysis of "success" literature on the subject, as well as the results of in-depth interviews with 33 key role-players in this field. Adapted from the source document.

Substance Abuse at the Workplace: The Problem and Possible Solutions

Author: Mogorosi, Lobelo11 Dept Social Work, U Venda, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61353373?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper discusses substance abuse as an example of an employee problem that can be addressed through an employee assistance program (EAP). The effects of substance abuse among employees are enormous, namely, employee absenteeism, possible poor employee relations and job loss, risk of injuries, and damage to organizational property. Workplace environmental "enabling" factors and indicators of employees' deteriorating work performance because of substance abuse problems are also discussed. Solutions are examined, ranging from policy, improved communication, information sharing and the development of appropriate programs. Towards the end the paper also deals briefly with the historical role of EAPs in dealing with this problem. Adapted from the source document.

The Impact of Stress on the Quality of Work Use at Tertiary Institutions

Author: Buys, Rina1; Terblanche, Lourie1 Dept Maatskaplike Werk & Kriminologie, U Pretoria, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61350132?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article intends to determine the presence of stressors, which lead to high stress levels and subsequently contributing to the employees' perspective of quality of work life (QWL) at a tertiary institution. Quality of work life refers to the extent in which employees are empowered to satisfy their own needs through their experiences in the work place in order to enhance productivity within organizations. Employers have the responsibility to establish a healthy workplace by placing a curb on stress and its resulting negative effects and to enable employees to accept ownership of their own lives in reaching optimum health and well-being. Adapted from the source document.

The Effectiveness of Stress Management Programmes at Tertiary Institutions

Author: Buys, Rina1; Terblanche, Lourie1 Dept Maatskaplike Werk & Kriminologie, U Pretoria, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61360836?accountid=14667

Abstract: This is the second article resulting from a doctoral study on the phenomenon of stress. In the first article, the focus was specifically on stress amongst employees at a tertiary training institution. In this second article the researchers reflect on the effectiveness of the current Stress Management Program (SMP) at this tertiary institution and illustrate that participation in this specific program contributes to a more positive experience of quality of work life amongst employees. Adapted from the source document.

The Coping Strategies Employed by UNISA'S Undergraduate Students to Address the Realities Experienced with Respect to Their Living Conditions in Sunnyside, Tshwane

Author: Alpaslan, Assim Hashim11 Dept Social Work, U South Africa, Pretoria, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/753992045?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper examines the coping strategies used by a sample of Unisa's undergraduate students who reside in Sunnyside, Tshwane, South Africa, with respect to their living conditions. The findings, derived from a qualitative research project based on semi-structured interviews of 24 participants conducted by six 4th level student social workers who conducted the fieldwork. Data analysis revealed that students rely on a repertoire of coping strategies to address the realities & challenges they face as a result of their living conditions in Sunnyside, where key results showed that overcrowding, noise, safety, expense & instability through constant relocation where key contributors. The participants also felt they were exploited by their landlords & letting agencies. Furthermore, the students were confronted daily by social realities such as xenophobia, crime & violence, substance misuse, prostitution, street children & begging. The participants did acknowledge some positive aspects of their location, such as their proximity to amenities, availability of public transport, & the fact that Sunnyside gave them a sense of connectedness. Recommendations, focusing specifically on the need for more research work, are put forward. Adapted from the source document.

Academic Support for First-Year Social Work Students in South Africa

Author: Collins, Kathleen1; Van Breda, Adrian1 Dept Social Work, U Western Cape

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/753992059?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social work students in their first year face the great challenge of transition from school to university, where independent & self-directed learning is called for. Students must face physical adaptations, such as moving away from home, & psychological ones such as entering adulthood. This article sets out the context for first-year social work students in South Africa, explaining particular needs of the typical student & the facilities available for support. The expectation of "deep learning" required of university student raises many questions & a proposal for a research project is suggested on teaching & learning in social work, to be carried out collaboratively by South African universities. A literature survey, with extrapolation & application of relevant principles to serve as foundation for the project, is presented. In conclusion, the authors describe three key areas for first year social work students. First, academic competencies students should acquire the skill to undertake tertiary level studies. Second, professional competency educators should remain resolute in maintaining focus on real world learning. & finally, assessment assessment of students should not target just knowledge, but the application of knowledge in a practical sense. Adapted from the source document.

Social Work Responsibility towards Stress Management

Author: Reynolds, Coen11 Dept Social Work, Hugenote Coll, Wellington, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/753991974?accountid=14667

Abstract: In this article, the author suggests that social work managers (any person who has control over two or more individuals) should create & maintain a work environment that will be conducive to maintaining the health & well-being of workers who contribute to the effective delivery of services. It is suggested that social work managers can use their managerial functions of planning, organising, leading & controlling as primary intervention strategies in such a way as they promote the health & well-being of employees. The article argues that managers in social work can benefit via their strategic planning processes, the principles of person-environment fitness, collaborative management, & an awareness of their own cognitive processes & blind spots in addressing organisational stress & eliminating potential organisational stressors. In conclusion, the authors describe how organisational stressors play a major role in the life of workers, & it is imperative that these stressors should be addressed by social work managers. It is recommended that stress intervention should start at the primary intervention level from the top down. The value of a stress audit & a proposal for a Management Assistant Programme are presented. Adapted from the source document.

A Developmental Approach to Dealing with Young Offenders: An Imperative for Probation Practice and Policy Framework

Author: Gxubane, Thulane11 Dept Social Development, U Cape Town, Rondebosch, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/753992395?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article briefly explores the historic background to the reform of child justice in South Africa before discussing the developmental approach to working with young offenders, where the author argues for a developmental approach to managing child offenders, which will not only maximise the opportunities for meaningful interventions that could translate into prevention of crime & recidivism among these young offenders, but will also offer long-term benefits for the offenders, their victims, & the country in general. The author highlights the importance of the equally important roles of the probation officers, such as research, advocacy & policy development. The author suggests that employers of probation officers need to embark on a strategic drive to provide resources & incentives. The article goes on to examine the concept of restorative justice as a proposed philosophical & developmental approach to working with serious offences, challenging the general misconception that restorative justice is inappropriate in dealing with serious crime. The author concludes by outlining some guidelines that can help probation officers in giving effective restorative justice. Adapted from the source document.

Circumstances of Foster Children and Their Foster Parents Affected by HIV and AIDS

Author: Roux, Adri1; Bungane, Xoliswa; Strydom, Corinne1 Dept Social Services, Bloemfontein

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/753992044?accountid=14667

Abstract: HIV & AIDS have a major impact on foster care, with both foster children & foster parents having specific needs. This study examines the circumstances of these children & their parents, & the social work services offered to them, in the Motheo District in the Free State province in South Africa. The study identified 21 children between the ages of 14 & 17 years, along with their parents, to participate in this research. A simple self administered survey was used to collect data from both the children & their parents. Eighty five percent of household received a foster grant, but only 8% received a salary. Fifty two percent of children did not know why they were in foster care, with the remaining due to family deaths. Asked whether anyone in the family was affected by HIV/AIDS, 33% of the foster children said yes, 57% said no, with the remaining uncertain. The authors conclude that foster parents affected by HIV/AIDS needed help with different aspects such as communicating with the child about the disease, handling conflict & administering discipline. Previous studies have shown that families affected by HIV/AIDS have little access to social workers, but that the role of these workers is essential to the families. The author summarises by saying that with the rate at which families affected by HIV/AIDS is growing makes it difficult for social workers to manage their workloads. Adapted from the source document.

Your Child Is My Child: Community Education in Sexual Abuse for a High Risk Area

Author: Grobler, Herman1; Van den Heever, Claudi1 Dept Play Therapy, Huguenot Coll, Wellington

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/753992267?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article focuses on community education & the need for keeping pre-school children safe from sexual abuse in Danville, Pretoria a known high risk area. The authors challenge the role of the community & the priority it gives to the sexual education of young children. A survey was undertaken of 38 parents, 1 psychologist, 9 teachers, 2 community members, 4 social workers, 2 school principals, 5 speech therapists, 2 occupational therapists & 2 theologians. Results showed that while most parents were aware of sexual abuse, 43% could not give a written description of what it entailed. Among the parents, 82% thought a perpetrator could be anyone in the community, while most of the professional respondents thought the perpetrator would be a trusted family member or friend. According to 49% of respondents child sex abuse occurs frequently, & 15% were aware of a pre-school child who was being sexually abused. The study showed that the main expense of a family was food & house (22%), cigarettes (14%), personal items (12%) & children just 9%. The authors discuss the sexual development of a pre-school child, community education as a form of sexual abuse prevention, & conclude that there is a significant need for community education in relation to safeguarding the young children. Adapted from the source document.

The Experiences of Pregnant Women Who Request an Abortion

Author: Humpel, Susan1; Strydom, Herman1 Social Work Dept, Potchefstroom Hospital Health Dept, North West Province, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/753992403?accountid=14667

Abstract: Although pregnancy termination has been legal in South Africa since 1997, pregnant women who request an abortion can find themselves in a dilemma & are often dependent on professional assistance. The women can be guided & supported in overcoming obstacles & normalising her functioning through crisis intervention. This study, of 25 pregnant women who participated in pre-abortion counselling at Potchefstroom Hospital, aimed to; discuss unwanted pregnancy as a life experience; distinguish between adults & teenagers who requested an abortion; study the meaning a woman attaches to the termination; & compile a profile of those that request an abortion. The findings showed that the causes & experiences of unwanted pregnancy included: ambivalence; denial; anger; depression; fear; helplessness; & detachment. Also shown to be a contributing factor included the relationship with, & the attitudes of, the biological father, & general poverty. The authors conclude that women with unwanted pregnancy should not be ignored, & social work aid should be available when & if it is needed. Adapted from the source document.
