The Laryngectomy Patient's View of Social Work Support Services in a Hospital Setting

Author: Steyn, Henriette1; Green, Sulina1 c/o Green -- Dept Social Work, U Stellenbosch, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/753992841?accountid=14667

Abstract: A laryngectomy is the surgical procedure of removing the entire larynx in advance of cancer of the larynx or hypopharynx. This article focuses on 20 laryngectomy patients' views of social work support services in Tygerberg Hospital, South Africa, & describes the role of the social worker in providing information, solving problems, offering social & emotional support & promoting rehabilitation opportunities. Seventy five percent of participants responded favourably to the role of the social workers in providing information, & 85% were described problem solving positively. The majority of participants (65%) found social workers invaluable with regard to contact to community resources, & 85% related to the role of the social worker in supporting the patients & families. However, 65% suggested the use of support groups during social service intervention. In conclusion, the authors suggest that to fulfil the roles outlined, support groups are indispensable to patients & their families in dealing with daily life challenges. The study showed the benefits of support groups are compatible with the above-mentioned roles of the social worker. Adapted from the source document.

Continuing Professional Development (CPD) for the Social Work Profession in South Africa

Author: Lombard, Antoinette1; Pruis, Santie; Grobbelaar, Margaret; Mhlanga, Dudu1 Dept Social Work & Criminology, U Pretoria, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/758126294?accountid=14667

Abstract: In July 2003 the South African Council for Social Service Professions (SACSSP) adopted continuing professional development (CPD) as a requirement for registration to practise. The CPD policy is the result of a transparent, well consulted and research-based process. Social workers and social auxiliary workers, who are currently the only registered persons at the SACSSP, had a window period of six years to voluntarily come on board with CPD before the mandatory commencement of CPD in April 2010. This article outlines the background and process that was followed in formulating the final CPD policy and presents the key content of the CPD policy. Adapted from the source document.

Research Findings and Implementation Challenges of the Continuing Professional Development (CPD) Policy for the Social Work Profession in South Africa

Author: Lombard, Antoinette11 Dept Social Work & Criminology, U Pretoria, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/758125082?accountid=14667

Abstract: The eighth draft of the developing CPD policy of the SACSSP was piloted throughout South Africa on a voluntary basis in 2003/4. To ensure a thorough evaluation of the pilot implementation of the CPD policy, a comprehensive research study was conducted in the Gauteng & Northern Cape Provinces, representing an urban & a rural province in South Africa. This article will present & discuss the research findings & conclusions on the implementation of the draft CPD policy. The research findings not only informed the content of the final CPD policy, but also highlighted many of the challenges underpinning the successful implementation of CPD in South Africa. Adapted from the source document.

The Role of the Social Worker to Empower Families in a Deep Rural Community

Author: Strydom, Corinne1; Wessels, Cornelia; Strydom, Herman1 Dept Social Work, School Psyco-Social Behavioural Sciences, North-West U, Potchefstroom, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/758124809?accountid=14667

Abstract: Research was undertaken in a rural area to investigate the nature of poverty, its effects on these families & how they can be empowered to live healthy lives. A random sample of 230 people was selected. A survey was conducted & data was collected by means of a personal schedule. It was clear that poverty had a negative effect on the families & that very little was done to alleviate their plight. For the sake of these families' wellbeing, their strengths should be identified & enhanced. The social worker is the person who can empower them. Adapted from the source document.

The Implementation of Family Preservation Services: Perspectives of Social Workers at NGOs

Author: Strydom, Marianne11 Dept Social Work, U Stellenbosch, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/758123378?accountid=14667

Abstract: Since 1997, in accordance with South African policy documents, social workers have been encouraged to implement a developmental social service policy towards social work service delivery. This means that in rendering social work services the focus should first be on preventative services, then on early intervention services & last on statutory services. The perspectives of social workers working for child & family welfare organisations on the feasibility of this requirement in policy documents were investigated. It was found that obstacles such as limited people power & funds placed serious constraints upon the implementation of family preservation services with a focus on prevention. Adapted from the source document.

____________________________________________________________

Evaluation of the Support to Care Giving By Local Non-Governmental Organisations (NGOs) in the Kanye Care Programme, Botswana

Author: Kang'ethe, Simon11 Skill Share International

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/758124758?accountid=14667

Abstract: The aim of this article is to evaluate the NGO support to care giving in the Kanye care programme. This research was exploratory & qualitative in design, & included 82 primary caregivers & five CHBC nurses. Findings indicate that care giving faces the challenge of inadequate NGO/CBO support. This is attributable to inadequacies in funding by donor communities; insufficient assistance from the government & civil society; weak community mobilisation to start NGOs; & government mistrust of the NGOs. The government has been advised to change its mindset & start helping the NGOs. The government should perceive them as complementary organs of the development process. Adapted from the source document.

Staying Alive with Dance! Self-Care for Women

Author: Kasiram, Madhu1; Sookoo, Ashika; Ilbury, Brenda; Pais, Shobha1 School Social Work & Community Development, U KwaZulu-Natal, Durban, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/758127623?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article presents researched support for the use of dance, music & rhythm in women's self-care & stress management in a globally networked world where competition & multi-tasking steal time from self-care. Both dance goers' & instructors' views were elicited to arrive at an understanding of how this simple yet effective medium manages stress & how it may best be taught for optimal gains. The key message in the article is on permission giving & taking, for self-care through dance. Social work & indeed health care practitioners are alerted to the potential for optimising functioning by simple overtures that cut across concentric levels of living. Adapted from the source document.

Gender, Race and Stress amongst Women in Management

Author: Suraj-Narayan, Gourie11 School Social Work & Community Development, U KwaZulu-Natal, Durban, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/758124819?accountid=14667

Abstract: Apartheid was abolished in South Africa in 1994. Since then the Employment Equity Act 55 of 1998 was implemented to promote racial & gender equality. Hence, more women were employed as managers. This study was undertaken in Durban & the surrounding areas to examine the stressors experienced by women managers in relation to gender & race. Non-probability sampling was used to select a sample of 30 women managers from five public & five private organisations using a semi-structured interview schedule & a biographical questionnaire. The study found that women managers experienced stress as a result of racial & gender discrimination. Adapted from the source document.

Professionalism, Postmodern Ethics and the Global Standards for Social Work Education and Training

Author: Sewpaul, Vishanthie11 School Social Work Community Development, U KwaZulu-Natal, Howard College Campus, Durban, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/818793264?accountid=14667

Abstract: In this article I deal with some of the inherent modernist & positivist notions underscoring the Global Standards for Social Work in relation to professionalism & codes of ethics. The dominant notions of professionalism derive from modernity's positivist embracing of factors such as detachment in "social worker-client" relationships, neutrality, the social worker as expert, scientific standards of truth, experimentation & universal laws. I raise questions about the sources of ethical practice & the place of ethical codes in relation to the moral impulse. I also question whether or not social work should consider making responsibility for, & being for the "Other" normative in social work. Adapted from the source document.

The Status of Social Work as Perceived by Key Human Service Professionals

Author: Raniga, Tanusha1; Kasiram, Madhu1 School Social Work Community Development, U KwaZulu-Natal, Howard College Campus, Durban, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/818793667?accountid=14667

Abstract: Since 1994 social work as a core human service profession in South Africa has been experiencing its own parallel process of transformation & is thus undergoing a major paradigm shift. However, key human service professionals seem not to appreciate the shift & often continue to hold obsolete perceptions of the profession. It is these perceptions that militate against efficient & effective service delivery, the central premise of this article. Together with understanding what perceptions prevail around social work, the paper recommends how training, teamwork & the general image of social work may be enhanced to allow improved access to, & delivery of service. Adapted from the source document.

Outcomes-Based Education: Is It Right for Social Work?

Author: Simpson, Barbara11 School Social Work Community Development, U KwaZulu-Natal, Howard College Campus, Durban, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/818793487?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article examines outcomes-based education & its usefulness as an approach to social work education, & specifically as the organising framework of the Bachelor of Social Work (BSW) degree. The processes that led to the development of the BSW in its present form are described. Some of the assumptions of outcomes-based education are provided & problems with them in relation to the BSW are examined. The article concludes that outcomes-based education does not serve the interests of social work as a discipline in the academy or as a profession. Adapted from the source document.

Using Persona Dolls as an Anti-Oppressive Technique in the South African Social Work Curriculum

Author: Bozalek, Vivienne1; Smith, Carol1 U Western Cape, Bellville, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/818793833?accountid=14667

Abstract: Although the literature on anti-oppressive practice has proliferated in recent years, it has remained at an abstract theoretical level with little indication of how to practically implement this in social work practice. The Persona Doll Approach (PDA) provides an example of the practical implementation of anti-oppressive practice. This article describes the practical application of the Persona Doll Approach in the social work curriculum. It uses a case study to demonstrate how one student engaged in anti-oppressive practice by using the PDA in his fieldwork placement. Adapted from the source document.

Content Areas for Curriculum Development: Spirituality and Social Work

Author: Bhagwan, Raisuyah11 School Social Work Community Development, U KwaZulu-Natal, Howard College Campus, Durban, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/818793471?accountid=14667

Abstract: Although social work recognises spirituality as being integral to the holistic paradigm, it has remained disconnected from social work education in South Africa. This paper presents data from a survey with final year social work students (N=342) with regard to their views on the content areas for a course on spirituality & social work. These content areas have been elaborated upon & transformed into broad guidelines which depict specific content for spirituality in education. This article is descriptive & the framework that has evolved includes, where appropriate, the exit-level outcomes (BSW programme) where spirituality content may be infused. Adapted from the source document.

Continuing Professional Development of Social Workers in Practice: An Explorative Investigation

Author: September, Rose11 Dept Social Work, U Western Cape, Bellville, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/818793244?accountid=14667

Abstract: The term "continuing professional development" (CPD) in this paper means a process of enhancing the knowledge, skills, expertise & capability of social workers throughout their professional careers. Social work is a dynamic profession & requires of social workers to remain abreast of developments in the field. This paper draws on a study conducted on the experiences & suggestions of 70 social workers regarding CPD. It proposes a more holistic, systematic & emancipatory approach to facilitate critical reflective social work practice & contribute to the expansion of home-grown social work theory & practice. Adapted from the source document.

Yesterday, Today and Tomorrow: Is Social Work Supervision in South Africa Keeping Up?

Author: Engelbrecht, Lambert11 Dept Social Work, U Stellenbosch, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/818793251?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper reports on exploratory research drawing on an historical analysis of social work supervision in South Africa & a qualitative inquiry into supervision practices of supervisors in an NGO environment. The aim was to examine the interplay between the development, current practices & future challenges of social work supervision. The research findings indicate that the historical & existing theoretical foundation & practice of social work supervision do not meet the dynamics of the contemporary social work domain in South Africa. Consequently, a context-specific conceptual framework within a social development paradigm is recommended for future supervision practices in South Africa. Adapted from the source document.

Community Keepers, Stellenbosch, South Africa

Author: Geldenhuys, Philip11 Youngleson, Annemarie

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/818793786?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper sets out to provide a qualitative description of the psychosocial problems experienced by learners at three secondary schools in the Western Cape. The learners selected were both male & female & originated from "Quintile 5" schools, which are considered well resourced & self-sustainable. These schools cater mostly for learners from middle to upper socio-economic groups. The results of this study indicate that psychosocial problems, connected to negative peer & family associations, were the most significant hindrances to the effective functioning of these adolescents. Subsequent research will be aimed at refining an intervention approach to address the highlighted psychosocial problems. Adapted from the source document.

Evaluating the Application of Restorative Justice at the Mangaungone-Stop Child Justice Centre

Author: Reyneke, Roelf1; Reyneke, Marlette1 Dept Social Work, U Free State, Bloemfontein, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/818794003?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article is based on qualitative research in the form of a case study of the Mangaung One-Stop Child Justice Centre in Bloemfontein. This study reflects primarily on the tasks of the probation staff in the context of the practice model utilised by the Centre from a restorative justice perspective. The main tasks of the probation staff in promoting restorative justice & diversion services rendered to children in conflict with the law are discussed, followed by an evaluation of the general restorativeness of diversion programmes. Lastly, some of the most pressing challenges experienced at the Centre are identified & some recommendations are made. Adapted from the source document.

Profile and involvement of retired volunteers at a non-profit organization

Author: Rensburg, Sanet Jansen van1; Strydom, Herman1 Potchefstroom Dienssentrum Bejaardes, Noordwes-U, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/818793240?accountid=14667

Abstract: Volunteering is one way in which aged persons can be involved in society for as long as possible in a constructive & positive manner that might also enhance feelings of selfworth, appreciation & belongingness. This study focused on the Potchefstroom Service Centre for the Aged, generally regarded as a success story with 1200 registered members celebrating its 25th year of existence during 2008. The focus of this article is on a profile of retired volunteers, the fields of practice & the degree of responsibility volunteers are prepared to take. The expectations of volunteers & the meaning voluntary work holds for retired volunteers were also discussed in this article. Adapted from the source document.

Differing HIV Infection Rates In Brazil And South Africa: A Comparative Study Of Policies And Practices

Author: Noronha, Rafael1; Smit, Andre de V.1 Rural Education, Awareness and Community Health Organisation, Cape Town, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/856405594?accountid=14667

Abstract: While the HIV infection rate nearly doubled in Brazil during the past two decades, it increased some sixfold in South Africa. This limited study reports on an analysis of the two counties' HIV/AIDS prevention policies and the findings of a qualitative study of Brazilian and South African HIV/AIDS non-profit organisations' perceptions of these divergent infection rates. The findings identify a number of differences in terms of policy, government action, civil society involvement and the role of the non-profit sector. It also briefly reports on future concerns, changing attitudes to the illness, and proffers limited counsel. Adapted from the source document.

A Profile Of Adolescents In Households Infected With, Or Affected By, HIV And AIDS

Author: Olivier, Korita1; Strydom, Herman1 School of Psychosocial Behavioural Sciences, North-West University, Potchefstroom, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/856405916?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article focuses on a profile of adolescents in households infected with, or affected by, HIV and AIDS. The aim of the research was to collect information from adolescents and about the households they are part of. This information is to serve as a starting point for developing and compiling a profile of these unique households. A questionnaire was developed in accordance with a prior literature study on adolescents from similar households. The information includes the number of members of households, the main caregiver, child-headed households, school attendance, health and wellbeing, employment, death of parents and bereavement counselling supervision practices in South Africa. Adapted from the source document.

Breaking The Silence-Is It A Dream?

Author: de Witt, Marike1; Lessing, Ansie1 Department of Teacher Education, University of South Africa, Pretoria, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/856407249?accountid=14667

Abstract: A fear of rejection may be the reason why HIV/AIDS remains an issue shrouded in silence in South Africa. The disease is still stigmatised and people are marginalised in their communities and society as a whole. The aim of the research on which this article is based was to gauge the perceptions of people on this issue, irrespective of their HIV/AIDS status. The role of community support groups, which came out very strongly in the research, cannot be over-emphasised. It is clear that communities will have to take responsibility for the establishment of such structures. Adapted from the source document.

Attitudes To ARV Access And Factors Undermining HIV/AIDS Prevention. Lessons From The 2008 Tsabong Stigma Case Study (Botswana)

Author: Kang'ethe, Simon M11 Skill Share International

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/856406850?accountid=14667

Abstract: Access to antiretroviral drugs among the people living with HIV/AIDS in Botswana remains a possible panacea only if optimally utilized. The research, explorative and qualitative in design, used an interview guide for focus group discussions and in-depth interviews. Findings indicate that prevention is compromised by: poverty driving some people to prostitution; increased libido effect of the ARVs; cultural and huge gender inequalities; alcohol intake and repeated pregnancies of those on ARVs, and use of biomedical and traditional healers' services in tandem. Suggestions and recommendations to the government, NGOs and care-friendly organisations to consider addressing all these challenges have been made. Adapted from the source document.

The Role of Hospice Caregivers in Caring for Families Infected With, or Affected by, HIV/AIDS

Author: Bester, Nerina1; Herbst, Alida1 Child Welfare South Africa (Kokstad)

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/856405451?accountid=14667

Abstract: In Hospice TLC in Kokstad, KwaZulu-Natal, caregivers play a vital role in the bio-psychosocial care of families infected with, or affected by, HIV and AIDS. Although their training may be more focused on the physical care, they also contribute towards the psychosocial care of these families. This article explores the role that Hospice caregivers fulfil in meeting the bio-psychosocial needs of these families. Data were collected by means of focus group discussions regarding the training, tasks, roles and scope of practice of caregivers. From the findings it was clear that these caregivers are a valuable asset in the multidisciplinary team and a number of recommendations are made to improve service delivery to families infected with, or affected by, HIV or AIDS. Adapted from the source document.

Loss Grief And Bereavement: The Experiences Of Children In Kinship Foster Care

Author: Pretorius, Edmarie1; Ross, Eleanor1 Department of Social Work, University of the Witwatersrand, Johannesburg, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/856407061?accountid=14667

Abstract: There seems to be a paucity of research on the grief and psychological trauma experienced by children in foster care who have been orphaned by the HIV and AIDS pandemic. This article is based on collaborative research conducted by the Nelson Mandela Children's Fund and the Wits Department of Social Work. Among the questions posed was whether organisations supporting foster families and children do assist the children to come to terms with the grief and trauma of losing their parents. From the main findings it was clear that needs and expectations in terms of emotional support and guidance were not adequately addressed. Adapted from the source document.

Cluster Foster Care: A Panacea For The Care Of Children In The Era Of HIV/AIDS Or An MCQ

Author: Gallinetti, Jacqui1; Sloth-Nielsen, Julia1 University of the Western Cape, Bellville, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/856407113?accountid=14667

Abstract: The South African Children's Act 38 of 2005 is arguably the first legislative instrument internationally to provide for cluster foster care. The legal and social underpinnings of cluster foster care, juxtaposed to conventional foster care, are examined and situated within contemporary social norms. The recent UN Guidelines for the Alternative Care of Children are also examined. The analysis discusses various models which are purported to constitute cluster foster care and the question is posed whether cluster foster care rests on a single theoretical model, or whether it is an empty vessel in which a multitude of overlapping models can be accommodated. Adapted from the source document.

Reflections on Burnout and Self-Care Management in Social Work

Author: Partab, Rubeena11 School of Social Work and Community Development, University of KwaZulu-Natal, Durban, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/856405954?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article explores pertinent concerns raised by social work students on their exposure to working with people with AIDS (PWAs). Compassion fatigue and burnout become a constant reality to these students, who audit their feelings within a support group environment. The poignant question they posed was: "How do we comprehend our own feelings after we have counselled an HIV/AIDS patient?" It is evident that self-care should not be regarded as a low priority or even negligible in the lives of healthcare professionals, as it may ultimately lead to vicarious trauma. It is strongly suggested that support groups for students working with PWAs become compulsory. Adapted from the source document.

Emancipatory Pedagogy And Community Work: The Teaching-Practice Nexus

Author: Sewpaul, Vishanthie1; Osthus, Ingrid; Mhone, Christopher1 School of Social Work and Community Development, University of KwaZulu-Natal

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1037881475?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article draws on fieldwork and research with bachelor level social work students based on an initial assumption that engendering critical understanding among students would contribute to critical action. It identifies the role of the educator in promoting democratic and participatory approaches to community work and research, and discusses the cascade effect from classroom to community engagement and research. The central theses is that achievement of emancipatory ideals means that participation intersects all levels of relationships and that complex and circular power dynamics between educator-students-communities be recognized, and that we work against neoliberal and new managerial influences in education. Adapted from the source document.

A University-Community Outreach Initiative: An Innovative Approach To Social Work Practice Education

Author: Simpson, Barbara1; Sathiparsad, Reshma1 School of Social Work and Community Development, University of KwaZulu-Natal, Durban, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1037881477?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social work practice education usually involves students being placed at agencies and there is limited evidence of universities establishing their own placements. This reflective article examines a university-community outreach initiative called University of KwaZulu-Natal: community outreach and research (UKZN: CORE), which provides placements for social work students in community-based student units supervised and managed entirely by university staff. We describe UKZN: CORE and, drawing on the experiences of university staff and students, we discuss the value and challenges of the project, and the possibilities for further development. Adapted from the source document.

The Rationale For The Involvement Of Field Instructors In Practice Education

Author: Strydom, Marianne11 Department of Social Work, University of Stellenbosch, Stellenbosch, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1037881480?accountid=14667

Abstract: Practice education is an integral part of the curriculum in the education of undergraduate social work students. The important role of practice education in the training of social workers means that training institutions depend heavily on the willingness of social workers to act as field instructors. The educational role of field instructors is, however, seldom acknowledged in organisations as a formal role. Given this context, this paper intends to explore the rationale for field instructors to become and remain involved in practice education. Their perspective on the value that practice education holds for the welfare organisation was also investigated. Adapted from the source document.

Studying To Become A Social Worker: Examining The Motivations Of, And Challenges Facing, Students At An Open Distance-Learning University

Author: Alpaslan, Nicky1; Lombard, Berto1 Department of Social Work, UNISA, Pretoria, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1037881483?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article is based on a research project adopting a qualitative research approach. It examines the motivations of a sample of students choosing social work as a career path, their reasons for studying at an open distance-learning (ODL) university and the challenges they faced in studying to become social workers at Unisa as an ODL institution. Adapted from the source document.

Obstacles And Facilitative Opportunities While Studying Social Work Within An Open And Distance-Learning Context

Author: Botha, Petro11 Department of Social Work, University of South Africa, Pretoria, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1037881486?accountid=14667

Abstract: The number of social workers in South Africa is insufficient to meet demand. Throughput of student social workers at tertiary institutions needs to be increased. Lecturers should act on factors influencing student success at their specific institutions. Knowing what their students experience as obstacles and facilitative opportunities while studying could assist them in a practical way. A convenience sample of 117 first-year Social Work students studying through Unisa completed a self-administered questionnaire. Regular contact with lecturers, clear communication, counselling facilities, early exposure to the profession, coordination of support efforts and effective use of technology are highlighted. Adapted from the source document.

Challenges And Changes In Teaching Person-Centred Counselling To Social Work Learners Via Distance Education

Author: de Kock, Desiree11 Department of Social Work, UNISA, Pretoria, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1037881489?accountid=14667

Abstract: The Department of Social Work at the University of South Africa (UNISA) is particularly challenged in teaching teach Social Work, particularly the practical skills, to learners countrywide. Apart from the distances involved that pose a challenge, the increase in student numbers for practical modules, which range from 3,926 first-year students to 919 fourth-year students in 2011, change is also inevitable. This article focuses on the challenges of, and changes in, teaching a person-centred approach (PCA) in developing the counselling skills of social work learners at UNISA as part of the quest to be leaner-centred in open distance-learning. The author concludes with some recommendations in this regard. Adapted from the source document.

Perspectives On The Factors Influencing Student Social Workers In The Execution Of Their Research Projects At Fourth Level In An Open Distance-Learning Context

Author: Makofane, Mankwane11 Department of Social Work, University of South Africa, Pretoria, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1037881491?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study presents the perspectives of fourth-year students, the principal lecturer and markers on factors influencing the students' planning, execution and completion of their research projects in an ODL context. The study is qualitative in nature and data were collected through an emailed guide with open-ended questions, telephonic discussions and face-to-face semi-structured interviews. The purpose of this paper is to examine the complexities and challenges associated with the implementation of a research project at undergraduate level and social work research instruction in an ODL context. The paper concludes with suggestions to stimulate further thinking and discussion in this area. Adapted from the source document.

Implementing A "Blended Learning Approach" In A Social Work Course: The Perceptions Of First-Year Students At A South African University

Author: Pillay, Roshini1; Gerrard, Priscilla1 Department of Social Work, University of the Witwatersrand, Johannesburg, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1037881499?accountid=14667

Abstract: Enhancing the value of the teaching and learning process by merging e-learning strategies with traditional face-to-face teaching strategies requires thoughtful application. This article focuses on a research study which implemented a qualitative research approach to explore the perceptions of first-year Social Work students before and after completing a Social Work course used using a blend of teaching and learning methods, including face-to-face learning experiences and e-learning strategies. Findings indicated that although most first-year students regarded the blended approach as an effective practice to enhance the learning process, there was much scope for development and improvement in course design and implementation. Adapted from the source document.

Spirituality In Pedagogy: A Qualitative Study With Educators

Author: Bhagwan, Raisuyah11 Department of Community Health Studies, Faculty of Health Sciences, Durban University of Technology, Durban, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1037881502?accountid=14667

Abstract: In South Africa little is known about spirituality in social work pedagogy. This paper reports on a qualitative study which explored educators' personal experiences of spirituality and their views with regard to its inclusion in education. It also explored their views with regard to appropriate content on spirituality for social work education and its integration into current teaching. Analysis revealed diverse conceptualisations of personal spirituality and also that spirituality was an important part of social work practice and education. It also revealed considerable support for the inclusion of spirituality in pedagogy through a gradual interweaving of it into existing courses. Adapted from the source document.

The Implications Of Adverse Childhood Experiences For The Professional Requirements Of Social Work

Author: Dykes, Glynnis11 Department of Social Work, University of the Western Cape, Bellville, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1037881506?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article foregrounds the notion of resilience to explore university students' self-concept development experiences and their impact on social work professional requirements. From the "Who am I?" assignments of first-year social work students, their family-of-origin experiences were used to explore social challenges that had shaped them. Findings indicated that students' self-concept development experiences reflected adverse childhood experiences. Elements of resilience were discerned for some participants, which augured well for their professional practice. For others this may he a source of concern. Longitudinal research is required to explore the outcome of this cohort of students in terms of their self-concepts and professional behaviour. Adapted from the source document.

Resilience Assessments In Social Work: The Case Of The SA Department Of Defence

Author: van Breda, Adrian D11 Department of Social Work, University of Johannesburg, Johannesburg South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/902082550?accountid=14667

Abstract: There has been a burgeoning interest in social work in strengths and resilience perspectives. The resilience perspective is highly consonant with social work values, but not easy to translate into practice. This paper presents a triangulated package of tools that the Department of Defence has developed for social workers to conduct resilience assessments with military families. The package comprises a theoretical model of family resilience, a standardised family resilience scale and a clinical assessment interview protocol. This package is presented as an example of how the resilience perspective can be incorporated into a particular field of social work practice. Adapted from the source document.

Theories Of Substance Abuse Prevention In The Workplace

Author: Steenkamp, Wilhelmina11 Department of Social Work, Tygerberg Hospital, Tygerberg, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/902082566?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article discusses theoretical approaches to the prevention of alcohol abuse in the workplace. The traditional approach, the ecological approach, the health promotion approach and the coping skills approach to alcohol abuse prevention in the workplace are considered in detail. Knowledge of the different approaches can contribute to more valid programme theories and prevention programmes. Adapted from the source document.

The Competency Base Of Social Workers With Regard To Attachment Theory In Foster Care Supervision: A Pilot Study

Author: Botes, Wezet1; Ryke, Elma1 School of Psychosocial Behavioural Sciences (Social Work), North-West University Potchefstroom Campus, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/902082576?accountid=14667

Abstract: Attachment theory has re-emerged in recent years as a critical factor in understanding and determining the quality of relationships between the primary caregiver and the child. Social workers were asked what they know and how they apply attachment theory in foster care supervision. The results suggest that, although the social workers knew that the quality of the relationship between the foster parents and the child is predictive of the success of the placement, they do not have a sufficient grounding in attachment theory to be able to provide effective intervention regarding attachment-based concerns within the foster care context. Adapted from the source document.

Community Home-Based Care Programme: A Marginalised Key Community Resource

Author: Qalinge, Lulama11 Department of Social Work, University of South Africa, Pretoria, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/902082583?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article seeks to explore the experiences and challenges facing community home-based caregivers in their endeavour to provide a critical key community service. It is a fact that community home-based care programmes provide a critical service to terminally ill patients who would otherwise have little access to any form of assistance. Critical as their role may be, caregivers continue to be marginalized. Coupled with the physical and emotional cost of providing care that is unpaid and undervalued, this poses a challenge to them. The qualitative study was conducted throughout the North West province of South Africa, utilising caregivers as participants. Adapted from the source document.

The Role Of Incentives In Raising Care-Giving Productivity In Botswana Care Programmes As Exemplified In The Kanye Care Programme

Author: Kang'ethe, Simon11 Department of Social Development, University of Fort Hare, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/902082810?accountid=14667

Abstract: The aim of the article is to explore the role of incentives in raising care-giving motivation and morale. The research study was qualitative in design and explorative in nature, with 82 primary caregivers involved in focus group discussions and one-to-one interviews with five CHBC nurses to confirm, contrast, cross-check and corroborate information received from the caregivers. The study found the following factors responsible for raising caregivers' productivity: availability and adequacy of food and care packages; incentives and motivation; recognising caregivers' role; training; and starting income-generating activities. It is recommended that all these factors be well anchored in the programme. Adapted from the source document.

Street Children's Stories Of Escaping To, And Surviving On, The Street -- "Slumdog" Life And "Millionaire" Ending?

Author: MacDonald, Juliet1; Terblanche, Susan1 Department of Social Development, Western Cape, University of the Western Cape, Bellville, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/902082815?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article reports on street children's experiences of going to the street, survival on the street, experiences of involvement in criminal activities, and intervention and detention programmes. A qualitative research approach was selected for the research project. Data were collected by means of story-telling. Data were analysed and verified according to the guidelines suggested by Creswell (1998). Findings indicated that participants experienced material, social and emotional deprivation as "push" factors for going to the streets. Survival depended on begging and repeated involvement in crime. Interventions and detention were not experienced as motivation for a change in lifestyle. Adapted from the source document.

The Impact of Theatre on Adolescents' Experiences of Self-acceptance, Acceptance of Others and Their Circumstances

Author: Combrink, Madeleen1; Strydom, Herman; van Deventer, Wilhelm1 Vakgroep Maatskaplike Werk, Skool vir Psigo-sosiale Gedragswetenskappe, Noordwes-Universiteit (Potchefstroomkampus), Potchefstroom, Suid-Afrika

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/902082826?accountid=14667

Abstract: The purpose of this study was to determine the effect of participation in a theatre production on the perceptions of, and personal growth in, acceptance among adolescents in Promosa, Potchefstroom. Adolescent members of a Youth Development Organisation were part of this project. A qualitative study was conducted. Data were collected by using a narrative approach and focus groups. The collected data were analysed manually and the results formulated thematically. Findings show that participation in this theatre production led to changes in perceptions of and personal growth in, acceptance of others, of the self and of the circumstances of these adolescents. Adapted from the source document.

Attitudes Of Secondary School Leavers Towards Manual Work: Implications For Youth Employment In Botswana

Author: Osei-Hwedie, Kwaku1; Kgwatalala, Diana1 Department of Social Work, University of Botswana, Gaborone

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/902084257?accountid=14667

Abstract: The paper discusses the attitudes towards manual work of secondary school leavers, i.e. Form 3s and Form 5s, in Botswana. It is based on a study of 200 secondary school leavers from four secondary schools. Despite the fact that many of them may not pass their exams, and may not get opportunities to continue their education, or find white- collar jobs, they have negative attitudes towards manual work. It is recommended that employers in the manual work sector, the government and the media should play a more active role in making manual work attractive to secondary school leavers. Adapted from the source document.

Barriers Hindering The Effective Integration Of Orphaned Children Living In Child-Headed Households Into Extended Family Folds

Author: Alpaslan, Assim1; Nziyane, Luzile Florence1 Department of Social Work, University of South Africa, Pretoria, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/925714646?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article describes the barriers (i.e. barriers that are related to poverty, relations and family, and cultural issues, as well as barriers relating to the circumstances of the orphaned children) that hinder the integration of orphaned children living in child-headed households (CHHs) into extended family folds. A sample of orphaned children who were heading CHHs, extended family members who were related to the children, and social workers who were rendering social work services to these client-systems participated in the study. Recommendations on how to address these barriers are proffered. Adapted from the source document.

"Life Is Not Pap And Vleis": Poverty In Child-Headed Households In Gauteng

Author: Blaauw, Derick1; Viljoen, Kotie; Schenck, Rinie1 Department of Economics and Econometrics, University of Johannesburg

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/925714653?accountid=14667

Abstract: Children are caring for an increasing proportion of orphans and abandoned children in several African countries. Children in child-headed households generally live under poor economic conditions. Given the dire need to alleviate child poverty, studying this phenomenon is of the utmost importance. The objective of this paper is to investigate the economic circumstances facing these children in Gauteng. The study assesses their monthly income and contributions from different sources to these child-headed households. These data are analysed in terms of poverty criteria to determine whether the children's monthly income conforms to the minimum income necessary for material survival. Adapted from the source document.

The Learning Of Sexual Abuse Prevention Concepts And The Reliability Of The CKAQ-RIII In The South African Context

Author: Dunn, Munita11 Centre for Student Communities, Stellenbosch University, Stellenbosch, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/925714657?accountid=14667

Abstract: The prevention of child sexual abuse presents a major challenge to society. The researcher developed a board game as part of the Hands Off Our Children Campaign (HOOC) to promote the prevention of sexual abuse by teaching children self-protective behaviours. A representative sample of 1 697 Grade 4 learners, nine to twelve years old, were selected from the Metropole East region, Western Cape. To determine the impact of the HOOC board game, the results of the Children's Knowledge of Abuse Questionnaire-Revised (CKAQ-RIII) in the experimental and control groups were compared. The reliability of the American-based CKAQ-RIII in the South African context was also investigated. Adapted from the source document.

Reporting of Sexual Abuse by Adolescents

Author: van der Schyff, Marthie1; Strydom, Corinne1 Kantoorhoof en maatskaplike werker te Child Welfare, SA, Welkom

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/925714701?accountid=14667

Abstract: There is a high incidence of sexual abuse of adolescents in South Africa. Despite this, only a small number of sexual abuse cases are reported immediately. The main purpose of this research was to investigate the reasons why adolescents fail to report sexual abuse, to establish reporting guidelines, and to determine the role of the forensic social worker in this regard. The research followed a quantitative approach. Two hundred and twenty adolescents from two high schools were involved. The findings showed that there were no definite guidelines available for the report of sexual abuse, and that forensic social workers have a definite role to play. Adapted from the source document.

Protecting Child Witnesses: New Developments And Implications For Social Workers

Author: Matthias, Carmel11 School of Social Work and Community Development, University of KwaZulu-Natal, Durban, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/925714705?accountid=14667

Abstract: Protective measures enabled by modern technology are important for child witnesses. By removing children from the courtroom, such measures diminish the danger of systemic abuse. Social workers can play a key role in motivating for protective measures and serving as intermediaries. This article evaluates changes in the law and implications for social work practice. The Criminal Procedure Act 51 of 1977, the Children's Act 38 of 2005 and reported court cases are discussed. It is shown that, despite amendments and attempts by the courts to provide clarification, the legal framework governing protective measures remains incomplete. Recommendations for improvement of the framework are proposed. Adapted from the source document.

The Implementation Of Policies Pertaining To Child And Youth Care Within A Team Context In Child And Youth Care Centres

Author: Rossouw, Lynette11 Department of Social Work, Stellenbosch University, Stellenbosch, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/925714708?accountid=14667

Abstract: Policy changes over the last fifteen years have had profound consequences for team members at youth care and education centres. This article provides a critical overview of the impact of these policy changes on team members and on their service delivery to youths. The focus is on the shift from working in silos to working in teams. The views and experiences of team members who implement changed policy are explored. Recommendations are made for the training of team leaders and team members, and for developing guidelines to equip them to adhere to minimum standards for care and support of the youth. Adapted from the source document.

Legal Instruments To Consider In Structuring Parenting Plans

Author: Robinson, Tanya1; Stewart, Linda; Ryke, Elma; Wessels, Cornelia1 Family Therapy Assessment Centre, Dainfern Valley, Gauteng

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/925714713?accountid=14667

Abstract: With amendments made to the Children's Act 38 of 2005 that makes provision for parenting plans, legal and mental health professionals now have the responsibility of structuring plans for divorcing families in South Africa. Because parenting plans are a new concept, substantive guidelines are needed to assist professionals in structuring these plans. This paper focuses on section 28 of the Constitution; the United Nations Convention of the Rights of the Child; the African Charter on the Rights and Welfare of the Child; and the Children's Act to provide a legal context for professionals for the structuring of parenting plans. Adapted from the source document.

Performance evaluation as a function of Social Work Supervision

Author: Abrahams, Edith1; Reynolds, Coen1 Hoof Maatskaplike Werker, Wes-Kaapse Provinsiale Regering, Departement van Maatskaplike Ontwikkeling

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/925714716?accountid=14667

Abstract: The purpose of this study was to investigate how social work supervisors perform their supervisory functions and apply performance appraisal. Performance management and performance appraisal play a crucial role in developing human resources. In the social work profession the social work supervisor is the person responsible to appraise the performance of the social worker because of the excellent position to observe the job performance directly and consistently. The researcher used qualitative research for an exploratory and descriptive study. Interviews were used as data collection method. It was concluded that performance appraisal is a cardinal component of the supervision functions. Adapted from the source document.

Unhelpful Help: The Social Work Profession's Response To Mass Poverty In South Africa

Author: Chikadzi, Victor1; Pretorius, Edmarie1 Department of Social Work, University of the Witwatersrand, Johannesburg, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1030869458?accountid=14667

Abstract: Poverty is a universal phenomenon and it is often the primary reason that people seek social services. The profession should reflect upon social work education and poverty eradication interventions implemented in the light of the causes of poverty and solution to the problem. The profession claims to be a change agent; however, education and practice often still contribute to perpetuating the status quo, which discourages poor people. This article challenges the profession and argues that if it wants to reclaim its pro-people and pro-change stance, it has to design alternative approaches to education and develop different intervention strategies when dealing with mass poverty in South Africa. Adapted from the source document.

Women And Child Abuse In South Africa: Lessons From Practice

Author: Hanson, Sheri11 Post-doctoral Fellow at the Centre for Social Development in Africa, University of Johannesburg, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1030869463?accountid=14667

Abstract: Exploratory research indicates that women and child abuse in same family systems is often overlooked because child protection agencies and women's advocacy groups may focus on the needs of only one party. This article provides an insight into how children and women's organisations address the phenomenon and identifies lessons for practise. Case studies are presented with reference to the generalist practice approach. Lessons for future practice are identified, including (1) the importance of comprehensive assessment procedures; (2) the need to deviate from micro-level and crisis-intervention strategies exclusively; (3) the significance of integrating different theoretical approaches; and (4) the need for collaboration between social service organisations. Adapted from the source document.

Household And Family Structure: A Baseline Study Among Primary School Learners In Chatsworth, South Africa

Author: Sewpaul, Vishanthie1; Pillay, Anitha1 School of Social Work and Community Development, University of KwaZulu-Natal

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1030869466?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article describes the results of a quantitative study with 328 learners in the Chatsworth area. The main aim was to understand the influence of household and family composition on primary school learners. The results of the study reflect that children growing up in two-parent households tend to fare better on several variables than children growing up in single-parent, step-parent or grandparent-headed households. Adapted from the source document.

Practice Guidelines For The Integration Of Child-Headed Households Into Extended Family Folds

Author: Nziyane, Luzile Florence1; Alpaslan, Assim Hashim1 Deputy Director, Department of Social Development, Pretoria

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1030869468?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article describes the practice guidelines for the integration of child-headed households into extended family folds. The practice guidelines resulted from a qualitative study which was based on semi-structured interviews to explore suggestions on how to overcome barriers that hinder effective integration of child-headed households (CHH) into extended families from a sample of orphaned children heading CHH, extended family members who were related to the children participating in the study, and social workers. The direct and implied suggestions which participants provided were related to the role that they want social workers to play in enabling and supporting the integration process. Adapted from the source document.

Knowledge, Attitudes And Beliefs Of Older Men Regarding HIV And Aids In South Africa

Author: Roux, Adri1; Strydom, Herman1 School for Psycho-Social Behavioural Sciences: Division Social Work, North-West University (Potchefstroom campus), Potchefstroom, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1030869470?accountid=14667

Abstract: The aim of the study was to ascertain the level of knowledge, attitudes and beliefs of the aged male on HIV and AIDS, and to what extent daily living has been influenced by the disease. The focus of the study was on older men who are affected by HIV and AIDS. In-depth interviewing was done within the exploratory design to gain data of a qualitative and quantitative nature. Interviews focused on the perceptions of participants on illness in general, but HIV and AIDS specically. Topics such as the influence Of HIV and AIDS on the individual, the household and the community were explored. Adapted from the source document.

Private Lives, Public Issues: Childbearing Experiences Of Adolescent Mothers In The Era Of HIV And AIDS In Bhambayi, Kwazulu-Natal, South Africa

Author: Raniga, Tanusha1; Mathe, Sibonsile1 School of Social Work and Community Development, University of KwaZulu-Natal, Howard College, Durban, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1030869472?accountid=14667

Abstract: Extensive research has been conducted to examine the correlates of adolescent childbearing and HIV risk in KwaZulu-Natal. However, there is limited research on the correlates of poverty, gender relations and HIV/AIDS on the childbearing experiences of adolescent mothers. This paper presents empirical evidence from one qualitative phase of a broader study on childbearing experiences of fifteen adolescent mothers from a predominantly informal settlement called Bhambayi in KwaZulu-Natal. On the basis of feminist social work theory, three important themes that are closely intertwined are deliberated: complex sexual choices, the devastating effects of HIV and AIDS on the family, and survival strategies. Recommendations for transformative interventions and further research are provided. Adapted from the source document.

Preventing Relapses Amongst Chemically Addicted Adolescents: Exploring The State Of Current Services

Author: van der Westhuizen, Marichen1; Alpaslan, Assim; de Jager, Marianna1 Department of Social Work, Huguenot College, Wellington

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1030869475?accountid=14667

Abstract: The susceptibility of adolescents to chemical addiction has become a major international concern. The researchers aimed to explore the state of current after-care service delivery to these youngsters in the Western Cape to provide social workers with recommendations on focus areas to be included when supporting them following treatment. A qualitative research approach was implemented to develop an understanding of the perceptions and experiences of social workers relating to after-care services. A literature control was conducted to provide a context from which recommendations could be made. The findings highlighted the need for further training and guidance in this regard. Adapted from the source document.

Emotional Reactions of the Mother of the Sexually Abused Child After Disclosure of Sexual Abuse

Author: Strydom, Corinne1; Stander, Wilna1 Skool vir Psigo-sosiale Gedragswetenskappe, Potchefstroomkampus van die Noordwes-Universiteit, Potchefstroom

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1030869477?accountid=14667

Abstract: The purpose of the research was to determine the emotional reactions of the mother of the sexually abused child after disclosure and to establish ways in which the forensic social worker could assist the mother in the forensic process. Fifteen mothers were involved in the research. A standardised measuring instrument (PMSI) was utilised in obtaining information with regard to the first objective and a self-designed questionnaire was used to investigate the second objective. The findings indicated that the mother presents with symptoms of trauma after disclosure and that the forensic social worker should perform certain functions with regard to the mother. Adapted from the source document.

The Contribution Of The Informal Economy To The Social And Economic Development Of Women-Headed Households In The Chegutu Urban District In Zimbabwe

Author: Nugundu, Kudzal1; Lombard, Antoinette1 Department of Social Work & Criminology, University of Pretoria, Pretoria, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1221408796?accountid=14667

Abstract: Zimbabwe faces serious political, social and economic challenges. As a result, the informal economy has experienced a rapid growth and has become the largest employer in Zimbabwe. Women, and in particular women-headed households, are the most affected. The article reviews the contribution of the informal economy to some social and economic development aspects of women-headed households (WHH). Findings indicate that WHH benefit from the informal economy, albeit on a survival level. The paper concludes that an integrated social and economic development framework should be adopted to respond to the plight of WHH in the informal economy. Adapted from the source document.

Income-Generating Projects: Alleviating Or Perpetuating Poverty?

Author: Kaeane, Raisibe1; Ross, Eleanor1 South African Social Security Agency (SASSA), Sedibeng District, Vereeniging

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1221408806?accountid=14667

Abstract: The study explored the perceptions of beneficiaries of income-generating projects. A qualitative research design was employed with a sample of 20 participants from two Development Centres in Sedibeng. Data from interviews revealed that the Development Centre was perceived to be an effective service-delivery model for alleviating poverty and enhancing quality of life of beneficiaries. However, participants were dissatisfied with the lack of clear expectations, planning and monitoring of projects. The conclusion drawn is that these projects were achieving their aims, although there is room for improvement in terms of knowledge and skills imparted, and participation of beneficiaries in decision-making. Adapted from the source document.

What Happens During Those Long Hours Next To The Road? An Exploratory Study Of Three Informal Day Labour Hiring Sites In Tshwane

Author: Schenck, Rinie1; Xipu, Lawrence; Blaauw, Derick1 Department of Social Work, University of the Western Cape

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1221408815?accountid=14667

Abstract: The purpose of the study was to describe the nature of socio-economic activities taking place at hiring sites in Tshwane. The research approach and methodology of this study were exploratory, descriptive and qualitative. Case studies were done on three sites and it was found that they were hazardous and lacked basic facilities such as shelter and toilets. Employer-employee interactions were found to be haphazard and sometimes manipulative and exploitative. It is recommended that processes could be facilitated which could include access to basic facilities, skills development, job search assistance and access to comprehensive social services. Adapted from the source document.

Mental Health Legislation: Does It Protect The Rights Of People With Mental Health Problems?

Author: Simpson, Barbara1; Chipps, Jennifer1 School of Social Work and Community Development

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1221408820?accountid=14667

Abstract: The Mental Health Care Act No. 17 of 2002 was an attempt to transform the mental health care system from one which focused on custodial care and protection to one based on human rights. This article attempts to answer three questions. Firstly, how has mental health care legislation historically protected the rights of mental health care users? Secondly, how does the 2002 Act protect these rights? And thirdly, is the Act being implemented in a way that protects these rights? A review of the literature reveals that despite the good intentions of the legislation, many challenges to its effective implementation remain. Adapted from the source document.

Stigma And Marginalisation: Structural Violence And The Impact On Mental Health

Author: Sturgeon, Shona11 Department of Social Development, University of Cape Town, Cape Town, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1221408825?accountid=14667

Abstract: Considering the high incidence of mental disorders, the link with health conditions, and that treatment for mental disorders is currently largely community-based, it is essential that social workers assume a central role in addressing the issues faced by people with mental disorders in the community. World-wide people with mental disorders and their families suffer from stigma, marginalisation and structural violence. Conversely, marginalisation causes the poor, disadvantaged and vulnerable to suffer disproportionally from mental disorders. Social workers should be pivotal in working developmentally with people with mental disorders and address the marginalisation that causes many of their problems. Adapted from the source document.

Attitudes Of Plwha And Other Selected Communities In Tsabong Towards Operationalising Biomedical And Traditional Therapies In Tandem To Face The Aids Epidemic

Author: Kang'ethe, Simon11 Social worker for Skill Share International and attached to the Botswana Network of People Living with HIV/AIDS (BONEPWA) in Botswana

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1221408832?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study explores and assesses treatment challenges arising from having biomedical practitioners and traditional healers work in tandem to assist people living with HIV/AIDS (PLWHA). It was explorative, descriptive and qualitative in design, The study used an interview guide to facilitate focus group discussions and one-to-one interviews. The following challenges were identified: medical safety of the clients; unhealthy conflict between biomedics and the healers; control and harmonisation of the health services; and the complementarity of the two service providers. The government, NGOs and other care bodies have been asked to work towards collaboration with biomedical practitioners and the healers. Adapted from the source document.

Children's Perceptions Of Parenting Practices

Author: Dunn, Munita1; Keet, Nelleke1 Deputy Director, Centre of Student Communities, University of Stellenbosch

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1221408842?accountid=14667

Abstract: This qualitative research examined primary school children's perceptions of parenting practices in a rural South African region. Explorative research with 211 middle-childhood children was conducted using semi-structured interviews, Junior Rotter Incomplete Sentences, drawings and focus groups. Participants from the lower socio-economic stratum presented with a lack of social skills, a feeling of inferiority and low self-esteem. Participants from the higher socio-economic stratum presented with a different quality of life reflected by social competence, access to resources, clear communication with parents and familial cohesion. It is concluded that children's perceptions regarding parenting practices are impacted upon by their socio-economic environments. Adapted from the source document.

The Effect Of A Child's Sexual Abuse On The Non-Accused Parent/Guardian's Psychosocial Functioning

Author: de Koker, Charlene1; Strydom, Corinne; Vermeulen, Antoinette1 Meestersgraadstudent in Forensiese Praktyk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1221408847?accountid=14667

Abstract: The aim of the research was to study the effect of the disclosure of a child's sexual abuse on the non-accused parent/guardian's psychosocial functioning. The objectives were to determine their reaction to the disclosure of the sexual abuse; to investigate how their psychosocial functioning was influenced; how the relationship between them and the child was affected; and to investigate the outcome of the cases. A qualitative approach, utilising in-depth interviews with the non-accused parents from the case loads of a welfare organisation, was used. This research has proven that sexual abuse of a child has a detrimental effect on the non-accused parent/guardian. Adapted from the source document.

Contradictions Of Concern To Benchmarking In The South African Bachelor Of Social Work Degree

Author: Collins, Kathleen11 Department of Social Work, University of Johannesburg, Johannesburg, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1266148179?accountid=14667

Abstract: The South African Bachelor of Social Work (BSW) degree is to be revised in 2012. Quality assurance of its implementation at universities is underway. This article presents a critical literature review of teaching and learning relevant to contemporary university training within the outcomes-based context of the BSW and a documentary analysis of departmental self-assessments at the first-year level carried out in 2009. The outcomes of the literature and empirical studies are contradictory and tend to undermine any perceptions of a straightforward benchmarking process. Adapted from the source document.

Promoting Deep Learning Through Personal Reflective E-Journaling: A Case Study

Author: van Breda, Adrian D1; Agherdien, Najma1 Department of Social Work, University of Johannesburg

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1266148186?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social work educators strive to enrich and integrate student learning. This paper proposes that deep, transformational learning can be facilitated through personal reflective journaling linking academic material and students' personal life experiences. The authors outline a theoretical framework on the place of personal reflection in academic learning. A case study is presented where a reflective e-journal was used in an undergraduate social work theory class on HIV. Journal extracts and students' review of their journaling experience illustrate how students integrated academic learning and personal experiences. The authors conclude that reflective e-journaling could be a helpful tool to enhance student learning. Adapted from the source document.

Community Engagement, Service Learning And Student Social Responsibility: Implications For Social Work Education At South African Universities: A Case Study Of The University Of Fort Hare

Author: Maistry, Margie11 University of Fort Hare working under the SARCHI Chair of Social Change and the Community University Partnership Programme (CUPP), funded by the National Research Foundation (NRF)

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1266148191?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article focuses on service learning as a form of community engagement and the inculcation of social responsibility (SR) in social work students. By utilising the Department of Social Work and Social Development of the University of Fort Hare as a case study, the article shows that it should not be assumed that a social work student is automatically socially responsible. An explicit and conscious effort should be made to inculcate SR in social work students. Recommendation is made for a theoretical framework that may assist towards educating social work students to become more socially responsible. Adapted from the source document.

Social Workers' Perceptions Of Inter-Organisational Collaboration In Child And Family Welfare

Author: Sitshange, Madoda11 Social Work Practitioner, Pretoria, South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1266148201?accountid=14667

Abstract: The objective of the study was to explore and describe social workers' perceptions of the concept of inter-organisational collaboration. Twenty-five social workers working in the field of child and family welfare were interviewed by the researcher using a specially designed interview schedule with closed-ended and open-ended questions. The research design was exploratory-descriptive using descriptive statistics and thematic content analyses to process and analyse the data. The findings revealed that while some social workers actively participated in and understood the importance of partnerships, their practice orientation tended not to be closely aligned with relevant theory. Adapted from the source document.

An Outcome Evaluation Of A Youth Development Programme

Author: Maposa, James F; Louw-Potgieter, Joha

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1266148204?accountid=14667

Abstract: This outcome evaluation assessed whether a development programme for youths aging out of foster care attained its goals. Relationship building was the only short-term outcome that was achieved. The medium-term outcomes of securing internships and finding suitable accommodation were achieved for some beneficiaries. The programme proved good enough for some beneficiaries regarding the long-term outcomes of securing employment, responsible alcohol use, resistance to drug use, safe sex and attending mentoring sessions. The programme did not succeed in attaining its most challenging long-term outcomes, namely finding habitable accommodation, improving education levels and community involvement. Adapted from the source document.

The Role Of The Social Worker In The Prevention Of Child Trafficking In South Africa

Author: Sambo, Juliet Patience1; Spies, Gloudien1 MSW (University of Pretoria, Department of Social Work)

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1266148212?accountid=14667

Abstract: Child trafficking is a global problem which involves multiple forms of exploitation, and hence it has been described as a form of modern slavery. South Africa is one place of origin, transit and destination. Children are increasingly being trafficked for purposes of sexual and labour exploitation. However, child trafficking has traumatic and devastating effects on the victims, affected families, communities as well as countries as a whole. The effects suffered by victims range from psychological, physical, emotional, social and economical in nature. Therefore, it was imperative to embark on primary, secondary and tertiary prevention in order to defeat the phenomenon. To that end, the researcher explored the role of the social worker in the prevention of child trafficking in South Africa. Adapted from the source document.

The Foster Care Backlog: A Threat To The Retention Of Social Workers?

Author: Ngwenya, Phindile1; Botha, Petro1 Department of Social Development, Johannesburg Regional Office

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1266148219?accountid=14667

Abstract: The Department of Social Development employs the bulk of social workers in the country. The government is faced with an overwhelming demand for services and an inability of social workers to cope with these demands. A study in the Johannesburg office of the Department, focusing on the foster care backlog, indicated reasons for, and consequences of this backlog. This article links these findings with factors associated with the turnover or departure of social workers. Recommendations are made on how the foster care backlog can be addressed and a stable, well-trained work force can be ensured within the field of foster care. Adapted from the source document.

Utilization Of Retired Voluntary Workers By Staff Of Service Centres

Author: van Rensburg, Sanet Jansen1; Strydom, Herman1 Potchefstroom Dienssentrum vir Bejaardes

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1266145114?accountid=14667

Abstract: The focus of this article is to determine whether service centres for the aged utilises retired persons as volunteers, what value volunteers can have for service centres, the kind of services performed by volunteers, frustrations staff experiences with volunteers and the characteristics and skills staff members need in working with retired volunteers. Data has been gathered by way of questionnaires, interviewing and observation done at selected service centres for the aged. The captured data is part of a larger study to develop a needs based empowerment programme for staff members of service centres for the aged. Adapted from the source document.

Life On The Streets Of Durban: No Millionaire Ending

Author: Sewpaul, Vishanthie1; Osthus, Ingrid; Mhone, Christopher K; Sibilo, Emma; Mbhele, Sithembile1 School of Applied Human Sciences

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1322712608?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article discusses the experiences and survival strategies of children and youth living on the streets of Durban. The use of triangulation, incorporating both qualitative and quantitative research and multiple methods of data collection allowed many children and youth to participate in the study, and enhanced its reliability. Despite the intensity and extent of problems in their home environments, the participants did not experience street life as a better option. In their comparison, home, shelter and street were equally worse and, contrary to participants' views in MacDonald's and Terblanche's (2011) study, street life was certainly for them "no millionaire ending". Adapted from the source document.

Excluded From Education And Work: Perceptions Of At Risk Youth

Author: Booyens, Margie1; Crause, Elsa1 Department of Social Development, University of Cape Town

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1322712612?accountid=14667

Abstract: This qualitative study was conducted among youth in three towns in the Western Cape. The sample comprises nineteen young men and women who left school before the completion of Grade 12 and were not in full-time employment. Their experiences, agency and aspirations related to two key life transitions are reported: Education for life and work, and starting a productive working life, viewed within the current governmental policy and programmatic framework. Their views on the role of government in relation to their situation are also reported. Selected considerations are put forward for social service professionals who engage with at risk youth. Adapted from the source document.
